He boasted that he mobilised the attack in retaliation to an assault allegedly by Left students on Periyar hostel earlier the same day.India Today reported Awasthi also identified both people in the most viral footage of the attack - of a girl with her face covered and the male with a sledgehammer - as fellow ABVP associates. Awasthi said that after the raid, he found a fellow ABVP member hiding. He assured her he was from ABVP, "took off the helmet, put my arm around her, and walked out as a couple".The stick in his hand was pulled out from a flag near Periyar hostel. Asked if he hit anyone, Awasthi said, "There was a man with a flowing beard. He looked Kashmiri. I beat him and kicked down the gate."Security guard GV Thapa told India Today that 10-15 men, in shawls with lathis, forced through Saraswatipuram Gate where he was on duty a little after 7pm on Sunday. "They threatened to beat me and went in," he added.Shah told the undercover reporters that he lent Awasthi the helmet. "It is a must when you smash glass." The mob came to his room too, but moved on after he told them (masked men) "it was an ABVP room." Asked if he was proud of their actions, he said, "Of course, of course."The third student was former JNUSU president of AISA, Geeta Kumari, who admitted to "closing the server room" to cripple the administration's functioning. "There are no exams. None of our demands are met. He (VC Jagadesh Kumar) didn't even meet us. Our VC does everything online, sends 'love letter' online, sends Happy Near Year online, sends warnings/ threats online..."Reacting to the probe, ABVP general secretary Nidhi Tripathi said, "Anyone participating in ABVP or JNUSU events cannot qualify to become members automatically. Akshat Awasthi is neither an office bearer, nor karyakarta of ABVP. Anyone involved in the violence at JNU should be prosecuted. We will fully support police in their investigation."

Title: Sec 144 can’t be used to quell dissent, repetitive orders an abuse of power: SC
Content:
(File photo)

NEW DELHI: Frowning at the mechanical imposition of prohibitory orders under Section 144 of the Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC) since the British era to the present day, the Supreme Court ruled on Friday they cannot be used to quell dissent or expression of grievance in a democracy.In its judgment on restrictions imposed on movement of people in J&K after the August 5 decision to remove its special status and divide it into two Union territories, the bench said, "Power under Section 144 CrPC cannot be used as a tool to prevent legitimate expression of opinion or grievance or exercise of any democratic rights."The bench emphasised application of the provision should be limited to situations of emergency and for preventing obstruction and annoyance or injury to any person lawfully employed. It also said "repetitive (prohibitive) orders under Section 144 would be an abuse of power" and directed authorities to notify all prohibitory orders passed in J&K so as to enable aggrieved persons to challenge it at an appropriate forum.But as in the case of the part of the verdict dealing with the suspension of internet in J&K, Justices N V Ramana, Subhash Reddy and B R Gavai recognised the need for the state to use Section 144. The thrust appeared to be more on the prevention of misuse of the provision; to ensure that it was used judiciously rather than turned into a blunt weapon.Thus, the court said the provision, which was both remedial and preventive, could be used not only to deal with an existing danger but also in situations when there was apprehension of one, so long as the "danger" qualified to be an emergency and likely to result in "obstruction and annoyance or injury to any person lawfully employed".The bench said the use of the provision was subject to judicial review and, hence, should be resorted to reasonably and on the basis of material facts. "While exercising the power under Section 144 CrPC, the magistrate is duty bound to balance rights and restrictions based on the principles of proportionality and apply the least intrusive measure," it said.The effort to negotiate the duel between the utility of Section 144 for dealing with emergency-like situations and the experience of its misuse came across clearly in the court's observation, "As emergency does not shield the actions of the government completely, disagreement does not justify destabilisation; the beacon of rule of law shines always."However, it also cautioned against too much stress on the "proportionality doctrine" to temper restrictions in cases relating to the security, sovereignty and integrity of India.It noted that imposition of the section over a larger area and longer duration required a higher threshold.Referring to senior advocate Kapil Sibal's argument that governments in future could misuse powers under Section 144 to impose blanket restrictions to prevent opposition parties from elections, the bench said, "Our Constitution protects the expression of divergent views, legitimate expressions and disapproval, and this cannot be the basis for invocation of Section 144 CrPC unless there is sufficient material to show likely incitement to violence or threat to public safety."

Title: Kashmir news: Govt deal in works for release of Omar and Farooq Abdullah?
Content:
(File photo)

26 detainees released

SRINAGAR: There were strong indications on Friday, a day after foreign envoys arrived in Jammu and Kashmir to assess the situation, that the government was working out a deal where MP and National Conference chairman Farooq Abdullah and his son, MLA and former J&K CM Omar Abdullah , would be released from detention in exchange for their promise that they would take a break from active politics for a while.Well-placed government sources said the offer was being readied and the Abdullahs may be approached.A top government source said one idea was to find a way to nudge the Abdullahs to move for a while to the UK.The sources said the two could, however, run their party's affairs through "agents in the UT of J&K".The Abdullahs have been in detention since J&K was stripped of its special status on August 5 last year and later bifurcated into two Union Territories.This came even as the J&K government on Friday revoked the detention warrants of 26 people, including senior lawyer Nazir Ahmad Ronga of Nishat.Ronga, a former Kashmir bar Association president, is a close associate of Mirwaiz Umar Farooq, a separatist who is chairman of his faction of the Hurriyat Conference.The revocation of the provisions of the J&K Public Safety Act of 1978 against the 26 came hours after the Supreme Court directed the J&K administration to review the curbs imposed in the UT while saying the freedom of speech and conducting business on the internet are protected under the Constitution .

Title: Kashmir news: Govt deal in works for release of Omar and Farooq Abdullah?
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

(File photo)

Title: Ajay Devgn's 'Tanhaji: The Unsung Warrior' Vs Deepika Padukone's 'Chhapaak': Early box office report
Content: Rajkummar Rao turned a year older today. The fans of the actor have taken to their social media to wish him on his special day. They have been sharing pictures of the birthday boy, his movie posters, unseen moments and more. Recently, his girlfriend Patraleekhaa penned the sweetest birthday wish for him.

Title: Indefinite Net suspension impermissible, says SC, orders immediate review in J&K
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Internet access in Kashmir was restricted following abrogation of Article 370

NEW DELHI: Thirty-five years after declaring that newspaper publication was part of the right to free speech, the Supreme Court on Friday ruled that expression of views and carrying out trade through internet are also part of the constitutionally guaranteed fundamental right to free speech and indefinite suspension of internet services is impermissible.

“We declare that freedom of speech and expression and the freedom to practice any profession or carry on any trade, business or occupation over the medium of internet enjoys constitutional protection under Article 19(1)(a) and Article 19(1)(g). The restrictions upon such fundamental rights should be in consonance with the mandate under Article 19(2) and (6) of the Constitution, inclusive of the test of proportionality,” a bench of Justices N V Ramana, R Subhash Reddy and B R Gavai said.

The verdict came on petitions filed by Congress’s Ghulam Nabi Azad and Kashmir Times publisher Anuradha Bhasin against the suspension of internet in the wake of the Centre’s decision to scrap the special status for J&K. The SC said it did not test “whether right to access to internet is a fundamental right” and was hence not expressing any opinion on it as none of the counsel advanced any arguments on this issue.

The order marked an attempt to deal with the perennial tension between the right to freedom and liberty and the requirements of national security and public safety, with the court seeking to locate the pendulum in the middle. It placed the “legitimate” use of internet in the pantheon of fundamental rights, while acknowledging that it was subject to reasonable restrictions, like other fundamental rights.

On balance, the court took the line that while access to internet should be the norm, deviations could be allowed in the interest of order and safety provided they were temporary, proportionate and justified by reasons which were spelt out clearly and reviewed periodically. “We direct the state and competent authorities to review all (existing) orders suspending internet services forthwith,” the bench said.

The SC also said since existing provisions did not provide for periodic review of orders or the duration they would remain in force, “we direct the review committee must conduct a periodic review within seven working days of previous review” of orders suspending telecom services.

The continued internet shutdown in Kashmir has been a contentious issue, with opposition and activists criticising the curbs and the government insisting it was a security issue to be evaluated by the local administration, wary of the use of social media and messaging services to organise and foment trouble. The internet shutdown also attracted adverse international commentary.

The verdict steered clear of getting into the question of whether the communication ban was illegal, made no adverse comments on the Centre but made it clear that a prolonged shutdown could not be countenanced unless it was periodically reviewed and a satisfactory justification offered. It could also set the stage for the executive to close the gap in rules which do not limit the period for which internet services can be suspended.

Writing the judgment, Justice Ramana said, “An order suspending internet services indefinitely is impermissible under the Temporary Suspension of Telecom Services (Public Emergency or Public Service) Rules, 2017. Suspension can be utilised for temporary duration only.”

On the criticality of internet in contemporary times, it said, “There is no doubt that there are certain trades which are completely dependent on internet. Such a right of trade through internet also fosters consumerism and availability of choice. Therefore, freedom of trade and commerce through the medium of the internet is constitutionally protected under Article 19(1)(g), subject to the restrictions provided under Article 19(6).”

In December 1984, the SC in the Indian Express case had declared that freedom of print media was covered under right to free speech and expression guaranteed under Article 19 of the Constitution.

The ruling making free speech and trade through internet part of Article 19 would mean views expressed on social media using internet must not fall afoul of restrictive boundaries in the shape of security of the state, friendly relations with foreign countries, public order, decency or morality, contempt of court, defamation or incitement to an offence. This could open a new chapter in social media experience.

It said no fundamental right was absolute and right to free speech too could be restricted by the government in compliance of requirements under Article 19(2) of the Constitution. To impose restrictions on free speech, including use of internet, the SC laid down the ‘doctrine of proportionality’ and said the degree and scope of restrictions, both territorial and temporary, must have a clear nexus with the necessity to combat an emergent situation.

Title: Govt staff can join rallies, post views on social media: Tripura HC
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

AGARTALA: Dismissing an inquiry against a retired employee of the state fisheries department, the chief justice of Tripura high court on Friday said that government employees can take part in political programmes, including meetings, and freely post their opinions on social media platforms, without attracting punitive measures under Rule 5 of the All India Services (Conduct) Rules.

Justice A Kureshi said that attending a political rally would not be considered as involvement in politics and government employees should have the personal liberty to post their opinions on social media.

Lipika Paul was dismissed from service on April 25, 2018, four days before her retirement, for taking part in a political programme in December 2017 and making a social media post against BJP.

"During election times, as is well known, political parties and their leaders as well as nominated candidates take out rallies and address public gatherings. Every person who is present in the audience during such addresses cannot be stated to have participated in the rally. The presence of a person does not either establish his or her political affiliation. A student of politics, an enthusiastic young man, a reporter or just a curious bystander - all are likely to be present in any political gathering. Even an opponent or a critic of a political party may also attend the gathering. Her mere presence at a gathering, therefore, without any further allegation, would not amount to her participation in such political gathering," the court order stated.

"I have taken note of the contents of the said post which originally was in Bengali and has been translated and presented before me. Nothing contained in the said post suggests canvassing for or against any political party. It only expresses certain beliefs of the petitioner in general terms. As a government servant the petitioner is not devoid of her right of free speech, a fundamental right which can be curtailed only by a valid law. She was entitled to hold her own beliefs and express them in the manner she desired of course subject to not crossing the borders laid down in sub-rule (4) of Rule 5 of the All India Services (Conduct) Rules."

Title: NCLAT gave Cyrus Mistry relief never sought, says SC, stays order
Content:
Cyrus Mistry (left) and Ratan Tata (File photo)

NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court on Friday took less than 10 seconds to stay the National Company Law Appellate Tribunal's December 18 decision reinstating Cyrus Pallonji Mistry as executive chairman of Tata Sons , a post from which he was removed in 2016 by the board of directors.The skills of a heavy-duty line-up of senior advocates - Harish Salve, AM Singhvi and Mukul Rohatgi - enlisted by Tata Sons to challenge the NCLAT judgment were underutilised as a bench of Chief Justice S A Bobde and Justices B R Gavai and Surya Kant ordered notice on its petition while staying operation of the order within seconds of the plea being called for hearing.This triggered strong protest from several other senior advocates - C A Sundaram, Shyam Divan, Maninder Singh and Neeraj K Kaul - engaged by the Shapoorji Pallonji group, Mistry and Sterling Investments. They told the SC that Mistry himself had said he did not want reinstatement as executive chairman but wanted to protect the interest of minority shareholders."The Supreme Court must keep operational the NCLAT decision rescinding conversion of Tata Sons to a private company from a public company," Sundaram argued.He also said representation of Shapoorji Pallonji group through a director, which has been traditionally done, must be maintained.Tata Sons refused and contended that the NCLAT order was completely wrong and set a wrong legal precedent which endangered corporate democracy.This was vindicated by observations from the bench which refused to accede to Shapoorji Pallonji group's fervent requests not to stay the NCLAT judgment. The group was seeking a status quo order.CJI Bobde said, "There appears to be a basic flaw in the NCLAT order reinstating Mistry as executive chairman of Tata Sons as that relief was never sought. Something appears very wrong. We looked at the judicial approach of NCLAT in the case and found it sorely lacking."Sundaram said a status quo order was necessary as stay would enable Tata Sons to take coercive steps under law to buy out shares of the Shapoorji Pallonji group, which has invested around Rs 1 lakh crore in Tata Sons. But Salve pre-empted the apprehensions by undertaking before the court that Tata Sons would not resort to coercive steps to buy back shares of minority shareholders.The SC asked the Shapoorji Pallonji group to respond to petitions filed by Tata Sons, Ratan Tata and other Tata group companies and their directors, in four weeks.Mistry was removed on October 24, 2016, nearly four years after his appointment. Of the eight directors, seven voted for his ouster while one abstained. Tata Sons, in its petition filed through solicitors Karanjawala & Co, said the NCLAT order directing reinstatement of Mistry was gratuitous as none of the appellants, Cyrus Investment or Sterling Investment, had ever sought such a relief.Criticising the NCLAT decision, Tata Sons said, "The impugned judgment has torn apart the rights of majority shareholders and directors enshrined under the articles of the Companies Act, 2013, and disenfranchised all other shareholders of Tata Sons, including Tata trusts."The petition is likely to be mentioned for urgent hearing on Monday. The NCLAT had suspended its direction for reinstatement of Mistry till January 18.

Title: Three arrested with ganja worth Rs 40k
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Accused with seized contraband

Rajkot: Three persons were arrested with a total of 5.744 kg ganja (marijuana) worth Rs 39,584 in two separate raids in Devbhoomi Dwarka district and Junagadh city on Thursday night.

In Devbhoomi Dwarka district, Kalyan Nath Bapu alias Kara Khasia (41) was arrested from Katkotala village of Bhanvad taluka. “Bapu, who is the priest of the village temple, had kept the contraband for his own consumption and was also selling some to the people,” said J M Patel, inspector with Devbhoomi Dwarka special operation group (SOG).

The police recovered 4.464 kg ganja worth Rs 26,784 from the priest.

In Junagadh, Hafiz Solanki (25) and Ramesh Gulwani (42) were arrested from Majevadi Darwaza locality with 1.280 kg ganja worth Rs 12,800.

“Solanki and Gulwani said they had come to the city to sell the contraband to sadhus in Bhavnath taleti,” said N B Barot, inspector with Junagadh SOG.

Title: Speed guns set to make a comeback by month-end
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

PATNA: After the successful trial of speed guns on the Jagdeo Path-Sheikhpura Mor flyover, the Patna traffic police are now planning to use them on other flyovers, roads and highways across the city from January-end.

In December last year, altogether 20 speed guns had been acquired to keep a check on overspeeding and reckless driving. Of these, only two were used by traffic cops and several motorists penalized on the Jagdeo Path-Sheikhpura Mor flyover.

According to transport secretary Sanjay Kumar Agarwal, 20 more speed guns with inbuilt printers will soon be acquired to keep tabs on errant drivers and frequent violators.

“Acquiring additional speed guns is a temporary arrangement. We are now planning to fix these guns on poles at strategic locations in the city and other parts of the state so that the entire system becomes automatic,” Agarwal told this newspaper on Friday.

He added, “The poles will detect the speed and number plates of the vehicles and also click their photographs.”

A senior traffic cop said, “Overspeeding is not just dangerous for motorists, but for others around them, too. If they clash with another vehicle, they are likely to get hurt or die. We have, therefore, taken several measures to reduce accidents and keep a check on rash drivers. We have identified the vulnerable roads, highways and flyovers in the city.”

Title: Say yes to Happy Streets, no to illegal parking
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Nagpur: With an aim to promote non-motorized transport, fitness, cleanliness and recreation, people have been turning up in large numbers for Happy Streets , organized by The Times of India and Maharashtra Times in association with the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC), on the last three Sundays.

Officials, corporators and activists have appealed to revellers to use public transport and avoid parking in non-permitted areas or in a haphazard manner blocking entry to buildings.

DCP (traffic) Chinmay Pandit said such vehicles will be towed away by traffic police. “Despite being a Sunday and early morning, traffic police will be on duty. They will also initiate action against two-wheeler riders blowing horns above permissible decibel level,” he said.

Municipal commissioner Abhijit Bangar said people residing close to West High Court where Happy Streets is held should use bicycles or come walking. “I am delighted to see a large number of people, especially youths, enjoying Happy Streets in early morning hours despite low temperatures. Happy Streets is a platform where people should learn discipline and create awareness among others,” he said.

“Haphazard parking is a big issue throughout the city. People coming to Happy Streets from far-off places should use public transport. The NMC is operating a big fleet of buses every morning. City buses plying on Amravati and Hingna Roads can be well utilized for Happy Streets. The NMC is executing several programmes to promote Swachh Bharat Mission, which too should be learnt from Happy Streets,” he said.

Corporator Sanjay Bangale said it is the responsibility of people coming to Happy Streets to keep citizens living in nearby areas happy. “Our aim is to make this city free from pollution and improve health. People should use bicycles or shared vehicles for Happy Streets or any mass public event. Participants should avoid creating problems for others by not parking in front of gates across the city. All these are part of public participation in developing and making the city free from congestion and pollution,” he said.

The NMC has given permission to park four-wheelers in two open spaces at Dharampeth and Tilak Nagar. Also, one lane of parking is permissible on Amravati Road, WHC Road (from Laxmi Bhuvan Square to Shankar Nagar Square), all roads coming to WHC Road at Times square, Coffee House Square and Laxmi Bhuvan Square. Another advantage for participants is that parking in permitted locations is free of cost.

Mayor Sandip Joshi, Bangar, West Nagpur MLA Vikas Thakre, Bangale and other guests who visited Happy Streets on last three Sundays appreciated the turnout and appealed to make the city happy with their full support.

Title: Police in search of a Darbhanga youth for links with Lakdawala
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

PATNA: Bihar police officials are trying to ascertain the identity of a youth from Darbhanga district, who was in touch with Ejaz Yusuf Lakdawala , a former aide of fugitive underworld don Dawood Ibrahim. Lakdawala was arrested from Jakkanpur police station area of the state capital by a joint team of Mumbai police’s crime branch and the state STF on Wednesday and subsequently taken to Mumbai by a flight the same day.

Highly placed sources said the Darbhanga resident had also contacted Lakdawala on his cellphone on Wednesday soon after he reached the state capital from Nepal. The youth, stated to be a native of a village under Jale block in Darbhanga, had reportedly promised Lakdawala to help him in obtaining a fake identity proof for him to be later used for getting a passport issued from the regional passport office in Patna.

Sources said the telephone number of the youth in question was provided to Lakdawala by a Maulvi during his stay in Nepal. “The youth in question was in dire need of a job and can be used for any purpose,” a police officer said, quoting Lakdawala, who was detained at the Jakkanpur police station before being flown to Mumbai.

The intelligence agencies have also come to know about another youth, who was present at the Mithapur bus stand under Jakkanpur police station area to receive Lakdawala, who was coming from Nepal. Sources said the identity of the two youths in question was being ascertained by the police. All the top police officers of the state were tight-lipped over Bihar connections of the arrested don.

Darbhanga in north Bihar had earlier been associated with a terror outfit Indian Mujahideen. Danish, stated to be a close associate of IM co-founder Yasin Bhatkal, was arrested from Laheriasarai in Darbhanga district in 2013 for his alleged involvement in subversive activities. Bhatkal, who was arrested from Raxaul on Indo-Nepal border in East Champaran district in August 2013, had spent long time in Darbhanga to set up a sleeper cell of the banned terror outfit.

Title: Gems & Jewellery council seeks import duty cut in the budget
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Chennai: Industry body All India Gems and Jewellery Domestic Council has written to the PMO, home ministry and the finance ministry seeking a reduction in import duty from 12.5% to 6%, ( It was increased from 10% to 12.5% in the last budget) and an increase the availability of credit from banks.

“A reduction in import duty will help ease demand. We are hopeful of a favourable move and expect to see gold demand similar to the levels of 2018, in the upcoming year,” said Anantha Padmanabhan, chairman, GJC. He noted that gold imports were down by 10%-15% y-o-y in 2019 and added that business saw a drop of 30% by volume in last six months. “As a result, quite some jewellery workshops shut operations. We are working with World Gold Council and Metal Focus to gauge the situation. Over the next 6 months, we hope to come up with an estimation of how many shutdowns were seen,” he added. Emphasising the need for tax reduction, Padmanabhan claimed the industry saw increase in gold smuggling resulting from increased customs duty, along with goods and services tax hike. Buyers were also opting to purchase gold from countries like Dubai, Nepal, Sri Lanka and Singapore. The GJC’s chairman also appealed to the government to constitute a steering committee before issuing a notification making hallmarking of gold mandatory across the country from January 15, 2021. Through the steering committee, the government may seek industry opinion before implementing the notification on hallmarking

With hope that the government would implement the recommendations, the council expects that the industry would post a 10% increase in business by volume in 2020 despite a 30% drop in last 6 months of 2019.

Title: Embroidery traders cheated of Rs 1.42 crore
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Surat: Eight textile traders and brokers cheated 49 embroidery unit holders of Rs 1.42 crores after they got the work done from these units but refused to make payment.

In a complaint registered at Salabatpura police station, one of the unit holders, Anil B Makani, 40, a resident of Kathodara in Kamrej taluka, stated that he came in touch with one Suresh Chudasama who operated a shop named Zoya textile in Millennium market. He was introduced to Chudasama by broker Mukeshbhai. Makani accepted material for embroidery work from Chudasama between September 26 and October 7, 2019 worth Rs 4,28,721 and also completed his job.

Chudasama had set a condition of making payment for the work in 60 days. However, when the time for payment came, he started making excuses and after sometime even closed his shop and fled, Makani alleged.

The complaint also states the names and amounts that were lost by other unit holders to the other trader who contacted them through different brokers.

In all the plaint was registered for loss of Rs 1.42 crore. Even three persons who helped Chudasama in getting the shop on rent have been named in the complaint.

The brokers who have been named in the cheating plaint include Shankar D Hasani, Manish Viradia, Shatrughna Borad, Bhavesh, Paresh and Mukesh Ballar apart from one Ramesh bhai, owner of KD Bhatiya dying and printing mills.

Salabatpura police said that they have started investigations and will find the accused based on a few leads they have got.

Title: PC seeks dismissal of 63 Moons suit
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Swati.Deshpande@timesgroup.com

Mumbai: Former Union finance minister P Chidambaram has questioned the maintainability and has sought dismissal of a suit by 63 Moons — a financial technology company founded by Jignesh Shah . The firm had sued him and two IAS officers for damages of Rs 10,000 crore.

The suit is in connection with the Rs 5,600-crore National Spot Exchange ( NSEL ) payment default case of 2013. It alleges misuse and abuse of erstwhile Forward Markets Commission by the trio and claims they are “personally liable” for their “wrongful and mala fide acts apart from the government itself”.

Chidambaram has sought dismissal of the suit. He says that the government ought to have been mandatorily made a party to the suit as the minister and bureaucrats were acting in their official capacities. The government is not a party. The two IAS officers are Ramesh Abhishek and K P Krishnan . Chidambaram also said he is filing a separate application for rejection of the suit for being “barred by law and for failure to disclose cause of action”.

The Bombay HC had on December 13 given an additional four weeks as a final extension to Chidambaram and the two IAS officers to file their statements in response to the suit. Justice A K Menon had noted in the order then, “If written statement is not filed within four weeks period, the suit shall stand transferred to the list of undefended suits.”

Chidambaram filed his reply on January 9. It says that the allegations in the suit are “baseless, entirely devoid of any substance and expressly denied”. Chidambaram has sought a stay on the suit, while the legal point of maintainability and making government a party is decided first.

He says that under the civil procedure code, “it is a mandate that where a suit is filed against a public officer for damages in respect of any act alleged to have been done by him in his official capacity, the government shall be joined as a party to the suit”.

The company has made multiple allegations against the department of consumer affairs (DCA), including that it had eventually forced the NSEL, promoted by 63 Moons (formerly known as FTIL), to suspend its trading. The suit alleged that an “abrupt directive by DCA in July 2013 created a panic and chaos”. DCA thus ought to be made a necessary party, says Chidambaram.

Through a statutory notice, the company had last February intimated the trio of its intention to file the suit. The HC had last year in June allowed the company’s plea to sue Chidambaram in Mumbai. “This is a suit for damages for the malicious and mala fide actions on the part of defendants claimed to have caused damage to the plaintiff (63 Moons) and resulted in erosion of the value of the plaintiff’s shareholding due to fall in price of its share on the Bombay Stock Exchange and National Stock Exchange, both situated in Mumbai,” the HC order had said then.

The HC is expected to hear the matter next week.

Title: ‘Non-customer facing regional level officers will be rationalised’
Content: Chennai: Canara Bank chairman T N Manoharan in a free-wheeling chat with Mamtha Asokan addresses various issues — from the bank’s branch rationalisation plan, employees’ worry over lay-offs, hurdles in the lending business, employee skill gap to need for a secondary market for corporate loans. The public sector bank has less than three months to complete the merge process with Syndicate Bank. In August, 2019 the Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced a mega merger plan for 10 PSBs which are to be consolidated into four. Post the merger, Canara Bank and Syndicate Bank will stand as the nation’s fourth-largest lender. Excerpts:What impact will rationalisation of officers have on Canara Bank and Syndicate Bank?Non-customer facing regional level officers will be rationalised, while the rest will remain unaffected. Service for the respective branches (both Canara Bank and Syndicate Bank) will continue, as there is no intention to rationalise them. Branches will continue as usual. There will be rationalisation only for the regional level offices where there is no customer interface. A joint task force is formed to monitor all steps of the merger and it will decide the basis of rationalisation as we reach our merger deadline of March 31, 2020.What kind of skill gap do you see among banks employees? Is there any immediate demand for skilling and reskilling of employees?Credit function needs immediate focus, even though marketing and sales are equally important. In terms of lending, while earlier the focus was corporate lending, now it is retail. Thus, skilled employees in credit function play a vital role. Demand for skilled employees in Know Your Customer (KYC) and anti-money laundering hold the second place, especially when digital operations on rise, so are frauds.On the whole, there is not much skill gap among the existing staff. As far as BFSI upskilling is concerned, we have BFSI Governing Council which overlooks this process, besides central recruitment process. Canara Bank has tied-up with private skilling institutions like Manipal BFSI.What are your concerns on bank’s lending business going forward?The primary concern is lending to corporate clients. Unlike other countries, we do not have a secondary market for corporate loans. The RBI Monetary Policy Committee has accepted recommendations in December to set up a ‘self-regulatory body’, that will help form a secondary market platform to address corporate loans and simultaneously set the rules and regulations.Will there be any lay-offs post the merger?Despite a rise in digital banking, the need for bank branches and physical presence of bankers is growing. Of the total transactions, we have achieved 74% online transaction (e-transactions), compared to 60% in 2018, and 40% in 2017. About five years ago, our employee strength stood at 42,000, while in 2020 it stands at 60,000, despite 18,000 employees having retired.Do you expect more consolidation among banks? What is the roadmap going forward?To compete globally we need strong and big banks. Even, the State Bank of India had to absorb smaller banks to attain that strength (branch and book). Why do we need so many small banks competing with each other? That’s why we need consolidation of banks to avoid unhealthy competition. There is a possibility for more mergers in the future.

Title: High CO2 levels may seal fate of Western Railway’s auto-shut door plan
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

The Western Railway is likely to abort its plan for automatic door-closing system in local trains following co... Read More

MUMBAI: The Western Railway is likely to abort its plan for automatic door-closing system in local trains following concerns over suffocation due to increased carbon dioxide levels in coaches and adverse impact on punctuality. Recently, WR conducted trials of the automatic door-closing system with the aim to prevent commuters falling off crowded trains. In 2019, 550 commuters died after falling off crowded trains.

During the trials held between January 2 and 5, a 12-car train with three coaches—a ladies compartment, a second class compartment and a luggage compartment—refitted with automatic doors were operated during both peak and non-peak hours. It was observed that the carbon dioxide level was between 710 and 960 parts per million (PPM) in the three coaches during non-peak hours.

As per specifications of the Integral Coach Factory, the concentration of CO2 inside a railway coach should be less than 700 ppm for ambient temperature.

“These levels are during non-peak hours. We have to still measure the levels during peak hours; it could be high as commuter density will be more,” said a railway official. CO2 levels between 1000 and 2,000 ppm can cause drowsiness, and levels beyond this can result in increased heart rate and nausea, said doctors.

“The trials are complete, we are now preparing a final report. The report will be sent to the railway board, which will then take a decision on whether or not to run non-AC trains with closed doors,” said Ravindra Bhakar, WR, chief PRO.

On the adverse impact on punctuality, during trials it was observed that the train with the three door-closure system took more time to cover the same distance when compared with regular rakes.

For instance, it was found that the running time of a 12-car between Churchgate and Borivli is 65 minutes with 20 station halts. But, the running time increased by 8-10 minutes due to time lost in opening and closing of doors. Sources said the travel time on the fast corridor between Churchgate and Virar is expected to increase by 6-7 minutes.

According to railways data, a 12-car train should carry 3,504 commuters, but during the peak hours, it carries an average 5,000 commuters.

Also, the average halt time at a station increased to 57- 61 seconds from 30-40 seconds due to opening and closing of coach doors. Also, if the train’s automatic doors malfunction during the peak hours, it will have a cascading effect on punctuality, said a source.

Commuters too were not enthused with the closed coaches. Mumbai Central resident Nirmal Jain said, “The door-closure system can only work in AC coaches. If we feel suffocated in winter months, imagine what would happen during summer?”

But Virar resident Raju Naik feels commuters need time to adjust to the door-closure system. “In regular trains, people get on and off a train even before it comes to a halt at the station, which is dangerous. If the doors remain shut, this situation can be avoided.”

Title: Bihar: 15% rise in crimes against women in 2018, says NCRB
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The number of crimes against women in 2018 went up by more than 15% as compared to the previous year, according to data published by the National Crime Record Bureau (NCRB). The state saw more than 2,200 cases in 2018 (16,920) as compared to 14,711 such cases in 2017. The number of cases reported in 2016 was 13,400.

The report highlights that in 98.2% rape cases in the state, the culprits were known to the victim.

However, the crime rate against women in Bihar, which is measured as number of incidents of such crime per one lakh population, is much lower compared to the national average across all states, which stands at 57.5. While the rate of such crimes in Bihar is 29.8, Assam has the highest in the country at 166, followed by Delhi with the crime rate of 149.6 per one lakh population.

The categories of crimes included in the NCRB report are rape, kidnapping, assault on women with intent to outraging her modesty, cruelty by husband and relatives and dowry death among others.

Bihar state women’s commission chairperson Dilmani Mishra attributed the rise in the number of crimes against women in the state to more women coming out to report. “Earlier women used to remain quiet, but now education and awareness regarding their rights have made them aware and they report to the police. Also women’s commission, police and the media have given them constant support to fight against atrocities and it is good that they are coming out of their homes,” Mishra said.

The NCRB report also pointed out that that in most rape cases in Bihar, culprits were known to the victim. A total of 651 cases of rape were reported in 2018 in Bihar and in 639 cases, rapists were known to the victim. Most of the known rapists were either friends, online friends or live-in partners or separated husbands accounting for 563 rape cases. Only in 12 cases, rapists were not known to the victim, while seven were family members and 219 were either family friends, neighbours, employers or other known persons. Of the total rape cases reported in 2018, there were eight cases of gang rape.

The data also revealed that 540 rape survivors were in the age group of 18 and 30 years, while 111 rape victims were in the age group of above 30 and below 45 years. There were 16 cases of rape of women between the ages of 45 and 60 years. No rape cases were registered among children below 12 years and there was just one case in the age group of 12 and 18 years.

Apart from rape, the state recorded 106 cases of assault on women and 113 cases of sexual harassment (Section 354 A of IPC). Though no cases of sexual harassment were reported from the work place, 22 such cases were reported from public transport and 91 from other places.

Other assault on women included cruelty by husband or relatives with 2,539 incidents reported, forced miscarriage 20, acid attack 6, disrobing 23, voyeurism 3 and stalking 17 in 2018.

Title: Rajkot: Medical student, 3 others held for bootlegging
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

The four accused with the beer cans in police custody

RAJKOT: A medical student was caught running a bootlegging operation in Bhim Nagar locality on Nana Mawa Road in Rajkot on Friday afternoon. Along with him, cops also nabbed two online food delivery service men who worked for the student and seized beer cans worth Rs 1,200 from them.

While the police identified the main accused as Vimal Mahida (26), a native of Godhra, they also unearthed why final year MBBS student started running the illicit business of supplying liquor. “During interrogation, Mahida confessed of turning to bootlegging for the past three months to finance himself after his parents stopped sending him money for having failed to clear his exams four times,” said J V Bhola, inspector with Rajkot taluka police station.

Cops also arrested Ajay Parmar, Rahul Parmar and Rakesh Sagathia, all aged 22. “Sagathia supplied the liquor to Mahida who had employed Ajay and Rahul as his delivery boys,” cops said, adding that they recovered 12 cans of beer from the accused and also a two-wheeler.

Title: ‘Patna Science College to apply for re-assessment’
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Patna Science College

PATNA: The 92-year-old Patna Science College , which was awarded ‘B’ grade (2.16 CGPA out of 4) by the National Assessment and Accreditation Council (NAAC) on Thursday, has decided to apply for re-assessment after expiry of the mandatory one-year time.

The college’s newly-appointed principal, S R Padmadeo, told this newspaper on Saturday that he was unsatisfied with the “poor NAAC grade”.

“I have started going through the self-study report submitted by the college and will make sure that all the loopholes are fixed. We will create a healthy environment of teaching and research in the institution before applying for re-assessment. With presentation of facts in a systematic manner, the college is bound to get an ‘A’ grade,” he said.

Earlier, in its first cycle of accreditation in 2007, Patna Science College had been awarded a ‘B++’ grade.

Meanwhile, former students of the institute, which was once called the ‘Cambridge of the east’, are equally disappointed.

“It is unfortunate to learn that Patna Science College , which was once at the helm of academics in the country, has deteriorated so much. We are all responsible for its downfall,” rued college alumnus and Shri Mata Vaishno Devi University (Jammu and Kashmir) vice-chancellor (VC) Ravindra Kumar Sinha.

Popularly known as the ‘Dolphin Man of India’, Sinha said, “With many academics being interested in other pastimes, the standard of teaching and research has gone down considerably. It will be difficult to restore the old glory of science college unless a sound academic environment is created here.”

Patna University former VC and science college’s former principal, Arun Kumar Sinha, observed that NAAC grades did not reflect the real status of any institution. “The peer team was all praise for the college, but it was awarded a ‘B’. The fact is institutions, which do their paperwork properly, are awarded better grades,” he said, but admitted that the college faced lack of teachers and infrastructure.

Another alumnus, Kanhaiya Bahadur Sinha, who is the working president of the Federation of University Teachers’ Associations of Bihar , criticised the entire process of accreditation of universities.

He said, “The new education policy draft envisages only two types of institutions, universities and autonomous colleges. Now, there will be only a few autonomous colleges in the country, opening the doors for more and more private colleges. The poor children of Bihar are bound to suffer with the mushrooming of the so-called autonomous and private institutions.”

Title: Woman gang-raped twice in Begusarai, four held
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Police on Friday arrested four youths on charges of raping a 26-year-old married woman at a village under the Mansoorchak police station area in Begusarai district , twice on the same day. The woman approached the police on Thursday, six days after the assaults, once her husband returned home from an outstation job.

The incident took place around 6pm on January 3 when the woman, mother of three, was returning home after buying vegetables from a local market. In her police complaint, the woman alleged that she was waylaid by the four youths – Dheeraj Kumar, Ajay Kumar, Sonu Kumar and Rajan Kumar – who took her to a nearby field and raped her.

The woman’s ordeal did not end there. The four youths forcibly took her to a deserted place behind the Mansoorchak block office, consumed liquor and again took turns to rape her. She was let off late in the evening only after being robbed of her cellphone and Rs 2,000 in cash.

While Dheeraj is a resident of Dashrathpur Kishun Tola, the other three accused hail from Mansoorchak village under the same police station area in Begusarai district.

Teghra SDPO Ashish Anand said the woman was sent to the sadar hospital at Begusarai for medical examination on Friday. “All the four accused have already been arrested. Further investigation is underway,” the SDPO told this newspaper over phone.

The woman lodged the FIR with the Mansoorchak police after her husband, who works as daily wager outside the state, returned home on Thursday.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Dehri shivers at 6 degrees C as cold winds sweep Bihar
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Biting cold continued to sweep the state even on Friday under the influence of cloudy condition and cold northerly winds. Meteorologists said though clear skies are expected by Saturday afternoon, dense fog cover would be witnessed in the early morning hours in Patna and most parts of south Bihar .

According to weathermen, the night temperature is expected to fall by two to three notches over the next two to three days. Day temperature, on the other hand, is expected to increase by a couple of notches at most places in the state.

Patna Meteorological Centre has predicted that minimum and maximum temperature in the state capital would hover in the range of 11-13 and 18-20 degrees C, respectively, till January 15.

Though India Meteorological Department (IMD), in its all-India weather bulletin issued on Friday evening, stated that cold day condition would prevail in Bihar on Saturday, officials at Patna Meteorological Centre ruled out such weather conditions.

According to daily weather bulletin issued by Patna Meteorological Centre on Friday, minimum temperature in the city was recorded at 12.6 degrees C, four notches higher than normal. Lowest minimum temperature was recorded at Dehri in Rohtas district, where the morning minimum fell to 6 degrees C.

The comparatively higher minimum temperature was attributed to the cloud cover prevailing at many places in the state from last couple of days under the influence of a western disturbance . The cloud cover prevented the radiation from the Earth’s surface to escape in the upper level of atmosphere in the early morning hours, thus keeping the minimum temperature tad high.

However, it was the maximum temperature of 17.4 degrees C in Patna, four notches lower than normal, which led to cold conditions during the day time. Lower day temperature was also attributed to the cloud cover.

Weathermen said it was the cold north-westerly winds which created shivery conditions in the state. “There has been substantial snowfall in the Himalayan region, including Uttarakhand and Himachal Pradesh, over the past few days. Cold north- westerly winds coming from the snow-laden Himalayan peaks was blowing in Bihar at an average speed of 12-14kmph on Friday, leading to shivery conditions. Such weather conditions would prevail in the state over the next two to three days,” an official at Patna Meteorological Centre said.

Title: Test run of AI-based baggage screening
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

PUNE: The airport authorities are conducting a trial of an artificial intelligence powered baggage screening solution, ‘Baggage AI’, which is supposed to ease the work of the airport authorities as well the CISF ( Central Industrial Security Force ) when it comes to baggage scanning during security check-in.

“Baggage AI is an artificial intelligence (AI) based solution developed to enhance security at airports. It is the first-of-its-kind threat detection system for security x-ray machines. This AI software technology can automatically detect various objects and other threats from the x-ray images produced during the screening of baggage and alert operators,” Pune airport director Ajay Kumar told TOI.

Himanshu Arora, the co-founder of the startup (Dimensionless Technologies) that developed the system, said, “There are many small things like a lighter, vaping machine and more which do not appear prominently in an x-ray scan. Baggage AI can detect these objects in the luggage and show them prominently with the help of shades and colour. The trial run has been ongoing for almost a month now.”

Kumar said, “The Airports Authority of India (AAI) had organized an ‘Innovate for airport’ programme under the Startup India initiative. Innovative solutions for airports from over 350 startups across India were screened and eight were selected to implement their solutions at various airports of the country. Of these solutions, Baggage AI is presently under trail at Pune airport.”

Title: Chausa PACS chairman’s son kidnapped from Patna
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Unidentified persons allegedly kidnapped the 19-year-old son of Chausa primary agriculture credit society (PACS) chairman Manoj Kumar Singh from Sai Temple area under Patliputra police station in the state capital on Thursday evening.

Manoj reached here from Chausa on Friday and lodged an FIR with Patliputra police station in this connection.

The victim was identified as Manish Ranjan. He had reached Patna from his native Chausa in Buxar district for writing JEE Main exam at a centre located in Patliputra industrial area, according to the FIR lodged by Manoj.

Manish, after coming out of the exam centre, had informed his father that he would stay at a rented accommodation of his friend Raghvendra Singh at Indrapuri and would return home on Friday.

Manish was moving on foot with Raghvendra after eating at a roadside eatery near the temple when a car approached them and kidnapped Manish after thrashing his friend.

It was Raghvendra who called Manoj’s nephew at Chausa informing him about the kidnapping around 7.30pm. Manish had made a call to his father around 5.30pm.

Manoj also mentioned in the FIR that at around midnight, he received a call from an unknown number and his son on the other side said he was in a train and reaching Ara. However, he failed to reach that number again when he rang back.

Patna SSP Upendra Sharma said investigation was on to trace the victim assuming that the boy was kidnapped.

Meanwhile, the victim’s father told TOI over phone that police had detained Raghvendra and was quizzing him. “Patliputra police station SHO Kamleshwar Prasad Singh told me that raids were being carried to recover my son,” Manoj said.

Title: 139 kitists take part in International Kite Festival at Surat
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

The skies over Surat were full of kites, including one that weighed 200kg of a local kitist, on Friday

SURAT: The skies over the city were full of kites, including one that weighed 200kg of a local kitist, on Friday. Over 100 kitists from abroad and different states of the country took part in the International Kite Festival organized by Gujarat Tourism, Surat district administration and Surat Municipal Corporation near the riverfront on old Adajan Road of the city.

Foreign kitists flew kites with shapes of dragon, fish, flag, queen etc in the presence of a large number of people. Kites of local people drew inspiration from religious themes. About 139 kitists, including 50 from abroad, took part in the event. Kitists from France , Nepal , the Netherlands, Russia, New Zealand, Singapore, Slovenia, Spain, Sri Lanka, Tunisia, the USA, Turkey, Thailand, Ukraine, the UK and Vietnam later enjoyed the cultural programme presented on the occasion.

“The wind was good and this made it easy for the kitists. People enjoyed different types of kites flying over the city landscape,” said a kitist from Surat.

All the kitists were welcomed in a traditional manner. City mayor also welcomed all the guests along with other dignitaries. International Kite Festival is being organized in the city for the past few years.

Title: Proper management of water resources need of hour: Governor
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Governor-cum-chancellor of universities Fagu Chauhan on Friday called upon the scientists and academics to work for sustainable development and proper management of water resources in the country.

Inaugurating the three-day 52nd annual conference of Indian Water Works Association at National Institute of Technology-Patna here, Chauhan said the entire world was concerned at the ever-declining water table and climatic changes and, if immediate solutions were not found, it would be perilous for the entire humanity.

He said all necessary measures aimed at conserving water resources and optimizing their utilization must be adopted at appropriate levels. The governor appreciated the recent water conservation schemes launched both by the central as well as state governments and said the ‘Jal Jeevan Hariyali’ scheme launched by the state government would not only help improve the declining groundwater level, but also create a better climate.

“All conventional sources of water like ponds, tanks, wells and ahar-pynes should be revived for augmenting water resources and meeting the water requirements of the people. Rainwater harvesting must be practiced at all levels,” the governor said.

State public health engineering minister Vinod Narain Jha said over-exploitation of groundwater resources for meeting agricultural and industrial needs has created acute problem of both quality and quantity in recent times. He, however, expressed the hope that the ‘Jal-Jeevan-Hariylai’ scheme would take care of this pressing need of the people and help improve water supply at panchayat level.

Chief minister’s adviser and former chief secretary Anjani Kumar Singh said of late tourist places like Rajgir, Nalanda and Bodh Gaya have started facing drinking water problem, creating hardships for the tourists. But he hoped that the ambitious scheme of taking the Ganga river water to Gaya would help rejuvenate Falgu river and solve the perennial water crisis of the region, he added.

Sulabh International founder Bindeshwar Pathak and Indian Water Works Association’s newly elected president Dineshwar Prasad Singh also addressed the conference.

Title: Two held for robbing gold ring worth Rs 50,000
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The crime branch arrested two transgender persons for robbing a woman of a gold ring worth Rs 50,000 on Senapati Bapat Road on Saturday afternoon.

The complainant is a student at a college in Lavale and stays in the hostel operated by the college. She was visiting her friends on SB Road on Saturday.

In her complaint with Chatushrungi police, the student claimed that she was about to enter a mall with her friends with two transgender persons approached her, seeking alms. As she opened her purse, she claimed one of them grabbed her arm, while the other snatched a ring from her finger. The duo then fled, she stated in the complaint.

She approached the police, and immediately, two constables rushed to the spot and started canvassing the area for clues. They received information that the suspects were at Hadapsar. A police team went to Hadapsar , nabbed the duo and recovered the ring.

Title: Ahmedbad: Man beaten unconscious, robbed at Vastrapur lake
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A 30-year-old man from the Satellite area was beaten and robbed by four men on Thursday night when he went for walk at Vastrapur lake .

In his FIR registered at Vastrapur police station on Friday, Kartik Mehta, 30, a resident of Parul Pushpak Flats near Shivranjani Crossroads, said he is a sales executive with a private company in Anandnagar.

“On Thursday at around 8pm, I went to the Vastrapur lake for a walk. After my walk, at around 10.30pm, I sat on a bench and began playing a game on my mobile phone,” Mehta stated in his FIR.

“An unknown man of around 30, wearing a khaki jacket, came up to me and asked on what I was doing there. I responded by saying why he was asking this? As I was talking to the man, three other men, also of about 30, jumped over a wall and began attacking me,” he adds.

The four men began punching and kicking Mehta on his face, chest and stomach. He suffered injuries to the left side of his face, just below the eye. One of the men hit Mehta on left side of his forehead with a stick.

The four men then went through Mehta’s pockets and took his two mobile phones, worth a total of Rs 17,000, and Rs 300 cash, and fled. Mehta, fell unconscious, was later taken to Sola Civil Hospital by a 108 ambulance summoned by an unknown person. He was later shifted to a private hospital in Thaltej.

After he regained consciousness, he gave a statement to the police and filed a complaint for assault and robbery against four unknown men.

Hardik Makwana, the investigating officer and a sub-inspector with Vastrapur police, said that none of the accused have been arrested as yet.

Title: Pune: Powered by electricity, Metro rake completes first trial without hiccups
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

A Metro rake powered by electricity completes a trial run on the 1.4km elevated stretch between Sant Tukaramna... Read More

PUNE: The first full-fledged trial run of a Metro rake powered by electricity was conducted on Friday without any hiccup to and fro on the elevated corridor between Sant Tukaramnagar and Phugewadi stations.

The rake drew power from the overhead electric cables recently installed on the viaduct. The rakes were so far being pulled by battery operated shunting engines on the stretch, which is part of the elevated section of Line 1 of the Pune Metro rail project — between Pimpri and Swargate.

Maharashtra Metro Rail Corporation Limited (MahaMetro) officials said Friday’s trial run was part of the initial testing. “Such trials will continue for the next two months and the running of the rakes will be checked on various other parameters,” an official said.

Two rakes have been introduced on the Metro viaduct along the PCMC-Dapodi stretch. Of the two, MahaMetro officials operated one rake on Friday for 2.4km. The second rake will be checked within the next few days. MahaMetro has completed laying of tracks on a 5km stretch and overhead cables for the supply of power on a 1.4km stretch. The supply was energized on Thursdayfor the rakes’ preliminary tests.

The MahaMetro officials said it was a milestone of sorts to run rakes on electricity within 30 months after the civil work for the project commenced.

MahaMetro has approached the Research Design and Standardisation Organisation, the Commissioner Metro Rail Safety and the Railway Board for obtaining various permissions for the trains’ operations. “The authorities are likely to visit the site and inspect the preparations before granting the permissions,” an official said.

Title: Surat: Labourer sentenced to death for rape, murder of his minor daughter
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

Title: Recession steals some zing out of Uttarayan
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

A massive fall is being experienced in kite and manja sales ahead of Uttarayan in the city markets

Surat: Recession has stolen some zing out of Uttarayan when people in Gujarat fill the skies with colourful kites and air with joyful noise. City’s kite and manja markets remain devoid of customers because of cash crunch, with business not even 60 per cent of the past five years, market sources said. But they are still hopeful of sales picking up on Saturday and Sunday before festival of Uttarayan on January 14.

Surat is famous for its kites and manja and businessmen in other parts of the country have been pre-ordering them. However, volume of outstation orders has come down this time.

Rekha Saddiwala, owner of Bhagwan Manja Centre in Bhagal, said, “We have less orders this year. A trader of Anand or Nadiad who previously used to buy 500 spindles of 1,000 yard manja has bought just 300 this year from us. Effects of recession can be felt this year. Till now, no substantial local sale has happened. We had good retail sales last year.” The rate of manja has gone up by just slightly. Last year the rate for 1,000 yard manja was Rs180 and now it is Rs200, she said.

Ravi Natali, another manja maker from Nanpura, said, “Recession is a factor for poor sales but more than that the younger generation is now keen to save birds during Uttarayan. They prefer to stay away from kite flying. People are taking oath in Jain and Swaminarayan temples not to fly kites to save birds. We have 30 per cent less business this year when compared to in the past.”

Kite seller Kamesh Champaneria said, “People who used to buy kites worth Rs1,000 from me just purchased for Rs500 this time. We pray that our available stock of kites is sold out. Rates of kite have gone up by around 12 per cent only.”

Title: Housewife loses Rs 1.75 lakh to online fraudster
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Surat: An unidentified fraudster withdrew Rs 1.75 lakh from the online account of a housewife in Rander locality on Thursday.

The accused called up Toral Mistry (47), a resident of Blue Bell Apartment of Canal Road in Jahangirpura, saying that her KYC identification was due. He made her download the app and transfer one rupee from her account. Within 20 minutes of her transferring one rupee, he withdrew Rs 1.75 lakh from her account in three transactions.

Mistry said she had received the call from an unknown number. Mistry was told that her KYC identification was due, and as a result her account would be inoperative for a day. As the caller spoke to her in Hindi, Mistry believed him.

“The fraudster asked Mistry to down an app and transfer one rupee from her account for verification. As she transferred the amount on Thursday evening, within 20 minutes, three transactions of withdrawal of Rs 75,000, Rs 50,000 and another Rs 50,000 took place. A few hours later when she went online to check if all was right, she found that her money had been stolen in an online fraud,” said an official from Rander police station.

“The call came from some out state number such as Jharkhand. Despite knowing about the online frauds of this kind, people still commit the mistake of believing tele callers. We are trying to get details of the number,” added the official.

Rander police station registered the case under sections 406 and 420 of Indian Penal Code and section 66D of Information Technology Act.

Title: Man stabbed to death over financial dispute
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Rajkot: A man was stabbed to death by two borrowers when he went to recover the money he had lent to one of them.

Police said the accused, identified as Suresh Gorala and his brother-in-law Kishor Jungi, attacked Kanji Hodar (60) with knives in Lakadi Bandar bridge locality of Porbandar on Thursday night. Hodar had lent Rs 15 lakh to Gorala, which he had gone to recover.

“On the night of the crime, Hodar had gone shopping with his wife Ratan. After shopping, he told his wife that he was going to meet Gorala and asked her to go home alone. Late in the night, Hodar called up his wife to inform that he had been stabbed and was going to Porbandar Civil Hospital in a 108 ambulance,” said an official from Kirti Mandir police station.

At Porbandar Civil Hospital after Hodar’s condition deteriorated and he was taken to a private hospital where no doctor was present. At this, paramedical staff decided to take him to Rajkot Civil Hospital, but on the way, Hodar succumbed to his injuries. The police have booked Gorala and Jungi based on a complaint lodged by the deceased’s wife and have also launched a manhunt for the duo.

Hodar’s two sons — Himanshu and Nilesh — are working with a private firm in Israel.

Title: Cholamandalam Finance raises Rs 400cr via 10-yr masala bonds
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Chennai: Cholamandalam Investment and Finance Company Limited has announced to have raised Rs 400 crore from UK-based development finance institution CDC Group Plc through issuing unsecured, subordinated, rupee denominated masala bonds.

Arun Alagappan, MD, CIFCLsaid, “CDC and CIFCL have joined hands to address the business credit requirements of small and medium road transport operators and MSME customers, thereby enabling them ‘enter a better life’. CDC’s investment in CIFCL’s Masala Bonds will support the extension of loans to driver-turned-owners and micro and small enterprises in underserved rural and semi-urban areas of India.” This is the company’s maiden masala bond issue which may be listed on London Stock Exchange or any other international stock exchanges in future. CIFCL which offers vehicle finance, business and home loans caters to small and medium road transport operators for new and used commercial vehicles with over 50% of the portfolio in low income states, the company said. Srini Nagarajan, CDC’s MD and head of Asia, said “Our investment will enable CIFCL to extend loans to small vehicle owners and facilitate availability of credit to rural and semi-urban markets and support the Company with subordinated-debt in this tight liquidity environment.” TNN

Title: Going for shareholder-led IPO: CAMS CEO Kumar
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Chennai: Computer Age Management Services (CAMS), Chennai-based technology driven financial infrastructure and services provider, on Thursday, filed its Draft Red Herring Prospectus (DRHP) with Sebi for its Initial Public Offering (IPO).

Anuj Kumar, CEO of CAMS said, “After 5-10 years, the natural expectations for shareholders is to get value out of their investments. So, our shareholders needed some form of exit and monetisation. This is a complete offer for sale, where the company is not raising money but is a shareholder-led IPO. They are likely no fully exit, some are selling small parts.” The IPO will be an Offer for Sale (OFS), in which 1,21,64,400 equity shares of face value Rs 10 each will be offloaded by the Great Terrain Investment Ltd (an affiliate of Warburg Pincus), NSE Investments Ltd, Acsys Investments Ltd, HDFC Ltd and HDB Employees Welfare Trust. The issue includes an eligible employee reservation of up to 1.5% of the post offer paid up equity share capital. The net offer will have a 50% allocation to qualified institutional buyers, 15% to non-institutional investors and 35% to retail individual buyers. The company’s book running lead managers (BRLMs) who are open to the offer are Kotak Mahindra Capital Company Limited, HDFC Bank Limited, ICICI Securities Limited and Nomura Financial Advisory and Securities (India) Private Limited. Speaking on expected deadline for the IPO, Kumar said “We are expecting for IPO to happen in about four months by April-May.” The company said market sources estimate the IPO size to be anywhere between Rs 1,500-1600 crore.

Title: SC stays HC order on DRI letter
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Swati.Deshpande@timesgroup.com

Mumbai: The Supreme Court this week stayed an October 2019 Bombay HC order that had quashed the letters rogatory ( LRs ) sent by the Directorate of Revenue Intelligence ( DRI ) to several countries in connection with a probe into the alleged Rs 29,000-crore overvaluation of Indonesian coal imports by the Adani Group .

A bench headed by Chief Justice S A Bobde issued notices to Adani Enterprises on the appeal filed by DRI against the order of Bombay HC bench of Justices Ranjit More and Bharati Dangre. The SC will hear the matter later this month again.

The Bombay HC order had brought to a halt an overseas investigation by the DRI. It had all the LRs sent by DRI to 14 countries, including Singapore and UAE, seeking information into the alleged overvaluation. An LR is a formal request to another country, seeking judicial assistance in accessing information on an offshore entity in a probe.

DRI is probing at least 40 companies, including the Essar Group, for overvaluation of imports. TOI was the first to report on the scam in its December 14, 2014, edition.

Making it clear that it hasn’t gone into the merits of the LRs, the high court had said: “We have only dealt with the contention as to whether it was permissible for the magistrate to issue such a Letter Rogatory without following the procedure mandated under the Criminal Procedure Code.”

Title: Traffic Safety Week starts from today
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Nashik: The city traffic branch is gearing for their annual ‘Traffic Safety Week ’ which is all set to start from Saturday with series of programmes lined up till January 17.

ACP Mangalsingh Suryawanshi said, a series of programmes like a strict drive against helmetless motorists, health check of the truck drivers, visits of school students at the Children's Traffic Education Park, putting banners of traffic awareness, organising blood donation camps, street plays on traffic awareness, action against illegal transportation of passengers, awareness about carrying driving license, drive to put-up reflectors on buses and auto-rickshaws, etc.

The police said that apart from spreading awareness among motorists they have also started taking strict action against erring motorists from last year due to which the rate of deaths from road accidents dropped considerably compared to the road deaths in 2018.

Police officials said that they aim to see that there are no deaths from road accidents in any part of the city as one death of a person has a bad effect on all his/her family members. The emphasis of the drive would be to encourage motorists to wear helmets as a maximum number of deaths in road accidents are due to head injuries suffered by bikers in the absence of a helmet.

Title: Kolkata: In season of protests, Muslim women make equal statement
Content:
Women offer Namaz on Zakaria Street on Friday

KOLKATA: The protests against CAA and NRC on Friday brought to the fore unusual and heart-warming images of several hundred Muslim women offering namaz in the open alongside the men before leading the march in an assertion of their identity as citizens, as well as individuals.More than three hundred women sat in straight rows outside Tipu Sultan mosque in Esplanade to offer their Friday prayers. The elders in the community could not recall any previous instant after Independence where Muslim women not only offered prayers in the open but alongside the men. Women’s rights groups within the community said it showed how ordinary homemakers were leading the protests against the draconian CAA and NRC and also making a statement against patriarchy.Islam gives Muslim women the right to offer namaz in the open or in a mosque, provided proper guidelines about separate space for ritual washing or wazoo enclosures are followed. “There is no restriction on women from offering namaz in open spaces or in the mosques. Instead, the religious scriptures say they should go to the mosque and offer their prayers if there is a separate passage for them and a separate place for ritual washing. When women are travelling, they have to pray in the open. Islam prohibits anybody from blocking another person’s way for prayers,” said Noor Jahan Shakeel, president of All Bengal Muslim Women’s Association.Qari Fazlur Rahman, who leads Eid prayers on Red Road every year, said it was heartening to see women fighting for their rights. “All of us must protest and fight for our rights within the framework of the Constitution,” he said.Offering namaz is mandatory for every Muslim. Friday prayers, which are normally shorter than the midday, or Zohar, prayers on other days, are considered special. On Friday, the protesters — among whom almost half were women — started assembling at Esplanade with the Indian flag in their hands from 11am. The women then approached the organizers and asked for a place to offer their prayers between 12.30pm and 1.30pm.“These women have come from far-off places and would have had to leave early without offering their Friday prayers. We made the provision here instead. Separate arrangements were made for the ritual washing or the wazoo,” said Uzma Alam, a social worker.Before they offer prayers, it is man-datory for Muslims to wash their hands, feet, face, clean their ears and nose and gargle. In Kolkata, only a couple of mosques have this provision for women, as a result of which most of them offer their prayers at home.“Women are reclaiming their own identity. They feel that being Muslim and women, they are more vulnerable. NRC in Assam has shown women are the worst sufferers,” said Hasnain Imam, a political scientist.

Title: Gujarat: Woman kills 25-year-old son for frequent drunken fracas
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: Tired of his frequent drunken fracas and addiction to alcohol, a woman allegedly bludgeoned her 25-year-old son to death in Rapar of Kutch district . The woman, who concealed the crime and presented it as a case of accident, was arrested on Thursday.

According to police, the accused, Navi Koli (55), was fed up of her son Dalpat Koli’s alcoholism and the frequent quarrels he picked up with family members and others after getting drunk.

On January 6, when Dalpat came home drunk and created a ruckus, Navi hit him with a bat on his head. As Dalpat began to bleed profusely, Navi took him to a private hospital in Rapar, where Dalpat succumbed to his injuries. Navi told the doctors that Dalpat had fallen off the staircase.

Next day when the preparations for Dalpat’s last rites were under way, his uncle Mangu Koli got suspicious after seeing the injury marks on Dalpat’s body.

“Mangu was convinced that the injuries inflicted on Dalpat had not been caused by the fall from the staircase. Hence, he called the cops. We took Dalpat’s body to GG Hospital in Jamnagar and conducted the forensic postmortem, which revealed that he had been bludgeoned to death. Following this, we interrogated Navi who confessed to her crime,” said R M Vasava , inspector with Rapar police station.

Navis was arrested on the complaint of Mangu.

Title: Bihar: Parallel rail bridge at Kiul likely to be ready in March
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Work on the Kiul-Lakhisarai railway yard remodelling is going on in full swing. Railways intends to complete this project by March 31 with an aim to further streamline huge traffic operation on this route under Danapur division of the East Central Railway (ECR).

According to ECR’s chief public relations officer (CPRO) Rajesh Kumar, railways is also building a new bridge parallel to the 100 years’ old rail bridge at Kiul. “The new Kiul rail bridge has the double track facility for ensuring smooth traffic on UP and Down lines. This work will also be completed by March 31 this year,” he said.

Besides, railways is installing a route relay interlocking (RRI) system at Kiul to replace the old manual lever pulling signalling system. “The RRI is the most advanced signalling system capable of averting any kind of mishap on tracks due to faulty signalling system,” he said, adding railways has already installed RRI system at Jhajha, Patna Junction and Danapur.

Kiul and Lakhisarai are two major stations, which connect Howrah and Delhi ends on the mainline route. While the east end of Kiul-Lakhisarai is linked to Jhajha and Bhagalpur sides, the west end connects Gaya, Patna and Barauni.

“Yard remodelling and advanced RRI system are likely to help railways in clearing traffic bottleneck at this junction point where a large number of passenger trains from both Howrah and Delhi ends pass through,” he said.

On completion of the project, the number of platforms at Kiul will increase from five to eight, giving more passage space for passenger and goods trains. “The remodelling of yard will also increase its capacity, including more space, for stabilizing rakes of passenger trains in the yard,” CPRO said.

Meanwhile, railways has decided to run Darbhanga-New Delhi Bihar Sampark Kranti Express (12565/12566) with Linke Hofmann Busch (LHB) coaches from January 17. This train will run with a load combination of 22 coaches.

Title: Bihar: ‘Threefold increase in crime against elderly people in 2018’
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The NCRB data for 2018 paints a grim scenario for another section of the state’s vulnerable population — senior citizens. Crimes against the elderly population in the state grew by nearly three times compared to the previous year.

In 2018, a total of 424 cases of crimes against senior citizens were reported in Bihar as compared to 141 incidents in 2017. However, state capital Patna reported no such crime in the same year. In 2016, the total number of such incidents was 272.
