But the rate of crime, which is calculated as the incident per one lakh population, against senior citizens in Bihar was 5.5, less than the crime rates in states such as Madhya Pradesh, Chandigarh and Gujarat, where it was 53.5, 42.1 and 44.4 respectively.

However states such as Assam , Jammu & Kashmir (which was a state in 2018), Jharkhand and Uttarakhand had set example with less than one crime per one lakh population. Meghalaya had zero rate of crime in this category.

In Bihar, 20 elderly people were murdered in 2018, while 42 faced attempt to murder. Two crimes under the category of attempt to commit culpable homicide were also carried out against senior citizens. In the category of simple hurt, a total of 189 incidents were reported, while in the category of grievous hurt, 165 cases were reported.

Interestingly, not a single crime against senior citizens was reported from Patna in 2018. As per NCRB, there were seven such crimes in 2017, which reduced to zero in 2018. A former police official said various steps have been taken to curb crimes against senior citizens. However, he expressed surprise over Patna registering zero cases in 2018.

But a survey conducted by HelpAge India in 2018 on elderly abuse had found that Patna stood at 7th position out of 23 cities in terms of elderly abuse. “Many senior people even after suffering verbal abuse or physical abuse do not go to the police station as they do not want to file complaint against their own family. Also, they have no option, but to suffer such abuses and live with them,” said a retired government employee.

Retired bureaucrat Gopal Shankar Prasad, 75, said most of the heinous crimes like murder of elderly citizens are because of property. “There are cases when the servant carries out theft and when identified, kills the owner. Apart from such issues, why will anyone hurt an old person?” he added.

Title: Don’t force patients to buy drugs from outside, PMCH doctors told
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The Patna Medical College and Hospital (PMCH) administration on Friday asked all its doctors to desist from forcing patients to buy medicines from outside. The doctors were also asked not to suggest patients to undergo pathological and radiological tests in private labs. The hospital administration has also asked the doctors to reach their respective departments on time wearing aprons.

The directions came after PMCH principal Dr V P Choudhary made a surprise inspection of outpatient departments (OPDs) of paediatrics, dentistry, gynaecology , orthopaedics, surgery, psychiatry, eye, neurosurgery, plastic surgery and radiology with a team of senior doctors.

Although most doctors were found available on duty, some patients complained to the principal that the medicines prescribed in some departments, including cancer department, were expensive and unaffordable for poor patients who come to PMCH not only from across the state but also neighbouring states and Nepal with great hopes.

Complaints were also made by some patients to the principal regarding pathological and radiological investigations required for ascertaining the disease.

Choudhary said altogether 256 medicines were available free of cost in the hospital and these medicines cover most of the diseases of all branches.

Likewise, about 70 pathological tests and all radiological investigations like ultrasound, CT scan, X-ray, MRI and ECG are available free of cost at the hospital, he said.

As some medicines prescribed for treatment of cancer are usually costly, Choudhary asked the doctors of radiotherapy to take them from the hospital and in no case suggest the patients to bring them from outside.

“PMCH is the only government hospital of Bihar where cobalt therapy for treatment of cancer is available free of cost,” the principal said.

Choudhary asked the heads of departments to regularly arrange ward teaching for students of MBBS and MS and MD as it would help them learn diagnosis and treatment in the company of senior doctors on duty.

Title: CM Nitish Kumar inaugurates slew of projects in Munger, Jamui
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

CM Nitish Kumar with other officials at Bhim Bandh in Munger on Friday

PATNA: Chief minister (CM) Nitish Kumar on Friday asked officials of Munger district administration to take necessary steps for beautification of Kharagpur lake. He said a team of experts should be sent to Kharagpur to prepare a work plan so that the lake could be developed as a new destination for eco-tourists.

Presiding over a division-level review meeting as part of the government’s ‘Jal Jivan Hariyali’ campaign at Munger museum hall, the CM asked the officials to use the lake water to provide drinking water to people in nearby areas.

“The renovation and beautification of Kharagpur lake will not only improve environment in surrounding areas, but also benefit the next generation. The lake renovation work should be done under the Jal Jivan Hariyali scheme,” he said.

Senior officials of all six districts of Munger division – Munger, Begusarai , Khagaria, Lakhisarai, Sheikhpura and Jamui – attended the meeting which was organised on the last day of the CM’s seventh phase of Jal Jivan Hariyali Yatra.

Nitish further asked the officials of all six districts to expedite the ongoing work under the ‘Har Ghar Nal Ka Jal (tap water to each household)’ scheme of the state government in each village under their respective jurisdictions.

He asked the district magistrates (DMs) to visit public grievance redressal centres on a regular basis and ensure that petitions filed under the Bihar Public Grievances Redressal Act are properly disposed of.

The CM asked the DMs to take necessary action against all those grievance redressal officers who remain absent from their workplaces or do not take interest in redressal of public grievances. The CM also stressed the need for speedy disposal of applications under the Mukhya Mantri Old Age Pension scheme.

Prominent among those who attended the review meeting were deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi, rural development minister Shravan Kumar, rural works minister Shailesh Kumar, labour resources minister Vijay Kumar Sinha, water resources minister Sanjay Kumar Jha, information and public relations minister Neeraj Kumar, Munger MP Rajiv Ranjan Singh alias Lalan Singh, chief secretary Deepak Kumar, DGP Gupteshwar Pandey and divisional commissioner (Munger) Vandana Kinni.

The CM, accompanied by ministers and several officials, also visited Bhimbandh Eco-tourism Centre at Bhimbandh village under Kharagpur block in Munger district and inaugurated several public utilities there. He asked the officials to improve facility of public transport at Bhimbandh for the convenience of tourists.

Earlier in the day, the CM visited Ratanpur gram panchayat under Gidhaur block of Jamui district and inaugurated several development projects.

Title: Lens on motor covers may aid buyers
Content:
File photo

MUMBAI: The dynamics of motor insurance in India is set to change with the insurance regulator taking a tough stance on auto companies controlling insurance distribution through broking firms.In December 2019 and January 2020, the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India ( IRDAI ) penalised a host of insurance broking firms, including Maruti Insurance Brokers , Hero Insurance Broking and Toyota Tsusho Insurance Broking — all linked to auto manufacturers. The fines ranged from Rs 1 crore to Rs 3 crore. The regulator also fined brokers like SMC and Aditya Birla Insurance Brokers for their dealing with auto companies.Insurance company officials say that fining brokers for dealing with select companies could now open up the business for two dozen companies. Customers could benefit if upstart companies start quoting low rates to get a toehold in the motor business.In all the cases, the charge was that customers who bought new cars were being denied choice and were indirectly forced to buy from a handful of insurance companies that were empanelled with the broking firms. Another point raised by the regulator was that all the companies in the panel were offering the same rates, indicating that there was some kind of price-fixing. Third, the regulator has identified cases where insurance companies have paid more than the permissible premium by reimbursing costsIt is an open secret in the insurance industry that auto dealers control motor insurance distribution. While the customer is given a choice of companies, they are the ones which are on the panel and often the pricing is similar. The customer is free to buy the insurance from any company, but the dealer — by quoting a blended price — leads the customer to believe that he is willing to bear the insurance cost.The court order making it mandatory for car buyers to take out a three-year cover and two-wheelers a five-year cover has put more power in the hands of the dealer.Although the insurance distribution firms are owned by auto companies (described as OEMs, or original equipment manufacturers by the regulator), most of the earnings are passed on to dealers.Given that the motor insurance market in India stood at over Rs 64,000 crore, the commission runs into several thousand crore (see graphic). They are a major source of revenue for the auto dealers who have to deal with thinning margins on auto sales. Besides the earning from selling insurance, dealers benefit as insured cars come back to them for cashless claims servicing and provide their workshops with assured business.

Title: Yes Bank prunes capital raise, director quits
Content:
(File photo)

MUMBAI: Share prices of Yes Bank closed more than 5% lower at Rs 44.8 on a day when a board member put in his papers alleging governance issues. The bank’s board also scaled down a capital-raising plan to Rs 10,000 crore from Rs 14,000 ($2 billion) earlier and decided not to proceed with a $1.2-billion investment offer by Erwin Singh Braich.In his resignation letter, Yes Bank board member Uttam Prakash Agarwal cited concerns about “deteriorating standards of corporate governance and failure of compliance”. Agarwal said he had issues with the way the bank was going about its equity raising. One of the complaints was the non-disclosure of binding offers from prospective investors.It may be recalled that Yes Bank had last month kept the market guessing on its equity raising plans by announcing that it has received a firm bid for a $1.2-billion investment from North American investors. However, it later disappointed the markets when it disclosed that the investors were little-known persons of Indian origin.While rejecting the offer from Braich, the bank said that the board was in favour of a $500-million offer from Citax Holdings and Citax Investment Group. “However, the relevant conditions precedent could not be completed as on date. Hence, Citax offer will be taken up during the next round,” the bank said.Countering the allegations by Agarwal, the bank said that it was reviewing the ‘fit and proper’ status of Agarwal as directed by the RBI. In this respect, the bank had obtained legal opinions from eminent jurists. “These opinions were to be considered by the Nomination and Remuneration Committee of the board/the board of the bank in their meetings scheduled for January 10, 2020. However, prior to the commencement of the proceedings of these meetings, the bank received the resignation of Agarwal.”Agarwal, however, denied that there were any fit and proper issues as he was part of the board for a year.

Title: Zomato gets $150 million from China’s Ant Financial
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

(Representative image)

BENGALURU: Online food delivery and restaurant discovery platform Zomato has raised $150 million from its existing backer Ant Financial at a pre-money valuation of $3 billion, according to a stock exchange filing made by its shareholder Info-Edge . The investment is part of a larger round of $500-600 million being raised by Zomato as it continues to battle Swiggy for market leadership in the food delivery space.

Info-Edge, which also owns classifieds portals like Naukri and 99acres , said its stake in Zomato will come down to 25.13% after the deal. TOI had reported in its edition dated March 5, 2019 that Zomato has a set a valuation of $3 billion for its next round of funding. The company has been working with investment banks Goldman Sachs and CLSA for the capital raise.

The development comes as Zomato is in discussions to acquire the India food delivery business of ride-hailing major Uber through a share-swap deal, as TOI reported on November 25. The deal hinges on a potential investment by Uber in Zomato as well.

Title: HC relief to Adanis in stock-rigging case
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Adani Group chairman Gautam Adani (File photo)

MUMBAI: In a relief to the Adani Group , the Bombay high court stayed an order of the sessions court, which had last November restored a criminal case against Adani Enterprises ( AEL ), its chairman Gautam Adani and managing director Rajesh Adani for alleged violations of market regulations. Justice A M Badar had on December 20, 2019, stayed the order of the sessions court after the group company, its chairman and managing directors approached the HC in appeal.

The sessions court by its verdict on November 27, 2019, had set aside a 2014 order of a Mumbai magistrate.

The magistrate had discharged (dropped the case against) the Adanis. The accusation was that they had allegedly manipulated share prices of AEL through firms run by stock broker Ketan Parekh. The allegations were also that AEL allegedly “provided funds and shares to Ketan Parekh entities, particularly for the years 1999-2000 and 2000-2001 for running illegal activities in the capital market with dishonest intentions”.

The government had challenged the magistrate’s order in the sessions court. The sessions court had held that the SFIO prima facie made a case of “unlawful gain” by the Adani Group promoters and Parekh of about Rs 388 crore and Rs 151 crore, respectively. The AEL formerly known as Adani Exports, based out of Ahmedabad, is the flagship of Adani Group. The case against them was of cheating and criminal conspiracy too.

In their challenge filed through advocate Ishwar Nankani, and argued by counsel Amit Desai, AEL and the two Adanis contended that the sessions court order be quashed as being “arbitrary and illegal”. It is violation of principles of natural justice and right to equality and right to life, added the appeal.

“Except for bald and general allegation of criminal conspiracy, there is no offence of cheating disclosed against the petitioner (AEL and the two Adanis), and the allegations are groundless.” They did not buy or sell its own shares as is expected under the Companies Act and admitted in the complaint. “Hence, there is no question of them cheating anyone, much less being a party to the conspiracy to cheat,”said the AEL petition.

The company said that the magistrate had rightly appreciated, while allowing its discharge plea, that a “being a juristic entity the company cannot be part of any alleged criminal conspiracy”. The session court has “arbitrarily disregarded” the magistrate’s finding that no case of cheating was made out, the AEL petition in HC said.

The government counsel H S Venegaonkar sought time to file a reply in the HC and the court had adjourned the matter to January 13, 2020.

Title: Speeding auto overturns, woman fractures hand
Content:
Hadapsar police arrested the driver, Bushan Suryakant Padwal (23) from Chandannagar, under the relevant sectio... Read More

PUNE: A 58-year-old woman travelling in an autorickshaw suffered a fracture in hand after its driver suddenly applied the brakes and the vehicle overturned near IBM in Phursungi around 5.30am on Friday.The Hadapsar police arrested the driver, Bushan Suryakant Padwal (23) from Chandannagar, under the relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code and Motor Vehicles Act. He was later released on bail.Sunanda Bapu Gaikwad, a resident of Church Road, suffered a fracture on her right hand in the accident . She is in a stable condition and recovering in a private hospital in Hadapsar.Gaikwad’s son, Abhijit, said, “My mother had boarded the autorickshaw from Bhosale village in Phursungi for going to the school near the Pune railway station, where she works as a peon. The driver was speeding on the deserted road. He lost control over the vehicle and suddenly applied the brakes. The vehicle overturned and the driver jumped out of the moving vehicle.”He said, “Passersby and the driver later lifted the autorickshaw, rescued my mother and rushed her to a private hospital. The driver claimed on spot that another vehicle had hit his autorickshaw from the rear. We feel that the accident may have happened when the driver applied brakes on coming across a pothole.”Padwal said, “I was driving on the left side of the road. I swerved to the right after a four-wheeler came in front of my vehicle. I lost control and the vehicle overturned. I have suffered an internal injury on my right hand.”Investigation officer Anil Sarde from the Hadapsar police said, “Sunanda Gaikwad, in her statement, said no vehicle had come in front of the autorickshaw. We have seized the vehicle for conducting an inspection at the regional transport office, Pune. A chargesheet will be filed soon against Padwal.”

Title: Hyderabad: Christian heads back TRS
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

K Chandrashekar Rao

HYDERABAD: The Christian Burial Ground Committee for Greater Hyderabad comprising bishops, pastors, evangelists and elders met here on Friday and appealed to the Christian community to vote for TRS candidates in municipalities and municipal corporations going to polls on January 22. Committee secretary Goneh Solomon Raj said they prayed for the good health and success of chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao and his son and municipal minister KT Rama Rao. They thanked the KCR-government for allotting 68 acres of various sizes land parcels for the purpose of Christian burial grounds in and around the city.

Title: Patna: Lohia Path Chakra deadline extended by 1 year
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

The project was initially targeted to be completed by December 17, 2018

PATNA: The deadline for ambitious Lohia Path Chakra project in the city has been extended from June 2020 to mid-2021. The project was initially targeted to be completed by December 17, 2018.

Based on swap and grade-separated U-turns and multi-sectional interchange technology at six traffic points – Bihar Public Service Commission (BPSC) office, Lalit Bhavan, Daroga Rai Path, Punaichak, Patna high court and Vidyut Bhavan – the Lohia Path Chakra project is proposed to do away with traffic signals and check posts on the stretch of Bailey Road between Lalit Bhavan and Hartali Mor.

State road construction minister Nand Kishor Yadav attributed the extension in deadline of the project to the change in its design. “The design of Lohia Path Chakra project was changed twice owing to upcoming Patna Metro Rail and R Block-Digha four-lane road projects. The project is now targeted to be completed in 2021,” the minister said, adding the project also encompasses landscaping and integrated drainage system and software-controlled solar light.

The first phase of the project, comprising stretch of Bailey Road between BPSC office and Lalit Bhavan and Daroga Rai Path, which was initially targeted to be completed by March this year, is now expected to be completed by June this year.

“As part of the first phase of the 3.5km-long road, one flank was opened for vehicular movement on Thursday,” said Yadav.

A BRPNNL official said one flank of Lohia Path Chakra project was opened for vehicular movement to allow construction of underpass on another flank on the same stretch.

“The stretch between BPSC office and Lalit Bhavan witnesses heavy vehicular traffic and congestion throughout the day. Commencement of vehicular movement on one flank will ease traffic movement,” he said.

The official added, “As of now, vehicles coming from Hartlai Mor are being allowed to use the elevated stretch in front of Lalit Bhavan. The underpass parallel to the elevated structure, which is under construction, will be used for vehicles coming from Patna zoo end.”

Meanwhile, work order for preparation of designs for constructing the structures in remaining locations – Punaichak, high court and Hartali Mor – has been allotted to a private firm. A BRPNNL official said the construction work on the remaining locations would take at least one-and-a-half-years more to complete.

File photo

MUMBAI: The dynamics of motor insurance in India is set to change with the insurance regulator taking a tough stance on auto companies controlling insurance distribution through broking firms.In December 2019 and January 2020, the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India ( IRDAI ) penalised a host of insurance broking firms, including Maruti Insurance Brokers Hero Insurance Broking and Toyota Tsusho Insurance Broking — all linked to auto manufacturers. Title: PayU acquires majority stake in PaySense
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

(Representative image)

BENGALURU: South Africa’s Naspers ’ fintech unit — PayU — has acquired a majority stake in online credit platform PaySense in an all-cash deal at a valuation of $185 million (Rs 1,312 crore). As part of this deal, PayU will merge its in-house digital consumer credit platform LazyPay with PaySense, the company said. PayU will own about 80% stake in the merged entity, which is being valued at upwards of $300 million (Rs 2,127 crore).

Additionally, PayU has committed an investment of another $200 million (Rs 1,419 crore) into the merged entity, of which $65 million (Rs 461 crore) is being invested immediately. The rest of the capital would come in the next two years based on the company’s performance.

PaySense co-founder Prashanth Ranganathan will head the credit business and continue to hold a stake in the merged entity. PaySense’s financial investors like Jungle Ventures and Nexus Partners will exit the entity after the transaction, which will result in a broader play in the digital lending space by PayU.

While LazyPay has about a million monthly active users on its platform, PaySense has disbursed loans worth Rs 1,000 crore in the last 2.5 years. LazyPay largely offered buy-now-pay-later financing options across online platforms, PaySense offers consumer loans, vehicle loans.

Siddhartha Jajodia, global head of credit, PayU, said this merger will enable PayU to offer full-stack credit solutions. “What this does is it really sets the stage for a combined entity that has all the basic components, all the capabilities, the digital lending stack, the data analytics platform, the ability to acquire customers and now the funding and liquidity power,” he said.

This is aligned with PayU’s broader strategy for financial services in India. Recently, the company invested in online wealth management platform Fisdom while it also acquired Wibmo last year.

Ranganathan said PaySense lends about Rs 100 crore a month now and has a non-performing asset ratio of just under 4%. “We have been very prudent about who we lend to and how much we lend to them. While it’s important to grow our loan book, we have been careful about how responsibly we lend to consumers. Our recovery has gotten better over time. We are almost operating at bank industry level now,” he added.

Title: Students disrupt VKSU senate meet
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

ARA: Students belonging to various unions tried to disrupt the senate meeting of the Veer Kunwar Singh University, Ara, on Friday morning. They were protesting against the fee hike for postgraduate courses.

Agitating students assembled before the main gate of the VKSU’s new building and tried to block the entrance near the Zero Mile, following which police resorted to lathicharge, which apparently led to a clash between the police and the students. Around half-a-dozen students and a sub-inspector were injured in the commotion.

All India Students' Association (AISA) later released a statement alleging that earlier the students pursued PG courses by spending barely a sum of Rs 2,000 to 5,000 but now they will have to cough up around Rs12,000 to 15,000 for the same and many poor students will be forced to drop out.

Meanwhile, the VKSU senate passed a budget of Rs 637.28 lakh for the fiscal 2020- 21 in its meeting held amid the ruckus on Friday.

Meanwhile, cutting across party lines, all the students’ unions have strongly condemned the police lathicharge on students on Friday. VKSU students’ union president Amit Kumar, who is also a state executive member of ABVP said, “Our democratic right to protest is being suppressed forcibly by the university administration. Now, we will not let the VC to enter the varsity unless he pays heed to our demands. Two ABVP members have fractured their arms and legs and 10 others were injured in the lathicharge."

The students’ wing of JD (U) also said that Sonu Pandey, Buxar district president of the Chhatra JD (U) and Amit Kushwaha, vice- president of the students’ wing have fractured their hands.

Inkalab Naujawan Sabha district convenor Shiv Prakash Ranjan announced ‘Virodh Divas’ to be held on Saturday against the VKSU administration.

Meanwhile, Bhojpur SP in-charge Sudhir Kumar Porika said police had to resort to lathicharge, when the students started pushing the police.

Title: Mangal and Rama lose Y-plus security cover
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

PATNA: The Union ministry of home affairs has removed state health minister Mangal Pandey and MP Rama Devi from the list of central government protectees.

Following the order, the highly trained CRPF commandos meant for providing VIP security to the duo under Y-plus category security cover were attached to their parent battalion on Thursday, MHA sources said.

Both Pandey and Rama are from BJP. Rama represents Sheohar Lok Sabha seat while Pandey is an MLC.

A senior police officer privy to the development, preferring anonymity, said after the removal of their names from the list, the state now has only five political figures as central government protectees.

“They are Union ministers Ram Vilas Paswan and Ravi Shankar Prasad, MPs Sushil Kumar Singh and Janardan Singh Sigriwal and BJP national spokesperson Shahnawaz Hussain,” he said.

Both Singh and Sigriwal are from BJP and represent Aurangabad and Maharajganj Lok Sabha seat respectively.

Sources said Paswan is accorded Z-category security cover of central forces while the other four have Y-plus security cover.

“Home minister Amit Shah and Union road transport and highways minister Nitin Gadkari are accorded with floating Z-plus category security. They would be provided the cover on arrival in Bihar,” he said.

One and a half years back, Bihar had at least altogether 17 politicians among the central government protectees getting various categories of security cover.

On July 22 last year, the MHA had removed the names of incarcerated former CM Lalu Prasad Yadav, BJP MP Rajeev Pratap Rudy, party leader Jitendra Swamy, LJP MP Veena Devi, former JD(U) MP Sabir Ali and former BJP MP Uday Singh, now in Congress, from the list of central protectees.

Title: Customs dept sleuths blow lid off dump in India racket
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

cap

Rajkot: India, which is already battling mounds of garbage , is becoming a dumping ground for solid municipal waste generated by developed countries.

The customs department has blown the lid off a sinister racket of garbage generated in US and Europe being imported under the garb of paper waste in India. The special intelligence and investigation branch of the department has seized 300 containers, which contained nearly 3,000 tonnes filth, at Mundra port.

In the last 10 days, the sleuths checked nearly 1,000 containers of which 300 were seized. The importers of these containers had declared paper waste in their bill of entry.

“This garbage was sent from developed countries like the US and those in Europe. The import of solid municipal waste is banned, but this was being imported in the guise of waste paper,” sources in the customs department told TOI.

Officials said most importers are from Rajkot and Morbi districts and they were getting handsome incentives for accepting the waste. Officials said the waste contained huge quantity of plastic and other household trash like diapers. If dumped in India, it poses a great threat of an epidemic and possibility of radioactive substance being sent is also not ruled out.

These containers were rejected by Indonesia customs last year and they were re-routed to India, which generates nearly 1.5 lakh metric tonnes of solid waste daily. Of this, just about 20% is processed.

Primary investigation revealed that there is a syndicate in developed countries, which are giving hefty incentives to the importers from developing countries just to dump their waste. There are over 20 importers from Rajkot and Morbi and some from Punjab and Delhi.

The customs department has also informed the Gujarat Pollution Control Board (GPCB), which is the licensing authority for waste paper import. The union ministry of environment and forest has also issued office memorandums (OM) defining the kind of waste paper can be imported in India, under this OM this municipal waste is illegal.” said a top official of customs.

“We will also issue showcause notices to the importers seeking explanation for misdeclaration and importing prohibited goods. The process of re-exporting these containers to the countries of origin will also be initiated,” a senior official said.

Title: 39 learn entrepreneurship skill at 5-day training programme
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

PATNA: A five-day training session for mentors, who would further train youths under Pradhan Mantri Yuva Udyamita Vikas Abhiyan (PM-YUVA) programme and help them inculcate entrepreneurship skill, concluded here on Friday.

The participants included 39 trainers from 27 partner institutes, including government as well as private industrial training institutes, polytechnics and training centres, which partnered with National Skill Development Corporation.

PM-YUVA nodal manager for Bihar-Jharkhand, Surya Kant, said the aim of the programme is to educate, motivate and support youth in development of entrepreneurship skills. “Mentors are trained enough to impart training to the youths in their own institutes and deliver entrepreneurship education to them,” he said.

Mentors who took part in the training programme were elated over the learning experience. Vikas Kumar, a lecturer in a government polytechnic college, said, “After attending the session, I am confident of giving business ideas to others, who were previously looking for a government job. Earlier, I thought government job was the best and only solution for employment, but this programme has changed my mindset.”

PM-YUVA is currently being piloted across 12 states in the country. The programme is being run in Bihar with the support of directorate of employment and training, labour resources department, state board of technical education and state science and technology department.

Title: Swachh Survekshan keeps civic officials on their toes
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Surat: Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) officials are working hard to regain the ranking for the city that it lost in Swachh Survekshan last year. Surat was pushed to 14th spot from 4th in national ranking last year and in the two quarters of this year, it is at 20th place. Swachh Survekshan of Government of India, being conducted since 2016, is the world’s largest urban sanitation and cleanliness survey and a five-member team would be in the city in next few days for spot inspection and citizen feedback. SMC officials are making people aware of the spots that the team is likely to visit around January 14.

The team members will visit 250 spots in the city and also interact with people. They will visit railway station, bus depots, vegetable markets, processing plants, public and community toilets, commercial and residential localities among other places in the city. They will also check how dustbins are being used, cleanliness of roads, footpaths and encroached upon sites etc.

“We have made large number of people aware about the impending spot visits by Swachh Survekshan team. The objective is to make people feel that they are participating in an important exercise,” said an officer of SMC.

Spot visits and citizen feedback carry huge weightage in Swachh Survekshan. “We have started night brushing and cleaning of city roads. We collect door-to-door garbage from 95 per cent households of Surat, which is now an open defecation free city,” the officer added.

Title: ABVP rally openly mocks traffic rules in Lucknow, ban on Section 144
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

ABVP members click selfies while driving vehicles without helmet or seat belt in a rally on Lohia Path on Frid... Read More

LUCKNOW: Scores of Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP) members took out a rally in the city, openly flouting the traffic rules and imposition of Section 144 of CrPC.

The participating bikers were without helmet while those in four-wheelers drove without the seat belt. The rally was taken out from 1090 Crossing till ABVP district headquarters in Kaiserbagh on Friday afternoon.

The rally was taken out when prohibitory orders are in place under Section 144 of CrPC which bans assembly of more than four persons at a public place. The rally was organised to welcome the newly appointed office-bearers of ABVP. The outfit’s members wore saffron turbans and followed the motorcade of senior leaders who were in SUVs. The rally also caused traffic congestion, leading to problems for commuters.

Asked whether ABVP had taken permission for the rally, ASP (east) Suresh Chandra Rawat said the organisers had informed them in advance but did not say whether the permission was sought. However, he added, that there was no traffic jam due to the rally as it moved smoothly without stopping anywhere from the starting point till destination. Asked why no action was taken against the ABVP members for flouting traffic norms, Rawat said “they were probing the matter”.

ABVP secretary Ghanshyam Shahi also denied that Section 144 was violated. “Our rally was peaceful and did not cause inconvenience to people,” he said.

Title: Bihar: 15% rise in crimes against women in 2018, says NCRB
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The number of crimes against women in 2018 went up by more than 15% as compared to the previous year, according to data published by the National Crime Record Bureau (NCRB). The state saw more than 2,200 cases in 2018 (16,920) as compared to 14,711 such cases in 2017. The number of cases reported in 2016 was 13,400.

The report highlights that in 98.2% rape cases in the state, the culprits were known to the victim.

However, the crime rate against women in Bihar, which is measured as number of incidents of such crime per one lakh population, is much lower compared to the national average across all states, which stands at 57.5. While the rate of such crimes in Bihar is 29.8, Assam has the highest in the country at 166, followed by Delhi with the crime rate of 149.6 per one lakh population.

The categories of crimes included in the NCRB report are rape, kidnapping, assault on women with intent to outraging her modesty, cruelty by husband and relatives and dowry death among others.

Bihar state women’s commission chairperson Dilmani Mishra attributed the rise in the number of crimes against women in the state to more women coming out to report. “Earlier women used to remain quiet, but now education and awareness regarding their rights have made them aware and they report to the police. Also women’s commission, police and the media have given them constant support to fight against atrocities and it is good that they are coming out of their homes,” Mishra said.

The NCRB report also pointed out that that in most rape cases in Bihar, culprits were known to the victim. A total of 651 cases of rape were reported in 2018 in Bihar and in 639 cases, rapists were known to the victim. Most of the known rapists were either friends, online friends or live-in partners or separated husbands accounting for 563 rape cases. Only in 12 cases, rapists were not known to the victim, while seven were family members and 219 were either family friends, neighbours, employers or other known persons. Of the total rape cases reported in 2018, there were eight cases of gang rape.

The data also revealed that 540 rape survivors were in the age group of 18 and 30 years, while 111 rape victims were in the age group of above 30 and below 45 years. There were 16 cases of rape of women between the ages of 45 and 60 years. No rape cases were registered among children below 12 years and there was just one case in the age group of 12 and 18 years.

Apart from rape, the state recorded 106 cases of assault on women and 113 cases of sexual harassment (Section 354 A of IPC). Though no cases of sexual harassment were reported from the work place, 22 such cases were reported from public transport and 91 from other places.

Other assault on women included cruelty by husband or relatives with 2,539 incidents reported, forced miscarriage 20, acid attack 6, disrobing 23, voyeurism 3 and stalking 17 in 2018.

Title: Kolkata: Cops, buses face mob fury after accident claims helmetless biker
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Firefighters douse the flames on Friday

KOLKATA: A mob took over Remount Road in south Kolkata, torching three buses, damaging two others and attacking cops with bricks, glass bottles and iron rods, after a helmetless biker was run over by a Behala-bound private bus near the exit ramp of Garden Reach Flyover on Friday. Five persons, including a woman, were arrested and charged with rioting and arson.

The incident was reported from the spot opposite Kolkata Port Trust Gate 13 around 12.30pm. Three men on a bike were trying to cross the road amidst incoming traffic when the handle of the motorcycle hit a bus on route 12C/1A. The rider, Anil Verma, 35, fell off and by the time the bus driver managed to apply the brakes, Verma’s skull had been crushed under the front wheel.

Verma, a local truck driver, died at the spot and local residents blocked the road, blaming cops for the accident and not allowing them to leave with the body.

“I lost my friend in front of my eyes. We have been demanding speed breakers and more policemen in this area for the past several months, but the cops don’t pay any heed and the place has become an accident-prone zone. We demand justice,” said Sanoj Yadav, another truck driver who was riding pillion with Verma.

When a large team of policemen arrived to lift the blockade, the mob turned violent and began attacking the cops. As the cops ran for cover, a section of the crowd began torching buses that were parked on the road. “It was a scary sight seeing passengers running for their lives. I, too, jumped off my bus and hid behind a shop from where I saw the crowd setting my bus ablaze,” said Maidul Islam, the driver of a route-235 bus.

With the situation spiralling out of control, cops cut off traffic movement on the road and called for backup, including Rapid Action Force personnel, who began a counter attack to drive the protesters away. Traffic movement resumed around 3pm after the burnt and damaged buses were towed away.

Since the collapse of the Majerhat bridge in 2018, almost all Behala-bound buses from north and central Kolkata are being diverted via Remount Road and Hyde Road, increasing the traffic load on the area. “Earlier, we could park our trucks easily and loiter on the road, but since buses were introduced on this route, the place has become accident-prone,” said Shiva Singh, another truck driver.

Title: Teen’s accident sparks mob fury in Bihar
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

The mob also ransacked the nearby government-owned sugar mill, besides vandalizing 12 SUVs and motorcycles par... Read More

MOTIHARI: An irate mob blocked NH-28A (Motihari-Raxaul road) near Bangara village under the Sugauli police station area and also vandalized several tractors, trucks and about half-a-dozen four wheelers on the road on Friday morning, after a 16-year-old boy Pulkit Kumar was crushed to death by a speeding oil tanker while he was on his way to the coaching class.

Sugauli police station SHO Rohit Kumar said the mob also attacked two SUVs of police and four constables were injured in stone-pelting. Later, Motihari SDO Priya Ranjan Raju and Motihari SDPO Vinit Kumar rushed to the spot with huge police enforcement. Police had to resort to lathicharge to chase away the mob which had blocked the NH and also from the nearby sugar mill campus.

Police have seized the oil tanker. However, the driver managed to flee. The villagers later put the body on the road and blocked it for several hours.

The mob also ransacked the nearby government-owned sugar mill, besides vandalizing 12 SUVs and motorcycles parked on the campus.

Meanwhile, the brother of the deceased, Ankit Kumar said, “Tractors carrying sugarcane often block the road and obstruct the movement of other vehicles. This causes lot of hardships to nearby villagers also.”

Meanwhile, police have sent the body for postmortem at Motihari sadar hospital. Senior police officers are camping at the site to maintain law and order. “No arrest has been made so far,” the SHO said.

Title: Penumbral eclipse dims moon for four hours
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

The eclipse on Friday night

KOLKATA: A subtle dimming of the full moon marked the penumbral lunar eclipse late at night on Friday and in the early hours of Saturday.

The eclipse set in at 10.37pm on Friday and ended at 2.42am on Saturday, and was at the maximum at 41 minutes past midnight. A faint shadow was cast over the moon, which reduced its brightness by 10%. The year is set to get three more penumbral lunar eclipses — on June 5, July 5 and November 30.

Title: ‘Weekend to be colder in Kolkata, chill to stay at least till Tuesday’
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Kids make the most of a sunny Friday to enjoy a game of cricket

KOLKATA: After a rainy Thursday, the mercury rose slightly on Friday. At 15.7°C, it was two notches above normal. But the Met office said the mercury will retreat beyond the normal mark by Saturday, making the weekend colder. The day temperature on Friday was 23.1°C.

“We expect the minimum temperature dip to around 13°C by Saturday and go further down to around 12°C the next day. We can expect a good cold spell at least till Tuesday with the northwesterly wind coming in without any obstacles,” said G K Das, director ( weather ) at Regional Meteorological Centre, Kolkata.

On Thursday, the minimum temperature was 15.5°C. The sky cleared up on Friday, making the mercury rise. The Met office said the residual moisture from Thursday’s rain was not allowing the mercury to slide.

Along with the minimum temperature, the day temperature on Saturday will also recede slightly. But the mercury could start rising from Wednesday. Weathermen fear a major western disturbance developing over Jammu and Kashmir could approach this region and push the temperature up. “We can’t yet assess how this will affect our region, but there is a chance of the temperature going up slightly from Wednesday. For now, there is no rain forecast for the city. ” said Das.

This winter, the minimum temperature had dipped to 11.1°C, with the mercury constantly staying under 12°C for a few days. Given the conditions at present, the Met office does not predict the mercury touching the 11°C mark for now.

Title: Patna: New gallery at science centre to be ready by April
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Work on the gallery, which is spread over an area of 600 square feet, is underway

PATNA: A new digitized ‘Ocean Gallery’ with 14 interactive exhibits, which is being developed on the premises of the Shrikrishna Science Centre (SKSC) at a cost of Rs 30 lakh, is likely to be ready by April.

Work on the gallery, which is spread over an area of 600 square feet, is underway.

“Altogether 14 exhibits will be displayed in different sections on themes like pressure and depth of ocean, ocean current, lights in the ocean, major constituents of sea, birth of ocean, temperature and salinity of oceans, mysteries of ocean, aquarium , ocean pollution, global warming and sea level, geological conditions of oceans, submarines and different types of ships, an SKSC official told this newspaper on Wednesday.

Interactive museum technology is being used for developing the new gallery, which has come up in place of an older gallery inaugurated in 1980. The official said, “We are renovating the previous gallery and adding more space to it so that all the exhibits can be accommodated here.”

SKSC project coordinator Amitabh pointed out that the ‘Ocean Gallery’ would explain the complex world of marine life to the visitors in a simple way by using augmented reality technology.

“This technology superimposes a computer-generated image on what is actually in front of the viewers. For instance, once you enter the ‘Ocean Gallery’, you will find yourself amid snow, penguins, and oceans,” Amitabh said.

He added, “Children will have a better understanding of the important principles and science related to oceans. Some exhibits will explain the Bermuda Triangle , while others will throw light on the scientific reasons behind changes in ocean currents and present challenges due to global warming.”

Earlier in 2019, a ‘Children’s Gallery’ was opened at the SKSC with six sections that included ‘assembly zone’, ‘ride zone’, ‘fairyland’, ‘farmland’, ‘play zone’ and ‘learning zone’. The gallery has altogether 32 exhibits like pyramids, virtual cars and bikes, doll house, robots and tubes.

Title: ‘Ex-Bhagalpur district magistrate signed a cheque for over Rs 12 crore in favour of NGO’
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Former Bhagalpur district magistrate (DM) Birendra Prasad Yadav had allegedly signed a government cheque for Rs 12,20,15,075 that was deposited into the bank account of NGO Srijan Mahila Vikas Sahyog Samiti , according to the supplementary chargesheet filed before the special CBI court-II against ten persons, including the 2004-batch IAS officer, in the multi-crore scam case on Wednesday.

Birendra, who is now the special secretary in the Backward and Extremely Backward Class Welfare Department, is the first bureaucrat to be chargesheeted in the scam which is related to fraudulent transfer of government money meant for welfare schemes into the Srijan’s Indian Bank account in connivance with the district administration and bank and cooperative department officials in Bhagalpur district between 2004 and 2014. The scam is stated to involve around Rs2000 crore. The NGO was supposed to impart vocational training to the women in Bhagalpur and adjoining districts.

According to the chargesheet, Birendra as the then Bhagalpur DM had signed a cheque of Oriental Bank of Commerce (OBC) for Rs12,20,15,075 on September 27, 2014 and it was credited into the Srijan’s bank account with Patal Babu Road branch of Indian Bank on September 30. It is also mentioned in the chargesheet that the signature on the cheque matched with that of Birendra in the forensic examination of central forensic science laboratory (CFSL) at New Delhi.

The amount was actually meant to be credited into a government account with Indian Bank branch. It was opened in the DM’s name after his order to close two old accounts with Oriental Bank of Commerce operational from 2008 and Punjab National Bank from 2010. The transferred amount was of Mukhya Mantri Nagar Vikas Yojana and it was kept in OBC.

Birendra had also signed behind the cheque in favour of Indian Bank’s branch manager, though it should have been in favour of Bhagalpur DM. His signature on the back of the cheque was “blank endorsement given to bank officers”. The bank manager wrote above the Birendra’s signature — “please credit to 822726685 with Indian Bank”. The CBI found in its investigation that the nine digit bank account number was in the name of Srijan.

After the cheque was presented to his branch for clearance, OBC manager Jaideo Singh met Birendra requesting him not to transfer the amount. But Birendra ordered him to clear the cheque the same day, the chargesheet stated. The CBI in its charegsheet has mentioned Singh’s statement that there was endorsement behind cheque for clearance in favour of a specific bank account with Indian Bank which was of Srijan’s and the DM knew it.

According to the chargesheet, the Indian Bank account was opened after Birendra’s subordinate Amrendra Kumar Yadav moved a proposal citing reason that both the old branches were far from the nazarat and it was difficult to operate them. The then DM had singed form to open new account with Indian Bank the same day his subordinate moved the proposal.

However, the CBI in its investigation found that all the three banks were located at the same distance from the nazarat and the Indian Bank’s branch was rather located at a crowded place. The CBI also mentioned in charegsheet that there was no need to close two old accounts and the new one was opened with dishonest intentions.

Title: Rajkot: Man held for practising medicine without degree
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: A man was arrested for allegedly carrying out medical practice without a legal degree in medicine in Bedala village on the outskirts of Rajkot on Friday. The accused was identified as Kirit Satani (30).

“We had received a tip-off that Satani was running his clinic without a degree in medicine, following which we raided his clinic. We recovered allopathic medicines, injections and glucose bottles from his clinic,” said H M Rana, sub-inspector with Rajkot special operation group .

During his interrogation, Satani told the cops that he had studied up to Class XII, and had worked in different hospitals as a male nurse. On the basis of his working experience in the hospitals, he had decided to open his clinic and start practising.

Title: Gorakhpur origin girl becomes US judge
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Samira

GORAKHPUR: Kin of Samia Naseem , who has been appointed as a judge in Chicago, have expressed happiness over her achievement. Samira had taken oath of office at the law department of Chicago on December 20, 2019.

Thirty-seven years old Samia was born in the US, while her father Khalid Naseem was born and brought up in Gorakhpur’s Gita Press area. Every year, Samia visits her ancestral home in Gorakhpur to meet her family and relatives.

Her father’s younger brother, Mohd Tariq who lives in Gita Press area, expressed happiness over his niece’s success.

He said, “I am very happy that my niece has become a judge in the US. I still see her as a little girl. She visits India every year and has toured all over the country. During her last visit, she also went to meet retired judge Kalimullah sahib.”

“I feel that she is inspired by her father as he practices corporate law in the US. Khalid went to the US in 1978 and married there with NRI Homaira. Samia was born there,” he added.

“Samia is an arts graduate from Simmons College, Washington, 2001 batch. In 2004 she got a degree of Juris doctor from George Washington University of Law School. She studied International Human Rights Law and Refugee Law in Oxford. She practised law in Chicago before becoming a judge. She is also a member of New York State Bar,” said Mohd Tariq.

Title: Gorewada tiger cub has rare hepatozoan infection
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Nagpur: A 9-month-old tiger cub which was brought to Gorewada Rescue Centre for advanced treatment from Chandrapur has been detected with rare chronic hepatozoan infection.

The cub, with heavy tick infestation, was captured on August 13, 2019, from Khutwanda in Tadoba-Andhari Tiger Reserve (TATR). Apart from tick infestation the cub was severely dehydrated, anaemic, debilitated and sluggish. It was under treatment at transit treatment centre in Chandrapur till October 15 last.

The male cub was brought from Chandrapur to Gorewada Rescue Centre on December 27, 2019. The cub showed abnormal distension of left and right sides of abdomen.

“It was kept isolated and was screened for presence of blood parasites. The samples were sent to department of veterinary parasitology, Nagpur Veterinary College, where it was confirmed to be chronic hepatozoan infection,” said Nandkishore Kale, divisional manager.

“The infection is caused by the ingestion of infected tick. It is comparatively rare in domestic cat family and not yet reported in wildcats in India,” says Dr Shirish Upadhye and Dr Vinod Dhoot of Wildlife Research & Training Centre (WRTC), MAFSU. The cub has been put on antibiotics. Doctors said the condition was treatable.

Title: MVA to continue BJP’s plantation scheme
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Nagpur: Maharashtra forest minister Sanjay Rathod has vowed to implement farm fencing scheme in the state to protect crops from depredation by wild animals and stressed on the need to protect tiger corridors.

In his first meeting after assuming charge as minister, Rathod was talking to senior forest officials including forest secretary Vikas Kharge, PCCF N Rambabu, chief wildlife warden Nitin Kakodkar, PCCFs Pravin Srivastava, MK Rao and APCCF Virendra Tiwari and others.

The minister said he would provide enough funds to implement farm fencing scheme. Solar fencing scheme for farmers is already under implementation in villages adjoining tiger reserves under Dr Shyama Prasad Mukherjee Jan Van Yojana.

He said that forest department needs to be more people-friendly. Rathod said apart from promoting tourism, relocation of villages from core area of parks will be taken up on priority. Of the 110 such villages, 66 have been relocated till now.

Stating that he wants to appoint wildlife veterinary doctors in tiger reserves, the minister asked officials to forward proposals in this regard. He also stressed on protecting tiger corridors and said the state wildlife board will be reconstituted soon.

Setting his priorities, Rathod said plantation scheme launched by earlier government will continue but officials should ensure survival of saplings. He also asked the foresters to continue with senior forest officers’ conferences held every three months. “First such conference after the regime change in the state will be held in next 15 days in the presence of chief minister Uddhav Thackeray and deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar,” said Rathod.

Earlier, the minister was briefed about the department’s functioning and various schemes being implemented. Minister of state for forest Dattatray Bharne was also present on the occasion.

Title: Karavali Utsav off to a vibrant start
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Mangaluru: The 10-day Karavali Utsav got off to a vibrant start at the Karavali Utsav grounds here on Friday.

After inaugurating the procession and the exhibition, district minister Kota Srinivas Poojari referring to the district as a land of temples said the region is rich in culture and tradition. This is evident from the fact that kambla, the traditional sport of Tulunadu, continues to be held after a legal fight in the Supreme Court.

“Traditional sports like kambala and cock fight have sustained because of people’s love for culture and deep-rooted traditional practices.”

At the Utsav’s inauguration, actor and Swarna Kamal national awardee Rishabh Shetty said his movie drew inspiration from culture and traditions of undivided Dakshina Kannada. For 'Ulidavaru Kandanthe', he showcased 'hulivesha' (tiger dance) and in Sarkari Hiriya Prathamika Shaale, Kasaragodu, Koduge: Ramanna Rai, Yakshagana was the highlight. The movie Sarakari Hi Pra Shaale, was an attempt to highlight the plight of government school and the need to protect our mother tongue, said the actor who studied in a government school. His movie also bagged the best entertainer award at the Karnataka State film awards 2019. D Vedavyas Kamath, Mangaluru City South MLA presided.

Twenty-nine cultural troupes from across the state participated in the colourful procession that was flagged off from from Nehru Maidan and moved via K S Rao Road, Navabharath Circle, PVS Circle, Lalbagh and culminated at Karavali Utsav Maidan.

Clean Utsav

The administration’s emphasis on cleanliness at the Utsav came in for appreciation. The waste collection van followed the procession and ensured that the path was litter-free.

Cultural programmes will be held on all days at Karavali Utsav Maidan and Kadri Park from January 11 to 19. Sports meets will be held at multiple locations on January 11. Yuva Utsav, a platform for students from various colleges in the district, will be held at Kadri Park on January 16 and 17. An international kite festival, beach games and musical programmes will be held at Panambur Beach from January 17. The exhibition at the maidan will be open till February 10.

Title: CM, guv to visit Gorakhpur Mahotsav
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Gorakhpur: Governor Anandiben Patel will inaugurate the three-day Gorakhpur Mahotsav commencing from January 11-13 while chief minister Yogi Adityanath will be present at the closing ceremony of the fest, comissioner Gorakhpur division, Jayant Narlikar told reporters on Wednesday.

“The fest will also provide a platform to differently-abled along with national and local artists of the city. Bollywood clebrities including Sonu Nigam, Alka Yagnk, Anuradha Podwal, Raju Srivastav and Bhojpuri artists like Baharat Sharma aka Vyas will be performing at the fest. MP Ravi Krishna will recite Atal Bihari Vajpayee’s poems while Neha Bannerji will present a dance drama ‘Dashavtar,’ he said.

Title: Traffic diversion for Nashik Run today
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

CLEARED SKHER

Nashik: The city police has effected traffic diversion in the Mahatma Nagar and Gangapur Road area in view of the Nashik Run to be held on Saturday . The traffic diversion will be in place from 5am to 12 pm, the police said.

The participants of the Run will use the left side of the road from Mahatmanagar ground - Parijatnagar Signal - Rocket Signal - Jehan Circle and till the Gate in front of Someshwar along Gangapur Road. On their way back from the gate in front of Someshwar, they will use the same lane to Mahatmanagar ground.

Motorists on the stretch from Mahatma Nagar to Someshwar via Gangapur will use the road on the other side of the divider. The lane left open for traffic will be used for two movement of vehicles during the traffic diversion period.

The police said the timing of the traffic diversion could be changed if required. The police said that the diversion has been effected to ensure that there are no issues of traffic congestion on the route of Nashik Run.

The traffic restrictions will not be applicable for all police department vehicles, ambulances, hearse and fire brigade vehicles, informed the police.

Title: Mela police stopped us from making announcements: Bhoole Bhatke Shivir
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Devotees at Magh Mela on Friday

Allahabad: Reuniting devotees separated from their families since several decades, it was the first time in years that the organisers at ‘ Bhoole Bhatke Shivir’ weren’t able to do their job on Friday, the inaugural day of this year’s Magh Mela.

The organisers alleged that the Mela police did not allow them to make any announcements and even took away their equipment.

Tiwari said, “We only had two speakers to make the announcements, but the police did not allow our volunteers to use them. We faced unwanted problems throughout the day without the announcement systems. We walked long distances to find the separated persons with their families.”

Tiwari also claimed that their requests to Mela administration for help did not yield any result.

The camp’s volunteers— belonging to different districts\states— have been helping reunite devotees at every Magh Mela, Ardh Kumbh and Maha Kumbh since their patron Raja Ram Tiwari started the tradition in 1946.

This Magh Mela, Mela police set up three lost and found camps on the venue in three separate zones — Parade Ground, Jhunsi and Arail.

On being contacted, IG (Allahabad zone) KP Singh said, “The announcements were stopped only briefly, especially when hardly one or two people were left at the lost and found camp.” The IG claimed that the camp’s volunteers have been asked to make announcements only when it was urgent, so that the misuse of loudspeakers could be checked.

Title: Vijay Tendulkar relevant in today’s testing times, says filmmaker R Balki
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

R Balki (left) receives a memento from PIFF director Jabbar Patel

PUNE: Filmmaker R Balakrishnan — fondly known as R Balki — called the late playwright Vijay Tendulkar as “one of the bravest writers” of our time and that he was “more relevant today”.

Balki was this year’s invitee to deliver the flagship Vijay Tendulkar Memorial Lecture at Pune International Film Festival at a multiplex on Senapati Bapat Road on Saturday. Unlike previous years, this year’s “lecture” was organized as a tête-à-tête between Balki and festival director Jabbar Patel.

It was during this interaction that Balki spoke about the legacy of Tendulkar, the pressure on filmmakers to be “different” in a world overflowing with content on various platforms, and his own journey in the world of films.

Tendulkar was a long-time colleague of Patel. Balki too had rubbed shoulders with the noted screenwriters and was full of praise for Tendulkar’s bravery and outspoken nature, despite the fact that his comments often landed him in controversy.

“Tendulkar was the bravest writer of our times and is rather more relevant today. He was brave not only because he was not afraid to speak his mind, but whenever there was disturbance in the society, he didn’t let that disturb him but used it to be more creative,” Balki said.

Balki has ideated and brough to life some popular television campaigns for some of the most recognized brands — from big names in FMCG to luxury jewellery and consumer goods.

And since his foray into films in 2007, with the quirky romance ‘Cheeni Kum’, he also left an indelible mark on filmmaking.

As part of the interaction, Balki also narrated the way he had to shoot the critically acclaimed ‘Paa’, where real-life father-son duo Amitabh and Abhishek Bachchan reversed their roles on screen.

“We shot this movie without the VFX (visual effects) and most of the film was shot from the top-down angle to make Amitabh Bachchan look like a child,” he reminisced.

With content of various lengths floating around on platforms that are becoming cheaper and more accessible by the day, Balki acknowledges the challenge that filmmakers and content producers face to differentiate themselves from the rest of the pack.

“Today we are exposed to a lot of content. We see more interesting, weird things happening in people’s lives. There is a lot of pressure on filmmakers to be different and original in such a world,” he conceded.

Title: Politicians divide people on caste lines: Ram Madhav
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

BJP general secretary Ram Madhav

HYDERABAD: BJP general secretary Ram Madhav seemed to be in a candid mood at a conference at the Indian School of Business (ISB) on Friday as he told the audience that politicians divide society, based on caste for electoral gains. He however added not all caste as an institution was not bad.

He also suggested forming a separate Election Commission cadre as part of electoral reforms to avoid political interference during elections, even as he quoted Jawaharlal Nehru and Karl Marx in his speech.

Speaking at the two-day 'Money power in politics – Indian democracy at work’ annual conference, Madav batted for a liberal democracy and liberal constitutionalism.

He observed that society could run on its own without the interference of the government for 90% of its affairs. According to him, government was needed only for 10% of the time.

He even said that it was ok to lose an election for sake of good governance.

“Indian society was never government-centric, but governments have increasingly made people heavily dependent on them," he said and added that power should be contained and regulated.

Madhav did not hesitate to quote India’s first prime minister Jawaharlal Nehru during his speech. “Nehru was once asked why he was so fascinated by democracy,” he said. “He answered democracy was the second-best available form. He was against asked what the best form was. Nehru answered it was yet to be invented. We are following the best available form of democracy.”

He added, “In democracy, people are supposed to be masters. ‘Government of the people’ is being done, but ‘government for the people’ is partly true and ‘government by the people’ is not followed. The biggest challenge is to make democracy more liberal.”

Madhav quoting Karl Marx’s principle of the ‘withering away of the state’ said that that it is those who are in power who won't allow it to happen. He said Lenin refused to wither away the state as he enjoyed power.

“I am not saying we have to leave it to anarchy. There should be minimum interference of the government, that too at a local level.”

Title: Ministry plans tourism hub on Kolkata Port Trust land
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Mansukh Mandaviya (Twitter image)

KOLKATA: The ministry of shipping has identified 32-acre riverfront land belonging to the Kolkata Port Trust to develop it into an entertainment and tourism hub. Less than 48 hours before Prime Minister Narendra Modi inaugurates the sesquicentenary celebrations of Kolkata Port Trust ( KoPT ), minister of state for shipping, Mansukh Mandaviya, announced the plan.

KoPT owns large tracts of land in Kolkata, Haldia, Howrah and the suburbs. The management has been making efforts to use this land profitably.

“The master plan for the development of KoPT’s riverfront land into entertainment and tourism hubs has been drawn out. This is as per the shipping ministry’s vision document to excel in maritime and inland waterway transport. In Phase-I, 32-acre land has been identified for the project,” said Mandaviya.

The minister added that a ship repair facility would also come up in the city. In March 2019, KoPT had signed a concession agreement with Cochin Shipyard Ltd for 15 years. A naval vessel will be the first to be repaired at the KoPT’s dry docks under the banner of CSL Kolkata Ship Repair Unit.

KoPT is the oldest operational port in the country. According to Mandaviya, the port facility has aided in industrialisation, employment generation and major economic activity in the region while serving a vast hinterland in India as well as landlocked neighbouring countries like Nepal and Bhutan.

He quoted predictions by industry analysts while saying that KoPT will continue to grow in the future with new facilities being developed.

Title: Chennai: Pongal exodus begins, buses in high demand
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

More crowd thronged Koyambedu bus stand than anticipated on Friday

CHENNAI: The great Pongal-time migration of city residents to southern and western districts began on Friday evening.

While nearly one lakh passengers left by government special buses and trains on Friday, at least 20% of Chennai’s population are expected to move to their native villages in the next three or four days.

Bookings for special buses on Friday increased by 350% over the normal 4,000 bookings done everyday. But on Friday, close to 18,000 seats were reserved in advance. Of this, 10,200 boarded buses from Chennai Moffusil Bus Terminus (CMBT) at Koyambedu .

Though special arrangements were made by the state transport department, a larger-than-anticipated crowd thronged the bus stand, leading to traffic congestion outside.

Pending flyover work, near the entrance worsened the situation. “Though we reached Arumbakkam in 30 minutes, it took us equal time to cross the 1km stretch after that to reach CMBT,” said Sudarashan who was travelling from Madipakkam to Koyambedu.

Too many vehicles started driving on the wrong side near the traffic signal forcing others to wait for longer than usual, he added.

However, on reaching the terminus, it wasn’t that chaotic except for longer waiting time for buses travelling to Tirunelveli and Nagercoil.

Unlike buses to Madurai or Trichy, frequency to these far-off places was not high and online booking rate was also high for these buses. Only rear seats and those near driver cabins were available, said passengers waiting on platforms 7 and 8.

As far as trains are concerned, Central and Egmore stations were overcrowded and unreserved compartments in all trains were packed. This left passengers, boarding trains at Tambaram, in the lurch and many had to stand near footboards all night to reach their destination.

Exploiting the situation, many private buse operators charged thrice than the normal fare. Since police didn’t allow them to park near CMBT they reached Tambaram and Perungalathur right from 6pm.

Title: Thieves a pain for sellers at book fair
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

This year, with nearly two crore books under 15 lakh titles on display in nearly 800 stalls, the threat of the... Read More

CHENNAI: They are casually dressed and act like eager bookworms desperately looking for their favourite title among the thousands on display. What they actually want is just a few seconds of attention away from them so that they can tuck a couple of books under their arms and saunter away.

Such thieves, regulars at almost every such gathering, have become a nightmare for sellers and publishers at the ongoing the 43rd Chennai Book Fair at YMCA in Nandanam . Several stall owners have increased the manpower to ensure nothing is lost. R Vijayakumar, a city-based book dealer who has stocked 20,000 books under 500 titles, says people stealing books is a regular phenomenon. “This year, we have added two more people to keep a close watch on such individuals,” said Vijayakumar, who has set up his stall in the first row.

This year, with nearly two crore books under 15 lakh titles on display in nearly 800 stalls, the threat of theft is high, say sellers. Inquiries made by TOI revealed that those who participated in last year’s edition together lost books valued between Rs 3,000 and Rs 10,000. S Ravi, an associate with a publication, said that 200 to 300 books were stolen during the fair in 2019. “We are clueless about the theft and come to know only during the final accounting. It is difficult to control the menace because our entire concentration will be on assisting genuine buyers and completing the billing process at the cash counters,” he said.

There has been no report of any incident of books being stolen in the current fair, which began on January 9 and is set to continue till January 21, said Ravi.

The usual targets of thieves, say representatives at the various stalls, are the books of leading authors and children’s books. Some sellers stressed that introducing barcodes on book covers and scanning books are sorely needed to prevent theft and to ensure that no book can exit the venue without being billed.

When contacted, R S Shanmugam, president of Booksellers and Publishers’ Association of South India (BAPASI), said that 50 CCTV cameras had been installed at vantage points at the venue and that several volunteers had been tasked with looking out for thieves.

“There have been instances of book thieves being caught and handed over to the police in the past,” he added.

Title: Atrocity FIR filed against the late Tarak Mehta
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Tarak Mehta

AHMEDABAD: Nearly three years after his death, the famous Gujarati writer Tarak Mehta has been named as an accused in an FIR under the Scheduled Caste/Scheduled Tribe (Prevention of Atrocities) Act filed at Nikol police station in the city, for allegedly using a casteist slur in a Gujarati play titled ‘Ek Murakh Ne Evi Tev’.

In his FIR, Rashmikant Parmar, 33, a trader of machine tools in Kathwada, stated that he had on July 22, 2019 seen the play on a YouTube channel.

“The play, ‘Ek murakh ne evi tev’, has been written by Tarak Mehta, directed by Bharat Shroff and features artists including Mukesh Raval, Santu Rajda, Manish Mehta, Chirag Acharya, Vimal Upadhyay, Jitu Mehta and Anuradha Kanabar,” states Parmar in the FIR.

The play was produced by Rangat Productions and obtained a certificate for broadcast from the Central Board of Film Certification (CBFC), it adds.

“Two minutes and thirteen seconds into the play, actress Anuradha Kanabar delivers a dialogue in which derogatory words are spoken against our caste. Due to this, the dialogue hurts the sentiments of my caste,” Parmar stated.

The writer, columnist, playwright and humorist Tarak Mehta died on March 1, 2017 at his home in Ambawadi in the city at the age of 87. He was also known for the popular Gujarati column ‘Duniya Ne Undha Chashma’. In 2015, he was awarded the Padma Shri for his work.

In his FIR, Parmar said that he had first filed the application of complaint in July 2019, but it took five months to register the FIR. “The FIR was registered only after I met various top police officers, including DCP Zone 5, under whose jurisdiction Nikol police station falls,” said Parmar.

DCP Zone 5, Ravi Teja Vasamsetty said that police would file a C (closure) summary as the accused is dead. “We have also inquired and found that Tarak Mehta has died but as the plea was pending for long, we filed the FIR. We will remove the name of Tarak Mehta during the course of our investigation,” said Vasamsetty.

Apart from Tarak Mehta, eight artists and an unknown member of the CBFC has also been booked under the Atrocities Act.

Title: Rural police help victim recover money from an online fraud
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik rural police helped a complainant from Malegaon get back part of his partial amount after he was duped by an online fraudster a fortnight ago.

The rural police said that on December 25, a complainant got a call on his cellphone, wherein he was told by the unidentified caller about a cash-back offer on an e-wallet, which can be claimed by simply clicking on the link from the cellphone.

The unidentified caller appealed to the complainant to take advantage of the offer by clicking on the link and getting the verification done, said the police.

Meanwhile, when the complainant clicked the link sent on his cellphone, he lost Rs 49,991 from his bank account, which he learned on getting a text message from his concerned bank.

The complainant immediately lodged a complaint with the cyber police station. Acting swiftly, PI Subhash Anmulwar instructed PSI Kalpesh Dabhade and police naik Arti Pardhi to start investigating the case. They took the entire information and checked the cellphone and the link which was sent to him by the fraudster.

The cyber police said that they were unsure to which bank the money was transferred, the cyber police contacted the concerned bank manager and informed him about the fraudulent transaction and sought details of the culprit who had withdrawn part of the money. However, the bank manager froze the further transaction and returned the remaining amount of Rs 24,184 to the complainant.

The police said that they sought details of the concerned conman from the bank so that he can be arrested and the remaining amount of the victim can be returned to him.

Arti Singh, superintendent of police, Nashik Rural said that they appealed to the people to not trust any unidentified phone caller who introduces himself as a representative or officer of a bank or e-wallet and does not give him any personal information of one’s bank account. Further one should also not share the one-time password (OTP) that one receives from a bank to anyone and also not click on the link someone has sent you on the cell-phone.

Title: Caste is good, not casteism: Ram Madhav
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Ram Madhav

Speaking about the caste system, Ram Madhav said, “The previous varna system is gone but caste system exists in a different form. Caste is good. I am not propagating casteism in the country. As an institution, caste can do good for a community like many social and religious intermediaries. It was religious bodies that fed the hungry and not the kings those days. Once hunger is mitigated, every citizen can be productive.”

Title: Couldn’t take a bus for 7 years due to trauma, woman recalls harassment
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

While experiences are many, the response to it is only one—avoid or ignore the situation and person.

LUCKNOW: A lewd comment while getting onto a bus, a hand ‘accidentally’ brushed against the chest while getting off a tempo or train or a song with vulgar lyrics directed at them by the cab driver—these are just a few forms of harassment faced by women on a daily basis while travelling in public transport.

While experiences are many, the response to it is only one—avoid or ignore the situation and person.

For the past seven years, Spraha Magan has not taken a bus to commute.

The 27-year-old has not been able to forget a traumatising incident she went through in 2013.

“It was just a regular day for me. I took the bus to college. In the morning, buses are generally packed and many men take advantage of this to misbehave with women. However, I had not faced something like that till that day. I was sitting in the aisle seat when a middle-aged man started rubbing his private parts on my shoulder. I was so shocked that I could not react. The bus was packed so nobody noticed. I was so traumatised that I could not take a bus again,” said the Singarnagar resident.

There are many like Spraha who face harassment or embarrassment every day. Karishma Rajawat, a bank employee, was in for a rude shock during an auto-rickshaw ride with her friends.

“We were going to Indiranagar from Hazratganj. We were busy chatting until my friend noticed in the rear-view mirror that the driver was masturbating. She immediately stopped the auto, asked us not to pay and jump out. The driver also understood and left in a rush. People don’t understand but incidents like these leave a huge impact on our lives. It gets difficult to move on,” said Rajawat (33). A similar case happened on November 13, 2019, when a 21-year-old graduate student had to jump off a moving tempo (three-wheeler) because she was being harassed by the driver who asked her to remove her scarf and share her number.

Parul Kushwaha (name changed on request) recalls how a man in a train to Delhi in March 2019 was harassing her.

“I was so scared that I began shouting. Soon, people gathered and began thrashing him. It is difficult because we freeze but shouting out loud is the only immediate rescue,” she added.
