Even app-based cabs, which are believed to be safer, are not free of such incidents.

Title: Vikram 2nd kin to retain deceased corporator’s seat
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Before Vikram, Congress corporator Kamlesh Chaudhary had retained seat after his father Dilip’s death in 2007

Nagpur: BJP candidate Vikram Gwalbanshi has become the second kin to retain a seat left vacant due to a sitting corporator’s death in the Nagpur Municipal Corporation’s (NMC) history. Vikram comfortably won the byelection from ward no 12 (D) on Friday.

Before Vikram, Congress corporator Kamlesh Chaudhary had retained seat after his father Dilip’s death in 2007.

Following the demise of four-time BJP corporator Jagdish in April last year, the saffron party nominated his son Vikram, activist of BJP Yuva Morcha, in the byelection. Of the total 22,151 polled votes, Vikram secured 13,386 votes (60.43%). Vikram’s victory margin was 9,636 votes.

Congress’s Pankaj Shukla polled only 3,750 votes, followed by Ashok Dorlikar (independent, 2,617), Praful Ganvir (Bahujan Bharip Mahasangh, 1,556), Akash Kawle (Aam Aadmi Party, 690), and NOTA (152).

A resident of Makardhokda, Katol Road, Vikram is third from his family to get elected as a corporator. Besides his father, Vikram’s mother Aruna was also a corporator for one term.

With city Congress president Vikas Thakre winning from West Nagpur three months ago, the party failed to grab the seat from BJP’s pocket even after Jagdish’s demise. A slew of BJP leaders, including city MP and Union minister Nitin Gadkari, campaigned for Vikram.

NMC sources said that even a couple of Congress corporators extended their support to Vikram as a tribute to Jagdish.

Thakre said the byelection was a wave of sympathy towards Jagdish, who was corporator for 17 years and in public touch for the last 30 years. “People’s sentiments towards Jagdish worked in Vikram’s favour. Jagdish was a simple and good person. I got a big lead from this ward in assembly elections. Therefore, this byelection cannot be compared with the political situation prevailing in the district and state. Congress won by a clear majority in zilla parishad elections. The same results will be seen in 2022 municipal elections,” he said.

Of the remaining three corporators from the ward, two — Harish Gwalbanshi and Darshini Dhawad — are from BJP. Former mayor Maya Iwnate is also from BJP.

Thanking Gadkari and leader of opposition Devendra Fadnavis for showing faith in him, Vikram said his victory was a real tribute to his father. “All from the ward loved my father for his developmental works. I will continue to work for people’s welfare and development and provide all basic amenities in my ward just like my father,” he said.

This was the second byelection in NMC’s current regime since February 2017. After the demise of BJP corporator Nilesh Kumbhare, Sandip Gavai of the same party was elected in October 2017 from ward 35 (A). Hence, the BJP has maintained its seat count of 108 in NMC’s house of 151.

Party-Wise Tally In NMC

BJP--------108

Cong-------29

NCP--------1

Sena-------2

BSP--------10

Independent- 1

Total-------151

Title: Barse ends ‘maun vrat’, says he is with students
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Nagpur: Professor Vijay Barse , on whose life acclaimed director Nagraj Manjule has produced Amitabh Bachchan-starrer film ‘Jhund’, concluded his three-day ‘maun vrat’ (silent protest) by addressing some teachers’ organizations and his supporters at Samvidhan Square on Friday. The film is yet to be released.

Barse said he stands in solidarity with the nation and students and will continue to support them whenever attacks like the one on Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) students are committed. “I did my bit of penance by remaining silent for three days, which is painful for a teacher,” he said.

Barse also extended support to ‘We the People of India’ protests which will kick off from Saturday at Samvidhan Square and continue till January 14. “ I will be there and listen what the youth are saying,” he said. He called for peace in the country and protection to students. “In the 1970s, students of Nagpur University were under attack. Then too, I had stood up to protect the students,” he recalled.

“Everyone must condemn attacks on institutions and students,” said Barse.

Meanwhile, organizers of ‘We the People of India’ have appealed to the people to join the stir against Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) / national register of citizens (NRC) and the national population register (NPR) by gathering at Samvidhan Square in large numbers.

Maharashtra assembly speaker Nana Patole is likely to visit the protest site on January 13 or 14. On Saturday, guardian minister Nitin Raut too would meet the protesters.

Title: Beauty of seasons, romance, valour brought alive at Kalidasa programme
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Bharatanatyam dance ‘Rutusamhar’ was showcased at the cultural programme organized by Kavikulaguru Kalidas San... Read More

Nagpur: Every season has its beauty embedded in it in the Indian context. And it was Kalidasa who brought out the best of nature in his long poem ‘Rutusamhara’ which was presented in a dance form that made the audience bask in the glory at Suresh Bhat Sabhagruh, Reshimbagh on Friday.

Organized by Kavikulaguru Kalidas Sanskrit University (KKSU) as part of two-day cultural programme, artistes of Bharat College of Fine Arts, Mumbai, were in their element while depicting six seasons — Grishma, Varsha, Sharad, Hemant, Shishir and Vasant.

The Bharatanatyam dancers swayed with words of the great poet as they unfolded the characteristics of summer, monsoon, autumn, cool, winter and spring. Human emotions of love and longing associated with monsoon in particular were marvellously showcased.

Nature and animal kingdom are inseparable as they act differently when it comes to manifestation. The artistes swirled while presenting postures of animals like swan, frog and deer. Sandhya Purecha and troupe from Mumbai did it with ease. So was presentation of ‘shringar rasa’. They also presented a small piece portraying the romance between Radha and Krishna.

Artistes of Rajendra and Nirupama of Abhinav Dance Academy, Bengaluru, presented three segment sequences highlighting the story of Mahabharata and Ramayana. Their performance showcased the journey of Rama and Sita and their lives in Panchavati. Rajendra and Nirupama as Rama and Sita were elegant.

The second segment was dedicated to the romance between Shakuntala and Dushyant. The duo then performed a jugalbandi of Kathak as their ghungroo-laden feet moved swiftly, with matching facial expressions.

Their presentation concluded on a powerful note as they presented ‘veer rasa’, narrating the story of Abhimanyu (Naveen Hegde), who was caught in the ‘chakravyuh’.

Kishor and Kishori Hampiholi of the city were at their best, narrating the story of Amrapali and her journey towards embracing Buddhism after she meets an influential monk in the dance drama.

Title: Need our own version of president government: Ram Madhav
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Ram Madhav

Ram Madhav believes that the country should slowly move towards its own version of a presidential form of government. “Politics today follows a highly incentivized model,” he said.

“The presidential system may disincentivize politics , but there are many other ways. Every new law made is bondage for the people. We should have laws that reduce responsibilities.”

Title: Cold wave back, icy winds sweep Lucknow
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

The gusty wind will continue to lash the city till Sunday accompanied by moderate to dense fog in the morning.... Read More

LUCKNOW: Lucknow residents reeled under ‘cold day’ conditions as dry icy winds swept the city on Friday.

Even the sunshine did little to bring any relief from the biting cold.

The gusty wind will continue to lash the city till Sunday accompanied by moderate to dense fog in the morning. Temperatures, however, will rise on Monday and Tuesday, followed by possibilities of thundershowers on Wednesday and Thursday.

The western disturbance (WD) responsible for Wednesday’s rain and Thursday’s overcast sky fizzled out on Friday. The phenomenon led to the revival of northwesterly winds coming from the hilly areas, which witnessed snowfall recently.

As the sky was clear overnight, the minimum temperature dropped to 7 degrees Celsius, a degree below normal. Icy winds condensed the moisture left behind by rain into fog in the morning, but the haze cleared by 9am due to the winds. The wind speed was recorded as 15km/hour.

As a result, despite the sunshine, the maximum temperature – peak value of mercury during the day – was restricted to 16.8 degrees Celsius, five units below normal. As per meteorological terminology, such a state is referred to as a ‘cold day’.

State Met director JP Gupta said, “Two WDs are expected to hit the hills next week. The one on Monday (January 13) will cut off the flow of icy winds towards plains, resulting in a rise in temperatures across the state. It may cause rain in the western part of UP, but the eastern region will generally remain dry. The WD will disintegrate by January 14.”

“The second WD is expected on Wednesday (January 15) and would make the weather conducive for rain or thundershowers across the state on January 16-17,” he added.

Title: Defer exams for Saraswati Puja: Partha Chatterjee
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Partha Chatterjee

KOLKATA: Education minister Partha Chatterjee on Friday said that he has requested all the universities across the state to postpone their examinations scheduled on January 30.

Chatterjee said, “Several students and representatives of the Trinamool Congress Chatra Parishad (TMCP) met me today. They informed me that some examinations are scheduled on January 30. I have instructed all universities to consider deferring the examinations due to Saraswati Puja .”

Chatterjee added, “I have been informed that the Saraswati Puja is on January 29 and will continue till January 30. So, students who organise these pujas, may want to plan their immersions on that day. I do not understand why the universities had planned their examinations even without checking the calendar.”

According to sources, Calcutta University has scheduled some undergraduate examinations on January 30. The fresh dates will be announced soon, following the minister’s instruction.

Title: Months after dad’s suicide, daughter too ends life
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Sakshi Chokhandre, 15, a student of Standard IX, committed suicide by hanging with a scarf from ceiling rod at her residence at Kadu Layout on Thursday. The reason for her act was not clear. Her father, Shashikant, had ended his life at a friend’s place in May last year.

The family members, still clueless about the reason behind Sakshi’s drastic step, are trying to connect the daughter’s suicide with her father’s as they had a special bond despite staying separately. The family sources claimed Shashikant’s suicide seemed to have adversely affected Sakshi. Shashikant, an autorickshaw driver, used to stay with a friend at Indora and not at home as he had a difference with wife Seema who supported the family by working at a hostel.

A relative said Sakshi had developed some uneasiness for the last couple of days. “She was normal and had done household chores earlier in the day. There was no indication from her words or even mood to gauge she would take the step later in the day. She had also spoken at length with a neighbour,” said the relative. “There was some frustration within her which may have compelled her to take the decision to end life,” he said.

The family members also informed Sakshi was a good student and had scored well in her Standard VIII final examinations.

It is learnt Seema had advised Sakshi to go her maternal uncle’s place which is in the vicinity before leaving for work as she had complained of uneasiness. Sakshi’s elder sister, Anchal, was at her maternal uncle’s place. Anchal was expecting Sakshi to reach at maternal uncle’s place too. As she did not turn up, Anchal and her maternal grandmother Sanghamitra went to Sakshi’s place to enquire about her health.

Anchal and Sanghamitra got worried as there was no response from inside after repeated knocks on the door. They alerted a neighbour who came to their help. She spotted Sakshi hanging from the ceiling after peeping through the window. Police were alerted. No suicide note was found. Kapil Nagar police have registered a case of accidental death.

Title: Madras HC seeks report from 40 returning officers as DMK alleges fraud
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: The Madras high court on Friday called for reports from more than 40 returning officers (RO) of the recently concluded rural local body election on whether they conducted recounting of votes as per the request by DMK candidates, if not the reason for the same.

Justice PD Audikesavalu passed the interim order on a batch of petitions alleging that the retuning officers concerned have not recounted votes in some wards where a request for recounting has been made despite the provisions of Panchayat Election Rules which mandates such recount if sought for in accordance with law.

The judge also orally observed that the court would direct departmental action against errant returning officers if it is found that they did not follow the rules pertaining to recounting.

This apart, the judge also heard another plea moved by the DMK, seeking direction to the Tamil Nadu state election commission to video graph with audio recording the entire proceedings of the indirect election to the posts of chairperson and vice chairperson of district panchayat council and panchayat union council to ensure free and fair election and to police protection for the election. When the plea came up for hearing, the court recorded the undertaking of the election commission that it will provide three tier protection and video recording of the election without audio recording.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Juvenile among two booked for rape
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

Title: Inspector absconding in liquor, cash bribery case surrenders before ACB
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Inspector Balvantaiah.(File photo)

HYDERABAD: Jubilee Hills inspector Balvantaiah, the main accused in a bribery case, who was absconding, surrendered before the Anti-Corruption Bureau ( ACB ) sleuths on Friday.

Balvantaiah told the police that he abruptly left bandobust duties at Krishnakant Park on Thursday afternoon and left in an auto to attend to his ‘ill’ wife.

On Thursday afternoon, the ACB team had arrested Jubilee Hills SI P Sudheer Reddy while demanding and accepting Rs 50,000 and two whiskey bottles as bribe from complainant M Vamsi Krishna Chowdary. Sudheer spilled the beans and said that he was acting upon the instructions from Balvantaiah.

After arresting the SI, the ACB team made him call the inspector to verify the veracity of his claims.

“Balvantaiah disconnected the SI’s call and called him back through WhatsApp. When the SI explained that the complainant gave Rs 50,000 and two bottles of whiskey, Balvantaiah reminded him saying that the initial agreement was for Rs 1 lakh. Subsequently, Balvantaiah told the SI to take the bribe and enquired about another complaint involving a woman. The SI told the inspector that both the parties agreed for a settlement on their own. The conversation was recorded in the presence of witnesses,” said an ACB official.

After laying the trap, the police team took the SI to Jubilee Hills police station to arrest the inspector there. However, after reaching the station, they realised that he was on bandobust duty at Krishnakant Park. Meanwhile, Balvantaiah changed into civilian clothes inside his official vehicle and left the place in an autorikshaw.

“ACB sleuths then told senior officials of Hyderabad commissionerate to call him, but Balvantaiah did not answer their calls. An hour later, his phone was switched off,” said a police source.

Balvantaiah’s house in Vanasthalipuram remained locked and his four phones were switched off. After the ACB sleuths launched a manhunt for him, Balvantaiah surrendered before the ACB officials at their head office in Banjara Hills on Friday.

The inspector told the interrogators that he forgot the cell phones, tab and wallet inside the official vehicle. However, ACB said that the team did not find the items in the vehicle. “Balvantaiah remained silent when asked if he had demanded the bribe and asked the SI to collect it,” said an ACB official. The accused were suspended by Hyderabad CP Anjani Kumar .

Title: Maharashtra yet to receive notification on NPR drive
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

PUNE: Maharashtra is yet to receive the notification on the National Population Register ( NPR ) drive to be carried out between April and September across the country, Census department officials have said.

The Centre has issued a directive, instructing the head of a family to make available details of 21 identifiers during the enrolment in the National Population Register (NPR). Among the identifiers are driving licence and Aadhaar, Permanent Account Number and voter ID cards.

Senior officials in the Census department have undergone training for the work during the past three months. “We have completed our training and are awaiting official orders from the government,” an official said on Friday.

The nationwide NPR is supposed to be held from April 1 to September 30 to record the “usual residents” of the country who have lived in an area for the past six months or more or people who intend to stay there for the next six months or more, an official notification stated.

In Maharashtra, the drive was supposed to start in May and end by June. However, Congress cabinet minister Varsha Gaikwad earlier this week issued a statement that the Maha Vikas Aghadi would not allow the rollout of the drive for the NPR in May.

Several state governments have stopped work on the NPR, claiming that it was the first step toward the National Register of Citizens (NRC) that would be used in conjunction with the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA). A group of 106 retired civil servants from across the country on Thursday put out an open letter on the social media stating that the CAA, NRC and the NPR could not be delinked as per the government’s claim.

The Census involves collection information about all residents of India without listing their names, the NPR is a list of names of all those who have lived in India for over six months, regardless of their nationality. A population register will contain the list of people usually residing within a specified local area (village/town/ward/demarcated area).

Title: Civic body chief inaugurates public toilet renovated under CSR activity
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

The refurbished corporation toilet near Panagal Park at T Nagar that was inaugurated on Friday

CHENNAI: After a meeting with representatives from banks and private businesses, the corporation has decided to allow business organisations to manage public toilets in the city under the corporate social responsibility ( CSR ) activity.

Commissioner G Prakash on Friday inaugurated one such toilet near Panagal Park in T Nagar.

It had been renovated by Star Health Insurance at an estimated cost of Rs 7lakh.

According to officials, ceiling leaks were arrested, flooring reinforced and new water pipelines were fitted in the toilet. The facility will be managed by a private agency for three years.

“The renovated facility has a separate room for breastfeeding and sanitary pad vending machines,” an official said.

Corporation officials said there are 7,888 public toilets at 1,245 locations and public sector banks and private firms can approach the civic body after selecting a toilet they wish to renovate and maintain, by going through www.chennaicorporation.gov.in.

Banks which deploy CSR funds for maintenance of public toilets will also be given space to install ATM machines and private firms can use the space for advertising as per the norms prescribed by the government, according to corporation.

Title: Cyber cheating FIRs flood Ahmedabad police stations
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A day before the state home department’s scheduled launch of ‘Cyber Aashvast’ (Assured Assistance Service Helpline for Victims At Shortest Time), on Thursday and Friday, city police stations were flooded with complaints of cyber fraud. Police stations in Ahmedabad district also registered multiple such complaints.

In Ahmedabad city, as many as 40 FIRs of cyber frauds were registered. The highest amount stolen was from the account of a Chandkheda-based man. Though he had filed the application to lodge FIR on May 22, 2019, the FIR was registered on Thursday.

The complainant, Kiran Darji, 37, a driver with a taxi company, said that he had in May last year searched on Google to learn about luggage allowed on an Air India flight. After a while, a man called Darji and said that if he pays Rs 99, he could take as much luggage as he wants.

As Darji’s mother was supposed to go to Canada, he readily paid the money. The man sent Darji a link for a survey and told him to pay the money after completing the form. After Darji submitted the survey, Rs 1.38 lakh wa

s stolen from his account. At least four complaints were about fraudsters introducing themselves as Paytm executives. They took details from the customers and then stole their money.

Title: Campus rift out in open as Centre sacks Amethi aviation university registrar
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

LUCKNOW: Union ministry of civil aviation has sacked Amethi-based Rajiv Gandhi National Aviation University (RGNAU) registrar Jitendra Singh with immediate effect. Singh has been replaced by Garima Singh, who holds the director’s position in the civil aviation ministry.

The order (a copy of which is with TOI), issued on Wednesday by under-secretary of the ministry Kameshwar Mishra, stated: “Order of the competent authority is hereby conveyed for the termination of probation of Jitendra Singh, registrar, RGNAU, with immediate effect. Singh, accordingly, stands removed and relieved from the position of the registrar with immediate effect.”

The order added that Singh was directed to vacate the office immediately and his official residence within seven days. Singh, the first registrar of RGNAU, was appointed by the President in April last year. The university, the first of its kind, commenced its academic session in August last year.

As per the order, Garima has been appointed as acting registrar till further notice. She would be serving in RGNAU in addition to her existing duties and responsibilities in the ministry, read the order.

According to reports, RGNAU acting vice-chancellor Amber Dubey, who is also a joint secretary in the ministry, entered the campus along with police personnel and Garima on Thursday and asked Singh to immediately vacate the office.

Circle Officer Tiloi Raj Kumar Singh told TOI that he had orders from his seniors to accompany Dubey. “It was the university’s internal matter. We were asked to accompany them to ensure law and order on campus,” he said.

When TOI contacted Singh, he said, “My termination is illegal and unconstitutional as no notice was served and no grounds were given.”

Singh alleged that several irregularities had been prevailing on the campus but Dubey was not paying heed to them.

Dubey had taken charge after the university’s former VC Nalin Tandon tendered his resignation on November 1 last year.

Title: Hyderabad: Pharmacist gets 10-year jail for rape
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

Title: Now, view Atal statue every Sunday
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Lucknow: General public will be permitted inside the Lok Bhawan on Vidhan Sabha Marg to see the 25-feet high bronze statue of former PM Atal Bihari Vajpayee from January 12. Chief minister Yogi Adityanath said the government office premises will be opened up for people from 10am to 5pm every Sunday.

“The decision has been taken to allow people to pay their respects to their beloved leader,” the CM said. Vajpayee’s statue was inaugurated by PM Narendra Modi on December 25 last year on Vajpayee’s 94th birth anniversary. The former PM and MP from Lucknow died in 2018.

His statue was built in Jaipur and has been installed at the entrance of the Lok Bhawan which houses the CM’s office. The culture department sanctioned the work of construction of the statue to M/s Words for Artist Foundary, Jaipur through a letter dated March 9, 2019. Rs 89.60 lakh was sanctioned for its construction.

Title: Pune: IT professional duped in job fraud
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Airport police on Thursday booked cybercrooks for duping an IT professional of over Rs4.22 lakh on the pretext of offering him a job between May 24 and November 15.

The 52-year-old Vimannagar resident had uploaded his profile on a job portal. On May 24, the cyber crooks called and offered him a job. They also sent him a link to pay a ‘registration fee’ of Rs6,995. The unemployed man clicked the link without verifying the sender’s credential and transferred the money, the police said.

The next day, the crooks offered him a job in an IT company and asked him to pay Rs45,000 as security deposit and provided him a link. The complainant transferred the required money into their bank account.

On May 29, the crooks took his interview for the post of service delivery manager. They later send him an e-mail stating that he had passed the interview following which he mailed them his documents as per their request, police said. Over 12 similar transactions,

the job seeker deposited over Rs4.22 lakh but he failed to get job. Eventually, he realized that he had been tricked. After recording his complaint, the cyber crime police transferred the investigations to the Airport police station for further action.

Title: Hyderabad: Man gets seven-year jail for dowry
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: LB Nagar court, on Friday, sentenced a man, Nagesh , and his parents to seven years’ and two years’ imprisonment, respectively, in a dowry harassment case. Nagesh’s wife had committed suicide in 2015 due to dowry harassment.

In 2015, Nagesh’s wife Lalitha committed suicide by hanging herself at her house in LB Nagar. The police had filed a chargesheet against the three accused. The court pronounced the sentence on Friday.

Title: Nashik: 23-year-old booked for selling nylon manja
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The city police have booked a 23-year-old youth for selling nylon manja and have confiscated the banned product worth Rs 7,000 from him.

The nylon manja (string) is used for flying kites . The sale of manja, however, has been banned in the city for various reasons and strict action is being taken against those selling nylon manja.

On Wednesday at around 8 pm, the Bhadrakali police received a tip-off about a person selling nylon manja in front of the Nanawali Masjid in the Bhadrakali area. Taking serious cognizance of the information, police laid a trap and caught the suspect red-handed.

They confiscated manja worth Rs 7,000 from the suspect and booked him under various sections of the Indian Penal Code.

The action was conducted under the guidance of commissioner of police Vishwas Nangre-Patil and deputy commissioner of police Amol Tambe.

Bhadrakali police said that the commissioner has instructed police officials to conduct patrolling by foot in the morning and evening hours in their respective jurisdictions.

Police said that the action against people selling nylon manja was necessary as the product is extremely dangerous and can cause serious injury. With the festival of Makar Sankranti around the corner, revellers throng city markets for buying kites and manja. Police said that their only concern was to ensure that people do not buy nylon manja as its sale and use is banned.

Police officials also said that their action against the banned product will continue. They also said that, last year, they had sent decoy customers in civil uniforms to various shops to check if nylon manja was sold anywhere.

In addition, police will also keep an eye on revellers to see if anyone is buying or using the banned product.

Title: Nine years on, potholes to remain on nine roads for a few more months
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Motorists are left to face pothole menace and bad surface layer on nine roads for the last nine years due to the Nagpur Municipal Corporation ’s (NMC) inordinate delay in completion of phase-I of Cement Concrete Road Project and early exit of contractor Mumbai-based Unity Infraprojects Pvt Ltd.

They will have to wait for a few more months as the qualified contractor — Kamptee-based Abhi Engineering — has refused to accept work order due to delay by the NMC in issuing it.

The NMC’s projects department tabled a proposal before the standing committee seeking approval to offer work to second followed by third lowest bidders Mahalsa Constructions and JP Enterprises, respectively, or go for re-tender in case the two companies refused to work on the rate quoted by Abhi Engineering. The committee will take a decision on the proposal in a meeting on January 14.

As per the proposal, Abhi Engineering refused to execute the work on December 12, 2019, citing inordinate delay from the NMC. Financial bids in the tender were opened on August 6, 2019. As per rules, the department has to take approval of the standing committee and issue letter of acceptance (LoA) to qualified contractor within 120 days from opening of bids.

The department tabled the proposal seeking the standing committee’s approval on September 5, 2019. But the committee delayed giving approval for reasons best known to it.

Standing committee chairman Pradip Pohane told TOI that all efforts will be taken to begin works at the earliest. “Approval was delayed due to code of conduct for assembly elections,” he said.

The chances of other two bidders taking the work at the rate quoted by Abhi Engineering seem bleak. Abhi Engineering has quoted Rs35.50 crore, Mahalsa Constructions Rs47.17 crore and JP Enterprises Rs 51 crore. The works on nine roads are difficult to execute as they require shifting of utilities. Besides, there are problems of land acquisition and removal of encroachments.

The NMC had appointed Unity to concretize 30 roads with a length of 26.84km on June 6, 2011, with a deadline of two years. But it could concretize only 20 roads till January 2019. Citing liquidation, Unity had obtained early exit from the project in March.

Due to pending concretization work, the NMC did not asphalt nine roads and is doing patch works for the last nine years. These roads comprise potholes and bad surface layer. Now, the NMC will take some more months to finalize the contractor, followed by deadline of three years.

Title: Tamil Nadu: 5 feet-long dugong washes ashore
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Over 5 feet long dugong washed ashore dead on Friday near Kottaipattinnam coast in Pudukottai district

TRICHY: A dead dugong , an aquatic mammal, which was more than five feet long, washed ashore on Friday near Kottaipattinnam coast in Pudukottai district on Friday.

The fishermen informed forest department after they found the carcass of the female dugong, which weighed around 270 kg, on Friday. Forest officials estimated its age to be about 9 to10 years.

They suspect it to have sustained injuries after being hit by a fishing trawler, which eventually led to its death.We have found injury mark on its back, said a senior official from the forest department. While postmortem was conducted by a medical team and the carcass was safely buried, we are awaiting a detailed postmortem report to ascertain reason for its death, said the official.

Title: Charusat convocation today
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Vadodara/ Anand: The 9th convocation of Changa-based Charotar University of Science and Technology (CHARUSAT) in Anand district will be held on Saturday.

Kerala governor Arif Mohammed Khan, who had earlier served as a cabinet minister in the union government, will be the chief guest and deliver the convocation address. Renowned American writer Dr George Musser will be the guest of honour for the occasion.

Students who will graduate in various disciplines will be felicitated during the ceremony. In total 2,048 students of different disciplines including 37 gold medal holders will be awarded degrees during the convocation function that will be organised at the campus.

These include 241 students of Faculty of Medical Sciences, 252 students of Faculty of Computer Sciences, 175 students of Faculty of Management Studies, 119 students of Faculty of Pharmacy, 279 students of Faculty of Applied Sciences and 949 students of six different branches of Faculty of Technology and Engineering including 33 PhD graduates.

Usually, graduates are awarded gold-plated medals but at CHARUSAT, all the medals are real gold medals. The university campus presently accommodates over 7,500 students and 368 faculty members.

Title: Regular inspection, upkeep of temples must, say experts
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Hyderabad: Heritage experts on Friday called for periodic inspection and maintenance of temples as a step towards preservation of heritage structures. Speaking at a conference on the ‘Dynamics of Hindu Temple Architecture’ in the city on Friday, conservation architect SP Anchuri said, “Inspections must be carried out every three to six months at temples.” To ensure there is no neglect, he suggested that the endowments department constitute a technical team to oversee preservation of the temples along with the managements.

“Most of these temples built thousands of years ago with stone and wood are stable by themselves, but human activity and natural calamities disturb this. Often the reduction of water table results in the sinking of temples,” said Anchuri.

Citing the example of the Thousand Pillar Temple, which required foundation work, he said that the original technology must be studied for any restoration process. The conservation architect also said that human interventions such as the provision of lighting or cooling systems in temples must be done in a way that does not mess with the heritage structures.

Anuradha Reddy, convenor, INTACH Hyderabad, said, “in the name of development, the identity of Telangana temples is being lost.” She said Dravidian elements are being included where such influence does not exist. “We see enamel being put, bathroom tiles being used and holes being drilled into granite at several temples. Pilgrim facilities where natural light and ventilation were the norm, are being transformed with air conditioning and artificial lighting,” she added.

Speaking of the Sitaram Bagh temple and the diversity of influence, she said, “The temple has Qutb Shahi, Rajasthani and local influence. Most temples in the state have no single style of architecture.”

Reddy, who has been recording temple architecture across the state, also warned that there is “little information on Telangana temples and more needs to be done in this regard.”

Title: Mumbai doctor cheats tour operator of Rs 1.8 lakh
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A CG Road-based tour operator on Thursday filed a complaint of cheating against a Mumbai-based doctor, for cheating him of Rs 1.89 lakh by availing of six domestic and four international air tickets in December 2017, for which he never paid.

In his FIR with Satellite police, Atish Nikumbh, 40, a resident of Satellite, said he runs a ticket booking business and most of his bookings happen over the phone. On December 24, 2017, Nikumbh got a call from the accused, who identified himself as Dr Ashish Sharma and said that he lives at Ballard (east) in Mumbai. “He told me that he needs six tickets from Goa to Mumbai, one ticket from Mumbai to New Zealand, two tickets from Mumbai to Oakland and one ticket from Delhi to China for his friends,” said Nikumbh in his FIR. The fare for these tickets was a total of Rs 1.89 lakh. Sharma told Nikumbh that he would pay for the tickets before December 25, 2017, but did not do so. Whenever Nikumbh asked him for the money, Sharma made some excuse or the other and did not pay any money. Nikumbh later learned that Sharma had cheated other tour operators as well. He then approached Satellite police and filed a complaint of breach of trust, cheating and criminal conspiracy. tnn

Title: Local experts to be roped-in for new gazetteer
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Nashik: District collector Suraj Mandhare has decided to come with the latest gazetteer reflecting the true identity of modern Nashik to attract foreign investments in the state.

After the first gazette was published by the British in 1883, the district administration published the second gazetteer in 1975 with some changes. “A comprehensive document featuring modern Nashik – is missing and hence we have decided to bring a new gazetteer which will attract foreign investments in this part of the state,” Mandhare told TOI.

The gazetteer to be published now will take everything in its stride right up to the modern-day. “All this information will be packed and presented to the visiting dignitaries who go by the government information about the particular region,” he said.

The collector will call upon the citizens to contribute to history, geography, local economy, phases of agriculture, climate, industries, art, culture, forest, and rivers, the specialties of the locals and their traditions and ethos, and the education sector of the city.

On preparation of the gazette, the officer said that a district-level the committee has been formed to collect, validate and moderate the information received from the contributors and include the same only after thoroughly examining the facts and eliminating the controversies. “Often when the foreign delegates visit Maharashtra, the best thing they rely on is on the gazetteer. If the document is 45 years old just imagine what could be the information they were getting. We have therefore in our meeting asked the people to come up with the authentic data on various parameters including health and water conditions which will speak about the quality of life in the region,” the collector said.

The district committee has met for the first time on the agenda and chalked out some plans for the same. In the next meeting, the committee will assign responsibilities and time-line before which the gazetteer has to be completed.

The gazetteer is excepted to be published in two volumes with each having 1600 pages. It will have 12 different topics including agriculture, tourism, economy, etc.

Title: History sheeter nabbed, huge haul of gold, silver recovered
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Yavatmal: Sleuths of Yavatmal’s LCB have arrested a history sheeter from Pusad and recovered a huge haul of gold and silver ornaments from him.

At a press conference held at the police headquarters on Friday, SP M. Rajkumar said that LCB chief Pradeep Siraskar and two APIs, Nilesh Shelke and Shrikant Jidamwar, nabbed notorious history sheeter Firoz khan alias Rando Saheb Khan from his residence on January 4. The police team recovered 309 grams of gold ornaments, 2400 grams of silver items, Rs1750 in cash and a bike collectively worth Rs.14.5 lakh.

The accused was in police custody remand till January 9. On Friday, he was awarded magisterial custody remand by the court.

During interrogation, the accused confessed to committing crimes under the jurisdiction of the Yavatmal city police, Awadootwadi, Arni, Mahagaon, Pusad, Digras, Darwha, Kalamb and Umarkhed police stations.

The break up of the criminal offences registered against the accused at various police stations is — Yavatmal city (5), Awadootwadi (8), Arni and Mahagaon (2 each) and Pusad, Digras, Darwha, Kalamb and Umarkhed (1 each).

According to the SP, at least 50 offences were registered against the accused of which 28 offences were registered in the neighbouring Adilabad district of Telangana.

The accused hired rooms in Yavatmal, Pusad, Buldhana and Hyderabad and moved from one place to another according to his convenience. He committed thefts in Nanded, Parbhani and Hingoli also. The details are yet to be obtained.

Firoz Khan (29), a resident of Tukaram Bapu Ward of Pusad in Yavatmal district, seems to be a one man army who committed burglaries and thefts single-handedly, said the LCB chief Siraskar. Further investigation is under way.

Title: Trains & buses burst at the seams, passengers rue poor arrangements
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

With Sankranti just a few days away, most trains and buses, especially those heading to Andhra Pradesh, are se... Read More

HYDERABAD: With Sankranti just a few days away, most trains and buses, especially those heading to Andhra Pradesh, are seeing a heavy surge in passengers. Passengers complain that the arrangements are insufficient despite announcements by South Central Railway (SCR) of running special trains and buses.

M Rama Raju, who goes to Kakinada each year, said, “Most buses and trains are full or have long waiting lists. I have been trying to book my seats for the past one week, but no tickets are available.”

Another passenger, Harish Kumar, who booked train tickets two months ago, is still on the waiting list. “I booked two tickets in 3AC and my tickets are still not confirmed.”

This year, Telangana State Road Transport Corporation (TSRTC) introduced 4,000 special buses, while SCR is running 442 special trains between various destinations of the zone from January 5 to 25. Officials from TSRTC said that people travelling to their hometowns have increased compared to last year.

“Since many people couldn’t go to their hometowns during Dussehra because of RTC strike, the number of bookings is more for Sankranti,” said J Devadanam, TSRTC divisional manager, Kukatpally.

Meanwhile, the number of passengers in Secunderabad , Kacheguda and Nampally stations have increased considerably in the past couple of days. “Compared to last year, we are operating 200 additional trains this time. There are 74 Janasandhran specials, 41 Suvidha specials and 327 other special trains. These trains are mainly run towards Kakinada, Vijayawada , Vishakapatnam, Vizianagaram, Machlipuram, Naded, Raichur and other places,” said an SCR spokesperson.

Title: Men barge into home, beat 52-yr-old woman to death
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Allahabad: A 52-year-old woman died after she and her partner were brutally attacked at their home by two unidentified men in Lohgara village, under Bara police station, late Thursday night.

Police said that the deceased was identified as Sunita, while her husband Lalmani Kushwaha is undergoing treatment at hospital.

Lalmani told police that the accused attacked Sunita with sticks and rods around 1am, when she had gone to open the main door of the house when someone called them from outside the house.

“When she went to open the main gate, two unidentified armed men attacked her on the head, leaving her critically injured,” said SSP Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj.

“The men also thrashed Lalmani, when he tried to save Sunita,” the SSP added.

Local residents rushed the two to the hospital, but Sunita was declared brought dead.

“Sunita and Lalmani were not married and the former had left her husband around 20 years back. The two had been living together ever since. Lalmani too had left his wife around 23 years back and had two sons with her,” said the SSP. Police, however, said that the family of the deceased claimed that the two were married.

Pankaj said, “Sunita did not get along with Lalmani’s two daughter-in-laws. A police team has been assigned the case.”

A a case under sections 302, 34 and 323 of the IPC has been lodged at Bara police station against two unidentified persons on the basis of a complaint by Lalmani. No arrests have been made in the case so far.

Title: Dist admin issues DO letter over lack of data on plantation
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Nashik: The district administration, taking strong note of the failure of several government offices in providing data of survival of the saplings planted during monsoon despite reminders, has served a demi-official ( DO ) letter warning of strict action on Monday.

“A letter has been sent by district collector Suraj Mandhare, who is also the president of district committee on plantations, after the offices failed to report the data on plantations carried out in monsoon,” a senior official from the district administration stated.

The DO letter has been issued to Nashik and Malegaon Municipal Corporations, public works department, water resources department, project officer tribal department (Nashik), Commissioner Sales Tax, superintendent of state excise department, among others.

Generally, DO is an ultimatum issued by a senior office to others in case of failure of the respective offices to comply by the orders, letters and reminders sent before.

Under ministry of forest’s ambitious 33 crore plantation programme, 1.97 crore plantation target was assigned to Nashik in which all government departments were asked to participate.

As per the programme, the departments were expected to provide detailed information about plantations carried out by them and the survival of the same to the district committee headed by the district collector.

The BJP government from 2014-19 had drawn up the plan for planting 33 crore saplings across the district under the stewardship of state forest minister Sudhir Mungantiwar.

In all 35 government departments, including collectorate, local civic bodies, zilla parishad offices and departments, among others, were given the task that was to be carried out from July to October.

By the end of October, the departments were expected to report their data of plantation and the survival statistics as well. However barring a few departments, many have failed to send their reports.

Title: Capital conundrum: AP drops KRMB office shift demand
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Hyderabad: The AP government, which has been demanding shifting of Krishna River Management Board (KRMB) office to Vijayawada, seems to have dropped the demand for now as it is grappling with protests over CM Jaganmohan Reddy ’s three-capital proposal. The YSRCP government, which proposed capitals at Vijayawada, Visakhapatnam and Kurnool, on Thursday did not seek shifting of KRMB office as tri-capital proposal was being examined by a committee.

KRMB chairman RK Gupta decided to take up office shift issue after getting clarity on capitals. AP government has been demanding KRMB office be located in their state as a major portion of the Krishna basin is in their territory.

Telangana chief secretary Somesh Kumar, AP special chief secretary Adityanas Das and irrigation officials from both states attended the meeting. “Telangana is likely to get 140 tmcft of Krishna water, while AP 84 tmcft for both irrigation and drinking water purposes till May,” sources said. KRMB might issue formal order on Friday.

Official sources said the Board members discussed accounting of excess water (flood water) about 130 tmcft used by AP in the past few months. While AP government’s argument was flood water cannot be considered excess water, Telangana said flood water drawn from major projects such as Srisailam, Nagarjunasagar, Pulichintala and Jurala were located on the main bund and would not be taken into consideration, but AP government had drawn water from other sources. “Both states agreed to discuss the issue during Telangana and AP CMs’ meeting scheduled to be held on January 13 or constitute a sub-committee to decide,” a senior irrigation department official from Telangana said.

Telangana urged KRMB to consider 20% allocation made for drinking water purpose as regenerated water, being used for drinking water purposes in Hyderabad. KRMB authorities reportedly informed the two sides that the issue would be referred to Central Water Commission (CWC). The meeting also discussed water diversion to right canal from Polavaram and cross bunds constructed on Nagarjunasagar left canal.

Title: Lucknow: Every second commercial building in Indiranagar illegal
Content:
According to Lucknow Development Authority (LDA) records, there are 221 commercial units and shops in Indirana... Read More

LUCKNOW: Safety is largely compromised in elite Indiranagar where every second commercial building is illegal. They violate the construction code either fully or partly, putting thousands of lives at grave risk every day.According to Lucknow Development Authority (LDA) records, there are 221 commercial units and shops in Indiranagar. Of these, 136 or more than 61% have been declared illegal in the past three years because they ignored LDA rules and have no fire department NOC.While notices were served to all along with demolition warning, the LDA thereafter failed to act. Now, its new vice-chairman Shiwa Kant Dwivedi has ordered a probe into why action was not taken against unauthorised constructions, directing officials to issue fresh notices.A TOI reality check revealed that fire safety was questionable in most of these commercial complexes, which also allowed shops to operate from basements meant for parking. As a result, people park vehicles on the road, leading to traffic snarls.In Sector 10, a five-storey shopping complex had fire safety equipment only at the owner’s office. “Scores of people visit this place daily. Such negligence can cost lives,” said Upendra, a shopper.Yet another shopping compex on Takrohi Road in Sector 14 was found without mandatory blaze battling equipment. “A fire in one shop can burn down the whole building. We risk our lives to work here. The owner doesn’t pay heed to our pleas,” said Krishna Ranjan, a shopkeeper.At another shoppers’ stop near Lekhraj market, live wires were found dangling everywhere. “These are death traps. Despite complaints, no action has been taken by the owner, I hear,” said Kamal, a customer.At the same building, shops also run from the basement. “Customers park their vehicles on the pavement or along the carriageway. When shopper footfall is high inside, there is severe traffic congestion outside,” said Pawan Chaurasiya, a commuter. LDA chief engineer Indu Shekhar Singh said the process to serve “final notices” to all these commercial units had begun. “The process will take a month. Thereafter, we will give seven days to take corrective measures before starting a demolition drive,” he added.

Title: Experts guide school principals on various issues
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: The annual meet and workshop of an association representing school principals on Thursday resolved to focus on child security as well empowering its members to prepare students for government scholarships exams.

School Headmasters Charitable Association ( SHCA ) invited various subject experts, including city cops, RTI activists and education officials to guide principals at the workshop.

Zafar Khan, founder-president of SHCA, said, “This is the seventh edition of our annual meet and workshop where our aim is to make principals aware of various issues that they face as administrators and make them able to take crucial decisions. Also, we have made it our mission to prepare students for scholarship exams like National Talent Search (NTS) and National Means cum Merit Scholarship ( NMMS ).”

Shivling Patve, education officer (secondary) for Nagpur district, said, “NMMS and NTS used to get high number of applicants from Nagpur, but that’s not the case anymore. Schools must try to create awareness about these important exams as they help students to prepare for competitive exams later on in life. Students are looking at a scholarship of Rs1,000 per month through these exams.”

To take this forward, Khan said another workshop will be held to make schools aware of NMMS and NTS. “We have now made it our mission and will be roping in NGOs to help pay the exam fee of any student who is unable to do so,” said Khan.

For safety and security of children inside schools, senior police inspector Ashok Bagul said it was important for principals to be aware of the law. “To hit a child is crime, be it a teacher or parent. There must be complete clarity on this among principals. It’s not like when we were kids and our teachers would wallop us without anybody batting an eyelid,” said Bagul.

Umesh Rathod, deputy education officer, talked about responsibilities of principals. “It is important for schools to follow procedure for everything, right from correspondence to hiring personnel and maintaining records,” said Rathod.

RTI expert and trainer Naveen Agarwal spoke to principals about the laws governing it. He talked about the responsibility of the school after it receives an RTI application and gave details about the timeline, type of information to be given and records to be kept.

SHCA secretary Dilip Bose and treasurer Sundip Gaikwad said that the association will continue to organize more workshops and facilitate interaction between their members and experts from various domains.

Title: Kamal Haasan urges Rajinikanth to help Tamil Nadu develop
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Kamal Haasan

CHENNAI: Actor and MNM president Kamal Haasan on Friday continued to nudge ‘superstar’ Rajinikanth to partake in the process to develop Tamil Nadu .

“Every citizen and Tamils have a role and responsibility in the development of Tamil Nadu,” Kamal Haasan told reporters. By virtue of being a citizen, Rajinikanth too has a responsibility to play his role to develop the state, Kamal added.

The MNM chief was taking off from where he left on Thursday, when he suggested that Rajinikanth had a larger role to play in TN’s development, while participating in a media event.

Towards the end of last year, both Kamal Hassan and Rajinikanth had said they would join hands, if need be, politically, for the betterment of Tamil Nadu. While Kamal launched his political party in early 2018, Rajinikanth, vowed on December 31, 2017, to take the political plunge in time for the assembly election in the state, which is scheduled to be held in the summer of 2021.

Title: Over 70.16 lakh trees felled in Maharashtra during last five years
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Even as the Indian State of Forest Report (ISFR)-2019 has revealed that Maharashtra topped the chart by having maximum tree cover, information sought under RTI reveals that in the last five years, 5,74,276 trees have been felled illegally and 64,42,401 with permission from tree officers.

According to information received under RTI by activist Abhay Kolarkar, 70,16,677 trees were felled in the state from 2015-2019. Of this, 5,74,276 were felled illicitly, which include 1,73,941 teak trees. The value of the green cover loss has been estimated at Rs26.04 crore. This doesn’t include the huge environment loss.

The data on illicit felling is up to September 2019. If the remaining three months till December 2019 were to be considered, the loss could be even more.

Similarly, permission to fell over 64,42,401 trees towards 69,412 cases was granted by range forest officers (RFOs) to private parties. Of these, over 43,66,790 were teak trees.

Interestingly, the figures don’t include thousands of trees that have been felled for various developmental projects in recorded forest areas (RFAs).

“The large-scale felling, both illicit and legal, exposes the state forest department’s indifferent attitude towards destruction of precious green cover. The RFOs, who act as tree officers under Maharashtra Felling of Trees (Regulation) Act, 1964, have to ensure that two trees are planted for every tree felled. But, forest officials never ensure whether compensatory plantation has been done or not by private parties,” charged Kolarkar.

“There is no system of checking whether each individual is planting trees in lieu of felled trees. Forest department too doesn’t have any information in respect of compensatory plantation under the said Act,” adds Kolarkar.

This is a huge loss despite spending several crores on salaries of protection force of the department. Almost all divisions are having mobile squads, along with armed constables from police department, he says.

“Even arms have been provided in most of the sensitive divisions. During the period under consideration (2015-19), more than 200 vehicles have been provided to the department and now almost all territorial divisions have independent vehicle. Yet, illicit felling is rampant,” alleged Kolarkar.

The RTI activist says information on tree felling is just the tip of the iceberg. There may be many cases where action is not taken by the department staff and many incidents may have gone unnoticed.

The latest report by Forest Survey of India (FSI) has stated that tree cover in Maharashtra has increased by 915sqkm compared to last report released in 2017.

Title: CCTV surveillance helped bring down crime in city
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Vadodara: The end of 2019 has brought some good news for the city police. The data for the year revealed that the occurrence of serious crimes registered under the Indian Penal Code (IPC) in the city had gone down significantly even as cheating offences registered a minor rise.

Details compiled by the city police regarding various offences registered in the city reveals that there was a fall of 6.25% in offences registered in the city. Against 3,009 offences registered in 2018, the number of offences registered in 2019 stood at 2,821 – lower by 188 offences.

What will come as a major relief to the city police is the fact that offences like housebreaks and robberies including chain snatching that had become a major headache in the past had gone down significantly. These coupled with burglaries were amongst major embarrassments for the city police in the past.

Apart from other offences, the number of cases of abduction that were largely of elopement, people being taken away to recover money and of children going missing had also come down. The incidents of attacks on government servants had also declined in 2019 as compared to the previous year.

A major reason for the fall is said to be CCTV surveillance that has increased significantly in the city. Sources said that another factor that deterred offenders was that several offences that took place during the year were detected promptly. The city police detected five dacoity cases, 37 robbery cases, 70 burglaries and 275 theft cases during the year. As many as 30 chain snatching cases were also detected.

Another reason for the reduction in crime is said to be the effective detention of habitual offenders under the Prevention of Anti-Social Activities Act (PASA). In all, 179 persons ere detained under PASA and the figure was higher by 30% in 2019 as compared to 2018.

Title: Maharashtra will soon clear funds for Nashik-Pune railway track: Hemant Godse
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

NASHIK: Hemant Godse, Member of Parliament from Nashik , on Friday said that the state government will soon give its consent for financing the Nashik-Pune railway double track project — the detailed project report for which has already been submitted.

Godse said that he has requested the state transport minister Anil Parab for expediting the process of construction of the railway track following which the latter has assured to look into the matter at the earliest.

“A detailed project report (DPR) is ready with the Maharashtra Rail Infrastructure Development Corporation Limited and only the state government’s nod is required so that the central government can take up the steps to start the construction of the track on priority basis,” Godse said.

“I met the transport minister to draw his attention towards the fact that people from Nashik and Pune are eagerly waiting for sanctioning of the track,” he added.

The semi high-speed double track project is expected to cost around Rs 16,039 crore. The construction is expected to begin in the current year and will require 1,200 days for completion.

Nashik, Pune and Mumbai is a triangle and Nashik-Pune rail link will open up faster connectivity between Northern and Southern states of the country not only for the passengers, but also for movement of goods.

“While the state government had given in principle approval few years ago, the central government had approved Rs 200 crore for preparation of the DPR in the year 2017-18,” Godse said.

Of the total cost of Rs 16,039 crore for the construction of the track, the state government’s share is of 20%. A good chunk of money will also be raised through private financiers.

Nashik-Pune double track will bring faster connectivity between the two cities. Not only the travelling time between Nashik and Pune will be reduced to less than two hours, but at the same time the North South trains that currently take the route via Kalyan will have an alternate route to travel on.

Title: Now, direct flight to connect Allahabad with Gorakhpur
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

The flight, which is being operated under the Regional Connectivity Scheme (RCS) routes, is being operated by ... Read More

ALLAHABAD: After direct air connectivity with six cities, Allahabad will now have a direct flight to Gorakhpur .

The ceremonial event marking the inauguration of the flight for Gorakhpur was held at the civil enclave of Bamrauli on Friday.

The flight, which is being operated under the Regional Connectivity Scheme (RCS) routes, is being operated by IndiGo. With the base fare of Rs 999, the flight would operate for all the seven days of the week.

The flight would leave for Gorakhpur at 01:10 pm and would land at 02:20pm. While coming to Allahabad, the flight would take off at 11:40am and land at 12:40 noon.

Presently, the city has direct air connectivity with Mumbai, Ahmedabad, Bengaluru, Raipur, Kolkata and Delhi.

State minister for civil aviation Nand Gopal Gupta Nandi, while inaugurating the maiden flight from Allahabad, assured that soon the city would have direct flight for Pune owning to high demand. He also said that talks are on for starting the flight for Haj from the city.

A total of 25 passengers arrived in Sangam city from Gorakhpur on Friday while 35 took the return flight.

Title: Kanpur: Police to attach properties of 28 identified rioters
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

File photo of violence during anti-CAA protest in the city

KANPUR: Police have decided to attach moveable and immovable properties of as many as 28 suspects who have been absconding since the incidents of violence and arson occurred during anti-CAA stir on December 20 and 21 in Babupurwa and Yateemkhana areas of the city. Police have also announced a reward on rioters who are absconding.

“In Babupurwa area, out of 39 rioters, 17 have been identified as absconders, while in the Yateemkhana area of the 28, nearly 11 identified rioters are absconding,” said IG Mohit Agarwal and added that the absconders are adopting unethical ways to evade arrest.

“As per the procedure, the police will move an application under relevant sections of the CrPC before the court for proclaiming a suspect to be an absconder after which the court will issue a notice to the absconder. The notice has a window period of 30 days, giving a final chance to the suspect to either surrender to the police and cooperate in the ongoing investigation registered against him/her or challenge the said notice in the court. Under this process, the notice is given to the immediate kin of the suspect, and it is also pasted on the house,” said a senior police official.

After the lapse of the notice period, another application is moved under relevant sections of the CrPC before the court, seeking permission to attach the assets of the absconding suspect and it is usually granted within a day.

“Despite running out of all legal remedies, these 28 suspects wanted by the different police stations, continue to evade arrest, forcing us to deal the cases with an iron hand”, the IG said.

As part of the process, police will collect data of movable and immovable assets registered in the name of listed suspects from the regional transport office and registrar of properties, and will also declare reward on absconding identified rioters, he added.

Title: Newborn screening to detect defects is a must, say experts
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

NAGPUR: Every newborn should be screened for defects like hearing loss, congenital hypothyroidism , congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) and glucose-6 deficiency.

Defects like hearing loss can be detected at the earliest during newborn screening. This ensures timely cochlear implant and good quality of life to kids born with deafness.

Expert doctors in the field of ear, nose, throat as well as head and neck surgeries — termed as otolaryngologists are holding a national conference in Nagpur. They said that neonatal screening is integral part of childcare in many countries just like immunization.

“Early detection and early cochlear implant ensures best results and less struggle for kids to join the mainstream,” said Dr Satya Prakash Dubey, national president of Association of Otolaryngologists of India (AOI).

“Government can make it compulsory to screen all babies at least for hearing loss. In Indian conditions, it takes two to four years to detect hearing loss in kids. This delays cochlear implant. Subsequently, it delays auditory verbal therapy which is must for kids undergoing cochlear implant,” said Dr Dubey.

Prof Niel Tolley, pioneer of robotic head and neck surgery in the UK, said head and neck surgeries have become very accurate with effective use of artificial intervention technique.

“Robotics have added accuracy to the otherwise complicated head and neck surgeries. We can avoid risks to brain nerves and paralysis,” he said.

Prof Tolley, along with Nagpur’s Dr Madan Kapre, has performed several thyroid surgeries on children in Melghat and he is well-versed with Indian conditions.

Prof Gregory Randolph, from Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, said risks like loss of voice after thyroid operations have become negligible with the new technique.

Surgeons coming from all parts of the country were surprised to know that progressive state like Maharashtra is yet to start state programme to treat kids with hearing loss.

“As many as 12 states in the country run specific programmes through which funds are allotted to needy patients to undergo cochlear implant surgeries. These surgeries are still not covered under Ayushman Bharat. Assistance to Disabled Persons for Purchase Appliances (ADIP scheme) has its own limitations. As these surgeries are complicated and costly, government support is a must,” said Dr Sanjay Agrawal from Indore. He said Madhya Pradesh government has funded the cochlear implants under Bal Shravan Yojana and performed 4,000 free surgeries in last four years.

Title: Gujarat high court paves way to regularize co-operative land that was last bought by farmers
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Gujarat high court

AHMEDABAD: A division bench of the Gujarat high court on Thursday cleared the way for regularization of land parcels held by cooperatives that were last last bought by farmers. Most of these land parcels are reported to be held by builders in the name of farmers and co-operative societies. The division bench upheld an order junking the state government’s 2017 circular, by which it restrained regularization of such land, in the interest of farmers.

The case pertains to land parcels in Ognaj village on the outskirts of Ahmedabad city, that were bought by cooperative societies in 1990s. The cooperative societies, mainly formed by builders, could not regularize the sales as they were not farmers, and according to the state’s tenancy laws, agricultural land cannot be sold to non-agriculturalists without permission of the district collector. As the district collector repeatedly rejected their requests, the NA permission could not be obtained over the last two decades.

In 2015, the Anandiben Patel government amended the Gujarat Tenancy and Agriculture Act by inserting Section 63AB in the Act. With this amendment, an agricultural land parcel, even if sold to a non-agriculturist, like a company or a cooperative, can be regularized by charging a premium if the last purchaser of the land was a farmer. The last transaction should have been made before June 2015.

In 2017, the Vijay Rupani-led state government issued a circular annulling the provisions of this amendment in the Gujarat Tenancy and Agriculture Act, 2015.

With the circular, many farmers who purchased land from cooperative societies in Ognaj village, could not regularize their purchase. Due to this, they could not obtain NA permission. The district collector has been denying the NA permission to cooperative societies, and then also to such farmers.

Following the 2017 circular, over half a dozen farmers from Ognaj moved the HC challenging the 2017 circular. In 2018, the single judge held that agricultural land, which was held by a cooperative society before final sale to a farmer, can be regularized on payment of a fixed premium.

The HC also held that a cooperative-society can be termed a ‘person’ for the purpose of land holding. The single bench ordered the district collector to take fresh decisions on applications filed by the farmers for NA permissions.

The state government challenged the single judge order before the division bench. It insisted that the provisions have been made in the circular in the interest of farmers.

After hearing the arguments, the bench of Justice S R Brahmbhatt and Justice A P Thaker observed that the government cannot nullify its legislation by issuing a circular.

Title: Gujarat: Diwalipura man arrested with high-end liquor stock
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

The raid was conducted by Gotri police in Guruprasad Society

VADODARA: The city police seized a large stash of imported liquor from the residence of a man in the Diwalipura area of the city. The man used to collect the bottles brought from abroad.

The raid was conducted by Gotri police on information that Jayanti Limbad residing in the Guruprasad Society in Diwalipura used to sell imported liquor. The residence of the accused was raided on the basis of the information and Indian Made Foreign Liquor (IMFL) as well as imported liquor bottles were found at his residence.

The seized stock included Tuborg beer, Old Monk rum, Jameson Irish whiskey , Johnnie Walker Black Label whiskey, Johnnie Walker Green Label whiskey, Jack Daniel’s whiskey and a bottle of wine. Most of the bottles were of one litre quantity.

Gotri police inspector A B Gohil said that Limbad used to like consuming alcohol and used to collect liquor for himself. He said that occasionally, he provided liquor to others too. The seized stock is valued at Rs 29,500 and Limbad was put under arrest following the seizure.

According to the police, Limbad used to procure the bottle from people travelling to the state from abroad. Many high-end liquor bottles recovered from him were of one litre capacity that are commonly sold at duty free shops.

Title: UP: Ex-director of AHVRI found dead in Banda hotel room
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

KANPUR: An ex-director of Animal Husbandry and Veterinary Research Institute (AHVRI) was found dead in a hotel in Banda district on Friday morning. The police have sent the body for postmortem examination and launched a probe.

Giving this information, ASP Lal Bharat Kumar Pal said, “R B Rai (62), a native of Bareilly, was in Banda to participate in a two-day seminar at the University of Agriculture and Technology. He was putting up in room no: 207 of a hotel. The room has been sealed for investigation.”

As per other guests staying in the hotel, when Rai did not come out of his room on Friday morning, the hotel staff opened it with a duplicate key, only to find him lying unconscious on the floor with blood coming out of his nose. They rushed him to the district hospital where doctors brought him dead on arrival.

The ASP said, “R B Rai was the ex-director of Animal Husbandry and Veterinary Research Institute (AHVRI), Andaman and Nicobar islands. A resident of Rajendra Nagar Colony in Bareilly, he was in Banda to participate in a two-day seminar organised by the Bundelkhand Vikas Board beginning Friday at the University of Agriculture and Technology. His two sons are settled abroad.”

As per the preliminary findings, doctors at Banda district hospital said he possibly died of a heart attack or due to an increase in blood pressure as blood was oozing out of his nose, police said.

The body has been sent for post-mortem examination to ascertain the actual cause of the death.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Two-hour stay as YS Jaganmohan Reddy appears before CBI court as CM
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

HYDERABAD: For the first time since he became chief minister of Andhra Pradesh on May 30 last year, YS Jaganmohan Reddy appeared before the special CBI court in Hyderabad on Friday in connection with the quid pro quo case filed by CBI against him.

Other accused, including YSRCP MP V Vijayasai Reddy, former revenue minister Dharmana Prasada Rao, along with IAS officers, industrialists and government officials of undivided AP also appeared before the court.

Jagan appeared before the court at 10.40 am and sat in the court hall for two hours. His earlier plea, seeking a joint hearing in the pleas of various accused in all the chargesheets seeking discharge from the case, was taken up for hearing.

Principal special judge of CBI courts BV Madhusudan Rao heard both his counsel and CBI counsel K Surender and reserved his orders to January 17. Heavy security was in place at the Gagan Vihar CBI court building when Jagan was present.

Jagan has been appearing before the court after the case was filed against him in 2013. It was only during 2018, that he sought a blanket exemption from court appearances to enable himself take up the huge mass contact programme ‘padayatra’ as the main opposition leader of AP. The court had rejected it and advised him to ask the trial court to dispense with his presence whenever it was needed.

Ever since he became the CM, his counsel has been filing the ‘dispense with’ pleas every week and accommodated by the court taking into consideration the busy schedule of the chief minister. Last week, the CBI court, however, directed Jagan and Vijayasai to appear before the court on January 10.

ED court to decide

Meanwhile, Jagan filed a separate plea before a special court trying the cases filed by the Enforcement Directorate (ED) under the Prevention of Money Laundering Act (PMLA) urging it to allow a co-accused in the case to represent him as it is difficult for him to appear before the court for all the hearings. It can be recalled the principal special judge court of CBI is designated as special ED court. The same court is now hearing both the cases.

Jagan filed another petition before the ED court, urging it to defer the trial in the cases filed by ED till the trial in CBI cases is complete and till the CBI court pronounces its order on the guilt or innocence of the accused. ED counsel TV Subba Rao has been arguing against these two pleas saying that section 44 of PMLA envisages a joint trial for both CBI and ED cases. “The trial in ED cases need not wait for CBI cases to conclude,” he said. He also opposed the plea of one accused representing another in the court. Madhusudan Rao reserved his orders in the cases to January 24.

Title: Will stop Shanti Yatra the moment CAA is withdrawn: Yashwant Sinha
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

NASHIK: Former union finance minister Yashwant Sinha on Friday said his Shanti Yatra was against the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) and he will conclude it the day central government announces its withdrawal.

Sinha’s rally started from Mumbai on Thursday and will pass through five states, including Maharashtra, Gujarat , Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh and Haryana. On Friday, his rally will pass through Pune before coming to Sangamner, Nashik and then to Gujarat.

“The government is actually afraid of people and it never confronts them at any point. Even today there are rallies across the country opposing the CAA. The protests will stop the day government announces recalling of the black act,” Sinha said at Sangamner in Ahmednagar district.

Sinha reiterated that the government was tossing up the CAA and other issues to create a flutter among people and divert their attention away from the major issues like country’s dropping economic health.

Former chief minister Prithviraj Chavan and MLA Ashish Deshmukh were also present at the rally.

Speaking to reporters, Chavan pointed out that BJP’s hidden agendas are now coming to the fore. “The party at the time of elections promised development, but has now switched over to its real agenda. There is a huge difference between party’s preaching and deeds,” Chavan said.

“The entire country is opposing the CAA and NRC, but home minister Amit Shah is bent on implementing the same. The government has failed to come clean on documents required to be sought from people to prove their citizenship. Without any information the government is setting up detention camps. We will fight till justice is done,” he added.

Title: Average wholesale onion price drops to 3,000 per quintal
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The average wholesale onion price at Lasalgaon APMC, country’s largest wholesale onion market, on Friday dropped by 15% to Rs 3,000 per quintal against Rs 3,500 per quintal on Thursday.

The average wholesale onion price has dropped by almost Rs 1,200 or 30% in the past five days — from Rs 4,200 per quintal on Tuesday to Rs 3,000 per quintal — owing to rise in supply.

In the retail market of the city, onions are being sold in the price range between Rs 40-50 per kg. The result of drop in wholesale price is expected to reflect in retail markets in the next two three days and retail onion price is expected to drop in the range of Rs 30-40 per kg.

Earlier, the average wholesale onion price recorded an all-time high of Rs 8,625 per quintal at Lasalgaon on December 16. But in the next 15 days it dropped to Rs 4,500 per quintal.

The price crashed further by Rs 1,000 to Rs 3,500 per quintal on January 1, only to go up to Rs 4,351 per quintal the next day.
