“Markets are witnessing rise in supply of fresh produce. Hence, the price trend in wholesale markets will be downward. The average wholesale onion price is expected to drop to Rs 2,200 per quintal by next week,” the APMC official said.

The minimum and maximum wholesale onion prices at Lasalgaon on Friday were recorded at Rs 1,200 and Rs 3,500 per quintal, respectively.

“Usually, the arrival of fresh kharif onions begin by mid-October, but unseasonal rainfall badly affected the kharif onion crop across Maharashtra. Around 75% of the onion plantation was damaged due to rains. This created scarcity of onions that increased the average wholesale onion price,” the official said.

“However, at around 45,000 hectare, the acreage of late kharif onions has increased at large in the district. Now, the harvest of late kharif onions is increasing gradually and the supply will increase further from the second half of this month,” he added.

Title: Fine Arts Fair set for comeback after 9 years
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

The fair is a legacy started in 1961

Vadodara: The Fine Arts Fair is back after a gap of nine years.

M S University’s famed Faculty of Fine Arts is all set to unveil the two-day fair from Saturday.

The fair is a legacy that started in 1961 by late professor Shankho Chowdhary and professor K G Subhramanyan. Since then it was held after a gap of every two or three years. The last fine arts fair was held in 2011.

“It is an eagerly awaited event that will revive memories of all those who have witnessed a Fine Arts Fair before – starting from students, faculty, alumni and citizens of Baroda. The fair is an ideal platform to bring everyone together for sharing the fun of creating for a cause!” said N G Bagodi, dean of Faculty of Fine Arts.

Appropriate with the theme of the fair – ‘Marine’ – a mega-sized octopus will be welcoming the guests at the entrance gate of the faculty.

Nearly 300 past and present students apart from staff are working day and night since last one and a half year to make this fair a success.

“The fair supports amazing themes every time. It is about mobile installations, live puppet shows, theatre, films, creative crafts, affordable arts, children’s books, innovative gate decoration, hand-crafted toys, enamel arts, ceramic crafts, textile, handmade jewellery in metal, ceramics, calendars, portfolios, sculptures and much more,” he said.

The fair is significant as funds generated from it have been donated in the past to the victims of earthquakes, tsunamis, riot victims, jawans in border areas, survivors of natural calamities and the needy students who require financial aid.

“The fair is also special because it upholds the Sanskar Nagari designation of Baroda – the citizens get a chance to be a part of a unique creative event,” he said.

Title: Tamil Nadu government awards Rs 1 crore aid to kin of slain SSI
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Wilson

Chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami on Friday announced a solatium of Rs 1 crore to the family of special sub-inspector Wilson, who was stabbed and gunned down by two men suspected to be ISIS sympathisers while he was on duty at a check-post at Kaliyakkavilai in Kanyakumari district on Wednesday night.

Earlier on Thursday, the chief minister had also informed the assembly that the government would give a job to one of the family members of the slain officer.

The Kerala police have also announced a reward for those who provide information about the two suspects, Abdul Shamim, 25, and Thoufique Yusuf, 27, both residents of Nagercoil in Tamil Nadu .

Title: Candidate for judge locks horns with Gujarat high court over right answer to legal question
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A candidate aspiring to be a civil judge has locked horns with the Gujarat high court over interpretation of a law. A fresh LLB, Diksha Trivedi (24), dragged the HC recruitment section to court, disputing the latter’s answer key on the issue of the validity of a cheque.

Trivedi approached the high court’s judicial side after her answer to a question, which was asked in an elimination test for civil judges, was declared wrong and she fell 0.23 marks short of a score of 50 to qualify for the next stage. The written examination is scheduled on January 19 and Trivedi challenged the examiner’s interpretation of the law and demanded that she be allowed to participate in the next level of the recruitment process.

The disputed answer concerned a question on Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, for the provisions of a cheque bounce. The question was about the time limit within which a cheque has to be presented to the bank. Trivedi opted for option ‘C’, whereas the HC’s answer key said option ‘A’ was correct.

Trivedi said the cheque has to be presented to the bank “within a period of six months from the date on which it is drawn or within the period of its validity, whichever is earlier”. For the examiners, this period is three months.

Trivedi not only lost one mark after her answer on was marked incorrect, but also incurred .33% negative marks. She secured 49.63 marks. If this one answer is proved correct, she would pass for the written test. She recorded her objections to the answer key with regard to this question. When there was no reply on her objection, she filed a petition.

In her petition, Trivedi cited a 2011 Reserve Bank of India (RBI) circular conveying to banks that the validity period for a cheque is three months. The student claimed that this was the RBI’s instruction for banking purposes, but so far as the law is concerned, the RBI’s instructions and present practice have nothing to do with the interpretation of the law, and the correct interpretation for the validity of a cheque is six months.

After a preliminary hearing, the high court on Wednesday permitted Trivedi to take the written test. There were 19 others who benefited from Trivedi’s fight, as they had also recorded their objection to the correct answer to this question. They too got permission to take the test. However, the HC said that the outcome of Trivedi’s litigation would decide the job status of these 20 candidates.

Title: Sabitha Indra Reddy, Dharmana Prasada Rao summoned in Jaganmohan Reddy quid pro quo case
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: The CBI court here summoned Telangana’s first woman minister Sabitha Indra Reddy , former revenue minister of AP Dharmana Prasada Rao and five others to appear before it on January 17 in connection with the quid pro quo case.

Principal special judge BV Madhusudan Rao passed this order on Friday while taking into cognisance a supplementary chargesheet filed by CBI in the quid pro quo case against AP chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy and others. The chargesheet revolved around irregularities committed allegedly for the purpose of helping Penna Cements, which is believed to have made huge investments in Jagan’s firms when his late father YSR was CM of undivided AP. The judge also dismissed the objections raised by Penna group over adding some more names in the list of accused in the supplementary chargesheet.

In the first chargesheet, CBI had named nine — Jagan, YSRC MP V Vijayasai Reddy, Penna Cements chairman Putta Pratap Reddy and six others — as accused. In the supplementary chargesheet, seven more persons — Sabitha, Dharmana and bureaucrats Y Srilakshmi, M Samuel and VD Rajagopal, tahsildar M Yellamma and DRO M Sudarshan Reddy — were named as accused.

CBI said Sabitha, as mines minister between 2004-09, and Rajagopal, as director of mines, went out of their way to grant mining leases to Penna Cements and arrayed them as accused in its chargesheet. Senior counsel E Uma Maheswara Rao, appearing for Penna Cements, urged the court to reject the supplementary chargesheet since it did not furnish any fresh material. The court, however, rejected the plea and summoned all of them.

CBI’s charge against Pratap was that his Penna group was showered with undue largesse by the YSR government by way of granting limestone mining leases, land allotments and concessions for a five-star hotel. In return, Pratap made Rs 68 crore investments in Jagan’s firms. CBI described this as a bribe for the benefits Penna group had extracted from the government.

Title: No water supply in Nashik on Monday
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) on Friday said that there will be no water supply on Monday across the city due to repair work.

The supply will be restored on Tuesday with low pressure. Concerned officials said that the supply will be restored to normalcy from Wednesday.

According to a statement released by the municipal corporation on Friday, the water supply department of the NMC will undertake repair work at its water treatment plants. The valves of pipelines will be repaired at various locations in the city.

The repair work will be undertaken at water treatment plants in Shivaji Nagar, Panchavati, Nashik Road and Gandhinagar. Moreover, repair work will also to be carried out at pumping stations in Chehadi, the Gangapur dam and the Mukane dam. All repair work will carried out on the same day, the statement added.

According to the statement, raw water will not be lifted from the Gangapur dam, the Mukane dam and the Chehadi weir on that day. Hence, there will be no supply of water across all six divisions of the city throughout the day from 9 am onwards.

Title: City girls beat Aligarh team in women’s cricket
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Kanpur: Kanpur Women XI grabbed Subhash Challenge Cup after they defeated Aligarh by 19 wickets in the final of state level Women Cricket Championship concluded at Chitrakoot on Friday.

Aligarh girls, batting first scored 67 runs in 20 overs. Aya and Neha Singh contributed 30 and 17 runs respectively. For Kanpur team, Babia Yadav and Archana Devi both bagged 3 wickets each. In reply, Kanpur girls hit required 71 runs with out losing any wicket. Ekta and Babita hit unbeaten 32 and 26 runs respectively.

The chief guest presented trophy and a cash prize of Rs 20,000 to the winning Kanpur team while Aligarh girls pocketed cash prize of Rs 10,000.

TT trial: Trials for district and region level for the table tennis team will be held at the Green Park stadium on January 13 and January 14.

Interested peddlers may contact Avinash Kumar Yadav, TT coach Green Park or the regional sports office at Green Park on the afore-mentioned dates.

Title: Properties worth Rs 78 crore of Chanda Kochhar, family attached
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Former ICICI Bank CEO Chanda Kochhar (File photo)

Title: Gujarat: Mines dept officer caught taking Rs 20,000 bribe
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: A supervisor working with the mines and minerals department of the Narmada district was caught accepting a bribe of Rs 20,000. The accused Deepesh Divetiya had sought money for not seizing a truck carrying sand.

The complainant, who brings sand from Bodeli and sells it in Surat, had approached ACB stating that his truck carrying sand was stopped by Divetiya on January 7 near Kevadiya.

Divetiya had claimed that the truck was overloaded and he would have to seize it. The complainant has claimed that he urged the official to let the truck go as it was carrying sand within its capacity. However, Divetiya asked Rs 30,000 and settled for Rs 20,000.

Divetiya was caught taking money in Rajpipla Surat rural ACB police police team.

Title: NMC builds speed-breakers at Tarwala junction
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Over 70 accidents took place in the past two years at the said spot

NASHIK: The Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) — in order to reduce the number of mishaps taking place at the accident-prone zone of Tarwala junction on Dindori Road in Panchavati area of the city — has constructed speed-breakers.

A delegation, led by NCP city president Ranjan Thakre, and residents of Tarwala had met municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game, seeking installation of speed-breakers, police post and other measures to stop accidents taking place on this stretch. Accordingly, large speed breakers have been constructed in all four directions at the signal.

Last month, some residents of Tarwala Nagar informed Game that over 70 accidents took place at the signal in the past two years. The accidents occur when speeding vehicles from different side cross the signal at night.

During a meeting, Game had assured the NCP delegation and residents of Tarwala Nagar that speed-breakers would be constructed at the signal.

“The civic body had already taken measures to stop accidents at the signals. The length of the road dividers had been extended at the signals. The NMC had also installed rumblers on the road, but those were removed by someone,” Game said.

Title: Chennai Corporation seeks Rs 53,000 crore from World Bank
Content:
The newly-built Pedestrian Plaza in T Nagar has received good patronage

CHENNAI: To fund a wide variety of infrastructure projects including 10 new pedestrian plazas , mega streets which would be pedestrian-friendly and pothole-free, and an off-street parking project, Greater Chennai Corporation has submitted a proposal requesting Rs 53,000 crore funding from the World Bank .This was after a series of meetings held by senior officials, including commissioner G Prakash, with Sumila Gulyani, programme leader of infrastructure and sustainable development at World Bank (India) as part of the Chennai city partnership programme.Corporation chief engineer (general and special projects) L Nandakumar told TOI that Chennai had been selected by the World Bank to be showcased as a model for other major cities in the developing world. “Officials were impressed with the execution of projects such as pedestrian plaza ,” he said. Creation of waterfronts on canals in the city after their restoration and constructing pedestrian-friendly footpaths on 302 bus route roads in the city were among the proposals given to World Bank. Nandakumar said the World Bank would take a call on which projects it would fund.The corporation has sought Rs10,000 crore each for three projects: 100 square km of mega streets; widening of 21 arterial roads including Sardar Patel Road and Kaliamman Koil Road; and area-based development in Sholinganallur, Velachery, Thiruvanmiyur, Mylapore, Anna Nagar, Thiruvottiyur and Purasaiwalkam.Area-based development would include construction of pedestrian plazas and allied facilities such as wide footpaths with seats and play areas for children, redevelopment of parks and 24x7 water supply with digital metering. This project is currently underway in T Nagar alone and the corporation wants to replicate it in the other locations as well, for which World Bank funding has been solicited.Two other significant projects are bio-mining of legacy waste at the city’s two dumpyards in Kodungaiyur and Perungudi at a cost of Rs1,338 crore and construction of 17 flyovers and seven bridges at a cost of Rs3,725 crore. Already, the corporation has used funds from the Chennai Mega City Development Mission, smart city fund and Tamil Nadu Urban Road Infrastructure Fund (TURIF) for these projects, apart from their capital outlays.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Rs 1 crore worth gold stolen from BJP man’s house
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: At least 400 sovereigns of gold jewellery and cash were stolen from the house of R M R Janakiraman, a BJP national general council member , at Minjur in Tiruvallur district on Friday.

The jewellery was kept in the house in view of Janakiraman’s niece’s marriage on January 20. The family had visited Chennai for shopping since his son and daughter-in-law had arrived from the US for the marriage.

The incident took place when they were away. On their return, they noticed that the house door was broke open and valuables were missing. Police estimated that at least 400 sovereigns of gold, valued at approximately Rs 1 crore , were stolen from five bureaus in the house along with at least Rs 50,000. Police, after initial inquiry, said the family took the gold ornaments from a bank locker on Thursday and kept them in the house.

Though more than 10 people worked in the house, none were there at the time of the incident. There were no CCTV cameras either at the house, police said.

Title: MVA cuts a wide swathe in bypolls of two civic wards, wrests power from BJP
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Victorious Shiv Sena candidate Madhukar Jadhav (yellow turban) with his supporters after winning the bypolls f... Read More

NASHIK: The Maha Vikas Aghadi ( MVA ) has added another feather in its cap as two of its candidates have won the the byelection in the two wards of the municipal corporation, the results of which were declared on Friday— which were previously the bastions of the BJP .

NCP’s Jagdish Pawar received 4,913 votes and defeated BJP’s Vishakha Shirsat, who secured 1,525 votes, to win the byelection in ward 22 (A) in Nashik division. The seat in this ward was lying vacant after BJP corporator Saroj Ahire resigned ahead of the state assembly elections . Ahire had left the saffron party and joined the NCP to contest from Deolali state assembly constituency.

Corporator Madhukar Jadhav from Shiv Sena won the byelection in ward 26 (A) in Satpur division. Jadhav defeated his rival, Dilip Datir from the Maharashtra Navnirman Sena (MNS) , by a margin of 2,809 votes. While Jadhav received 5,865 votes, Datir secured 3,053 votes in the byelection.

The seat in ward no 26 (A) was lying vacant after Datir resigned as corporator from the Shiv Sena and joined the MNS to contest state assembly election from Nashik West constituency. After facing defeat in the state assembly elections, Datir again bit the dust in the ward byelection.

There are total 122 corporators in the Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC). Currently, one seat in ward 4 (A) is lying vacant following the demise of a BJP corporator. Hence, presently, the total strength of the civic administration is 121.

Despite having lost the byelections in the two wards—the polls for which were conducted on Thursday, BJP is still in the power in the civic administration with 64 seats.

The Maha Vikas Aghadi was an alliance stitched by the Congress, NCP and Shiv Sena to come to form the government at the state. The alliance formed by the three parties at the state seems to have trickled down to the civic bodies, as is evident from the MVA’s back-to-back victories in the ZP polls and ward byelections. The recent victories in the ward byelections has only lifted the spirits of the local MVA leaders who attribute the triumph to Shiv Sena chief Uddhav Thackeray.

By winning the two seats, the MVA’s strength in the NMC has swelled to 48. Of this, 35 belong to Shiv Sena, 7 to NCP and 6 to Congress. While the MNS has 5 seats, there are four independents in the state.

“BJP has lost the byelections in both the civic wards. Our victories were a result of Shiv Sena supremo Uddhav Thackeray taking over as the chief minister. People have shown their confidence in Thackeray and this is a clear sign of victory,” said Ajay Boraste, leader of the opposition from the Sena in the NMC.

“The MVA’s victory was because of the money power and also because the Aghadi is in power in the state. They misused power to win both the seats,” said Jagdish Patil, BJP’s group leader in the NMC.

Title: Vehicles sans FASTags spend more on tolls
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

In Kaniyur toll plazas, the number of cash lanes was reduced to two from six, while increasing the number of F... Read More

COIMBATORE: Now that the FASTags have been made compulsory, motorists who are yet to comply with the rule are at the receiving end as they are not allowed to buy two-way tickets and enjoy the nearly 30% discount as earlier.

The rush at the cash lanes in toll plazas such as Kaniyur toll plaza in the district have, meanwhile, come down considerably and the motorists needn’t have to wait long for their turn.

The central government had earlier passed a rule making FASTags compulsory by January 15 for all cars to cross toll plazas and doubling the toll amount for the vehicles that fail to comply with the fiat.

While all toll plazas have been instructed to make required changes, motorists have been given a 30-day extension to fix FASTags.

In Kaniyur toll plazas, the number of cash lanes was reduced to two from six, while increasing the number of FASTag lanes to six from the earlier two from January 15. “Our cash lanes continue to witness queues, while the FASTag lanes are moving seamlessly with cars hardly having to slow down for 30 to 45 seconds and just two cars standing in queue at a time,” said Murali, toll plaza manager.

If motorists without FASTags were to enter the lanes meant for FASTags, they would be charged double the toll fee as penalty. They also won’t be allowed to buy two-way toll tickets. “Motorists buying a two-way ticket save at least 27% to 30% compared to buying two one-way tickets. For example, cars which need to pay Rs 55 for a one-way ticket need to pay only Rs 80 for a two-way ticket. But we don’t offer two-way tickets at cash lanes anymore,” Murali said.

Pointing out that the toll plaza on an average sees around 30,000 cars daily, he said around 45% of them was using FASTags. “For vehicles that want to fix FASTags at our place, we have bankers setting up counters at the toll plaza office, where motorists can submit their photo and id proof and fix the same at a fee of Rs 250, and then recharge it online,” Murali said.

Title: Reduce black spots in Nashik to prevent accidents: Civic chief Radhakrishna Game
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Datta Mandir Chowk has been identified as black spot

NASHIK: Municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game has directed the civic officials to take measures for reducing black spots in the city.

Game’s instructions came during a meeting of traffic mobility cell of the Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) held on Thursday.

During the meeting, NGO Nashik First submitted a list of over 17 black spots to the municipal commissioner, demanding immediate measures to prevent accidents.

Game instructed the officials concerned to take necessary measures such as installing speed breakers to control the speed of the vehicles and thus prevent accidents on these black spots as identified by the NGO.

Civic officials said that they will examine the list of black spots furnished by the NGO and take necessary measures.

“We have already identified some black spots with the help of the traffic police department. But, the NGO has also furnished a list of some black spots in the city where mishap often occurs. We will take their list into consideration,” said an NMC official.

“Recently, we conducted a survey in the city to find out black spots where frequent accidents occur. We have identified black spots at around 17 locations across six divisions of the municipal corporation,” said Abhay Kulkarni, chairman of Nashik First.

“During the meeting, we highlighted the need for preventive measures at black spots in the city and sought immediate measures from civic officials,” said Kulkarni.

Some of the black spots identified by the NGO include Datta Mandir square in Nashik Road, Carbon Naka in Satpur, Tarwala Nagar in Panchavati, near Ashoka Hospital in Vadalagaon, Tapovan Corner and the stretch near Hotel Green View on Trimbak Road.

A discussion on strengthening of the public transport system in the city also took place during the meeting. The NMC is going to take over the city bus service from the Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation (MSRTC).

NMC has six divisions — Panchavati, New Nashik, Satpur, Nashik Road, Nashik East and Nashik West.

Mayor to start ‘visit to ward’ project from today

To understand the grievances of citizens, mayor Satish Kulkarni has announced to start ‘visit to ward’ project on every Saturday starting January 10.

Kulkarni will begin his visit from ward no. 31. He will visit each ward and interact with the residents to understand their grievances better.

The mayor said that the issues of the residents including water supply, garbage collections through garbage vans, roads, drainage, gardens and others would be sorted during the visit.

Title: Echo of tradition in the new generation
Content:
The unadorned start was compensated by the momentousness of the programme, on Day 9, Thursday, of Saptak.

AHMEDABAD: Pandit Umakant Gundecha began an exposition of Rageshree with a one-word preface: “Ijazat…” (with your permission). The unadorned start was compensated by the momentousness of the programme, on Day 9, Thursday, of Saptak. The Dhrupad maestro was being accompanied for the first time by Anant, the son of Pandit Ramakant Gundecha.The familiar line-up of the Gundecha brothers — Pandits Ramakant and Umakant — had changed because of Pandit Ramakant’s demise last November. “I was happy performing with Anant,” Pandit Umakant Gundecha told TOI. “We live in a joint family and since his childhood, Anant has been immersed in my jugalbandi with his father. You could say Dhrupad inheres in Anant’s blood. When I sang with Anant, I felt Ramakant was with me on the stage.”Rageshree can burst onto listeners like good news. A popular interpretation of the raga is found in ‘Shubh din aayo’ (from “Mughal-e-Azam”) rendered by Ustad Bade Ghulam Ali Khan. In that song, the raga lends the throb of urgency to the bustle of the palace, the dancing courtiers, and the sweep of finery. But on Thursday, Rageshree was delivered with an elegiac alaap. The mood brightened later, with Anant Gundecha’s self-assured performance shooting out rays of a distinguished legacy. “It is impossible to fill my father’s shoes,” Anant Gundecha told TOI. “I try to do justice to the knowledge given by him and my uncle.”Indeed, Saptak demonstrates the flow tradition. The first baithak on Day 8, Wednesday, had brought sarodiya Amaan Ali Bangash to the stage. His father, the sarod god Ustad Amjad Ali Khan, himself gave TOI an insight into the programme. “Amaan played Lalita Gauree,” Khan-sahab told TOI. “That was followed by Nand Kauns. Parveen Sultana’s guru Pandit Chinmay Lahiri and I were the only two musicians who performed Nand Kauns all over the country.”Vocalist Monica Shah took the stage in the first baithak. The second featured the flute recital of Rakesh Chaurasia.

Title: MSU’s 68th convocation on January 29
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Vadodara: Chairman of of the University Grants Commission (UGC), Prof D P Singh will be the chief guest for M S University’s 68th annual convocation on January 29.

The university since last couple of years has been witnessing delays when it comes to holding annual convocation ceremony.

Even this year, there has been a delay in finalising the chief guest for the academic ceremony. Sources said that the university had approached union minister Prakash Javadekar with whose office dates were being finalised.

Some syndicate members had also floated suggestions of inviting eminent sports personalities, but things could not be materialised.

Title: Photos: Varun Dhawan is back in Mumbai after promoting 'Street Dancer 3D' in Jodhpur
Content: Varun Dhawan's 'Street Dancer 3D' has been the talk of the town since the announcement. The film team is visiting various cities across the countries to promote the film.Varun recently jetted of to Jodhpur for the promotion where he received a grand welome. Pictures and videos of the same are all over the internet.Now, the actor is back in Mumbai and paparazzi clicked his pictures at the airport. He wore a grey t-shirt with a leather jacket over it, blue denim and grey shoes. He even posed for some selfies with fans while passing through the premises of the airport.Check out the pictures here:Meanwhile, 'Street Dancer 3D' stars Shraddha Kapoor alongside Varun. The film is the third installment of the 'ABCD' franchise.With this film, Varun and Shraddha will be reuniting after sharing the screen space in the second part of the series. Helmed by Remo D'Souza , the film also stars Aparshakti Khurana and Shakti Mohan. The film will hit the theatres on January 24.He will also star in David Dhawan 's 'Coolie No. 1' remake with Sara Ali Khan. The film has been slated to release on May 1, 2020.

Title: Nashik: Numismatists make a beeline at Rare Fair 2020
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

NASHIK: “Rare Fair-2020,” a three-day exhibition of rare coins , bank notes and stamps kicked off in the city on Friday. It is being organised by Collector’s Society of Numismatic & Rare Items, Nashik .

Over 75 coin collectors from various parts of the country are participating in the exhibition. The collection includes various rare and unique items collected by the participants over the years.

Commissioner of police Vishwas Nangre-Patil formally inaugurated the event and appreciated the efforts of the organisation. He also honoured the exceptional work of the organisation in the field of Numismatics.

Ramavtar Jain, a stamp collector from Ahmedabad, who will showcase his rarest collection — the first stamp ticket from 1852 worth Rs 1.5 lakh — said, “People spend so much of money in watching movies and it’s like a hobby for them. But, my interests are different. I like to collect rare and unique stamps. I do not have a count of the number of stamps I have.”

Among the note collectors, one participant displayed his collection of misprinted notes.

Nitin Jain from Balod, Chhattisgarh, said “I got some misprinted notes from my friends and then I started looking for more of them. I, now, have a catalogue of real misprinted notes. It has become a hobby for me, but nothing comes for free.”

One of the collectors also had some unique silver items. Suraj Pasari from Vadodara has displayed an 80-year old lipstick holder which he had bought from a friend.

“It is made up of 68 gm pure silver. It is a unique item which no makes any more. The British must have got it made from a goldsmith,” shared Pasari.

The last fair was organised in 2018 which had attracted over 50,000 people over a period of three days. This year too, the organisers are looking forward to a good response from people.

“People like to display their rare collection during such events. The members of our organisation also evaluate the coins of the public on the basis of condition, name and variety, and tell them the price of them which they can sell off to the collectors,” vice president of the organisation Rajesh Junnare said.

As part of the event, an auction of rare coins is scheduled on Saturday at Indraprasth Hall, Gangapur Road.

Title: Aligarh MP accuses AMU of allowing “anti-national” activities on campus
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Agra: Aligarh MP Satish Gautam of BJP on Friday wrote a letter to vice-chancellor Tariq Mansoor of AMU , castigating the way varsity authorities had been handling the allegation of “objectionable and indecent” activities on campus.

The MP’s letter comes a day after AMU students allegedly shouted inappropriate slogans against PM Narendra Modi and CM Yogi Adityanath, while forming a human chain inside the campus in solidarity with JNU students and teachers, who were attacked by masked men earlier this week. Around 25-30 students were later booked by police for this.

In his letter, the MP said he expects the VC to take strict action against the “handful of anti-social elements” that are vitiating the peaceful atmosphere on campus and ruining the academic session of scores of students.

He said it is unfortunate that the university feels pride in welcoming people who are “anti-government, anti-national and anti-Constitutional”. The administration watches mutely as such people come and speak against the government and the nation inside the campus. He said such activities inside AMU send the wrong message across the world that an educational institution has turned into a hub of anti-national activities.

The letter stated while it is the university’s moral responsibility to smoothly carry out educational activities, students should focus on their studies, that the situation on campus is reversed and efforts are made by the administration, teachers and students to end the poison.

Attacking university registrar Abdul Hamid, the MP said a senior IPS officer was appointed for the university’s welfare, not for watching anti-social activities being carried out on campus.

AMU students have been protesting against CAA, NRC and NPR on campus for the last month. Even members of the faculty have joined their candlelight vigils on campus every evening for the last 10 days.

Title: Agra: 300 metric tonnes per day waste-to-compost plant to start operating from today
Content:
According to an official estimate, 100 municipal wards of Agra produce around 1,000 metric tonnes of solid was... Read More

AGRA: The mega facility for processing of biodegradable waste into compost at Kuberpur landfill site will start operating on Saturday. The plant developed with an investment of Rs 11.27 crore has the capacity to convert 300 metric tonnes per day (TPD) of waste into compost.According to an official estimate, 100 municipal wards of the city produce around 1,000 metric tonnes of solid waste every day. Out of this, 650 metric tonnes comprises non-biodegradable waste while 350 metric tonnes biodegradable waste.Talking with TOI, municipal commissioner Arun Prakash said, “The modern plant for processing of biodegradable waste into compost will start operations on Saturday. In five sheds, a total 300 TPD compost will be produced. Agra Municipal Corporation workers are separately collecting biodegradable waste from different parts of the city. Now, we will be able to utilize almost all the green waste produced in the city.”At present, AMC is operating five small waste-to-compost plants in different parts of the city. On a daily basis, 35 metric tonnes of compost is being produced at these centres.Meanwhile, working on its “zero-waste city” plan under Swachh Bharat Mission, AMC has delivered 880 tonnes of compost to Indian Farmers Fertilizer Cooperative Limited (IFFCO), which was prepared by processing biodegradable waste collected from different parts of the city. In addition, it is providing compost to farmers free of cost to encourage organic farming.In October 2017, a power purchase agreement (PPA) was signed in Lucknow between Uttar Pradesh Power Corporation Limited (UPPCL) and Spark Bresson Private Limited, a Czech company, contracted by the AMC, to set up and operate the waste-to-energy facility. Under the agreement, UPPCL agreed to purchase electricity produced at the waste-to-energy plant in Agra.According to the AMC officials, the work to set up the waste-to-energy facility is likely to start by the end of this year after securing permission of the Taj Trapezium Zone (TTZ) authorities and Archaeological Survey of India (ASI). The waste-to-energy facility will ensure that heaps of garbage get collected.

Title: ‘To others Yesudas is legend, to me he’s guruji’
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Chennai: The world has been singing praises about the voice of Kattassery Joseph (KJ) Yesudas , who turned 80 on Friday, for close to six decades, but very few know it was a taunt, from a guru, that set him on the path.

“I don’t know why he [the guru] used to call me ‘mappila,’ the way some people address Muslims in Kerala,” Yesudas had told TOI in 2012. “He always told me I couldn’t sing, but when he repeated, ‘Mappila, you can’t sing for nuts’, before I took the stage at Radha Lakshmy Nilayam music school in Tripunithura, Kerala, it shattered me.”

It goaded him into a strict regimen of learning that has made him what he is today— a singer seeking humanism in music, a philosopher who finds music in human relations, and somewhere in between a philanthropist who helps provide free heart surgeries for poor in Kerala and elsewhere.

And he remains ‘ guruji ’ for Gangai Amaran , for taking him to Sabarimala first in the 1970s. The musician-lyricist-director, youngest of the Pavalar brothers including Ilaiyaraja, says it’s just not music that has connected them. “To Yesudas, I was special. Any day, I can gate-crash into his house and have a meal. Whenever I say, ‘Yeniki Malayalam Samasaram Ella’, he would say, ‘Dai Amar, it is Yeniki Malayalam Samsarikaan Arinjunda’.”

On another occasion, they were recording ‘Manitha Manitha Ini Un Vizhigal’ from ‘Kan Sivanthaal Man Sivakkum’ when Gangai Amaran was asked to leave the studio because he found something amiss with the rendition. “Later, he realised I was right, and we patched up.”

Several musicians and singers from Tamil Nadu and Kerala, who greeted Yesudas through videos and tweets, say any conversation with him begins and ends with music, devotion, discipline and god.

Krishnachandran, with 1,000 songs in Malayalam and Tamil, says he faces ‘starting trouble’ when asked to speak about his association with the legend . “I was born in 1960 and he started his career in 1961. I grew up breathing and listening to his songs. In Kerala, Yesudas is be all and end all for us. Days begin with his soulful music and the nights end in a similar fashion.”

After making his debut as an actor, Krishnachandran got the chance to sing with S Janaki and Yesudas in Malayalam film ‘Ina’. “I was teased by Das Ettan for debuting in a movie alongside Jayabharathi. But, slowly he realised my singing prowess and after the ‘Ina’ song recording, he complimented me which made me feel I received a national award of sorts.”

Yesudas, Krishnachandran says, never encourages small talk. “Even if a conversation starts on a lighter vein, Yesudas makes sure the discussion is always about music.”

Title: Agra Municipal Corporation takes up garbage collection from door to door in city
Content:
The civic body presently has 100 twin-dustbin autos.

Route map of

garbage collection

vehicle in a ward

AGRA: After cancelling the contract with private companies, Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) has started collecting garbage door to door on its own across all the 100 wards of the city. However, some of the localities are yet to be covered. To increase efficiency, the civic body administration has decided to deploy three twin-dustbin autos in each ward.The civic body presently has 100 twin-dustbin autos. These have separate sections for biodegradable and non-biodegradable waste. AMC has initiated the process of purchasing 200 more such autos. Besides, the civic body administration is going to rope in NGOs to strengthen the door-to-door collection plan.Municipal commissioner Arun Prakash said, “We have prepared an action plan for waste management. Soon, three twin-dustbin autos will be deployed in each of the 100 wards of the city. Separate route maps have been prepared for these vehicles to operate. Each vehicle will collect garbage from 1,000 houses in one ward. By this, we will be able to collect garbage from three lakh houses, ensuring a litter-free city.”Prakash added that NGOs will be roped in to aid in collecting garbage. Each volunteer (NGO) ensuring garbage collection from 1,000 houses in the assigned area will be paid at the rate of Rs 15 per house at the end of each month. Besides, improving maintenance of sanitation and hygiene in the city, this will generate employment for at least 100 people with a salary of Rs 15,000, he added.The civic body administration is working on a plan to charge for door-to-door garbage collection and add it in house tax bills of residents who refuse to pay directly to the workers. For this, the house tax collection software will be updated.On Friday, the municipal commissioner conducted inspection in half-a-dozen localities of the city to check status of door-to-door garbage collection. He directed supervisors to ensure standard cleanliness work in the city ahead of the central government's cleanliness survey -- Swachh Survekshan 2020.Meanwhile, AMC has started installing advanced global positioning system (GPS) devices in all garbage collection vehicles for real time monitoring of their movement. The move is aimed at ensuring that garbage collected from different parts of the city reaches the landfill site in a time bound manner. It will also enable the authorities to keep a tab on fuel consumption.

Title: Residents oppose city corpn’s plan to construct micro composting centre
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Coimbatore: Residents of GV Residency and cadre of DMK on Friday staged a protest opposing the city corporation’s move to set up a micro composting centre (MCC) on the land earmarked for a scheme road in their area.

“A couple of decades ago, the city corporation proposed a scheme road to connect Avinashi Road and Trichy Road, passing along the border of the layout in parallel to a water channel. But, when World Classical Tamil Conference took place in the city in 2010, the road was laid through the layout but not as per the proposed design,” president of GV Residency Welfare Association N Narasiman said.

“When we questioned the corporation, they assured us in writing that it was laid temporarily, and it would be re-laid as per the proposal,” he said, adding that the civic body had not taken any steps to correct it till date.

Explaining that 40,000 square feet of open space reservation (OSR) site is located adjacent to the scheme road, he said the corporation has commenced constructing the centre at the OSR site and the land earmarked for scheme road, thus blocking the road.

President of Tanthai Periyar Nagar Welfare Association S Paramasivam said by constructing the centre amid the residential area, the civic body was putting the health of the public at stake.

“When we visited the centre at Kavundampalayam, we couldn’t tolerate the foul smell emanating from it. Not just us, even the workers at the centre are struggling to cope up with the strong smell. Also, the centre is filled with flies belying corporation’s claims,” he added.

“At Kavundampalayam, the centre is located at least a kilometre away from the residential area. But here, the centre is constructed within the residential area. Already, we are bearing the foul smell emanating from the water channel filled with sewage. If the centre is also established, it would become unbearable,” another resident of GV Residency, S Karthik, said.

Denying the allegations, the corporation officials said that the land was earmarked for OSR site and not for road. As we could be using the centre to turn wet waste into manure, foul smell would not emanate from the centre, the official added.

Title: Gang involved in duping job aspirants busted; 3 arrested
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Agra: Next time you see or hear any advertisement of ‘work from home’ - an online job, fetching handsome monthly remuneration - be cautious as it may be a trick to lure gullible job aspirants, says Agra cyber cell after they busted a gang involved in duping several job aspirants.

According to police, a group of men hailing from Hathras, Aligarh and Mathura had floated a fake online company of data feeding, and charged job aspirants with minimum registration fee of Rs 7,000 in the name of job offers.

Sub inspector Amit Kumar, the member of Agra cyber cell investigating team, said on Friday, “The matter came to our light after a Dayalbagh-based woman identified as Tulika Gupta filed a complaint of being cheated for Rs 10,800 by the gang in the name of offering a job. During investigation, we found that the gang was operating from Mathura district.”

“We arrested three men, including Yogesh Kumar, a graduate hailing from Hathras, Rohitash alias Bhola, another resident of Hathras who is professional wrestler, and intermediate pass Harish Kumar of Aligarh,” said investigating officer.

He added that the kingpin of the gang identified as Sachin of Mathura is absconding, but we managed to retrieve data of over 100 men and women of Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh and other states from whom the gang managed to extort up to Rs 8 lakh in the past six months.

Title: Man gets 14-yr jail term for raping 7-yr-old
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Agra: A special POCSO court in Agra on Friday awarded 14-year jail term to a 24-year-old man for raping a seven-year-old girl.

The sentence was awarded by special judge VK Jaiswal of additional sessions court, Agra. The rape convict was found guilty on charges of Indian Penal Code Section 376 (rape) and POCSO Act.

Speaking to TOI, district government counsel Vimlesh Anand, who presented the girl case, said, “The incident took place on October 17, 2017 around 1.30 pm in Jagdispura area of Agra city. The girl had gone to a nearby shop on her mother’s request to buy grocery when she was stopped by the accused, identified as Gaurav, who took her to his place and raped her.”

Anand said, “When the girl shouted for help, residents of the area got to know. They soon nabbed the accused and took him to police. The medical reports of the girl had confirmed rape.”

Title: Indian rail official’s ‘wall of kindness’ spreads warmth this winter
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Agra: In a world where some global leaders endeavour to build “walls of hatred”, a 32-year-old Indian railway official has tried to turn walls of some railway stations in western Uttar Pradesh into “walls of kindness”. Here, train passengers have been voluntarily hanging their warm clothes for the needy.

With this unique initiative, even as the state’s temperature dips to bone chilling cold, Sanjay Kumar of north central railway zone has spread warmth among the underprivileged and homeless living near the stations of Dadri, Aligarh, Firozabad and Etawah, among others. The noble initiative was introduced more than a week ago by the assistant traffic manager, Tundla.

Kumar’s cause drew much inspiration from Iran’s ‘dewar-e-meherbani’, a charity work which gained momentum in the winter of 2015, after the country’s economy was hit hard with multiple sanctions imposed by the United States and some European nations leading to increase in number of unemployed and homeless people. Some of these Iranians who could not afford enough clothes, found relief from the ones placed on various walls by local volunteers. Of course, Kumar’s cause of building “wall of kindness” comes at a time when leaders like Donald Trump and Benjamin Netanyahu are working on building “walls of hatred” along their nation’s respective borders with Mexico and West Bank.

“With the help of colleagues, friends and other railway staff members, we have started hanging warm clothes - both old and new - on the walls of our railway stations for destitute and the underprivileged. The response has been positive so far with children, women and the elderly often walking up to these walls and taking clothes from there as per their requirement,” said Kumar, who is a 2016-batch Indian railway traffic service officer.

“Soon, we also saw train passengers donating their clothes for these walls. We intend to spread this initiative to more possible locations where privileged people can come forward and contribute to those in need - who can come by and pick up clothes to survive the severe winter months,” Kumar added.

Posted four months ago in Allahabad division, Kumar along with his senior divisional security commissioner Manoj Kumar Singh, was also credited for helping nearly 6,000 AMU students for a hassle-free and safe boarding of trains after police and university administrations asked the students to vacate hostels and leave for their homes, immediately, post anti-CAA clashes between police and students.

Title: Max temp 4 degrees below normal, possibility of rainfall on Jan 13
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Agra: The maximum temperature in Agra on Friday was recorded at four degrees Celsius below normal. Cold winds blew at a speed of 20 km-per-hour, causing shiver in morning and evening. There was a slight respite for people in the afternoon with mild sunshine spreading warmth.

According to the metrological department, with moderate fog, temperature is going to drop on Saturday and Sunday. There is a possibility of rainfall on Monday.

On Friday, the maximum temperature was recorded at 18.3 degrees Celsius. The minimum temperature remained at 6.7 degrees Celsius, which was one degree less than normal. In the evening, visibility level decreased below 500 meters.

Besides Agra, cold wave swept across Firozabad, Mathura, Etah, Aligarh and Mainpuri. In Aligarh, maximum temperature was recorded at 17.4 degrees Celsius. The mercury level in the entire region remained in the grip of cold wave.

To relieve people outdoors from the cold wave, Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) has installed gas heaters and is operating them during the evening at over a dozen places around the city. Besides, people setup bonfire at different places around the city.

Meanwhile, Friday's air quality index in Agra was recorded in the moderate category at 171. According to the central pollution control board (CPCB), particulate matter 2.5 remained the prominent pollutant. The air quality in moderate category can cause breathing discomfort to the people with lungs, asthma and heart diseases.

Title: Tirupur police reach out to public to launch dedicated beat system
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

TIRUPUR: The city police will soon launch a dedicated beat system by improving public participation.

Under the system, the city has been divided into 22 geographical areas called beats, police commissioner Sanjay Kumar told reporters. “There are 10 police stations including two all women police stations in the city. For each beat, WhatsApp groups that have 200 members either living or working in the respective beats have been formed. Each beat will have a dedicated police constable, who will frequently get in touch with the members of the groups as well as meet them in person,” the officer said.

“As many as 88 police constables have been deployed to conduct round-the-clock patrol. The personnel will interact with people and address law and order issues based on information they receive. We hope the drive will help our personnel gain confidence and bring public closer to us. We want to create a forum for open dialogue,” Kumar said.

Preparatory work for the dedicated beat system was launched two months ago, said deputy commissioner of police V Badrinarayanan. “Thanks to the system, as many as 4,400 people are in constant touch with us. It has helped us to improve policing. We could prevent a house break-in in Thirumuruganpoondi recently,” he said.

“Of the 22 beats, we have so far provided mobile tracking devices (MTD) in 10 beats. If an emergency call reaches toll-free number 100, the police personnel present near the crime scene would be assigned to attend the emergency. MTD, a GPS-enabled device, helps to increase accuracy and reduce the time in reaching the spot. We plan to have the device in all beats soon,” Badrinarayanan said.

As data collected from the field is entered in computers, even if a constable is transferred or promoted, the duties will be carried out seamlessly, said constable Sanjay.

Title: 10 sovereigns stolen from house
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Coimbatore: Unidentified burglars broke open a house on Nanjundapuram Road in the city on Thursday and decamped with 10 sovereigns of gold ornaments and Rs 5,000 in cash from the house.

Dhandapani, 56, of SNV Garden at Ramanathapuram, owns a welding workshop in the same locality. On Thursday morning, Dhandapani locked his house and went to a temple with his family members. When Dhandapani and his family returned home in the night, they found lock of the front door of the house broken open. Ten sovereigns of gold ornaments and Rs 5,000 were also missing from the almirah in the house.

Dhandapani informed Ramanathapuram (crime) police who rushed to the spot and held inquiry with the neighbours. The finger print experts also visited the house and lifted a few finger prints from the almirah and doors.

The Ramanathapuram police registered a case and further investigation is on.

Title: Suicides due to poverty up by 162% in Gujarat, unemployment by 21% in 2018
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Gujarat showed signs of distress related to economy when state authorities recorded 294 suicides in 2018 where reason for ending life was termed as ‘poverty’. According to the National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB) report ‘Accidental Deaths & Suicides in India’ released on Thursday, 318 persons ended their lives citing ‘unemployment’ as the reason.The figures were 163% and 21% more than the ones recorded in 2017.Among the cities, Ahmedabad recorded 31 suicides due to unemployment and Vadodara 18. The report also revealed that 67 persons ended lives due to bankruptcy and 136 for career issues in Gujarat.The biggest rise compared to 2017 was recorded in ‘daily wage earner’ category where compared to 2,131 in 2017, 2018 recorded 2,522 — a rise of 18.3%. The number of persons identified as ‘unemployed’ rose from 369 to 411 — a rise of 11.3%. In 891 cases, the suicide victims were identified as self-employed, a rise of 2% from 872 in 2017.The ‘professional’ category recorded a slight dip of 1% in suicide victims — from 869 to 856. Government employees were identified as suicide victims in 75 cases which were slightly higher compared to 69 in 2017. Retired persons also recorded 11.4% rise in suicides with 260 cases.Out of 7,793 suicide victims in 2018, 73.3% were earning less than Rs 1 lakh per annum, 25.5% were earning Rs 1 lakh to Rs 5 lakh, 1% Rs 5 lakh to Rs 10 lakh and 0.2% above Rs 10 lakh. Number of those committing suicide having over Rs 5 lakh per annum income got reduced by 55.5% from 182 in 2017 to 81 in 2018.

Title: Will get you booked under sedition charges: BJP leader threatens AMU students
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Agra: A day after some AMU students were booked for raising derogatory slogans against PM Narendra Modi and CM Yogi Adityanath, BJP leader Raghuraj Singh has threatened to get the students booked under sedition charges, if they do not stop indulging in anti-national activities.

The AMU students were booked on Thursday evening after they raised derogatory slogans against Modi and Yogi while participating in the formation of a human chain to express solidarity with JNU students and teachers, who were attacked by a mob in their campus in New Delhi.

Talking to media, Singh warned the students against opposing CAA and NRC and advised them to mend their ways. “Students will not be able get bails if they are booked under sedition charges,” he said, adding that the students were taking undue advantage of the situation by defaming the leaders.

Title: TN: Three dogs poisoned to death at Ramanathapuram
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: Three stray dogs were poisoned to death by unidentified miscreants at Ramanathapuram in the city on Friday.

A resident of Ramanathapuram lodged a complaint with the police after her attempt to save the dogs failed.

“Early this morning when we stepped out of our house, we noticed that one of the stray dogs was behaving abnormally. Shortly, we noticed that blood was gushing out from its mouth. As we were hurrying to take the dog to veterinary hospital, it died,” the complainant, J Indhumathi, said.

“In a few minutes, we noticed another dog dying in a similar way at a ground near our house at Vigneshpuram. One of our neighbors also shared a similar story with us,” she said. Doctors had confirmed that the dogs were poisoned to death, she said.

About a year ago, 10 stray days were poisoned to death in the same area.

Incidents of dogs being poisoned to death are often reported in the city. One of the reasons cited is that there is an increase in population of stray dogs, which some see as a menace.

“The corporation should be blamed for poisoning of dogs. The civic body has failed to act upon complaints regarding dog menace. Walk into any street and you will see a pack of dogs. The number of dogs has visibly increased in the recent times. They often chase people and bite them. People are just scared to walk on the streets,” G Aravind, a resident of RS Puram, said.

It has been two and half years since the corporation stopped implementing the animal birth control (ABC) programme in 80 wards after closing the dog shelter at Ukkadam in 2017. A corporation official said a dog shelter at Ondipudur is under construction. Once the shelter is commissioned, birth control programme would be restarted,” he told TOI.

Title: Madras HC puts focus on rampant misuse of ‘media’ sticker by fake journalists
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Expressing its dismay over the rampant misuse of ‘ Press ’ stickers and ‘media accreditation’ cards issued by the state government by persons with criminal backgrounds, the Madras high court has observed that some minimum criteria must be brought in for registering news magazines and papers.

“All the black sheep should be weeded out. A person who prints two papers claims to be a reporter or a media person. Due to such people, mainstream journalists are being sidelined. Even genuine reporters do not get accreditation card provided by the state government,” said a division bench of Justice N Kirubakaran and Justice P Velmurugan on Friday.

The bench made the observations while hearing a plea moved by Sekaran, who claimed to be a journalist. He alleged that retired IPS officer Pon Manickavel had made false claims in his report filed to the court in his capacity as a special officer of the idol wing CID.

Questioning his credentials as journalist, the bench directed the state to file a report as to the number of recognised news magazines and papers in the state along with the number of employees in each such organisation and details of accreditation cards provided. The court further directed the government to inform as to the availability of any scheme providing financial assistance to journalists in the event of their death. The state was directed to file the report by January 21.

“Like ‘ advocate ’ stickers, ‘press’ stickers are also misused by many with criminal background claiming to be a reporter. The court wants the state to file a status report as to the number of cases filed against fake journalists for blackmailing and exploiting businessmen,” the bench added.

Title: SC allows student to challenge HC order banning protests in AMU
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Agra: While refusing to interfere with the Allahabad high court order banning protests and rallies either at the main gate of the administrative block of the Aligarh Muslim University ( AMU ) or within a 100-meter radius of the block and the vice chancellor’s official residence within the campus, the Supreme Court on Thursday allowed the petitioner to challenge the High court order.

Appearing for the petitioner, Huzaifa Aamir Rashadi, who is former students’ union secretary, senior advocate Indira Jaising assisted by advocate Paras Nath Singh, submitted an application before the apex court stating that the high court’s order was passed behind the backs of students.

A two-judge bench of the Supreme Court comprising Justices Sanjay Kishan Kaul and KM Joseph proceeded to grant liberty to the petitioner to approach the concerned High Court, if the decision was indeed passed behind the backs of the students.

“The Allahabad high court on May 17, 2019 on the petition filed by the AMU administration, had banned dharnas at AMU’s administrative block main gate or within its 100-meter radius. However, the Aligarh district administration had told the high court that the protest was staged in a very peaceful manner and there was no question of deterioration of law and order in the university,” said advocate Paras.

The high court had further directed the university to earmark an area where the students could congregate freely in a peaceful manner to protest.

Title: Anti-CAA protesters vandalise Shiv Sena functionary’s car
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Tirupur: Miscreants attacked a Shiv Sena functionary’s car while the vehicle was passing through a road where a protest against the citizenship amendment Act was under way on Friday. Muslim outfits including Aikkiya Sunnath Jamath were staging a the protest against the central government for amending the CAA at CTC bus stop junction on Kangeyam Road around 3pm when the incident happened. Police had diverted vehicles at a traffic signal before the CTC bus stop towards Valam Bridge. While all motorists abided by the traffic diversion, Muruga Dineshkumar, a Shiv Sena functionary, refused to take the alternative route and drove through the stretch where the protest was staged. When the vehicle was passing through the crowd, some miscreants hurled stones on the car damaging the windshield.TNN

Title: Project to produce biodiesel from used cooking oil
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Coimbatore: The food safety department plans to launch the repurpose used cooking oil (Ruco) project in the district next month to turn used edible oil from the food industry into biodiesel.

With the city corporation refusing to collect used oil and no other disposal method available, restaurants, bakeries and sweet makers here have been selling the oil to smaller food business operators and soap manufacturing units. Some pour it down the drains, leading to clogs.

Officials of the department, who recently attended a meeting conducted by the Food Safety and Standards Authority of India in New Delhi, had met some people who run units that process cooking oil and convert it into biodiesel the closest one being in Hyderabad.

According to a survey conducted by the department, 150-200 large-scale food business operators in the district generate 30,000 litres of used oil a day. The department plans to make them collect the oil daily and hand it over to an agent. “We are trying to identify an agent, who can collect the used oil from hotels and store it in a godown and then transport it to a processing unit to turn it into biodiesel,” designated food safety officer K Tamilselvan said. “The agents will pay the hotels for the oil collected, so they don’t lose the revenue they were earning.”

The department hopes agents can collect oil from large-scale food business operators in Coimbatore from February to kick-start the project. It has identified 150 food business operators who consume more than 50 litres of cooking oil a day for the initiative.

The project is operational in Madurai, where 8,000 litres of used cooking oil is collected each day from 55 food outlets and restaurants. “They have some teething issues, but they are being sorted out,” Tamilselvan told TOI.

Gastroenterologists warn against the reuse of cooking oil, which leads to short and long-term health issues. Studies show that a series of complex chemical reactions take place altering constituents of cooking oil and free fatty acids, ketones, alcohols and other radicals are released when it is reheated.

“While it often leads to acidity and indigestion issues, in the long-term, it can lead to stomach and esophageal cancer,” Dr V G Mohan of VGM Hospital told TOI.

Title: Higher reaches in U’khand covered with snow; clear weather helps in restoration and repair work
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Uttarkashi/Dehradun: With clear weather and bright sunshine since the early hours of the day on Friday, there was a much-needed respite to people from the rains and snowfall of the past few days. Both the plains and the hills of the Himalayan state received abundant sunshine and it also provided the opportunity for relevant departments to ensure that the snow was cleared from the roads and electricity supply restored in the affected villages.

According to information provided by state emergency operation centre, almost all the state highways were opened for traffic movement on Friday. However, around 50 rural roads, mainly those in remote belts, were still covered with snow and consequently remained blocked. The highest number of blocked rural roads was reported in Uttarkashi district. Meanwhile, the Met department predicted that clear weather conditions will continue for some more days.

Met director Bikram Singh said, “Similar weather conditions are expected to continue till January 12. Another spell of rain is predicted from January 13 onwards.”

Meanwhile, despite facing difficulties like blocked roads and interrupted water and electricity supplies, residents of Uttarkashi, particularly farmers and tour operators, expressed delight over this year’s record snowfall. They claimed that timely snowfall especially in lower altitudes will be beneficiary for agriculture and tourism sector of the hill district, and will eventually boost the local economy.

Apple farmer from Sukki village, Mohan Singh Rana said, “Timely snowfall will increase the productivity of apple, walnut, apricot, pear and peach. Even though we have faced difficulties like cutting off of roads and disruption in power and water supply, we are pleased with the snowfall, as it is going to be a big boost for our local economy in the long run.”

President of Uttarkashi trekking and mountaineering association, Jayendra Rana added, “Adventure lovers used to travel to high-altitude areas to enjoy snow, but now they will get similar experience by visiting nearby destinations such as Assi Ganga valley, Varunawat mountain top and Chaurangikhal, without any difficulty. Besides, tourists and pilgrims can also see sufficient snow at Himalayan shrines and high-altitude areas such as Dodital, Dayara Bugyal, Kedarkantha, Har ki Doon and Tapovan till April-May.”

Title: Madras HC allows Ramaswamy trust’s horses to race
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Madras high court

CHENNAI: In a reprieve to industrialist A C Muthiah , the Madras high court has permitted the trust (Dr MAM Ramaswamy Chettiar of Chettinad Charitable Trust) managed by him to field horses in upcoming races organised by Madras Race Club (MRC). Earlier, the club management had restrained the trust from participating in the races citing a dispute over ownership and registration of horses bequeathed from late M A M Ramaswamy.

The court directed the race club to collect necessary entry and other fees so as to enable the participation of the horses of the trust in the classic races conducted by it in the 2020–21 season. The court also made it clear that the trust shall not be prevented from using the gold brown racing jersey which was originally allotted to M A M Ramaswamy.

Justice Senthilkumar Ramamoorthy passed the interim order, after refusing to accept the contention of the club management that a public trust cannot own horses and participate in races.

Citing the Hyderabad Race Club case, the judge said, “Statute might provide exemption from tax to buildings used for religious, educational and charitable purposes and is, therefore, not an authority for the broad proposition that a public trust cannot be a horse owner or cannot participate in horse races.”

The issue pertains to an order passed by the stewards of the club dated December 27, 2019, directing the trust to apply to the club for ownership/usage of racing colour in the appropriate form, with the necessary supporting documents and fee. It further ordered that the trust is ineligible to race the horses pending registration of ownership and to use the racing colours pending registration. All entry of horses by the trust made as on the date were also cancelled.

The order was passed on the basis of a representation made by MAMR Muthiah, foster son of Ramaswamy, alleging that the trust was unfounded and that his father Ramaswamy was not stable in the fag end of his life and using it some persons had attempted to grab his assets, including the horses owned by him, illegally.

Challenging the order, the trust moved the high court contending that Ramaswamy disowned his foster son even during his life time and that the entire properties owned by him, including the horses, had been transferred to the public trust only as per his will.

Title: ‘No CAA’ roar rents the air as sea of Tricolour soars in city
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

AIMIM Chief Asaduddin Owaisi (centre) surrounded by a sea of Tricolour during the ‘Tiranga Rally’ to protest t... Read More

Hyderabad: Tens of thousands of people holding the Tricolour in their hands swarmed a public meeting place in Hyderabad on Friday to protest the Citizenship (Amendment) Act.

Less than a week after a similar rally brought the city to a halt, the ‘Tiranga Rally’ organised by AIMIM president Asaduddin Owaisi under the United Muslims Action Committee banner, saw thousands of men, women and the elderly march to the Shastripuram grounds for a public meeting.

It was the first such rally organised by MIM where protesters condemned Telangana chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao for his silence on CAA and NRC.

Earlier in the day, thousands gathered at the Mir Alam Eidgah to offer Friday prayers before they began a 2-km march to an open ground in the Old City where Christian organisations, advocates, students from Osmania University, school teachers and children joined the Hyderabad MP’s march with supporters in tow.

“If someone from the government or police insists that you show your Aadhaar card, will you show it to them?” asked Owaisi, as the crowd waving the Tricolour replied in unison: “No, we will not.”

“If someone from the government asks your identity proof tell them you are Indian. I urge the government and police not to force people to show documents,” Owaisi said at the massive gathering.

While the ‘Million March’ last week was organised by some 40 small Muslim groups, without the support of Owaisi’s All India Majlis-e-Ittehadul Muslimeen, on Friday the Old City again wore a deserted look after MIM cadres urged traders to down shutters and join the march in an equal show of strength.

“Listen India’s Prime Minister, these people here reject CAA. I once again appeal to the government of India to take back CAA, stop the work pertaining to NPR and National Register of Citizens (NRC),” Owaisi said amid huge applause.

A sea of people was seen moving in different directions by taking narrow lanes to get closer to the stage where members of the committee were addressing the crowd.

“Leke Rahenge Azadi”, (We will take our freedom) “Hindustan Zindabad” (Long live India) and “Baap Ladey Goron Se, Aur Hum Ladenge Choro Se” (Our fathers fought the White people, we will fight the thieves) were the most common slogans raised.

People also condemned the attack on Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) students, apart from raising slogans against PM Narendra Modi. Woman who participated in large numbers also raised anti-Modi slogans and backed JNU students. “Goons barged into the JNU campus and targeted students. They have the support of police and Central government,” said a woman.

Title: Nod to construction of biomedical waste plant in Dehradun
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

DEHRADUN: The proposal for the construction of a biomedical waste plant was approved during the board meeting of Dehradun Municipal Corporation (DMC) on Friday.

The plant will be constructed under public-private partnership (PPP) model.

The plant has been approved in view of the increase in the amount of biomedical waste collection in the city. As per the estimates of the civic body , the city produces around 300 metric tonnes of garbage daily.

“Hospitals and other medical facilities are fast increasing in the city. As a consequence, there is an increase in the amount of biomedical waste. Thus, there is an urgent need for a biomedical waste plant in the city. At present, there is only one biomedical waste plant in the entire Garhwal region and that is situated in Roorkee . The performance of that plant is not up to mark and our contract with them is running on an extension,” DMC commissioner Vinay Shankar Pandey told TOI.

The official added that the biomedical waste generated from all the 100 wards of the city will be treated in the proposed plant.

Decisions regarding profit sharing, selection of firm, and others will be taken after further discussion, he added.

Title: Dehradun Municipal Corporation board meeting: Smart vending zones, open gyms, waste management discussed
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

DEHRADUN: Several proposals relating to civic facilities were approved during the board meeting of Dehradun Municipal Corporation (DMC) on Friday. The meeting was attended by senior DMC officials and ward councillors of the city.

During the meeting, ten different locations in the city were selected for smart vending zones. Two vending zones each will be put up in Gujrada, Malsi, and Harbhaj Wala ward. Danda Lakhond, Banjarawala, Nanur Khera, and Aamwala wards will have one smart vending zone each.

The proposal to make open gym chargeable was also approved in the meeting. The cost of gym's yearly membership has been fixed at Rs 1,800. The use of an open gym was made chargeable after it was found out that several people were not using the equipment properly. Casual use by some people has impacted the functioning of equipment, say officials.

Several locations — including Nehru Colony, Indira Nagar, Ekta Park, Vijay Park, Harrawala, among others — were chosen for developing open gyms. Also, the DMC announced that extra plastic dustbins will be installed in the city, especially in the newly added wards. Several councillors of new wards complained about the poor service of the door-door garbage collection facility, to which the DMC officials assured them that the health department has taken steps in this regard and the service will improve by next month.

It was also decided that people suffering from leprosy will be relieved from paying house tax. The DMC also approved the proposal to start social policing. For this, authority will be given to members of various NGOs, RWAs, and other organisations, who have a track record of taking initiatives to improve the sanitation condition of the city. These organisations would have the power to impose fine on people who throw garbage in public space.

“The DMC will shortlist some locals, who have actively participated to improve the sanitation levels of Dehradun. The list will mostly comprise of members from various NGOs and RWAs. They will be given proper training and will be issued with identification cards. They will have the power to impose fine the moment they see anyone violating rules and littering the road with waste,” said DMC commissioner Vinay Shankar Pandey.

The DMC has also decided to construct a few wedding halls in the city. These halls would cost Rs 5000 (at most) for an entire day. After requests from the councillors, the DMC has decided to form a committee which will decide whether it is feasible to lower the charges of these halls or not.

Yet another important decision was to relax the property tax rates in all 100 wards of the city. The updated rates will be announced soon. Apart from the above decisions, some other minor proposals were also approved during the meeting.

Title: Madhya Pradesh: EOW cracks down on gutka firms, child labourers rescued
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

The labourers rescued from a gutka factory at Govindpura. (R)

BHOPAL: Madhya Pradesh EOW on Friday raided business establishments of prominent pan masala and gutka manufacturers in Bhopal, Indore and Gwalior following complaints of massive tax evasions.

Several child labourers were rescued during the operation, say officials.

Raids were conducted at factories of some of the top brands in Govindpura around 4.30am. Separate teams raided other gutka companies in Indore and Gwalior. The raid team in the state capital was led by EOW SP Arun Mishra. Ready stocks worth more than Rs 5 crore were found at these units.

EOW had shortlisted these companies immediately after chief minister Kamal Nath ordered a crackdown last week. On January 3, in his first meeting of the year with bureaucrats, CM Nath had said: “Shudh Ke Liye Yudh is a massive drive that is gathering popularity through public support. But there needs to be action against gutka and paan masala sellers, apart from cartels involved in the manufacture and supply of fake medicines.”

“Anyone indulging in unethical business, jeopardising public health with adulteration or causing loss to the government will be dealt with strongly. We have eyes on all such people,” said EOW DG Sushovan Banerjee. A member of the raiding party in Bhopal pointed towards the stacks of gutka at a factory, and said: “We suspect they supply gutka packs worth Rs 25 crore a day, far in excess of what they have disclosed in their records. They produce the excess amount at night and by 9am the next morning, the ‘unaccounted’ packs are sent off to different destinations. They have 40 labourers only to load packs of gutka pouches in trucks, so you can imagine the amount of gutka that is produced and supplied from this factory alone.”

Knowing that the clandestinely produced gutka is loaded in trucks early in the morning, the EOW team raided at 4.30am. As they detected more illegal activities — like child labour and mixing of tobacco in gutka— personnel from departments like labour, revenue, commercial tax, excise, central excise and police also joined the operation.

Officials say the government had been trying to plug leakage of revenue from gutka and tobacco companies. Excise duty is calculated under ‘Pan Masala Packing Machines (Capacity Determination and Collection of Duty) Rules, 2008’, modified in 2010, and ranges from Rs 14 lakh to Rs 77 lakh, depending upon the price per packet of pan masala (non-tobacco) and production capacity of machines. For flavoured supari, the tariff is charged on MRP. Duty is calculated at 2.36% per packet, excluding 35% abatement.

It is alleged that the companies had been underreporting the capacity of their machines in collusion with a section regulatory officials. “We are involving various departments in the raid. There are multiple issues, ranging from adulteration, hygiene, tax evasion, child labour, labour exploitation, electricity theft, and GST. We will be comparing the volume of production with the tax paid. Machines will be checked to assess production capacity,” said an officer.

Considering the increase in average speed of packing machines, the government had revised the capacity of production and consequently increased the duty applicable under the compounded levy scheme to pan masala and tobacco products, including gutka, chewing tobacco, unmanufactured tobacco and ‘filter khaini’, machine-packed in pouches. “Manufacturers are creative enough to dodge regulators. They have machines that can pack 900 pouches in a minute and run 24x7. Their production capacity is beyond imagination,” he added.

“The manufacturer makes a declaration regarding the number of packing machines installed in the factory, on the basis of which monthly duty determined per machine is paid.
