Mismatch has been found in the declaration and production capacity of machines,” said the officer. The role of some excise officers are also under scanner for siding with these companies.

Title: CM KCR’s silence on CAA echoes in rally
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Hyderabad: Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao’s silence on CAA echoed loudly in the protest rally organised by his ally MIM on Friday.

Many protesters carried banners against the CM, while slogans rent the air urging him to speak up.

After offering Friday prayers at Mir Alam Eidgah, as the crowd moved towards the meeting venue they carried black banners taunting KCR: “Kab khoon khaulega tera, muh khol kuch to bol” (When will your blood boil, open mouth and say something). Another read: “Steering apne haath mein hai, phir ye car galat raste par kyoun jari” (Car steering is in our hands, then why is car moving in wrong direction).

The anti-KCR posters stumped the state intelligence too. Since the protest against NRC and CAA broke out, this was the first major rally where public came out openly against the TRS government’s silence on the issue. The cops tried to corner the agitators carrying anti-KCR banners, but they swiftly moved towards the public venue. “Like CMs of other opposition ruled states such as Kerala and West Bengal, KCR should also be vocal about the draconian law,” said Mirza Baig, one of the protesters.

Title: PMPML short of around 600 buses, ridership affected
Content:
In 2018, PMPML scrapped nearly 240 old buses and got only 158 buses as replacement.

PUNE: The Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML) is short of around 600 buses even after the procurement of 119 e-buses and 400 CNG-run vehicles in 2019, an official of the transport body said.“The present PMPML-owned fleet has 1,650 vehicles. Our aim is to cater to 20 lakh passengers a day. Now, the PMPML caters to 12 lakh commuters daily because of bus shortage. To achieve the target, new buses would be needed as we had to scrap around 400 buses,” a senior PMPML official said.The PMPML’s daily ridership has been more or less stagnant from 2009, the official said. “We hope to get 500 new buses by March. If the procurement is done on time, we can scrap the old buses. As the new buses are taking time, the ones that needed to be scrapped are still operational. Timely induction of the 500 buses, would turn things around for the transport body,” the official said.In 2018, PMPML scrapped nearly 240 old buses and got only 158 buses as replacement. “The deficit is affecting the ridership,” another official said.PMP Pravasi Manch activist Sanjay Shitole had a different point of view. “Why does the PMPML think that the ridership would increase only if new buses were inducted? In the past few years, the PMPML has got some new buses. Then why has its ridership been stagnant? If they focused on punctuality, buses not breaking down and not skipping stops, the ridership would increase,” he said. A daily commuter Samar Datre agreed. “If punctuality and maintenance are assured, we would be happier using the service,” he said.

Title: Gauri Lankesh murder suspect arrested in Jharkhand
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

AURANGABAD/RANCHI: The Karnataka special investigation team (SIT) probing the murder of activist-journalist Gauri Lankesh arrested a suspect from Katras in Jharkhand's Dhanbad district on Thursday. The suspect, Rushikesh Devdikar (44), was named in an earlier chargesheet filed in the murder case. A local court in Dhanbad allowed the Karnataka team to take Devdikar on a three-day transit remand.

Devdikar lived in Aurangabad till two years ago and ran a store there. Early on Friday, the Karnataka SIT, along with the local unit of the anti-terrorism squad (ATS), went to the house where Devdikar lived. An ATS officer told TOI they had come to Aurangabad to verify information on Devdikar. "The suspect resided in the city till 2-3 years ago and operated a store. He had also taken a shop on rent," the officer said.

Jagdish Kulkarni, owner of the shop taken on rent by Devdikar, said, "He was very religious. He took my shop on rent and ran a store for two years before closing it down. While leaving, he said he was shifting to his in-laws' place in Solapur."

Police sources said Devdikar was picked up from a house at Bhagat mohallah in Katras, Dhanbad, on Thursday. He was working at a petrol pump in Katras for the past seven months, said IG (operations) Saket Kumar Singh, who is also the spokesperson for the Jharkhand police.

SSP (Dhanbad) Kishore Kaushal said, "The Karnataka police informed us that the suspect is right-leaning and was involved in several other murder cases." Police said nothing objectionable was found at Devrikar's Katras residence.

Lankesh was shot dead on September 5, 2017 in front of her house in Bengaluru. So far, the Karnataka SIT has arrested 16 other suspects in connection with the murder and filed chargesheets.

The investigative agencies from Maharashtra and Karnataka are working together after common links in the murders of Dr Narendra Dabholkar, Prof M M Kalburgi, Govind Pansare and Lankesh. Prior to this, the Central Bureau of Investigation, which is probing the Dabholkar murder case, had arrested Sachin Andure, who was from Aurangabad. CBI alleged that Andure was among the two persons who shot at Dabholkar in Pune in 2013.

Title: Pune: Senior officials term technicians ‘unfit for job’
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

PUNE: A section of the senior officials of the city’s transport utility have termed its team of in-house technicians as “untrained” and “inexperienced” in the maintenance of the newly procured electric and midi-buses.

The comment came a day after the board of directors of the Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML) approved a plan to float a tender for hiring a special team of technicians for the maintenance of midi-buses.

“The board accepted our proposal to outsource technicians for the maintenance of the midi fleet. The reason being, the present team of in-house technicians are untrained and inexperienced to deal with the new technology,” said a senior official, on the condition of anonymity.

As per the sources, the PMPML has a fleet of over 150 technicians, maintaining buses at 13 depots. At present, the public transport utility has 119 e-buses and 233 midi-buses.

“There is a staff crunch, considering that the PMPML continues to increase its fleet tally over the years. We strongly feel that the new buses need a special team of technicians. Many of the mechanics we have now were doing a completely different job before being transferred to the current position,” the official said.

“All the midi-buses have been manufactured by the Tata Motors. These buses have smaller engines and are technologically advanced. In December, two PMPML technicians had suffered injuries following an explosion in a midi-bus that was under maintenance. This shows how ill-equipped they are to handle these buses,” the official added.

A text message was sent to PMPML chairman and managing director Nayana Gunde on reasons behind hiring outsourced technicians for the buses. The reply was awaited till going to press.

The comments of the senior officials about the in-house technicians sparked dismay among the activists. They said the officials of the transport utility were demeaning their own organisation.

“If you feel you technicians are ill-equipped to look after the newly procured buses, why not train them better? Such comments clearly shows that there is no scientific and planned approach involved,” said PMP Pravasi Manch’s Sanjay Shitole.

Title: Two-day summit on dental implants starts today
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Over 250 students will undergo hands-on training in dental implant during the two-day summit that will start on Saturday.

Implantology is a super-specialised branch in dentistry, which is not taught in detail in dental colleges and awaits for proper platform. The summit aims to bridge this gap.

Dental Implant Care Foundation (DICF), an organisation working on upgrading dental implantology, will conduct the summit, Youthasia, in association with Sinhgad Dental College. “The students and practitioners can opt for careers in dental implants after attending the summit,” implantologist Mohit zamad, DICF founder-president, said.

The conference is exclusively for the beginners of implantology to undergo scientific orientation. Implantologists, including Nitin Vaidya ( Raipur ), Dhruv Arora ( New Delhi ), Sujit Bopardikar (Mumbai), Vipin Sood (New Delhi), Venkat Nag (Hyderabad) and Aakanksha Zamad (Nagpur), will guide the participants.

“This summit will benefit students who are pursuing bachelor or master degree in dental surgery,” Zamad said.

Title: Madhya Pradesh: Relief to victims now focus in war against land mafia
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

FIRs have been registered against over 200 housing societies in MP. (File photo)

BHOPAL: The war against land mafia in MP that started last month, has now reached its next phase. After booking land mafiosi and bulldozing illegally-raised structures, the government will now focus on providing relief to victims who bought plots in various housing societies, but never got it.

FIRs are registered against more than 200 housing societies in MP; a majority of such complaints are registered in Indore and Bhopal . Government has decided to address the issue in three ways. First, the district registrars having judicial powers would exercise their powers and pass relevant orders.

Second, a proposal has been mooted to have full-time public prosecutors in Bhopal and Indore; and the third is to bring the ADG cooperative fraud under the cooperation department for speedy recovery of such cases.

Officials source said, the chief minister has already given a nod to bring ADG cooperative fraud under the cooperation department in review meet of drive against land mafia last week and the actual process would be initiated soon. The district registrars are already on job to pass adequate orders. The government received around 2000 complaints against the societies in Indore and Bhopal. Out of these, around 1500 are from Indore and remaining 500 from Bhopal.

Principal secretary, cooperation department, Ajeet Kesari said that purpose of the drive would not be solved unless people affected due to land mafia get relief. It started after chief minister Kamal Nath declared war on ‘mafia of all kinds’. He ordered a crackdown on syndicates that run land rackets, drug rings and muscle into mining and cooperative sector. The drive was started in Indore last month and soon spread to the entire state. Various departments were asked to make a list of land defaulters and put members of land mafia behind the bars. Civic bodies are carrying out anti-encroachment drives in Bhopal, Indore, Gwalior and Jabalpur as a part of this drive.

Title: Any attack on exchange of art is attack on India: Kamal Nath
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Madhya Pradesh Chief Minister Kamal Nath addressing BLF 2020 at Bharat Bhawan in Bhopal on Friday. Former Unio... Read More

BHOPAL: Chief minister Kamal Nath inaugurated the second edition of the Bhopal Literature Festival 2020 at Bharat Bhawan on Friday.

Speaking at the inaugural he said, “Any attack on the liberal exchange in arts and literature is an attack on India.” Welcoming the authors and speakers participating in the event, he said, “Madhya Pradesh — the Heart of India — has a rich culture and diversity. Such festivals will help in branding MP as a state of rich literature.”

“I heard that director of the festival Raghav Chandra said that such festivals focus on liberal expression and exchange of arts and literature. This liberal exchange is something we have to treasure as it been the ethos of our country. Brotherhood and tolerance are the ethos of India since the time of Ashoka and Chandra Gupt Maurya. It is our duty to protect this ethos as any assault on them is actually an assault on India. We have to preserve this for generations to come,” the CM said.

He further said, such festivals will help in branding Madhya Pradesh as the state of literature.

Seeing Bharat Bhawan quiet and secluded made me unhappy, he said, adding that more events like the BLF should be held regularly to keep alive the spirit of the multi-art centre. “After becoming the CM of the state, I felt very unhappy while passing Bharat Bhawan as there would be no activity. I have seen this place as a jungle, I have also seen Bharat Bhawan being inaugurated and seeing it in a state of inactivity made me sad. I hope more such events happen here and we turn Bharat Bhawan into a better Bharat Bhawan”, he said.

On a lighter note the CM added, “I am delighted to be here at BLF, I don’t know how politicians and arts go together, but I am here. Other than me only Jairam Ramesh is here and I keep my distance from him as I keep away from people who are more intellectually superior to me.”

Culture minister Dr Vijaylakshmi Sadho also welcomed the guests and authors and appreciated the efforts of the organizing team for inviting a number of noted authors to the City of Lakes.

Title: MBBS, BDS fee can be charged only for 4.5yrs, not 5yrs: HC
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Hyderabad: The Telangana high court on Friday rapped private medical colleges, saying they cannot collect fee from MBBS and BDS students for five years when the course duration was only four-and-a-half years.

The court was also critical of the state government and Telangana Admission and Fee Regulatory Committee (TAFRC) for siding with the private college managements instead of standing up for parents and students.

A bench of Justice MS Ramachandra Rao and Justice K Lakshman pronounced the verdict in a petition filed by a student, D Padma Teja, of Warangal district. “The period of study of MBBS course as per the Medical Council of India regulations on graduate medical education, 1997, is only four-and-a-half years and not five years,” the bench said.

It said the private colleges should collect year-wise fee for four years. For the remaining six-month period, half-yearly fee should be collected, it said. “It was unfortunate that rules framed by the higher education wing did not provide an opportunity either to students or parents’ association before TAFRC decides upon the contentions of private medical colleges’ association,” the bench said.

Ripping into TAFRC and the government, it said this deprives the students and parents of any scope to protect their interests over fee fixation. “Neither the state government nor TAFRC seem to be bothered about this serious omission in the rules.”

The bench, in its order, said: “We accordingly declare that the action of TAFRC in recommending as well as the action of the state government of Telangana in accepting the recommendation and also in issuing GO (Ms No. 120) on July 20, 2017, permitting the private medical colleges to collect tuition fee from students for five years as arbitrary and illegal.”

The bench categorically said the colleges should collect fee for only four-and-a-half years only. It brushed aside the argument that the authorities were doing it keeping in view of the needs of those who fail in MBBS exams.

“Such exceptions cannot be generalised and it is unfair to ask all the students to bear the burden,” the bench added.

Title: Pune: DCB to finalise monthly waste collection fees soon
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD : The Dehu Road Cantonment Board ( DCB ) will soon finalise the monthly user charges for garbage collection.

Ramswroop Haritwal, DCB’s chief executive officer, said the authorities have prepared the draft bye-laws for solid waste management, which were discussed at the monthly board meeting on Wednesday. “The suggestions and objections from the citizens will be invited soon, following which a hearing will be conducted. The DCB will then approve a resolution about charging user fees from property holders for garbage collection,” he said.

The proposed user charges for houses will vary from Rs 50-150 depending on the dwelling size. Commercial establishments, hospitals, clinics, and others too will pay the monthly user charges.

Elected members Raghuvir Shelar, Vishal Khandelwal, Gopal Tantarpale, Rahul Balghare, Sarika Naiknavare and Aruna Pinjan pointed out that the user charges for houses were too high. “This was bound to result in dumping of garbage on roadsides,” an elected member said.

Brig Sanjay Khanna, who presided over the Wednesday meeting, said the residents, commercial and healthcare establishments should segregate garbage at source into wet, dry and hazardous. The cantonment should collect the charges every month, he said.

Elected member Shelar said the cantonment collected Rs 200 as annual charges for garbage collection so there was a need for the cantonment to provide two bins per house every five years for garbage segregation.

Title: CM Kamal Nath rebuts Shivraj Singh Chouhan’s claims on new liquor policy
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Kamal Nath

BHOPAL: CM Kamal Nath and former CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan had a war of words over liquor policy on Friday.

Chouhan, LOP Gopal Bhargava and state BJP president Rakesh Singh launched a direct attack on Congress and CM Nath, saying the new policy of allowing licence holders to open sub-shops by paying extra will turn the state into ‘Madira Pradesh’

On Thursday, the state government issued a gazette notification to allow opening of liquor sub-shops within a gap of 5km between two shops in municipal areas and 10km in rural areas. Congress justified the stand by terming it as step to counter adulterated liquor trade in state.

“The decision will lead to opening of 2,000 to 2,500 new liquor shops in MP. Congress wants to turn Madhya Pradesh into ‘Madira Pradesh’. The government wants unemployed youths to remain inebriated so that they cannot question it. Chief minister Kamal Nath claims he is running a drive against mafia, but he is working for liquor mafia. Opening of new liquor shops will increase crimes against women. When BJP was in power, it did not open new liquor shop and decided to go for phased liquor ban in MP. Did Congress mention in its manifesto that it would open new liquor shops? I have written to the CM to cancel it. If the decision is not rolled back, BJP will hit to streets to protest against the decision,” said Chouhan.

CM Nath was quick to respond. Chouhan’s claim that no new liquor shop was opened during his tenure was false, Nath said.

“When Congress was in power in the state till 2003, there were 2,792 liquor shops in MP, including IMFL and countrymade liquor shops. It increased to 3,683 in Chouhan's tenure by 2010-11. As per the population and area, MP has far fewer liquor shops than BJP-ruled Uttar Pradesh . There are five liquor shops in MP per 1 lakh population, while in UP there are 12 liquor shops per lakh population,” CM Nath said.

The CM also told Chouhan that his estimate that the new policy will lead to opening of 2,000 to 2,500 new liquor shops in state is incorrect. “As per the policy, no new liquor shop would be opened and only subshop can be opened by liquor license holders that too with prerequisite conditions,” Nath said.

MP law and minister P C Sharma held a press conference to counter BJP’s claims and shared details of action taken by government against illegal sale, possession and transportation of liquor.

“As many as 400 new liquor shops were opened in the tenure of Shivraj Singh Chouhan as CM. Crimes against women were highest in the country during Chouhan’s tenure. With the new policy, government just wants to ensure that ones who want to drink get quality liquor and not adulterated,” he said.

Bhargava said Congress has started sale of liquor in religious cities. The new policy would add to incidents of domestic violence and crime against women

Title: UP Board of Madrassa Educationreduces number of question papers
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Bareilly: On the lines of ICSE and CBSE boards, UP Board of Madrassa Education has reduced the number of question papers to a maximum of six examinations for Munshi/ Maulvi (Class X) and Alim (Class XII).

Madrassa students earlier used to appear for more than 10 subjects but they will now have to write five compulsory and one optional subject. The madrassa board exams will take place in February.

During a meeting of board officials with experts, it was decided to cut down the number of question papers to facilitate students along the lines of other boards, including UP Board for Secondary Education, ICSE and CBSE. After officials reduced the number of question papers, they merged a few subjects. For instance, the students appearing for Munshi/ Maulvi exams will have one question paper of theology (Sunni/ Shia) for three topics - Tafseer, Hadith and Fiqha.

Besides, the board has introduced sessional marks in each subject in which students will be given marks on assignment, attendance and viva voice/ moral activities for the first time. The students of Munshi/ Maulvi will have 20 sessional marks in each paper while Alim students will have 30 sessional marks.

Deewan Saheb Jaman Khan, state general secretary, Teachers’ Association Madaris Arabia Uttar Pradesh, said, “The aim of conducting exams is to test the knowledge of students and it can be done with less number of question papers. As the board officials have reduced the number of papers to almost half, it will reduce the burden on the students.”

According to officials, Bareilly has nearly 450 madrassas. District minorities’ welfare officer Jagmohan Singh said, “In Bareilly district, 7,154 students will appear for madrassa exams. The number of students has decreased in comparison to last year as a few students used to appear for both UP Board of Secondary Education and UP Board of Madrassa Education. As exams of both boards will clash this time, the number of applications has decreased by 1,000.”

Title: Maharashtra: Man falls 100 feet at Sinhagad fort, mom’s call aids his rescue
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Members of rescue team carry software engineer Pravin Thakre on a stretcher on Friday

PUNE: His mother’s casual call to him from Nagpur on Thursday night saved the life of an injured software engineer, who had fallen 100 feet down into a gorge from ‘Wind Point’ at Sinhagad fort earlier in the evening.

The software engineer, Pravin Thakre (28), had gone to the fort alone. He told his mother, who called him around 9pm, that he had fallen into the gorge in the evening and was lying there virtually immobile as he had sustained injuries to his back and hands.

Shaken, the mother shared her son’s plight with relatives and friends. Thakre’s sister and two friends flew down to Pune on the first available flight and reached the fort on Friday morning.

A man on the fort, Mihir Behere, saw the trio searching for Thakre and helped them begin the rescue effort. Thakre, who works with a leading software company in Bhosari, was brought out of the gorge around 10am by two team members of mountaineering club Giripremi and villagers.

Dr Prashant Gaikwad of a private hospital in Khadakwasla, where Thakre has been admitted, told TOI, “His condition is stable now and he is out of danger. He has suffered lumbar and cervical trauma.”

Gaikwad said, “Thakre told us that he was clicking photographs of the sunset from ‘Wind Point’ when he lost balance and fell into the gorge. No one noticed him fall. He was unable to move because of the injuries. He somehow managed to tell his mother about the fall when she called around 9pm.”

Not knowing whom to contact in Pune, Thakre’s sister and friends began searching for him at Sinhagad fort by calling out his name. “But they were not able to trace him because of the fog,” said Behere.

Behere immediately called up Umesh Zirpe of Giripremi. “Two of our club members, Siddharth Jadhav and Atul Murmure, were on the fort then. They, along with Ghera Sinhagad deputy sarpanch Amol Padher and his team, found Thakre lying in the gorge. Our team members had a stretcher with them. They brought Thakre to the top within half-an-hour and took him to hospital,” Zirpe said.

Padher told TOI that Thakre lay on the grass in the gorge the whole night. “Had his parents contacted the Pune police control room, we would have rescued him in the night itself,” he said.

Title: Independent journalism crucial to health of democracy: US Consul General
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

BHOPAL: No democracy can run without independent journalism. It is due to independent and strong journalism that transparency in democracy and government's responsibility towards the people is determined. Consul General of the US Consulate, David J Ranz, said this during his visit to the Makhanlal Chaturvedi National Journalism and Communication University here on Friday.

In his address, Ranz said that he respects the challenges and risky profession of journalism. Speaking on Indo-American relations in the conference session, Rainz said that the transparency, trade, values and not interfering in each other's internal affairs are important links for the relations between the two countries. "Both countries have touched new heights of relations. India and America are geo-strategic partners, whose cultural values as well as mutual interests are common for development," said Ranz.

Describing India as a fast-growing economy, he said that multinational companies can invest a lot to further strengthen India's economy, provided India makes an effective change in its trade and investment policies.

On this occasion, Rainz also answered several questions raised by the media students. Answering questions about America's role on climate change, he said that large developing countries like India and China should take responsibility for environmental protection. "India should play its role in reducing renewable energy and global warming," he said.

Talking about the issue of higher education in India, Rainz said that America has the best universities in the world. "Students of India can also go to study here after fulfilling the rules under academic exchange," he added.

In the welcome address of the conference session, Vice-Chancellor of the university, Deepak Tiwari, said that the failure of journalism would be a failure of democracy, and for successful journalism, prospective journalism students are ready to question the authority in the public interest. Underlining the role of Indo-US relations in addressing the challenges of environment, unemployment and global problems arising from technology, Tiwari said that the time ahead is full of expectations but the challenges are no less.

Ranz is currently the acting deputy assistant secretary of South Asian countries (India, Bangladesh, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Bhutan and Maldives) in the US Bureau of South and Central Asian Relations.

Title: DBT, SEC selection done as per law: Bedi
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Puducherry: Lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi maintained that depositing cash equivalent of rice in bank accounts of beneficiaries and selecting a state election commissioner ( SEC ) through a transparent and fair process have been done as per law and directions of the Union government.

“The office of the Lt Governor is bound to read and apply the rules and laws as they exist. Both the direct benefit transfer (depositing cash equivalent of rice directly to the bank accounts of the beneficiaries) and the selection of state election commissioner are as per law and also the decision and directions of the Union government. The Lt Governor’s office works only for the welfare of all people and ensures accountability in its functioning,” Bedi said in a WhatsApp post.

Bedi said the Union government deposits cash in the accounts of six lakh below poverty line families under the direct benefit transfer mode to enable the beneficiaries to buy 5kg of rice a month. In addition to the Centre’s scheme , the Puducherry government distributes free rice to all ration cardholders (20kg for below poverty line families and 10kg for above poverty line families). The government distributed free rice through the public distribution system for 17 months and released cash to the beneficiaries’ accounts for 10 months since June 2016.

“All of BPL and even APL population are now receiving cash under direct transfer of money to buy rice at will. Every beneficiary has a choice to buy it from the market at the time he or she wants and also the quality and quantity of his choice. Money has gone directly to beneficiaries’ bank accounts without any leakages. If this is not the welfare of the people, then what is? Leakages? Bad quality? Loss of money? Loss in distribution? Underweight or diversion of rice? Lack of supply? Non-payment of bills to contractors? Saving costs in distribution? Every month crores of rupees are being saved because of direct transfer,” she said.

On the mode of selection of SEC, she said selecting the best candidate would serve the interest of the people whereas nominating an official to the post will serve the interest of the political establishment. She pointed out that the Union government directed the Puducherry government to opt for an open selection trial to appoint SEC and not nominate an official to the post.

Title: Indira Gandhi had a special bond with Madhya Pradesh: Jairam Ramesh
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Rajya Sabha MP Jairam Ramesh speaks at BLF 2020 on Friday

BHOPAL: The first and last Prime Minister to walk the talk on environment conservation was late Indira Gandhi , said Congress leader and Rajya Sabha MP Jairam Ramesh here on Friday.

Ramesh was speaking at the second edition of Bhopal Literature Festival at Bharat Bhawan. Talking about his book ‘Indira Gandhi: A Life in Nature’, Ramesh said, “Gandhi called herself a child of nature … She felt very deeply about environment which is why India got four of its Acts on environment protection — The Wildlife Protection Act, 1972, Water (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1974, The Forest (Conservation) Act 1980 and Air (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1981 — during her tenure.

Ramesh said that Gandhi had a special bond with Madhya Pradesh and held many discussions with the ex-chief ministers of the state on conservation of tigers and the Bastar forests (which were earlier a part of MP, now Chhattisgarh ).

Talking about a letter she wrote to the then chief minister of Madhya Pradesh Shyama Charan Shukla after the moratorium on tiger hunting in 1971, Ramesh said, “Her chief ministers often disagreed with her. Indira Gandhi would write on an average 6-7 letters a month to her CMs on issues related to the environment.”

In one such letter to Shyama Charan Shukla she wrote, “MP is one of the few states that has not responded to the Wildlife Board’s appeal on the moratorium on tiger shooting. MP has a special responsibility in the matter as it is the most important of the few tiger’s remaining strongholds of India. In the interest of conservation of this famous and unique region of Indian jungle I request you to reconsider the matter … Strict measures should be taken to prevent poaching in all its manifestations.”

Gandhi visited Kanha just two months before her assassination. “It is the only national park or wildlife sanctuary she ever visited. She felt that national parks are for animals not for humans,” said Ramesh.

He also said, that the Environment Protection Act of 1986, came into being as the government realized the importance of such a provision after the 1984 Bhopal Gas Tragedy.

The Rajya Sabha MP said that because of Gandhi India has institutions and regulations in place that further the cause of environment conservation but over the years they have been weakened. He added that environment is a critical issue in the current scheme of things and should be given its importance in politics. “There is no denying that India is a developing country and needs development activities like construction of highways, industries and dams. But, we have to strike a balance between development and environment.”

Ramesh said that the Indian way of life is living in harmony with nature. “Indira Gandhi said Indians do not need to be taught about environment protection because Indians worship nature. Indian civilization is based on many living in harmony with nature.”

Title: Exclusive interview: Education plank is neither Hindu nor Muslim, says Manish Sisodia
Content:
Manish Sisodia

Atul Mathur

How do you react to the events of the past few days which have put university campuses in turmoil?

Is it a battle between ideology and free speech and thought? How do you see it?

Do you think the reasons are different ideologies and also the fact that values and aspirations of the youth do not match with what is being discussed these days?

During the anti-CAA protests, the

Aam Aadmi Party

government has been missing from the scene. Is it a strategic decision?

Tell us about the AAP model of education

What are you plans on higher education?

Do you have apprehensions that the issue of CAA and NRC will polarise voters, which may turn the focus away from your plank of performance of five years?

The

BJP

is trying to counter your issue of development with the card of regularisation of unauthorised colonies. What do you have to say?

AAP and especially the CM are no longer very combative on PM Narendra Modi. Is it your strategy?

Where did the idea of ‘Deshbhakti’ curriculum come from?

Do you find anything praiseworthy in what BJP has achieved on the development front?

Do you think your government has done enough in transport and infrastructure in the past five years?

Your first press conference five years ago was on redesigning of roads. Why could it not be done?

BJP alleges that the Delhi government has denied funds to civic bodies. What do you have to say?

What is your philosophy behind giving freebies?

Delhi’s deputy chief minister, Manish Sisodia , is seen to be the architect of the AAP government’s agenda for education . In an interview with, he says unlike other parties which talk about religion, caste and ideologies during elections, they want people to vote on the issue of education. He says they wish to do constructive and positive politics and bridge the gap in the quality of education imparted to the rich and have-nots.Both as education minister and a parent, I am really worried. A lot of people called me from other states to find out if their kids studying in Delhi University were okay. This incident has worried parents across the country. Our universities, which should have been known for research and academics, are now known for violence. I am both sad and worried.It’s a political failure. Politics is not just about forming a government and spending money wisely. It’s about giving leadership to people. If there is an issue, leaders should proactively engage people and talk to them. It’s not about using police to check law and order — you need to find solutions. It’s true about any protest. During the Nirbhaya agitation, when thousands of people stood at India Gate, if the leadership had gone there and promised punishment to the culprits, things would not have turned violent. When a protest happens, our political regimes either become aggressive or go on the defensive. They should talk to people. I don’t know why they don’t talk. It’s not good politics.Issues and political ideologies will always be there. You have to see the future of the country. The youth is concerned about quality education, its affordability, jobs and a career. You have to assure students that we are creating jobs for you, giving good quality education. This is what he expects. You don’t do that.We have said about it at many public forums and Parliament. Our viewpoint is very clear. We are going into elections and have worked very hard on education. We had said earlier that we will do so much work that the next election will take place on the issue of education. That has been our dream. Whenever elections approach, people start talking about religion, caste, reservations, ideologies. No one talks about education. Fortunately, this has changed in Delhi now.The present model gives quality education and job assurances to only five per cent of people. It does not reach 95 per cent. They get a degree but have no assurances of a career, health facilities, business opportunities and family and can easily be instigated on religion and caste. If they are assured of a career and develop rational thinking, this will not happen.The biggest problem in expanding higher education avenues is the DU Act of 1922, which says there will be no affiliating university. It was not changed even after independence. A one-time exception was made to create Indraprastha University, and that was the second mistake. That’s why higher education institutions could not come up. Otherwise four to five good universities could have been built. To give higher education to children in a city of two crore, an archaic act of 1921 cannot work. It ties your hands. We have been requesting Centre but they never respond.For 2.5 lakh students who pass senior secondary every year, only 90,000 had the scope to get admission in DU colleges, IP University, IITs and other institutions. We tweaked the system in the first year and expanded wherever it was possible. As education minister, my concern was both quality and quantity. We spoke to the vice chancellors of universities and told them to expand seats and promised to give infrastructure and funds. Now the intake is 1.4 lakh. We have to provide for one lakh seats more. From next year, two universities will start working. The entrepreneurial university will be one of the biggest universities of Delhi and accommodate 1.5 lakh students. We opened nine vocational colleges in 2017. We opened two new campuses of Ambedkar University and another campus of Delhi Technological University. Two new DIET centres were opened for B Ed programmes. The B Ed programme that we had for in-house training has been opened to all. We opened a new Delhi Pharmaceutical Sciences and Research University. About 16-17 new colleges have started.For quality, the status of a university cannot be judged by the placements it provides. A university’s standard is gauged by its research work. We asked universities to arrange 50% funds from market for their research projects and matching grants are given by the government. We keep a budget for that. And DTU, IIIT and BIPSAR have progressed in the research sector.I don’t think CAA and NRC can polarise voters. The debate is not happening on the merits of CAA. They are trying to make it revolve around the Hindu-Muslim issue. People have made up their mind. Other parties are trying to tell people that this is anti-Hindu and that is pro-Muslim. We say, nothing is pro-Hindu or pro-Muslim about education. If we had said this six years ago, nobody would have trusted us. But people have seen that education and health facilities have improved. Ninety three per cent of households have water supply, and these people are from every segment. People are very happy. I am quite optimistic that CAA and NRC are not working at the ground level.I see a big fraud by BJP. You need to change land use. One thousand seven hundred colonies are on agricultural land and government land with 40% in O-zone (Yamuna banks). You say there is registry and also that any law under implementation can be enforced any time – such as DDA Act, masterplan…According to the masterplan, a colony may be illegal. You can say these properties are exempt. When a court or NGT asks you, you start demolishing. In case of any order, officers will start demolitions and this paper cannot save them. That’s my concern.Let’s do constructive politics. Let’s do positive politics. It is good for us. Where was the conflict? SC has said except three subjects, we don’t have to send our files to them, it helps us.In the first year, we worked very hard on infrastructure. When it took off, we worked on teachers training the next year, sent teachers abroad where they understood that education is much more than classroom practices. Then we started a happiness curriculum for up to VIII and an entrepreneurship curriculum too. The narrative of patriotism has a very narrow scope these days. People are in love with the name of the country, its symbols and the Army, but they don’t question or rise when a bribe is asked for. A person sings the national anthem and claps in India-Pakistan matches and calls himself a patriot. But he is willing to give or take a bribe and deprive another person of his due. This is not patriotism. People follow traffic rules due to fear of the police. Patriotism is not limited to nationalism. People’s definition of patriotism is all about symbols. We asked children their definition of patriotism. They said saving environment is patriotism and so is safety of women. We are trying to teach these things in the name of moral education or civic sense. But telling children to be good citizens has become wishful thinking and not implemented effectively. We are trying to expand its definition. Twelve years of Deshbhakti curriculum will make them patriotic at heart.I can’t see anything. Economy is going down. I can’t call any area developed unless you provide education and health facilities. Infrastructure development is not the only development. They have destroyed education and government institutions.Lot of bridges which were stuck, such as Signature Bridge, have been constructed. Infrastructure is also about hospitals and schools, which we have improved.There were a lot of ifs and buts. Encroachments were a major problem. Things take time to take off. It is happening now. We could not buy new buses because of some court cases but now buses are being added every day. In next six to eight months you will have a huge caravan of buses. In fact, the SC order of July 2018, which defined the role of the elected government and LG, helped us a lot. Decisions are being taken quickly now.It’s a joke. We have given at least one-a-half times of what they used to get till 2014-15. We did not deduct previous loans and interest accrued on that even. So, we have almost given two times of what MCDs used to get. But there is so much corruption that they are not using it wisely and the money is going down the drain.My philosophy is that those who have not been given much by god should be given by law. What is the cut-off limit for giving things free? Everybody has a different argument about what should be free or shouldn’t be free. A larger debate on the subject is required. For a developed economy, the citizen should be confident that they will get good health, education and governance. You can’t build a country without that.

Title: JD(U) man killed for ‘opposing’ booze mafia in Bihar
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

ARA/BEGUSARAI/PATNA: A JD(U) youth wing functionary was shot dead in a Bhojpur village for allegedly opposing liquor mafia in the district while a 35-year-old man with criminal antecedents was gunned down in Begusarai district on late Thursday evening.

Saheb Yadav, the district JD(U) youth wing general secretary, was shot dead by unidentified criminals at his Roop Bandh village under Jagdishpur police station in Bhojpur district when he had gone out of his home to answer the call of nature. The assailants were waiting outside and fired at close range leading to his instant death. Yadav, who used to raise his voice against liquor smuggling in the area, was rushed to the hospital at Ara where the doctors declared him brought dead.

JD(U) district president Ashok Kumar Sharma said the involvement of liquor mafia in his killing could not be ruled out as Yadav used to oppose them. Bhojpur SP (in charge) Sudhir Kumar Porika said two suspects were detained for interrogation in the case.

In another incident, the Saran police recovered the body of a 45-year-old medical practitioner, Shiv Kumar Singh, from Rasauli village under Panapur police station in the district on Friday morning. He had been missing from his private clinic since Thursday evening. The deceased belonged to neighbouring Nayagaon but lived and practised medicine at Rasauli for over a decade.

Saran SP Har Kishore Rai said a special investigation team has been set up to crack the case. “Prima facie it appears that Singh was killed due to personal enmity,” an investigating officer said. He had stab marks on his body.

In another incident, one Naresh Yadav alias Mini Naresh was gunned down at Kashimpur village under Naya Gaon police station in Begusarai district on Thursday night. Police said Naresh, the ward member of Gorgama panchayat, was attacked when he was sitting with a friend near his house.

Naya Gaon SHO Yashoda Nand Pandey said Naresh was an accused in murder, loot and kidnapping cases. “His murder is stated to be a fallout of gang rivalry in the area,” he added.

The police recovered one used cartridge from the site. The SHO said the assailants escaped with Yadav’s mobile phone after committing the crime. An FIR has been lodged against three named accused in this connection. However, none was arrested in the case.

Title: Bareilly: Two youths get death penalty for raping, killing 12-year-old girl
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

Title: Delhi: CBI deputy director’s wife hit by bike, dies
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: The wife of a CBI deputy director was killed after being knocked down by a bike outside a gurdwara , when she was walking back home in northwest Delhi on Thursday night.

The 20-year-old biker was later arrested from his residence in Wazirpur.

Sandhya Bisht (51) was returning from the gurdwara at C-7 block of Keshavpuram, when the bike hit her from behind due to which she fell face down on the road. Her husband Rakesh Bisht is posted with CFSL at Lodhi Colony.

Witnesses told police that she was walking on the side of the crowded road when Vijay, driving recklessly, hit her. Bisht landed a few feet away. Some of the passersby tried to chase the bike, but Vijay managed to flee. Bisht was rushed to a hospital where doctors declared her dead on arrival. She had sustained injuries on her head and neck due to the fall. Police were informed by the hospital authorities. Her family members were also called.

Witnesses told officers that the motorcycle had a Delhi number. Various police teams later traced the bike using CCTV footage and the description given by the locals. Vijay worked at a electrical shop.

Bisht’s body was handed over to her family members after postmortem. A case was registered for causing death due to negligence.

Title: Anamalai tribals mint money with new lemongrass variety
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

All this changed around 15 months back, when a group of scientists from Lucknow-based Central Institute for Me... Read More

COIMBATORE: Not many people know that in small tribal villages, inside the Anamalai forests , between Pollachi and Valparai, the exotic flavouring ingredient and aroma producing lemongrass grows wildly.

Hardly a few metres away from Attakatti, Anamalai Tiger Reserve, these farmers have been using the grass, calling “sukku pullu” or “inji pullu” to keep away wild animals and distilling it to produce the fabled oil and selling it for an income. However, over the years, they lost interest in it because of the low aroma quotient and oil yield.

All this changed around 15 months back, when a group of scientists from Lucknow-based Central Institute for Medicinal and Aromatic Plants (CIMAP) heard about this cluster and visited them. “We decided to include them in our aroma mission, which aims to increase production of aromatic essential oils like geranium , vetiver, rose and lemongrass,” CIMAP former director, chief scientist and nodal, Aroma Mission, CSIR-CIMAP, Lucknow, Alok Kalra said. “We gave around 70 farmers, from two settlements—Vellimudi and Kadamparai, 6 lakh slips of a high yielding variety of lemongrass, called Krishna, and gave them two upgraded distilling units to extract the oil and sell the finished product to traders,” he said.

Ten months later, the 70-odd farmers who tried cultivating the new variety in around half an acre each, are reporting 200% increase in crop yield and oil. “The farmers are getting a yield of 3 tonnes biomass in one cutting per acre, which is 2 tonnes more than what they got. Considering that there are two cuttings in a year, farmers are expected to see an increase in yield of 4 tonnes per acre annually,” Kalra said. “Though we have now tasked them with mainly multiplying the new variety and produce planting stock, we tested the produce for oil quality and found them to be highly potent,” he said.

One tonne of the new lemongrass variety produces 12kg of essential oil which has citral concentration of 80% to 85%. This is higher than the earlier 70% concentrate they derived. “The industry accepts around 80% concentrate and pays a minimum of Rs 900 per kg, but since these tribals don’t use chemicals, they can sell it as organic lemongrass oil and charge even higher,” CIMAP scientist in charge, Bangalore, V. Sundaresan said.

CIMAP scientists did not just give the farmers new variety stalks, but also installed two new oil distilling machines made of stainless steel. They also got another private concern Ultra International to sponsor two more distilling machines, so it extracts oil more efficiently. “These machines also use the earlier distilled grass waste to burn, reducing requirement of firewood,” Sundaresan said.

The forest department seeing the results has reportedly asked CIMAP to include a few more tribal settlements in the lemongrass cultivation programme, hoping the increase in revenue will keep tribals away from illegal activities like cutting down sandal or poaching.

Scientists estimate that wild lemongrass is being cultivated across around 500 acres in the Anamalai forests, in the Attakkatti region. They hope that eventually this belt will provide around 50 to 60 tonnes of essential oil to the aroma industry.

Title: Miscreants vandalize Tasmac bar
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Tirupur: Unidentified miscreants vandalized a Tasmac bar after one of them quarreled with the bar staffer in the city on Thursday evening.

The bar is attached with a Tasmac shop near Puthu Road bus stop at Ponkovil Nagar on Dharapuram Road in the city. Two men, who came to consume liquor at the bar, picked up a wordy quarrel with each other.

When K Vinoth Kumar, a staffer of the bar, intervened, one of men attacked him and snatched a one and a half sovereign gold chain from him.

Later, the miscreants were joined by four of their friends, who vandalized the bar by breaking vessels, lights and a refrigerator.

Vinoth Kumar lodged a complaint with the Nallur police. Police have recovered CCTV footage and are yet to identify the miscreants. tnn

Title: Bareilly’s platform 2 unfit for halting AC Double Decker Exp train
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Bareilly: The rail track of platform number 2 at Bareilly Junction railway station is no longer fit for halting of AC Double Decker Express train that runs between Lucknow and Anand Vihar Terminal (Delhi). The authorities declared it unfit after repairs were carried out.

Officials said after repairs, the height of the track had increased by more than six inches due to which the gap between the track and platform shed has been narrowed for halting the Double Decker Express there. Station superintendent Satyaveer Singh said the train in question would now halt at platform number 1 until the shed of platform number 2 is elevated.

The station superintendent said the executive engineer (track) has given his approval to run and halt passenger trains on platform number 2 but the engineer infrastructure (works) is yet to send his report to halt Double Decker train at the said platform. “Until his report arrives, we cannot use that platform for the Double Decker train’s halt. However, regular passengers’ trains are being halted there,” he said.

Notably, the height of AC Double Decker is comparatively higher than the regular passenger trains. According to railway sources, the height of the coaches of regular trains is 4,025 mm while the height of the AC Double Decker trains is 4,366 mm.

At present, there are three sheds at platform number 2. Among them, the middle one has been replaced with a new one which is quite high but two corner side sheds are yet to be replaced.

Singh said at present, the movement of the Double Decker Express is suspended till January 31 due to fog.

“All (down) trains, including Double Decker, have always been halted at platform number 1. The problem arose with Double Decker (up) as all up moving trains halt at platform number 2. Owing to the current situation, AC Double Decker (up) is also being halted at platform number 1. As a result, at times, we have to stop the ‘down’ train approaching the station at the outer signal. And sometimes, the Double Decker waits at outer signal till platform number 1 is cleared,” the railway official said.

Title: AAP slams BJP for attack on party’s new face Shoaib Iqbal
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

BJP’s Sambit Patra claimed Shoaib Iqbal (in pic) had been booked in multiple cases

NEW DELHI: Senior Aam Aadmi Party functionary Manish Sisodia on Friday slammed BJP after its spokesperson Sambit Patra hit out at chief minister Arvind Kejriwal over the induction of Shoaib Iqbal into AAP. Patra said that five-time MLA Iqbal had been booked in multiple cases and his induction suggested that AAP would do anything for votebank politics.

Sisodia defended the entry of Iqbal into AAP and rubbished BJP’s charges that AAP was engaged in appeasement politics.

“If a person who has joined AAP is criminal, then BJP should be ashamed that he is roaming free. Delhi Police has been under BJP government for six years, and could have put him behind bars. Now, BJP is talking about him only because he has joined AAP,” Sisodia said.

The deputy CM asked BJP to “place Delhi Police under the command of Delhi government if they are unable to handle it.”

“We will put all criminals whether they belong to BJP, AAP or any other party behind bars,” Sisodia said.

Before joining Congress, Iqbal was five-time MLA of Matia Mahal assembly constituency from four different parties. His departure from Congress is considered a major blow to the party just before Delhi assembly election.

Iqbal is known to have a big influence in Matia Mahal and neighbouring Ballimaran and Chandni Chowk assembly constituencies. AAP leaders say that his support will strengthen the party before polls.

Iqbal rubbished the BJP’s charges and said that he would file a defamation suit against Patra. “The remarks of the BJP leaders are nothing but a bundle of lies. I have never been convicted in any criminal case. Cases against me are politically motivated and none of them are of serious nature,” Iqbal added.

“If I am a criminal, why did BJP remain silent for six years when I was in Congress? Now that I have joined AAP, they are levelling wild allegations against me. They should take action if they think I am a criminal,” Iqbal said adding that BJP is afraid of losing the upcoming elections, so it is resorting to such dirty tricks.

To a question, Sisodia said it was an open secret that which party was an expert on polarising the polls. “Delhi assembly election will be held in the name of education and work of the AAP government,” Sisodia added.

Over a BJP leader’s call to boycott Chhapaak, Sisodia said: “It’s painful to see people getting scared of films based on social issues. How can they be scared of a movie which is based on an acid attack victim?” he asked.

Title: Most suicides by victims of sex abuse in last 2 years were in Madhya Pradesh
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

BHOPAL: Madhya Pradesh is not just the rape capital of the country, but it is among the states where the maximum number of rape survivors have committed suicide in the past couple of years.

As per the National Crime Records Bureau , in 2017, MP topped the list of states when it came to suicide by victims of rape and sexual abuse — and 50% of such suicidesin 2017 were committed in Madhya Pradesh. In 2018 too, the state remained in the top, followed only by Tamil Nadu.In love-related suicides and suicides due to failure in examinations too, Madhya Pradesh was among the top five states in 2017 and 2018.

As per the figures released by the NCRB in accidental deaths and suicides in India (ADSI) reports for 2017 and 2018, rape or abuse was the cause of a total of 107 and 192 suicides in both the years respectively. In 2017, MP accounted for nearly 50% in suicides due to rape/abuse and 49 cases were reported from the state alone. It was highest in the country.

In 2018 also, out of the 192 cases of suicides where rape or abuse was the cause, 27 were reported from Madhya Pradesh.

The state was reported to have the second highest number of such cases in the entire country.

In both 2017 and 2018, many people committed suicide due to failure in exams in MP. The state was third in the country in reporting suicide due to failure in examinations in both 2017 and 2018. In 2017, 312 people committed suicide due to failure in examination and in 2018, 248 people committed suicide for the same reason. Love affairs were also among one of the most prominent causes of suicide as 449 people ended their lives due to love affairs in 2107. In 2018, love affairs was the cause of 403 suicides in the state.

Stressing on the need of mental health assessment of rape survivors, psychiatrist Dr Satyakant Trivedi said, “Mental health assessment of rape survivors should be made mandatory as it is mandatory in case of suicide survivors,” “Teaching mental health should be made mandatory in school curriculum. This would address many problems,” he said. “Suicides due to failure in examinations is increasing. Exams were there in olden times too, but the incidents of suicides were less. Kids have grown poor in stress-handling skills. They are subjected to a stressed lifestyle where outdoor activities are restricted.”

“Due to increase in social media, kids are getting addicted to instant gratification of needs. This is also deterring them from learning to cope with failure. Adding mental health in school curriculum will create awareness and address these issues too.” he said.

Title: Viral video: Man booked for thrashing disabled grandma
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Rudrapur: A day after a video went viral on social media in which a disabled elderly woman is being thrashed by her 26-year-old grandson, the accused was booked on Friday.

Identified as Sushant Mandal, a resident of Makrandpur village in Gadarpur police jurisdiction area of Udham Singh Nagar district, the accused can be seen hitting her grandmother and pinning her head to the floor. Mandal was continuously hurling abuses on her grandmother while the other women of the house were trying to stop him. Meanwhile, the old lady was trying to crawl out of the house as she couldn’t stand on her feet. She was crying and pleading all throughout the incident.

The 12-minute-long video was shot by Mandal’s neighbour. Taking suo motu cognisance of the incident, city police detained Sushant on Thursday. Police also lodged a case against the accused under section 323 (voluntarily causing hurt) of the IPC on the basis of a complaint filed against him by victim’s other grandson Debashish Mandal. The accused was also challaned under the Police Act.

Jaswinder Singh, SHO of Gadarpur police station, told TOI, "A case has been registered and the accused will be presented in the court. Primary investigation suggests that the victim, who is sick, was trying to get out of the house on her own. When she refused to came back, the accused became violent and thrashed her".

Title: 91 govt doctors on leave for years in Bareilly division
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Bareilly: Bareilly division has nearly 50% government doctors in comparison to sanctioned posts as per records but a reality check showed that 91 doctors have been absent from duty for the last few years. Now, the health department has submitted a report to the effect to the state government.

Health officials said according to records, 91 doctors posted in government hospitals, community health centres and primary health centres have been “missing” and have not reported at their respective centres for years. Of these, the highest number of absentee doctors are in Shahjahanpur district at 41. The number of doctors on leave without permission is 17 in Bareilly, 22 in Pilibhit and nine in Budaun districts.

Explaining, an official who did not wish to be named said, “These doctors are probably working in private hospitals or in some other city. A few of them have not reported on duty for more than five years. As they have not resigned from their posts, their names still figure in the records showing that they are working with us.”

The absence of each doctor means that a post is shown as filled whereas it is vacant. This when there is already a shortage of government doctors, adding pressure to the health service by the state.

When contacted, additional director (health) Dr Rakesh Dubey told TOI, “We have informed principal secretary and state government about the doctors who have been absent from duty for years. The higher authorities will take action against such doctors at their level.”

According to the data accessed by TOI, there are 866 posts of doctors in Bareilly division. Of these, 488 are “working” while 379 posts are lying vacant. Out of 488 doctors working in government hospitals of Bareilly division, 91 are on long leave. Of the total 379 posts lying vacant in Bareilly division, 39 vacancies were created as the doctors concerned had resigned the posts.

In Bareilly district, 128 government doctors are working against the sanctioned posts of 229. Due to shortage of doctors, the district hospital in Bareilly does not have specialists, including cardiologist, neurologist, urologist and dermatologist. Patients are forced to travel to other cities for treatment or undergo treatment at private hospitals.

In Shahjahanpur district, of the total 172 sanctioned posts, only 72 are full while 100 posts are lying vacant.

Title: Special operation to be launched to capture killer leopardess in Bijnor
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Bijnor: Days after a leopard was shot dead at Bhogpur village in Najibabad tehsil by villagers, a highly specialized and well-equipped team, led by UP’s principal chief conservator of forests (wildlife) arrived in Bijnor on Friday and inspected Mandawar area around Mohandiya village where a rogue leopardess is suspected to have killed at least three people in the area. Since November 27, six people have been mauled to death by leopards in the district.

The team of experts from Lucknow led by PCCF (wildlife) Sunil Pandey conducted an inspection of Mohandiya village. The photos of the leapardess were captured by a trap camera set up in the area. The thorough search for the big cat will begin on Monday.

PCCF Pandey inspected the place and saw the leopard’s pugmarks. He issued a series of instructions to the local authorities.

Giving details, Bijnor divisional forest officer M Semmaran, “PCCF Sunil Pandey took stock of the situation and instructed us how to conduct the operation to catch the leopardess which has been lurking near Mohandiya village area. It had killed a 65-year-old labourer in a sugarcane field on December 26.”

Semmaran said, “We are bracing for a successful operation which may be launched on Monday. A team of experts from Kanpur and Lucknow will arrive to tranquilize the big cat. Besides, elephants will be brought from Kalagarh, Corbett National Park, for conducting the search operations. A team from Dudhwa National Park will fly drones to spot the leopardess. Apart from this, special cages are being sent from Chidiyapur, Uttarakhand. Scientists from Wildlife Institute of India, Dehradun, have been invited to monitor the operation.”

Since the leopard attacks on people began in November, farmers have been living in fear in the area. Villagers are up in arms as the forest department has failed to capture the big cat despite setting up six cages and a dozen camera traps amid the sugarcane fields of Mohandiya village. They have put baits like dogs, goats, chicken, mutton and cat lure to attract the killer cat but it has eluded capture. However, it has been captured in cameras several times, indicating that it is still in the area.

Content:
BJP’s Sambit Patra claimed Shoaib Iqbal (in pic) had been booked in multiple cases
