Title: Probe team identifies 37 in WhatsApp group
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

New Delhi: The Special Investigating Team probe into the January 5 violence at Jawaharlal Nehru University has identified 37 of the 60 members of ‘Unity Against Left’ , a WhatsApp group that allegedly mobilised the assailants into attacking students and teachers. Of the identified, 12 were determined not to be affiliated to any political group. The people that SIT has identified will be asked to record their statements on how and when the group was formed. Like them, the nine students who were named by SIT on Friday will also be summoned for questioning.

Among those spotted in the WhatsApp group, 10 were discovered not to be students of JNU and efforts are being made to trace them. While police pinpointed Manish Jangid, secretary, JNU ABVP, as being a part of the group, the latter claimed that he was added to the group by someone else. He maintained that he realised this only after switching on his phone in the evening.

Questioning of some people yielded the information that the invite to join the group was sent through SMS. However, some of those who joined left within a few hours when violence broke out. However, the cops are likely to go after them to ascertain their roles in the mob attack. When the cops contacted some of the numbers that did not have names associated with them, they were either switched off or unreachable, but the investigators are tryingto track them individually.

Meanwhile, police have asked hostel wardens in JNU to direct the students injured in the January 5 clashes to record their statements. A temporary office of the SIT has been set up on the campus to facilitate this. Police sources said there was a list of 34 students who suffered injuries. They had been instructed to appear before the SIT. While some responded over phone, none has personally gone to police. The sources explained that the statement of these students would provide crucial information to the investigators since other than mobile phone videos, no other evidence has been recovered, with the security cameras having been non-operational at the time. The police team has already questioned the security guards who were on duty when the mob entered the university as well as the wardens of the hostels where violence took place.

The sources also said that while mobile phone videos of the attack were available, police had not been able to get leads due to the dark lighting and the masks that the attackers wore.

Senior SIT members agreed that the nine suspects named on Friday were only involved in skirmishes during the day, not in the evening attack. The probe on the clashes after dark, including at Sabarmati Hostel, is under way.

The cops will send notices to the nine students named as involved in violence by Special Investigating Team at its press meet on Friday to help the investigators in identify the other people seen with them in CCTV and mobile phone footage that have been recovered.

Title: Bajrang Dal tears posters of Chhapaak outside mall, SP men throng to watch Deepika’s film
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Muzaffarnagar: Opposing ideologies faced-off at the Grand Palaz mall on Friday as Bajrang Dal activists protested outside, tearing posters of the movie Chhapaak, starring Deepika Padukone, while Samajwadi Party workers trooped en masse to the theatre inside to watch it. The actress had courted controversy by visiting JNU recently, after students of the university had been attacked inside by masked goons.

According to sources, police rushed to the mall after Bajrang Dal activists were reported to have created a ruckus, and pacified the activists. Shenki Sharma of the Dal said, “She visited JNU, whose students are anti-national, so we’re protesting her movie release.” Soon after, dozens of SP workers wearing party caps arrived to watch the movie, evidently to show support to the actress.

SP’s Shamsher Malik said, “We went to watch the movie after [party supremo] Akhilesh Yadav instructed all workers to watch it, but we’ve been told by security that our presence can create trouble, so we had to return without watching it.”

Earlier on Thursday, a bunch of Akhil Bhartiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP) activists burnt Padukone’s effigy to protest her support for JNU students. A number of ABVP supporters hit the streets to raise slogans against the actress and burnt her effigy in front of the mall, where her film premiered on Friday.

An ABVP activist Dinesh Tyagi said, “Deepika visited JNU to support anti-nationals, we are against such activities conducted at JNU.” Another ABVP member, Aditya Sharma, said, “Rather than standing in support of the Nirbhaya rape verdict, which was pronounced on the same day, she stood with anti-nationals. We won’t let her movie Chhapaak be released in Muzaffarnagar.”

Title: Temperature dips, locals continue to feel chill
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Bareilly: There was no respite from the chill on Friday, even though the sun made a momentary appearance in the morning. The Indian Meteorological Department (IMD) has forecast colder days till the weekend.

Residents woke up to a foggy morning on Friday, with minimum temperature standing at 6.3°C, 1°C below normal. The maximum temperature too declined to 12.9°C, 8°C below normal.

According to IMD, the temperature may fall till Sunday. Experts have predicted Bareilly will witness moderate fog till the weekend, but weather will change from Monday. It is expected that temperatures will climb upwards from Monday, when the district may witness cloudy skies with light rain. Weathermen have predicted rain and thunderstorm in the next 6-7 days.

Weather expert Neeru Agarwal said, “As the sun moves towards the northern hemisphere, the weather will slightly improve around January 14. However, locals will continue to feel the chill, because of the dry and cold wind coming from the north-western direction.”

With temperatures dipped in the area, it affected normal life. People were seen huddled around bonfires across the city. According to health officials, the chill has led to a rise in the number of fever and pneumonia cases being reported at district hospital. Following rain and thunderstorm on Wednesday, district magistrate Nitish Kumar had ordered closure of schools up to Class VIII till Saturday. Schools will now reopen on Monday.

Title: Meerut records 6.7 degree Celsius; lowest temp in a week
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Meerut: Chill was in the air as mercury settled at 6.7 degree Celsius on Friday, the lowest temperature in the week so far.

“The maximum and minimum temperatures recorded Friday were 17.9 degrees and 6.7 degrees respectively. The maximum and minimum humidity levels recorded were 91% and 48%,” said Brij Mohan, in-charge of meteorological department in Meerut.

Doctors have advised elderly people and children to take special care and avoid going outside. Morning walks, too, can be harmful especially for those with breathing issues, doctors said.

“People should keep themselves warm with extra cloths and by staying indoors as much as possible. Meanwhile, special care should be taken in cases of viral fever and a doctor should be seen immediately,” said Mohan.

Meanwhile, the health authorities are also keeping a tab any winter-related deaths in the district.

Title: Pakistan should also make a law and take all Muslims who feel ‘persecuted’ here, says BJP MLA
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Muzaffarnagar: A controversial BJP MLA in western UP on Friday suggested Pakistan should also make a law and give citizenship to all those Muslims who are feeling persecuted in India. He was asked about the ongoing protests against the recent amendments to Citizenship Law in the country.

“Let us exchange those who are feeling persecuted,” BJP’s Khatauli MLA Vikram Saini told reporters after coming out of a local court where he had appeared as an accused in 2013 Muzaffarnagar riots. At least 62 people – 42 Muslims and 20 Hindus—were killed during the communal riots in 2013. Over 50,000 were displaced and some of them continue to live on makeshift camps. The MLA told reporters that he was “framed” by local police after the riots on the directions of the then SP government.

“The CAA and NRC are in favour of country. Hindus and Sikhs are facing persecution in Pakistan for decades now, and we are providing a shelter to them. I would like to say that Pakistan should also enact such a law for the Muslims who are victims here and provide citizenship to them.

“Those oppressed in Pakistan should come here, and those feeling oppressed here should go there. Let us exchange them,” he said.

Saini also slammed actor Deepika Padukone for sharing stage with protestors in JNU.

“The actress should not have gone there, see she is facing criticism now. Citizens of the country should think that her movie should watch or not? I think we should not watch her movie.”

In September last year, Saini had said that the country’s first Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru was a “characterless” man responsible for the partition.

On August 6, soon after the abrogation of special status of Jammu and Kashmir, Saini had said, “All bachelors in BJP, who are eager to get married, can go to Kashmir and we have no problem with it. In fact, Muslims BJP activists should be happy, now they can get married to ‘gori’ (fair) Kashmiri girls.”

Title: Bio-fencing to prevent wild animals from raiding fields
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

The forest department officials claimed that the two species of plants don’t need water to grow and cost-effec... Read More

COIMBATORE: After banking on technology all these years to prevent man-animal conflict, the Coimbatore division of forest department now plans to look for traditional ways to curb the menace.

Even as the forest department plans to procure hi-tech cameras with a range of more than a km to watch the movement of wild elephants, it has decided to promote ‘ bio-fencing ’ to prevent wild animals raiding agricultural fields in the division.

As part of the plan, officials from the department would meet farmers and advise them to plant Suramul ( Cylindropuntia ramosissima), a cactus species, around their field. This thorny plant is traditionally used as natural fence in some parts of the country.

District forest officer of the Coimbatore forest division D Venkatesh said Suramul had grown along the elephant-proof trenches on the eastern side of the Anuvavi Subramaniaswamy temple in Coimbatore. The wild elephants and other animals avoid the thorny plants. “Some of the farmers from Karamadai and few other areas had planted ‘Euphorbia’ Species in their agricultural fields located near the forest boundaries. They told us that it helped prevent wild animals entering their agricultural lands,” Venkatesh said.

He said farmers from Coimbatore often complain about wild boars damaging their crops. Such bio-fencing would prevent wild boars as well.

The forest department officials claimed that the two species of plants don’t need water to grow and cost-effective.

To prevent man-animal conflict, the forest department has been taking various steps in Coimbatore forest division. Elephant-proof trenches (EPT) were dug around the boundaries of the forest to prevent entry of wild elephants into human habitations.

“We have to spend Rs 5.5 lakh for one km of EPT. We could not dig trenches alone to prevent the wild animals. So, we plan to introduce the bio-fencing scheme for Coimbatore forest division,” Debasis Jana, additional principal conservator of forests, Coimbatore circle, said.

Title: Narayanasamy moves Madras high court over free rice scheme
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Puducherry: Chief Minister V Narayanasamy has filed a petition before the Madras high court pleading to quash the decision of lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi and the BJP-led government in the Centre to deposit cash equivalent of rice in bank accounts of beneficiaries instead of disbursing rice free of cost to ration cardholders through fair price shops.

Speaking to the media on Friday, Narayanasamy said the high court admitted his petition and posted it for hearing next week. He pointed out that two Union ministries have taken a contradictory stand on the free rice scheme .

The Union consumer affairs, food and public distribution ministry agreed ‘in principle’ to provide rice free of cost through the fair price shops to the ration cardholders, while the Union home ministry insisted on direct benefit transfer ( DBT ) mode of transferring cash equivalent of rice to the bank accounts of the beneficiaries, he said.

He accused Bedi of questioning the country’s sovereignty and its democratic setup and posing unnecessary hindrances to the elected government.

“When all the neighbouring states, Tamil Nadu, Kerala, Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh, distribute rice free of cost through the fair price shops why not Puducherry? Who gave her (Bedi) the authority to stall the projects of the elected government? She has no right to do so. What is the necessity to refer the issue to the Centre? She cannot be forwarding each and every file to the Centre citing differences in opinion with the council of ministers. A referral can be done only in the rarest of the rare cases,” Narayanasamy said citing a Supreme Court order in a case between the Union government and Delhi government.

Replying to Bedi’s charges of corruption in the free rice scheme, he said the government will initiate appropriate action against officials indulging in corrupt practices. “After an extensive survey, we realised that most of the people preferred rice to cash and it is the duty of the government to fulfil the demand of the people,” he said.

Narayanasamy said public works minister A Namassivayam, who holds the portfolio of local administration, will also file a petition before the high court pleading a direction to scrap the move of the home ministry and lieutenant governor to select a state election commissioner and uphold the appointment of retired IAS officer T M Balakrishnan as the state election commissioner in July last year by the government.

He accused Bedi of trying to favour her officer on special duty G Theva Neethi Dhas in the selection of the state election commissioner and ensuring that the eligibility criteria set by the local administration secretariat matched Dhas’s profile. He said Bedi has no moral right to accuse the government of disobeying the Centre’s directions as she failed to honour the directions of the Centre on designating Dhas as her consultant and in redelegating her financial powers to secretaries, heads of departments and offices and council of ministers proportionately. He said Bedi designated Dhas as her officer on special duty while the Centre insisted on designating him as her consultant.

Title: Rly station master arrested for rape
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Bijnor: A 37-year-old station master of a local railway station has been arrested by Bijnor's Najibabad police for allegedly raping a 23-year-old woman on the pretext of marrying her.

Although, the case was lodged on December 19 last year, the arrest was made on Thursday evening. In her complaint with police, the woman had alleged that the man had barged into her house when she was alone and raped her. She said her family was out to attend a “jagran” at the time. A case was registered against the accused under IPC section 376 (rape) and 493 (cohabitation caused by a man deceitfully inducing a belief of lawful marriage).

According to police, the station master fell in love with the woman and wanted to marry her. Sanjay Panchal, Najibabad station house officer, said, “Police have filed a case against the railway official. Prima facie, it seems to be a matter of a love affair gone wrong. During investigations, it came to light that the accused was already married when he entered into a relationship with the woman. He allegedly made a false promise of marriage to the woman and also harassed her.”

The accused was arrested on Thursday evening and sent to jail,” police said.

Title: Leopard killing: Dy ranger, guard suspended for dereliction of duty
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Bijnor: Days after villagers allegedly shot dead a suspected man-eater leopard at Bhogpur village in Bijnor district, divisional forest officer has suspended the deputy ranger and beat guard for not informing higher authorities about the presence of a big cat in village.

Najibabad divisional forest officer Manoj Kumar Shukla has suspended deputy ranger Shishpal Singh Bisht and forest guard Raghuveer Singh for dereliction of duty. Local authorities kept the higher authorities in the dark about the presence of the leopard in the area.

The killing took place in Kaudiya range of Najibabad division on January 6 hours after a leopard had mauled to dead a 14-year-old boy when he was out of school. Villagers claimed that the leopard had been hovering around a school in the sugarcane field for some time. It could have killed another child if it was not shot dead.

This is the first incident in Bijnor district when villagers cordoned off an area and shot dead a big cat. The villagers surrounded a cane field where the leopard was hiding. They gunned down the big cat and dragged its carcass across 100 meters.

So far, 80 unnamed villagers have been booked for killing the leopard under provisions of the Wildlife Protection Act.

The carcass of the leopard has been sent to IVRI, Bareilly for a postmortem.

Title: Vishal Dadlani pens poll campaign song for AAP
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Vishal Dadlani

NEW DELHI: Playback singer Vishal Dadlani has composed a campaign song for Aam Aadmi Party ahead of Delhi assembly election. It captures the central theme of AAP’s campaign—acche beete paanch saal, lage raho Kejriwal. The teaser of the song, which will be released by senior AAP functionary Manish Sisodia on Saturday, is already out.

The teaser, being shared on social media by AAP volunteers, shows people from different strata of society backing Kejriwal, the chief minister addressing a public gathering, and women supporting him.

Dadlani had composed the popular song “Paanch saal Kejriwal, Kejriwal” during the poll campaign in 2015. Acche beete paanch saal, lage raho Kejriwal is the slogan which AAP uses to explain to people that the past five years have been good and the phase should continue.

Title: Madhya Pradesh: Educated and financially well off handle stress better, suggests NCRB
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

BHOPAL: In what appears to be a clear co-relation between economic and educational status and suicide, 80% of the people who committed suicides in Madhya Pradesh during 2017 and 2018 earned less than Rs 1 lakh per annum and were educated only upto matriculation or less. This startling figures were thrown up by the national crime records bureau ( NCRB ) data released the other day.

The data from Madhya Pradesh suggests, less than 0.5% people who earned more than Rs 10 lakh per annum and were graduates or above committed suicide. As per the report of the national crime records bureau (NCRB) titled accidental deaths and suicides in India (ADSI) for year 2017, a total of 11,770 people committed suicide in Madhya Pradesh.

And of those, 9366 were either matriculation pass or less. This comes out to be 79.5% of the overall suicides that took place in that year. Similarly, in the same year, 8,955 people committed suicide which is again 76% of the overall suicides committed in the same year. But when it came to suicide victims who were graduate and above, only 377 people committed suicide, that is 3% of the total suicides that took place the year.

Similarly, only 12 people who earned more than Rs 10 lakh per annum committed suicide in 2017 which is only 0.3%.

In the year 2018 too, 82.9% people who committed suicide were either educated till matriculation or less.

And in terms of earnings, 74.5% people who ended their lives by committing suicide in 2018 earned less than Rs 1 lakh per annum. But when it came to educated people, only 2.7% of the people who committed suicide were educated upto graduation or above. And only 53 or 0.4% of the people who earned more than Rs 10 lakh per annum committed suicide in the same year.

Explaining it, psychiatrist Dr Satyakant Trivedi said, “The way to tackle a stress of an educated person is better compared to a less educated person. Same thing goes with people with high earnings, like in case of any problem or stress, high earning people have more resources and hence have more support systems, thus they are less likely to commit suicide, compared to people with low earnings”.

Title: Friends of Police coordinator faces charges of duping man of Rs 4 lakh
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: A 38-year-old man on Friday sought action against a Friends of Police coordinator for duping him of more than Rs 4 lakh.

R Jagadeeswaran, of East Street at Masakkalipalayam, petitioned the city deputy commissioner of police (crime) E S Uma, saying Friends of Police coordinator S Senthilkumar, of Nehru Nagar, had cheated him in a real estate deal.

Pointing out that Senthilkumar was engaged in real estate business, Jagadeeswaran said he, along with his wife J Dhanalakshmi, who is a private school principal, had approached him for a site at Kanuvakkarai village in Annur.

“We paid him Rs 10,000 as advance in 2013 and an agreement was made between us. We then paid him Rs 1.35 lakh in monthly installments. In November 2018, Senthilkumar told us that the site was not approved and that he was not able to repay Rs 1.35 lakh. He also demanded another Rs 3 lakh to arrange an alternative site for us and promised to do the land registration at the earliest,” Jagadeeswaran said.

Subsequently, Jagadeeswaran paid Senthilkumar another Rs 3 lakh on November 28, 2018. However, the latter went back on his word on land registration. “Later, we came to know that Senthilkumar and his accomplices had already sold the sites to others. When we demanded him to repay the amount, he not only refused that but also threatened us, saying he had good rapport with senior police officials and that no one would take action against him,” Jagadeeswaran said.

When contacted, Senthilkumar said Jagadeeswaran was a close friend of his. “The problem is between the landowner, Eswaran, and Jagadeeswaran. The issue is settled, and Eswaran is ready to provide the land. The complaint against me is only a bid to tarnish my image,” he said.

Title: Man killed over ‘illicit’ relationship, one arrested
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

BIJNOR: Amroha police have claimed they have solved the mystery surrounding the murder of a man whose body was recovered from a field on January 8. According to police, the victim, a quack by profession, had gone missing since December 31 last year. His body was recovered on January 8 in a field in Amroha district . Local police now claim the victim was murdered by the husband of a woman with whom he allegedly had an illicit relationship.

The deceased, Amar Singh, resident of Jhundi Mafi village under Said Nagali police station, ran a clinic at Kakather village under Gajraula police station. He had left his clinic on December 31 but did not reach home afterwards. His cousin had filed his “missing” complaint on January 6, and told cops he had left Amroha saying he would be going to Hapur.

Police said his body was found in the jungle of Dakewali Dagrauli under Hasanpur police station. The investigation revealed the deceased had an illicit relationship with a woman, Poonam of Sakrauli village under Hasanpur police station.

Amroha SP Vipin Tada said, “Police smelt a conspiracy and picked up Poonam’s husband Nanak Khadakvanshi to grill him. He confessed to his crime and told cops when he found out about Amar Singh’s illicit relationship with Poonam, he had a fight with his wife. Eventually, he convinced his wife that the path to reconciliation was through her abandoning her paramour. She agreed after much persuasion, and started maintaining distance with Amar, but he tried to forcefully meet her. That’s when both husband and wife hatched a plan to eliminate Singh.”

“Poonam called him to their house on December 31. When Amar Singh reached, Poonam’s husband strangled him to death with her help, put his body on a bike and dumped it in the forest. Six days later, when there was no enquiry about Amar, they decided to pick up the body and throw it in a field close to a road, so that family members of the deceased found it,” the SP added, further saying, “Police have recovered the bike used in the crime and arrested the killer.”

Title: Panel led by ex-judge to organize jallikattu at Avaniapuram: HC
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Avaniapuram jallikattu will be organised this year by a committee headed by a retired district judge as was done last year based on an order of the Madras high court Madurai bench. A division bench of Justice M Duraiswamy and Justice T Ravindran made this oral observation while taking up a batch of petitions on organising jallikattu events in Madurai district.

The petitions included one seeking inclusion of representatives from people belonging to all communities on jallikattu organising committees and with regard to dispute in organising jallikattu at Avaniapuram . The counsels submitted that in 2019 the court had passed an order constituting a committee headed by a retired district judge to conduct the jallikattu. The judges adjourned the hearing of the petitions to January 13 to pass orders.

The court observation cheered up the villagers of Avaniapuram who have been upset at the district collector’s order that Thenkal Vivasayigal Sangam led by its president V K Kannan would be part of the organising committee. People burst fireworks on hearing the court order and distributed sweets to share their joy. K R Murugan, organiser of Veerakula Amaran Iyakkam who has been part of the protests for the past few days, said they were happy that an official committee was going to conduct the games this year. `` Last year too, a committee comprising a retired judge, eight members of Thenkal Pasana Vivasayigal sangam, 16 villagers and three advocates conducted the games. It went well though the prizes were less in number,” he said.

``When one person is not given importance, then we get to celebrate the games in a united manner. Now we can start organising and I think registration for tamers and bulls will start by Sunday,’’ said Ravichandra of Avaniapuram. Meanwhile, the district collector has ordered that prizes meant for any of the jallikattu games in Madurai should not be handed over to individuals or the organising committees. Any sponsorship for the prizes should be deposited in the account of the district collector, he said.

Meanwhile, the state government has passed an order permitting jallikattu at Avaniyapuram from January 15 to 31. The order was passed by the animal husbandry, dairying and fisheries department. A notification in this regard would also be published in the extraordinary gazette.

Title: Drinking session goes horribly wrong, cousins bludgeoned to death, one arrested
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Bijnor: The city woke up to the shocking news of two brutal murders after bodies of cousins were recovered from city police station area on Friday morning. Police acted swiftly in the case and arrested one Narendra Singh alias Nanhe who has reportedly confessed to murdering the cousins during a drinking session on Thursday night.

In its official statement, the police claimed that Narendra acted in a fit of rage after he was cornered as an argument with the deceased during the drinking session turned into an ugly brawl. Narendra allegedly hit the deceased with a log, thereby inflicting severe head injuries and fled from the spot.

The incident took place at Dara Nagar Ganj village, around 12 km away from district headquarters. The deceased was identified as Sukkhe (40) and Prem Singh (41) of the same village. Both were cousins.

The bodies of the deceased were found on Friday morning near an ashram when a passerby spotted them. They informed the cops and villagers about the matter. After getting wind of the incident, villagers congregated and police also reached there. The cops took the bodies to district hospital for postmortem.

Police have registered a case against Narendra under section 302 of IPC. The deceased’s son alleged that Narendra thrashed his father to death. He took his father and uncle with him on Thursday evening.

On being asked about the matter, Bijnor superintendent of police Sanjeev Tyagi said, “Police have registered a case against the accused. He was arrested from a ‘machan’ [a makeshift shelter to guard the crop] in a field. He has confessed to his crime. Actually, Narendra settled down at Dhampur town, close to the house of his in-laws. He frequented here at Daranagar Ganj. He came here on Thursday as well. He met Sukkhe and Prem. He invited them to a liquor party. They agreed. The trio reached near to a temple in Daranagar Ganj and had consumed liquor. During the drinking session, they got into a heated argument and started hurling abuses at each other.”

Tyagi added, “The arrested accused told the cops that when they were on their way home and reached an ashram, both Sukkhe and Prem grabbed them and started thrashing. This led to a clash. Narendra found a log and struck it on their heads. They collapsed and could not get up. Blood was oozing from their heads. After hitting on their heads, Narendra fled from the scene and on Friday morning he learnt that both Prem and Sukkhe had died.”

According to villagers, illicit liquor led to the clash. Notably, Khaddar area is a hub of illicit liquor. It is manufactured in the region and sold at throwaway prices. Most of the villagers along the banks of Ganga here have reportedly become addicted to the liquor. Villagers had earlier informed the cops, but they didn’t do much.

Title: Haryana woman missing with daughters reunites with family
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Bareilly: A 30-year-old woman who had gone missing with her two daughters on November last year, was finally reunited with her family on Friday, with the help of local NGO, which is dedicated to rescuing lost persons and helping them trace their family members.

The deputy chief probation officer (dy CPO), Neeta Ahirwar, said Sharda was rescued by the police when she was found wandering in Aonla.

“Since she was not in a condition to give much information about her family, the police approached us and we sent her to Nari Niketan after producing to city magistrate. She had two daughters – a three-month-old infant and a two-year-old girl – when the police rescued her. For her to get reunited with her family, we took the help of a local NGO run by Shailendra Sharma,” Ahirwar said.

Shailendra Sharma said she couldn’t give enough information about her family except that she was from Panipat, Haryana.

“We approached the Panipat police and shared her photographs with them. The police further informed other districts and all police stations in Panipat. The information regarding missing persons was collected at superintendent of police office there. On Wednesday, they contacted us and informed us that they have the details of Sharda’s family members who had filed a missing complaint in Jind district,” Sharma said.

Later, Haryana police shared the phone number of the family member with Sharma. After being satisfied, dy CPO asked the family to reach Bareilly.

On Friday, Sharda’s father Maman Raj, mother Nanaki, brother Ravi and uncle Nandlal reached here to take her back home.

“My daughter and granddaughters had gone missing after boarding the wrong train. Since then we had been trying hard to trace them, but couldn’t succeed. We were quite afraid of thinking about the state of my daughter. Thankfully, I got see her and my granddaughters safe and sound,” Sharda’s father said.

Title: Kalindi Kunj road still shut, residents to hold a protest
Content:
Affected by the closure, residents of Sarita Vihar and 10 villages will stage a protest outside the DCP’s offi... Read More

NEW DELHI: The Kalindi Kunj road has been shut for the past 26 days due to the anti-Citizenship Amendment Act protests. As a large chunk of the diverted south Delhi-Noida traffic is taking the parallel Madanpur Khadar-Agra canal road to avoid snarls at DND Flyway and Ashram, residents of Sarita Vihar and 10 villages in the area are forced to travel for around two hours to cross this 1.5km congested stretch.The residents of Sarita Vihar, Madanpur Khadar, Jasola Village and some nearby areas in south-east Delhi have now decided to stage a protest outside the DCP’s office on Mathura Road on Sunday demanding that the Shaheen Bagh protesters be shifted to clear the blockade. On Thursday, a group even tried to shut down the colony roads leading to A block in Sarita Vihar and Jasola village.Ashok Vidhuri, a social activist who stays at Sarita Vihar, said the decision to protest outside the DCP’s office was taken after Delhi high court rejected the residents’ petition. “With the Agra canal road blocked through the day, the residents of Madanpur Khadar and Sarita Vihar need almost two hours to even reach Badarpur. It’s even affecting patients’ movement to hospitals. How can this be allowed? There are designated locations for protests; why do you create problems for others who have nothing to do with it,” asked Bidhuri.More than 2 lakh vehicles use the Kalindi Kunj road and a chunk of it is now taking the Madanpur Khadar-Agra canal road, which is not even equipped to handle this heavy volume of vehicular traffic. “There is a culvert here that has already been declared dangerous. Who will be responsible if it crumbles under the pressure,” he said.Raj Kumar Kaushik, a village panchayat member, said even children were forced to leave for schools two hours before the scheduled time. “I have to wake my child at 6am and leave for the school that starts at 8am. Since DND Flyway is nearly inaccessible now, we have to find our way through this snarl,” he said. Kaushik said police had also expressed helplessness in dealing with the mess.The snarls at DND Flyway is also impacting Noida-Greater Noida Expressway and during peak hours, areas like Sarai Kale Khan, Sunlight Colony and Maharani Bagh are getting gridlocked as commuters try to take internal roads to move faster.“We have been trying to convince the traffic police to deploy additional personnel to manage this mess, but so far nothing has been done,” said a member of a residents’ welfare association at Maharani Bagh.

Title: Vishal Dadlani pens poll campaign song for AAP
Content:
Vishal Dadlani

NEW DELHI: Playback singer Vishal Dadlani has composed a campaign song for Aam Aadmi Party ahead of Delhi assembly election. It captures the central theme of AAP’s campaign—acche beete paanch saal, lage raho Kejriwal. The teaser of the song, which will be released by senior AAP functionary Manish Sisodia on Saturday, is already out.The teaser, being shared on social media by AAP volunteers, shows people from different strata of society backing Kejriwal, the chief minister addressing a public gathering, and women supporting him.Dadlani had composed the popular song “Paanch saal Kejriwal, Kejriwal” during the poll campaign in 2015. Acche beete paanch saal, lage raho Kejriwal is the slogan which AAP uses to explain to people that the past five years have been good and the phase should continue.

Title: New Year and new fitness resolutions
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Just a week into the new year, and with fresh resolutions to stay fit, hundreds in the city are flocking to the gyms in the city. Gym owners say that each year more and more people in the city become aware on the need to stay fit and healthy.

“Just within five days after the new year began, we had around 50 people join our gym. It is common to see those with fitness goals for the new year walk in at this time. People in Madurai are now more aware about fitness though the numbers are nowhere close to how it is in metro cities,” said Sukumar, owner of one of the biggest gyms in the city with around 2,000 members.

Both men and women are walking into gyms with specific fitness goals in mind. “Women mostly only come for weight loss. But I’ve seen both genders come in for workout to avoid age-related cardiac illnesses, diabetes, high blood pressure and cholesterol,” said Yogesh, who runs a gym in Villapuram.

With a gym on every other street in the city, residents will need to shell out anywhere between Rs5,000 and Rs20,000 per year on gym packages, depending on the quality of facilities, equipment and size of the gym. “I’ve noticed that many gyms are coming up with packages by which you pay much less if you take the yearly package. I think it is good because it makes us want to come regularly at least for the sake of money spent,” said Vinitha D, a resident of SS Colony.

While elite gyms boast of ensuring that members continue their gym sessions with follow up by trainers, some of the smaller gyms in the city are often seeing a loss of members a few months after New Year. “Seasonally people come and go. Some take resolution and then stop after a while. Usually, in my gym, if around 100 people come in, almost half of them don’t come regularly,” said Yogesh. The main reasons include no time to spare or is lazy to come to the gym.

Another aspect of gym and fitness is maintaining a proper diet. Gym owners say that while awareness has increased about the need for workout and exercise, many still refuse to believe in the need for a healthy diet. “I would say 75% of our fitness depends on our diet intake. You can’t expect to lose weight if you work out here and then go home to eat so much rice and whatever you want,” said Yogesh. On the other hand, some of the bigger gyms have staff to personally handle diet for the members and provide them with a workout suited best for their bodies.

Quote:

Women mostly only come for weight loss. But I’ve seen both genders come in for workout to avoid age-related cardiac illnesses, diabetes, high blood pressure and cholesterol - Yogesh | Gym owner

Title: Mahila Congress demands leader of opposition’s resignation for comment against Deepika Padukone
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Gopal Bhargava

BHOPAL: The state unit of Mahila Congress on Friday protested outside the residence of leader of opposition Gopal Bhargava , condemning the crude language he used to criticise actor Deepika Padukone’s visit to JNU. On Thursday, Bhargava had said in Harda that actresses had no business with students and should “stay in Mumbai and dance”. “Heroines’ work is to dance in Bombay. Why should they go to JNU?” he said, and followed it up with a shocker on the state government declaring Deepika-starrer Chhapaak tax-free: “If it had been a porn movie, then too they would have declared it (tax free) if Deepika were in it,” the BJP veteran said. On Friday, state Mahila Congress president Mandvi Chouhan demanded a public apology from Bhargava and his resignation from the post of LOP. A large number of Congress workers marched to Bhargava’s residence, shouting slogans and carrying placards. Bhopal district Congress president Kailash Mishra and his supporters also joined the Mahila protest. “We condemn Bhargava’s mentality. Even after being in public life for so long, he cannot respect women. How he perceives women can be gauged from his words,” said Chouhan. “It is not entirely his fault, though, because the political party he works for teaches to be disrespectful towards women from the beginning. The result is Bhargava’s offensive and indecent comments, insulting women. We demand an apology in public because he has insulted women of the entire country. After that, he should resign,” she added.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Congress may be first to declare names of 20 candidates
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Delhi Congress is likely to announce its first list of about 20 candidates in a couple of days. Sources said the screening committee held two long discussions to deliberate on potential candidates and almost reached a consensus on a few names.

The screening committee is headed by Rajiv Satav and includes Virender Singh Rathore and Challa Vamshi Chand Reddy, who were appointed by Congress president Sonia Gandhi in the last week of December. Delhi Congress chief Subhash Chopra, AICC general secretary in-charge PC Chacko and co-in-charge Kuljeet Singh Nagra are the ex-officio members.

Congress wants to be the first party to declare the names of candidates for at least 20 of the 70 assembly constituencies. Sources confirmed that some of these probable candidates have already been told to start campaigning.

“In constituencies where there are no doubts on candidates, we don’t want them to wait till the list is made public and lose precious time. We have told them to start campaigning at the ground level. The posters can come up later,” said a Congress functionary.

Those aspiring for tickets include several children of politicians, who have been waiting in the wings for the past few years. Sources said Chopra’s daughter Shivani, chief spokesperson Mukesh Sharma’s son Ankit, veteran leader JP Agarwal’s son Mudit, former Sadar Bazar MLA Rajesh Jain’s son Pratik, former speaker Yoganand Shastri’s daughter Priyanka, Jangpura MLA Talwinder Marwah’s son Arjun, former Model Town MLA Kunwar Karan Singh’s daughter Akanksha, former MP Mahabal Mishra’s son Vinay are keen to contest this time. In some cases, both father and son/daughter have shown interest in contesting the election from the same or different constituency.

The party leadership, sources said, is still deliberating on going with experienced leaders or trying young blood. A senior party functionary, who contested the last Lok Sabha election, has insisted that he will only file his papers if all other candidates of the 2019 polls put their hat in the ring. “Our aim is to give tickets to 35-40 young leaders,” said a senior party functionary.

Title: In 2018, fewer farmer suicides in Andhra Pradesh
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: Farmer suicides in Andhra Pradesh saw a decline in 2018, compared to 2017. Data in the latest National Crime Records Bureau ( NCRB ) report, Accidents and Suicides in India-2018, place Andhra Pradesh fourth in the country in terms of number of farmer suicides in 2018, behind Maharashtra with 3,594 farmer suicides, Karnataka (2,405) and Telangana (908).

The reasons behind farmer suicides are not specified in the report.

Of the 664 farmer suicides in the state in 2018, 593 were male and 71 were female. Data also show that 199 suicides were committed by farmers who cultivated their own farmland, 166 by those who had leased out their land and 299 were engaged as agricultural labourers.

K Lokanadham, district secretary of the Communist Party of India (Marxist) said increased input cost coupled with crop loss due to conditions of extreme weather, poor marketing facilities and low profits are some reasons behind farmer suicides.

CPI(M) and Communist Party of India (CPI) functionaries said a majority of farmer suicides in the state has been reported in the Rayalaseema region and scattered locations in north-coastal AP. Poor returns from farming have forced small farmers in parts of Vizianagaram and Srikakulam districts to migrate to nearby cities and towns in search of livelihood, they added.

Left parties have stated that extending freebies to the agricultural sector will not address the crisis, and have instead demanded input subsidy, improved marketing facilities and profitable price for farm produce. Though the YSR Congree-led state government has launched the Rythu Bharosa scheme for financial assistance to farmers, some tenant farmers remain outside its ambit, they said.

While several committees have recommended that a minimum support price (MSP) that is at least 50 per cent above the cost of production be extended to farmers, the implementation of the formula is yet to be taken up. Farmers have been made the victims and their efforts have gone unrecognised, rued N Anil Kumar, a farmer from the region.

Title: Bodybuilding not popular as professional sport in city
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Despite a number of bodybuilders from Madurai winning accolades in state, regional, national and international levels, youngsters in the city are not inspired to take up bodybuilding as the choice of sport for a professional career.

A major hurdle in taking up bodybuilding professionally is money. “Madurai men have been known for bodybuilding. I’m training 12 bodybuilders in my gym currently. However, it is an expensive sport that requires dedication and also full support of parents. Monthly expenses can come up to Rs 30,000 for the food and supplements that need to be followed,” said Yogesh, a successful bodybuilder, who also runs a gym in Villapuram.

Bodybuilders and gym trainers feel that youngsters have a better chance of succeeding in the sport but have not been making use of it. “At 18, if a boy starts preparing for bodybuilding then by the age of 24, he will become a world class bodybuilder. It is the ideal age for muscle growth and good metabolism. Food and supplements would also work better then,” explained Yogesh.

However, the mention of supplements creates an air of fear of among those who may be interested in pursuing the sport. “Bodybuilding is a good sport. However, many tend to ask why consume so much protein supplements with a pre-conceived aversion. Parents also don’t realise that it is nothing so different from Horlicks or Boost that children consume,” said Dhanasekaran R, a professional bodybuilder who has won many competitions at various levels. He hopes that more youth can be lured into taking up bodybuilding by making government job opportunities available for them, including jobs in railways and air force.

Title: Illness, family disputes are top motives
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Accidents and Suicides in India-2018 report of the National Crime Records Bureau ( NCRB ) points to ‘ family problems ’ and ‘ illness ’ as the primary motives behind suicide in the state in 2018.

A total of 5,319 persons, including 3,751 men and 1,566 women, committed suicide in the state in 2018. The report states that 1,610 people committed suicide due to illness and 1,515 persons ended their lives due to family problems in the state in 2018. Another 376 persons committed suicide due to bankruptcy while the number of marriage-related suicides stood at 412 for the same year.

The data for 2018 also show that another 85 persons committed suicide after failing an examination, while unsuccessful relationships led to 154 suicides.

A senior police official said rapid changes in society, inability to cope with pressures at work, family disputes, failed relationships and failure in examinations were the main reasons behind the increasing number of suicides.

While psychiatrists said NCRB figures for the state point to suicide as a growing concern in a digital era, police officials added that some suicides were motivated by trivial reasons and they have appealed to the management of colleges to appoint counsellors to address challenges faced by students.

Title: UP accounts for 93% of malware in India: NCRB
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Officials Blame It On Computer Illiteracy

Meerut: Out of 1,218 cyberattacks involving ransomware (a type of malicious software designed to block access to a computer system until a sum of money is paid), 1,136 took place in Uttar Pradesh in 2018, according to recently released NCRB report. Notably, there is 400% rise in such cases across the country as compared to the 2017 numbers. In 2017, there were just 300 such cases countrywide, though UP had still the highest 245 cases involving ransomware then.

Even the states considered to be information technology hubs, like Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh, are nowhere close to UP. While Andhra Pradesh has zero such cases registered in 2018, Karnataka has seven.

The only state that comes next to UP is Jharkhand with mere 51 cases. Nevertheless, Karnataka still tops the charts when it comes to non-ransomware cyberattacks.

According to NCRB data, in terms of cybercrime that comes under section 66C (identity theft when someone fraudulently or dishonestly makes use of the electronic signature, password or any other unique identification feature of any other person) of the Information Technology Act, 2000, Karnataka accounts for 5,526 cases followed by UP with 4,285 cases. All other states are well below 1,000.

According to a senior police officer in UP’s cybercrime cell, “Computer illiteracy combined with negligence is the primary cause of ransomware attacks.”

The officer added, “In IT hubs like Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh, computer literacy is high and people are educated enough to take cyber security seriously. In UP where people have considerable access to information technology, they are less vigilant due to ignorance. Good anti-virus software and not falling prey to attractive but unauthentic lucrative baits in the form of cash rewards are some of the safeguards. Besides, there are times when small firms or individuals attach their backup data to internet by plugging devices into their systems. Such data is always vulnerable to ransomware. But considering the size of the state and its population, 1,136 is still a minuscule figure when compared to the way people throw caution to wind.”

Title: Delhi assembly elections: BJP plans slew of small meets for better reach
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: With Delhi assembly polls inching closer, BJP functionaries have decided to address small corner meetings in densely populated areas such as unauthorised colonies for “effective outreach”.With the nomination process beginning Tuesday, the party also formed a 15-member election committee on Friday to shortlist “winnable” candidates from each seat and suggest their names to the parliamentary board for final announcement. The panel members include Delhi BJP president Manoj Tiwari , six other Delhi MPs, Rajya Sabha MP Vijay Goel, leader of Opposition in outgoing Delhi assembly Vijender Gupta, among others.Taking a cue from BJP national president Amit Shah’s address to booth workers at Indira Gandhi Indoor Stadium last Sunday, the party leaders have decided that they will prefer corner meetings over addressing bigger public rallies. Shah is likely to address several such smaller meetings of 200-300 people in the next few days. Top party leadership, including PM Narendra Modi and Shah, may address rallies closer to the elections.Meanwhile, senior BJP functionaries said that they will focus on meetings with smaller groups of 300-500 people. “Such meetings prove more impactful. Big rallies require more efforts and people often show reluctance to attend them unless big names like PM Modi or Shah are speaking. We have planned smaller meetings for “target” groups apart from candidates’ door-to-door campaign and roadshows,” a senior BJP functionary said.Another party functionary said that more such meetings will be held in unauthorised colonies where the Centre has started giving ownership rights to residents and in JJ clusters where the slum dwellers have been promised pucca houses under the Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana.

Title: Centre may retender airport modernization
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Nagpur: Even though GMR Airports has bagged the tender for modernization of the Nagpur airport, the central government may ask Mihan India Limited (MIL) to go for retendering, said Union transport minister Nitin Gadkari during the inaugural function of the Liberty Cinema to Mental Hospital flyover on Friday evening.

Gadkari didn’t mention the reason and expressed hope that the Centre would not take this decision as it would delay the project.

TOI had reported on December 4, 2019 that the union civil aviation ministry had questioned MIL regarding the need for privatizing the airport.

This was because GMR, which emerged as the highest bidder with an offer to share over 14% of the revenue, would have given less than what MIL, the current operator, earns on its own.

In 2019, the earnings of airports were Rs49 crore. After roping in GMR, the figure may have come down to Rs15 crore.

Commenting on the broad gauge Metro project, Gadkari said that it had got in principle approval. “After the Nagpur-Nagbhid narrow gauge line is converted to broad gauge, we will run a Metro up to Wadsa. Before that, BG Metro will connect Bhandara, Narkhed and Wardha with Nagpur. Later, we will run a BG Metro between Chandrapur and Gondia,” he added.

On Phase II of Nagpur Metro, Gadkari said that it was expected to get approval of the union cabinet soon. “Then Metro will connect Hingna, Pardi, Dattawadi, Butibori and Kanhan with the centre of Nagpur. People living in adjoining areas will get a fast mode of connectivity to the city,” he added.

Regarding Reach III of Phase I of the Metro, he said that chief minister Uddhav Thackeray was expected to inaugurate it soon.

The city MP further said that work has started on the inter-modal station (IMS) in Ajni and it would improve connectivity to areas adjoining the city.

“The Centre has approved doubling of railway lines from Nagpur to Rajnandgaon, Itarsi and Sewagram at the cost of Rs6,000 crore. JICA had sanctioned a loan for rejuvenation of Nag River and Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) needs just a small permission from the state government. Work will start on the project after that,” said Gadkari.

“We have sanctioned Rs68 crore for the Jaripatka railway overbridge (ROB). The detailed project report (DPR) of ROB between Shanti Nagar and Kawrapeth is ready. MahaMetro will build a cement road from RBI Square to Agrasen Square while the National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) will build a four-lane road behind Mayo Hospital,” the minister said on road projects.

Devendra Fadnavis, the leader of the opposition in state assembly, said that the city had witnessed an unprecedented development under the leadership of Gadkari and hoped that the momentum would continue.

Title: Slowdown good, has changed govt’s mindset: Experts
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Bengaluru: The current slowdown in the economy can be beneficial for the country in the long run, at least two experts said on Friday.

They made the observation during a seminar — Make in India: Making it Work — at Xavier Institute of Management and Entrepreneurship. While former vice-chairman of Tata Steel B Muthuraman said the slowdown has helped the government change its mindset, chief managing director of BEML Deepak Hota said it will be helpful in ushering in the new-age industry 4.0.

Hota said the sluggish economy is good for the country right now. “As per the Systems Thinking Approach, one needs to slow down to speed up. Now is a good time to pause and introspect on what needs to be done. This is exactly what the government is doing right now,” he said.

Muthuraman said the sluggish economy is leading to positive changes. “In some ways, the slowdown may help us in future as there’s been a change of mindset in the government, which one has not observed for many years,” he said, explaining that proposals to sell 100% stake in Air India and privatise the railways are examples of the shift.

“There had been talks of selling 25% stake in Air India, but 100% is what was needed. This change in mindset plays a very big part in the Make In India movement,” he said.

Pain points in the economy

Other speakers highlighted problems like financial distress in several sectors like construction, mining and automobile industry, and also the high cost of logistics that is discouraging investment. R Mukundan, MD, Tata Chemicals, said though there are bright spots such as the IT industry and sectors like chemicals and petrochemicals, several self-created problems have hit the Indian economy in general. “Unintended problems after demonetisation hit MSME demand and put pressure on consumer demand. Though Goods and Services Tax is a fantastic move, difficulty in implementation is creating problems,” he elaborated.

Land reforms needed

Experts stressed the need for capital formation, a healthy credit flow, simplification of labour laws, business-friendly land acquisition system and more. SD Tripathi, vice-president (HR), Tata Steel, said the biggest challenge in starting a manufacturing unit was buying land.

While Mukundan said land must not be acquired from farmers and that ‘they must be left alone’, President and MD of Volvo Group, India, Kamal Bali suggested: “Industrialists, who want to set up, design and make in India, may not be experts in acquiring land and may want just a ‘plug and play system’, where they come, decide on a lease cost for 10-20 years and start work. Because most of them don’t want to get into the process of buying land, which includes a huge capital cost and ownership title issues.”

Title: Pune: Legal cases make tax target look distant
Content:
Representative image

The prospects of recovering over Rs1,000 crore by the civic body in property tax arrears by the end of this fiscal hinge on the results of 341 legal cases

PUNE: The prospects of recovering over Rs1,000 crore by the civic body in property tax arrears by the end of this fiscal hinge on the results of 341 legal cases — some of which are decades old.This was revealed in a reply to a Right to Information (RTI) query raised by an elected member in the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) about details of property tax recovery and the pending legal cases. The civic administration’s reply also stated that the cases were pending in various courts, including the district court, lower courts and the Bombay high court.“The number of cases pending in the courts is huge. The civic administration should focus on the cases and ensure recovery of the arrears. Tax has been legally imposed and follows a due procedure,” said corporator Ulhas Bagul, who had raised the RTI query.“If there is any legal dispute pertaining to the tax as raised by the property owners, the PMC should resolve it at the earliest and recover the dues. Only amnesty schemes will not help,” he added.PMC officials said the civic administration has adopted a wait-and-watch stand on the legal issues. “Some cases are pending since 1988. Out-of-court settlements of many cases are difficult,” an official said.Vilas Kanade, head of the PMC’s property tax department, said, “We are taking measures to speed up the process to recover the property tax arrears. All information sought by the courts are provided with as quickly as possible. The civic body has also approached the Lok Adalat and explored alternative mechanisms to resolve the disputes.”The officials said the civic body had targeted to mop up Rs2,100 crore in property tax during this financial year, which ends on March 31, 2020. Till December 31, 2019, the civic body has collected up to Rs1,100 crore.The officials said the PMC has around 10.2 lakh properties in areas under its jurisdiction. Owners of around 7.8 properties have paid the tax and the levy is to be recovered from 2.4 lakh properties.The civic administration offers discount to the tax payers clearing dues before May 31.

Title: Odisha: NHRC seeks report on teen pregnancy in government schools
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

BHUBANESWAR: The National Human Rights Commission ( NHRC ) has sought an action taken report from the Odisha chief secretary regarding several incidents of pregnancy of minor girls in different schools across the state. It has asked for a report within four weeks.

The NHRC warned that in case the report is not received within the stipulated time, the commission shall be constrained to invoke a coercive process under Section 13 of the Protection of Human Rights Act, 1993, for personal appearance of the concerned authorities.

The commission passed the order on Monday after hearing a petition filed by human rights activist Radhakanta Tripathy last month on teen pregnancies in schools, especially residential institutions.

The petitioner alleged that minor girls belonging to SC and ST categories faced sexual exploitation in some residential schools.

Tripathy cited examples of three recent incidents reported from tribal-dominated Koraput and Nabarangapur districts. On December 12, a Class IX girl of a school under Taragaon police station limits in Nabarangpur district was found to be pregnant.

On December 8, a Class X girl of a tribal residential school in Koraput district was found to be pregnant during a medical checkup.

Similarly, on December 4, a Class VII girl of a residential school in Koraput district was found to be pregnant.

The husband of the school principal was arrested for allegedly raping the minor.

The petitioner also pointed out the incident of March 2015 when the then SC and ST development minister, Lal Bihari Himirika, had disclosed the names of 17 sexually abused children in the assembly. Himirika, while reading out the list, had also given details of their schools and the classes they studied.

The state runs more than 1000 such residential schools, known as ashram or sevashram schools. More than three lakh students study in these schools. Most of the students stay free of cost in the hostels. “It is the responsibility of the state government to give the girls a safe environment,” the petitioner said.

He also requested the NHRC to monitor preventive and punitive actions taken by the state government and take legal action against errant officials, elected representatives and culprits and rehabilitate all the victims after ensuring their basic human rights.

Title: Frequent changes in diversions on Sirsi Circle flyover peeve motorists
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

BENGALURU: Motorists entering the city from Mysuru Road continue to brave snarls and bumper-to-bumper traffic, thanks to BBMP’s inept handling of diversions on Sirsi Circle flyover, which have been put in place to facilitate maintenance work on the elevated corridor.

Most motorists take the flyover prepared for the worst as they’re aware of the ongoing work. Yet, frequent changes in diversions without prior notice are leaving them stumped and forcing them to spend a long time at the wheel to reach their destinations.

BBMP introduced a series of curbs on December 16 to facilitate relaying work on the carriageway leading from Sirsi Circle to Town Hall.

On Friday, motorists who took the flyover hoping to reach Town Hall were in for a shock at the down ramp of TCM Royan Road. With barricades stopping them from moving ahead, they had to go down the ramp and enter TCM Royan Road. Those heading towards Town Hall had to take a right, enter congested streets and reach KR Market before moving on to NR Road.

“I would take only 10 minutes to cover the 2.5km distance even after the diversions were enforced last month. But on Friday, it took me more than an hour,” said Nanda Kumar, who frequently rides on the flyover.

A check by TOI found cars stranded for over an hour on the flyover. While TCM Royan Road was clogged, the diversion through Baskhb Garden Road was too narrow for even two cars to move side by side.

“I was stuck on the flyover from 2.30pm to 3.15pm and traffic didn’t move an inch. When vehicles finally began to move, we were forced to get down TCM Royan Road ramp, take a right near Bakshi Garden and head towards KR Market,” said Prashanth Kumar, a salesman working with a private firm. “I missed an important meeting,” he added, blaming BBMP for the mess.

Many commuters using the flyover said BBMP is complicating things by changing diversions without keeping citizens in the loop. “First, it allowed vehicles heading into the city to use the flyover till the Town Hall, while those coming in the opposite direction were to exit at Briand Square down ramp and get into Chamarajpet to move towards Sirsi Circle. On Friday, we had to get down at TCM Royan Road ramp as barricades had suddenly been installed,” Nanda Kumar rued.

“The bus traffic near KR Market is the biggest problem. There are at least 10 buses exiting Kalasipalya and the market area at any point of time, due to which we had to wait longer,” said Ajmal Khan, a frequent commuter and resident of Deepanjalinagar.

A senior BBMP official said their options are limited and they are doing everything to ease traffic. “Till the surfacing work is over, diversions will be in place. People will have to bear with them,” the official said. The work will be over within a month, he added.

Title: This Josephite didn’t miss a single class in 12 years of schooling
Content:
Naman Bipin Bafna is now pursuing BCom

Brother no less

‘His desire is phenomenal’

BENGALURU: On Friday, St Joseph’s Boys’ High School instituted a new award for an outstanding achievement — first time in its 161-year history, one of its students did not miss a single class in 12 years of schooling.Eighteen-year-old Naman Bipin Bafna has to his credit 100% attendance from class 1 to 12. According to school authorities, this is the first time that one of their students has achieved this feat.Naman attributes this impeccable record to his passion for fitness throughout school life. “I hardly ate food from outside, barring from the canteen a couple of times a month. I was into sports — athletics, football, cricket , basketball — and I was focused on my health and stamina. I ate fresh and healthy homemade food and stayed away from junk,” says Naman, adding, “My parents always motivated me to go to school.”“Once when in class 5 or 6, I had fever , but I still went to school because there was something important happening that day. Other times, whenever I fell sick, it was either a weekend or during some holiday,” he recalls.Naman, who is currently pursuing BCom at St Joseph’s College of Commerce, doesn’t have 100% attendance now as he has to simultaneously prepare for Chartered Accountant because of which he has to miss classes once in a while. “But still I’m the one with the highest attendance,” he says.The teen, who scored 90% in class 10 and 91% in class 12 exams, says he was never even tempted to bunk classes. “School was fun. What would I do sitting at home,” he quips.Naman’s father Bipin Bafna, a textile businessman and resident of Avenue Road, says it was his son’s love for school that drove him to Museum Road every day.Naman’s younger brother, also a student of St Joseph’s Boys’ High School, is treading the same path. The eighth grader has not missed a single day single UKG. “I hope he will manage to maintain this record. It’s special,” says Naman.Naman’s passion to come to school is extremely heartening. I’m sure, there would have been days when he’d have been unwell — say a cold or a headache. But his desire to come to school overcoming everything is phenomenal— Uday Kumar | vice-principal, St Joseph’s Boys’ High School

Title: Nellai Kannan gets conditional bail in hate speech case
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The Tirunelveli principal sessions court on Friday granted conditional bail to writer and orator Nellai Kannan , 75, for his provocative speech against Prime Minister Narendra Modi and home minister Amit Shah .

Kannan had delivered the provocative speech during a public meeting organised by the SDPI to condemn the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) at Tirunelveli on December 29, 2019. Based on the complaint by a BJP functionary, the Melapalayam police registered a case against him under Sections 504, 505(1)(b), 505(ii), 153 A, 506 (i) of the IPC. Following protests by BJP cadres, Kannan was arrested at a guest house in Perambalur and was produced before the Tirunelveli judicial magistrate court. The court remanded him in judicial custody till January 13 and he was lodged in the Salem Central Prison. Kannan filed a bail petition before the Tirunelveli principal sessions court. On Friday evening, the principal sessions judge A Nazir Ahamed granted bail to Kannan with conditions including affixing his signature at the Melapalayam police station twice a day at 10am and 5pm.

Meanwhile, Kannan’s petition before the Madras high court Madurai bench seeking to quash the FIR registered against him for his provocative speech came up for hearing on Friday morning.

The counsel appearing for the complainant submitted that the case was registered against Kannan as his speech would lead to law and order problems.

Title: Bengaluru: Indian Mujahideen man gets seven-year jail for stadium blasts
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: A special court on Friday awarded a seven-year jail term to Fasih Mohammed, a member of Indian Mujahideen (IM), for his role in the blasts triggered outside M Chinnaswamy Stadium on April 17, 2010.

Three low-intensity bombs exploded outside the stadium a little before an IPL match between Mumbai Indians and Royal Challengers Bangalore was to begin. As many as 17 people, including policemen, were injured.

The conviction came after Fasih, who’s from Bihar, pleaded guilty, sources said. “Fasih confessed to have known prime suspect and founder of IM, Yasin Bhatkal. Fasih introduced the other accused to Yasin when the latter decided to plant explosives outside the stadium,” the sources added.

After the blasts, Fasih flew to Dubai where he worked an an engineer. He was arrested in August 2012 after he was deported from Dubai. Faish is the third person to be convicted in the case after pleading guilty.

The case was investigated by Central Crime Branch, which named 14 men led by Yasin in the chargesheet.

Title: PMC fails to present a/c statement in eight years
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Pune: The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) has not presented the annual statement of accounts for the last eight years.

The statement is important as details of the expense in the annual budget and its performance are given in this statement. The civic body had made the report available to the public last in 2011-12.

Sajag Nagrik Manch, a citizens’ group, has sought the information under the Right to Information Act (RTI). The group claimed that the reports have been kept unattended at the PMC’s printing press.

Vivek Velankar of the manch said the civic administration was expected to present the report as soon as the financial year was complete. The elected members of the PMC are expected to get these reports. They are also available for citizens who have to buy them.

“The information that we have got in the reply to the Right to Information Act application is shocking. The civic administration has prepared these reports, but they have been kept unattended at the printing press. They are neither available to the standing committee chairman, nor to the elected members nor to the people,” he said.

According to the Municipal Act, annual administration report and statement of accounts is mandatory.

“The publication and submission of these reports is a must. We will make sure that the reports for our tenure are published. The previous reports are not part of my jurisdiction, but I will speak with the civic officials and seek a follow-up,” Hemant Rasane, chairman of the standing committee, said.

Ambrish Galinde, head of the PMC’s audit department, said the civic administration will make the reports available for the citizens, online. “We have completed the works for all reports, except for two years. We will upload the completed reports online. They will be updated on the official website of the PMC,” he said.

Title: Steps taken to provide security to elected representatives: TN to HC
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Madurai: The state government has informed the Madras high court that it is taking steps to provide police protection to the elected local body representatives when they submit applications with genuine apprehensions.

The state said this in reply to a petition moved by a former DMK minister seeking police protection for the elected DMK union councillors from Virudhunagar district to enable them cast their votes for the ensuing indirect election on January 11.

In his petition, the DMK MLA of Aruppukottai constituency K K S S R Ramachandran, stated that the DMK party has gained majority seats in the nine panchayat unions in Virudhunagar district.

The ruling AIADMK members in connivance with the government officials and police officers with the help of antisocial elements are attempting to kidnap the elected DMK councillors.

He stated that attempts were also made to intimidate the councillors and their family members to prevent them from casting their votes for the indirect election for the posts of chairman and vice-chairman of panchayat unions which is to be conducted on January 11.

Ramachandran said that he had submitted a representation to police officials seeking protection for the elected representatives of DMK for them to take part in the indirect election.

Since there was no positive response from police officials, he moved the high court Madurai bench. When the case was heard on Friday, a division bench of justice M Duraiswamy and justice T Ravindran recorded the state’s submission and disposed of the petition.

Title: Luxury car sales fall 15% in 2019
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Pune: Luxury carmakers in the country recorded a decline of a cumulative 15% in sales in 2019.

The top three luxury car sellers in the country, Mercedes Benz India, BMW India and Audi India, sold a cumulative 28,021 cars in 2019 compared to 33,111 in 2018, according to the data from respective companies. The top three automakers account for about 85% of the luxury car market in India.

According to market players, apart from slow economic environment, luxury car sales was also hit by high taxes. Apart from 28% GST, luxury car buyers also have to pay a 15% surcharge on buying luxury cars.

“We fail to understand this. Luxury cars generally bring in new technology and safety features, which soon become a standard in the industry. It does not help that the government views luxury cars as some sin goods,” a top executive of a luxury car maker said.

“If the government cuts taxes, more people will buy and even at 28% GST the government will end up earning equal or more revenue,” an executive of a luxury car seller said.

Title: 20-yr-old woman in Bihar seeks divorce as hubby avoids regular shave and bath
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: In a bizarre case, a 20-year-old woman from Vaishali district has sought divorce claiming that her husband stinks as he does not shave, take bath and brush his teeth regularly. She also complained that her husband doesn’t follow etiquette and manners.

The state women’s commission (SWC) listened to Soni Devi’s complaint and asked her husband Manish Ram (23) to mend his ways within two months. Or else, the commission would take appropriate action on the complaint.

SWC member Pratima Sinha said on Friday that Soni, a resident of Nayagaon village under Desri block in Vaishali district, approached the commission on Thursday seeking divorce from her husband. “I was taken aback by her silly reasons cited for seeking divorce,” Pratima said.

In her petition, the woman said she was married to Manish, a plumber by profession, in 2017. “My husband stinks as he won’t shave and bathe for nearly 10 days at stretch. Moreover, he doesn’t brush his teeth. He also doesn’t have manners and follow etiquettes,” the petitioner alleged.

The SWC member said the complainant was adamant on her demand for separation from her husband. “I don’t want to live with my husband anymore. I can no longer bear the humiliation. Kindly get me rid of this man (read husband); he has ruined my life,” Pratima quoted Soni as saying.

Soni also insisted on her husband return the jewellery and other valuables, which her father had given as dowry at the time of marriage . “We have no children. Even our relationship as a husband and wife is not cordial. Life has no meaning. It’s worthless,” she told the commission.

The SWC member said she tried to convince the couple not to break their marital bond. “I have given her husband two months’ time to mend his ways. If his behaviour is not found satisfactory even after that, we will take appropriate action and refer the matter to the family court for separation,” Pratima told this newspaper.

Manish, when contacted, said, “Hum saath rahna chahte hain (I want to live together).” He was a bit nervous over the development and said he would mend his ways and try to win the confidence of his wife.

Though Soni is not a convent educated woman and belongs to a lower middle class scheduled caste family, but she is aware of the happening around and also knows her rights, Pratima said.

When asked whether the commission was empowered to do anything in such a case, the SCW member said, “We mainly play the role of an arbitrator on such issues.”

Elaborating further, Pratima said, “At least we can help the woman by pursuing her in-laws’ to return the valuables. It’s true that she will have to approach the family court for final separation. We will cooperate with her. But our first priority is to settle the matter.”

Pratima also said she had come across such a complaint for the first time ever since she took over as a member of the commission. “Divorce is taken by married couples’ on petty issues, which is not a good sign,” she added.

Title: Madras high court slaps Rs 25,000 fine on petitioner for false case
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The Madras high court has imposed a cost of Rs 25,000 on a petitioner for filing a false case stating that his associate who was the elected representative was abducted in Tuticorin district. In his petition, M Palpandian, a resident of Tuticorin district, stated that after the rural local body election was declared, his associate Senthil Murugan contested as an independent candidate for the post of ward 17 councillor of Kovilpatti panchayat union. Palpandian stated that Senthil had won the election by defeating the prime political party candidates.

Aggrieved over his victory, Senthil was abducted in a car by some unidentified people on January 3. Even though he informed the police officials about this incident, no action was taken. Hence, the petitioner filed a habeas corpus petition before the high court Madurai bench seeking to produce Senthil before the court.

When the petition was heard on Friday, Senthil, who was produced before the court informed the judges he was not associated with the petitioner and was not abducted.

Taking note of the submissions, a division bench of justice T Raja and justice B Pugalendhi imposed the cost for wasting the court’s time by filing a false case. The judges directed the petitioner to pay the cost to the Gandhi Memorial Museum in Madurai.
