It maybe recalled that the court on Thursday, imposed a cost of Rs 15,000 on a petitioner for filing a false case stating that his father who is the elected DMK ward councillor of Mudukulathur panchayat union in Ramanathapuram district was abducted.

Title: Biochemical waste plants to be developed in hills, HC told
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Nainital: The State Pollution Control Board on Friday informed the Uttarakhand high court (HC) that it has held a meeting to set up Medical Waste Management Plants in at least two locations in the state.

The SPCB, in an affidavit, also informed the bench of Chief Justice Ramesh Ranganathan and Justice Alok Kumar Verma that it has selected Almora and Narendra Nagar for establishing these facilities. “The SPCB has said that it has already invited Letters of Interests for developing the Medical Waste Processing Plants that are to be developed at these two locations,” said a lawyer appearing for the petitioner.

The bench of Chief Justice Ramesh Ranganathan and Justice Alok Kumar Verma has been hearing a clutch of petitions that had highlighted the monopoly enjoyed by two private biomedical waste and disposal management facilities. The Public Interest Litigation (PIL) also states that both the plants are in plains (Roorkee and Rudrapur) and therefore the waste generated in the hills are not being disposed properly which ultimately affects the ecology of the sensitive region of the state.

“The SPCB has also said that both the plants are proposed in hills to cater to the waste generated there. The affidavit added that the committee set up after the meetings of SPCB and secretaries of the urban development, health and industries will decide other locations to develop such facilities,” the lawyer said, adding that the court will hear the matter next on February 11.

Title: KCB starts water tank demolition in Khadki
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

The demolition process began in the morning with the cantonment employees and policemen barricading the roads ... Read More

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: The Khadki Cantonment Board on Friday started demolishing the dilapidated old elevated storage reservoir in the busy Khadki bazaar to prevent any accident.

The demolition process began in the morning with the cantonment employees and policemen barricading the roads around the elevated storage reservoir (ESR). The staircase of the ESR was demolished around 3pm.

Several vendors of Sanjay Gandhi market were barred from selling vegetables on handcarts near the ESR because of the demolition work. The work had to be conducted slowly because a large complex — Shewale Towers — is located nearby.

Pramod Singh, the chief executive officer (CEO) of the Khadki Cantonment Board ( KCB ), said, “We had asked the PMC ( Pune Municipal Corporation ) to demolish the dilapidated ESR to prevent any accidents, but in vain. As a result, the cantonment took the decision to demolish the ESR and demand reimbursement of expenditure from PMC.”

Singh said, “The KCB has awarded the contract for demolishing the ESR at a cost of Rs43.51 lakh and will demand reimbursement from the PMC. If it does not reimburse this expenditure, we can adjust it against the water tax the cantonment has to pay to it. The contractor has accepted the condition that he will be held responsible if there is any mishap during the demolition process.”

The public health engineering (PHE) department, now known as Maharashtra Jeevan Pradhikaran (MJP), had built the ESR having a capacity of 22 lakh litres at Khadki bazaar in 1976 for supplying water to the bazaar area at a cost of Rs30 lakh then. In 1988-89, the state government abolished the PHE and the PMC took over the water supply distribution work in the KCB limits.

The PMC had declared this ESR “unsafe” in May 2007 but still used it to supply water to Khadki bazaar by filling it up less than its capacity. There was lot of bickering between the KCB and the PMC over who would demolish the ESR and the construction of the new ESR.

Title: Maharashtra: Health education exam a must in Standard XI, XII
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Standard XI and XII students of the Maharashtra State Board of Secondary and Higher Secondary Education will have to appear for a compulsory examination in health and physical education.

The education department announced that the theory paper will be for 25 marks and students will get 90 minutes to appear for the exam. The practical test will be for 25 marks.The board announced the exam format for the newly introduced subject on Thursday.

Earlier, apart from health and physical education, the state board had introduced a 25-mark paper on water security and environmental education for 50 marks. State board secretary Ashok Bhosale said, “The health and physical education subject has been made compulsory for all faculties of the junior college. The subject is for 50 marks, divided into practical and theory tests. Students will be given grades after conversion of marks.”

The exam will be conducted in the second term.

As for the exam for the water security subject, student projects will carry 30 marks and journal assignments and seminar reports will carry 20 marks to make up the total 50 marks.

Title: Delhi Police probe marches Left, Left, Left, Left
Content:
A glass gate is seen vandalized inside the JNU campus after the attack on JNU students on Sunday night (File p... Read More

NEW DELHI: The clashes on JNU campus were triggered by the assault of four students who had gone to register for the winter semester on Sunday morning, according to Delhi Police ’s Special Investigation Team. On Friday, the SIT officially narrated the sequence of events starting from January 3 till January 5, established after speaking to around 200 students, campus residents and teachers.The tensions began at 1pm on January 3, said SIT chief Joy Tirkey, DCP (Crime), when some students affiliated to the Left-backed students’ union entered the registration centre at the School of Social Science and heckled the staff to cease the registration process. After they forcibly shut down the server, the registration process came to a halt.Since it was a centralised server, the whole system had to be rebooted, which took around four hours. The JNU administration informed the cops about this and the restoration process was conducted under police protection. An FIR was registered, in which police named JNUSU president Aishe Ghosh and a few other students.On January 4, after overwhelming the JNU security guards, some students broke open the door at the rear of the building in which registration was taking place. They allegedly manhandled the staff, tore out the server wires and vandalised the computerised system. This led to the CCTV cameras, biometric systems at the administrative block, the JNU website and security features going off. In its complaint to police, the JNU administration named Ghosh and 19 others.The third wave of violence took place around 11.30am on Sunday, when four students reached the registration centre and were waiting outside. Since the servers were out of order, the process was being conducted manually. A group of 15-20, allegedly from leftist student organisations, arrived and harassed the quartet. This was captured in a mobile phone video.The cops said that later at around 3.45pm, some masked intruders entered Periyar Hostel and attacked some residents. They also vandalised hostel property. In a video of this incident captured on CCTV, Chunchun Kumar was seen pelting stones with one hand while his other hand held a stick. Ghosh was also seen. In a mobile video, Dolan Samanta was seen fighting with another student.“We established this sequence based on our investigation so far and have sought eyewitness accounts. We have appealed to them to come with mobile phone videos since CCTV footage is unavailable due to the damaged servers,” said DCP Tirkey.Some teachers, on being informing about the clash, intervened to check the two groups. Around 6.30pm, JNUTA held a peace meet and called on JNUSU members not to resort to violence. It was around this time that the fourth phase of the attack commenced. According to Delhi Police, masked assailants, allegedly led by ABVP members, started attacking students near the Sabarmati T-point and chased some to Sabarmati Hostel, others to Narmada Hostel. The mob vandalised the hostel rooms and attacked JNUSU members, including Ghosh.The cops disclosed that the attackers from both groups appeared to have precise information about the targets. The people who have been identified will be questioned.

Title: Pro-cockfight lobby hopes for politicos’ aid
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

VISAKHAPATNAM: Organisers are urging political parties not to disrupt the cock-fight season in view of the forthcoming elections to various civic bodies.

Villagers are approaching politicians to secure police permission to hold the annual event.

Except Krishna and Guntur districts where the capital agitations are going on, the villages are ready for cock-fights. But in East and West Godavari districts organisers are yet to buy roosters but preparations are going on in coastal districts.

“Nobody can stop the cock-fights, a tradition since the days of our forefathers. If we stop, TDP will cash in on it. We are requesting the state leadership to get the government nod for the cock-fights,” said a YSRC politician in Konaseema.

An organizer in the Delta area said he the YSRC leadership would give the green signal for the traditional fights. More than 200 big and medium arenas and hundreds of small arenas are ready for the Sankranti rooster fights to be held from January 14 to January 16.

Roughly Rs 800 crore would be bet on the cock-fights, a punter said.

West Godavari district SP Navdeep Singh Grewal said they have set up two teams in each mandal with videographers. “So far 2,000 people were bound over and warned. We have taken Rs 5 lakh as bound over money from each person,” the SP said.

It is learnt that the TDP leadership has given hint that they are willing to support the events but crucial would be the decision of YSRC.

YSRC politicians feel that if there is no verbal go-ahead from the top party leadership, it would have an impact on local bodies elections.

Title: Farmers seek paddy procurement centres in all village panchayats in Sivaganga district
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Farmers have spent as much as Rs 13,000 to Rs 15,000 for cultivation on one acre of land and up to Rs 22,00... Read More MADURAI: The Communist Party of India (Marxist) in Sivaganga has demanded that paddy procurement centres should be inaugurated in 445 village panchayats in the district while paddy farmers in the district are getting ready for harvest after nearly five years. Sivaganga district has been drought prone for more than four years and last year crops had failed due to drought. In previous years, farmers, who had attempted to cultivate paddy, incurred heavy losses even after cultivating the crop with the help of wells and tankers since paddy procurement centres were not established in the district. K Veerapandi, a farmer said that paddy had been cultivated in about 70,000 hectares in Sivaganga district and harvesting had begun in places like Devakottai . “Two types of paddy, the fine grains and the bigger grains, have been cultivated and the government usually procures only the fine variety but this year they should accept both,” he said. In the previous years, there were a lot of malpractices in the procurement centres, where those who took the centres on contract, made the farmers pay for threshing paddy though the government gave a subsidy for the same. Though the procurement is done for bags of 41 kilograms each, the people at the centres weigh a bag at 42 or 43 kilograms causing loss to farmers. Now, farmers have been giving bags of paddy to private parties, who are taking them for cheap rates--Rs 900 per bag, while the government will pay Rs 1,700 for the same. Farmers have spent as much as Rs 13,000 to Rs 15,000 for cultivation on one acre of land and up to Rs 22,000 if they employed workers during the cultivation process. Hence, the government should open procurement centres in all the village panchayats to help the farmers pay their dues without delay as most of them have borrowed heavily to cultivate paddy this year though there were good rains, said Kandasamy of Sivaganga. If the centres are opened in all the villages, the procurement can be done faster and farmers will not face losses as paddy starts drying when the procurement process takes long and they lose about 10 kg per bag, said Veerapandi.

Title: Ex-CISF man moves court against poor portrayal of police in Darbar
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Tuticorin: Upset over the alleged poor representation of police and uniformed services personnel in Rajinikanth-starrer Darbar, Maria Michael, a former Central Industrial Services Force (CISF) personnel has filed a defamatory case before the judicial magistrate – III in a Tuticorin court on Friday. He has sought action against the film producer Lyca Productions, director A R Murugadoss and Rajinikanth.

In his representation, Michael had cited that the film that hit the big screens on Thursday showed the actor who plays the role of a top police officer in an inappropriate attire that includes his hairstyle and his dressing in which he seen leaving the buttons open exposing his vest. “In a dialogue the superstar also says he is not a commissioner but a scoundrel. These are among the aspects that upset our client,” his counsel M Gobikalyani said.

Gobikalyani and fellow counsel Jebasingh Selvin stated that such misrepresentation not only tarnishes the image of the police and upset those in service and retired personnel and also misguides aspirants who want to join the police and other uniformed services. He added that the case was filed before the court and would be heard on January 21.

Title: Pune: Three arrested on murder charge
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Koregaon Park police on Friday arrested three youths and booked two others for bludgeoning to death Nilesh Shendge (23), a criminal on their records, over a petty dispute at Darodemala Chowk around 12.30am.

The arrested include Aniket Wakhare (21), his cousin Abhishek Wakhare (21) and Fayyaz Shaikh (27). Shendge was released on bail from the Yerawada Central Prison eight days ago.

Police said Shendge and five others were partying and were allegedly under the influence of liquor. A dispute ensued with the victim for not meeting them and addressing them as “bhai”. When the dispute grew heated, they abused Shendge, beat him, attacked him with an iron rod and bludgeoned him to death with a tile, the police said.

Acting on a complaint registered by the victim’s mother Janbai Shendge (45) of Darodevasti naming five men responsible for killing her son, a police team from the Koregaon Park police, arrested the three and have launched a hunt for their two accomplices.

Title: GVMC banks on public support to ace SS-2020
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation ( GVMC ) commissioner G Srijana said that people’s participation is vital for the civic body to bag a good rank in Swachh Survekshan-2020 .

The commissioner visited Srivalli Nagar Colony in Zone I of the city on Friday. Speaking on the occasion, Srijana asked residents of the city to shun single-use plastic items to make Vizag a plastic-free city. “Garbage sorting should be done under three different components—dry, wet and hazardous waste—before it is handed over to the sanitary staff of the GVMC,” said Srijana to the residents.

Srijana took note of home composting carried out by residents of the colony and appreciated their move to use the same manure for cultivating vegetables and fruits.

The commissioner distributed dustbins and cloth bags to residents. Srijana also asked residents to provide feedback on seven questions relating to the condition of public/community toilets, cleanliness of public/commercial areas, waste segregation and awareness of Swachh Survekshan-2020.

The residents brought forward civic issues, such as pig menace and lack of street lights, to the notice of the commissioner. They also requested for a park and clearing the silt in a nearby storm water drain in a written representation to the commissioner.

Srijana asked the concerned officials to address the issues raised by residents.

Zone-I commissioner B Ramu, assistant medical officer Dr B Jayaram and others accompanied the commissioner on the visit.

Title: Pune: Court grants bail to youth from UP held for forgery
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A magisterial court here on Friday granted bail to a 22-year-old youth from Uttar Pradesh in a forgery case.

The Uttamnagar police had arrested Naveen R Tripathi, a resident of Pratapgarh in UP, on Tuesday after an investigation with the assistance from the Southern Command’s Military Intelligence unit revealed the bogus claims he made in the FIR. On Wednesday, the court ordered Naveen’s custodial remand for two days following which he was produced before the magistrate on Friday.

“The court of judicial magistrate first class T N Nirale granted bail to Naveen against a personal release bond of Rs15,000 and a surety in the like amount,” his lawyer Prasad Nikam told TOI.

The police said that Naveen allegedly forged National Defence Academy (NDA) and UPSC documents and had lodged the cheating FIR to hoodwink his parents from whom he had taken Rs1.32 lakh on the pretext of joining NDA. He had appeared for the NDA entrance exam in 2015 but could not clear it. “He told his parents that he would join the NDA soon and took Rs1.32 lakh as fees, but spent the same for shopping and partying,” said inspector Sunil Pandharkar of the Uttamnagar police. “Naveen studied the joining instructions on the NDA website and used the same to create forged documents,” Pandharkar added.

Eventually, the youth, his parents and other relatives reached the academy where Naveen produced the joining documents before the guards. The NDA authorities told Naveen and his family that the documents were fake. “Following this, Naveen lodged an FIR of cheating,” he said.

Naveen told police that three persons posing as NDA officers had interviewed him in Gujarat in 2016 after which he had received a joining letter and other forms from the academy’s e-mail IDs. The police probe revealed that he got a demand draft drawn in favour of NDA and later got the same cancelled following which the bank reverted the amount to his account.

Title: Bodgeshwar board told to keep an eye on kids at zatra
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Panaji: The Goa State Commission for Protection of Child Rights has written to the president of Shree Dev Bodgeshwar Sansthan (Bodgeshwar temple committee), requesting a vigilant approach towards children at the ongoing zatra. The move comes after 50-odd children were found without parental support at the zatra last year.

The commission has requested the president of the committee to take steps to ensure that no children are left vulnerable at the zatra.

After receiving a complaint last year, the commission had conducted an inspection of the fair. Chairperson of the commission Sushma Mandrekar Chodankar stated that she found 50-odd vulnerable children not properly dressed or had eaten in days and were in unhygienic conditions.

"They were loitering in and around the fair premises and were selling articles and balloons. Some of the children were used for performing acrobats and also for begging," Chodankar stated in her letter to the president of the temple committee.

A copy of the letter to the temple committee has also been sent to the director general of police, North Goa SP and Mapusa PI.

Title: Pune: Youth in net for sharing child porn clips on web
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Sangvi police on Wednesday arrested a 21-year-old salesman of a garment shop on the charge of sharing videos related to child pornography on the social media.

A team from the cybercrime cell of the Pimpri Chinchwad police took the youth into custody and subsequently handed over to the Sangvi police. The cell had received information about him from the state cyber unit.

The police said the youth, a resident of Pimple Gurav, had posted the video clips on his social networking site page on January 5. The National Centre for Missing and Exploited Children, an agency that monitors such activities on the social media, noticed the video clips on his social media page and alerted the National Crime Record Bureau (NCRB). “After getting in the information from the NCRB, the state cyber cell alerted the cybercrime cell of the Pimpri Chinchwad police,” said an officer from the Sangvi police.

He was arrested under section 67-B (punishment for publishing or transmitting of material depicting children in sexually explicit act) of the IT Act and the relevant sections of the POCSO Act.

Title: Minister distributes Pongal gift hamper on second day
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

A Ration card holder received the pongal gift from a PDS shop in Madurai

MADURAI: Pongal gift hampers were distributed for the second consecutive day on Friday with minister for revenue, disaster management and IT R B Udayakumar distributing them at some places in the district. The minister gave away the hampers to cardholders in Chekkanoorani, Karadikkal, Melaurapanur, Sathangudi and other places coming under the Thirumangalam constituency. As many as 31,647 beneficiaries received their hampers at the function.

Crowds thronged the shops from early in the morning and received their tokens for receiving the gifts. Some of them said that they should be given the cash in envelopes or covers, but shopkeepers told them that it was to ensure that there were no complaints of currency notes missing, later. As many as 84,70,93 rice cardholders in Madurai district are eligible to receive the Pongal gift hampers this year and are being given through 1,389 shops. Meanwhile, an advocate in Tuticorin, Joseph Ginosen has submitted a petition to the Tuticorin collector Sandeep Nanduri seeking that Pongal hampers be distributed at the homes of the beneficiaries. He said that many people including elders and pregnant women are forced to stand for long hours in queues to receive the hampers. There are incidents of some cardholders being told they are not eligible for the gift after standing in the queue for long. It would be good if hampers are distributed at doorsteps, and the list of beneficiaries should also be displayed outside the shops, he said.

Title: Shops in Old City down shutters in support of rally
Content:
Normal life came to a halt in parts of Old City on Friday

The Old City Hyderabad Traders Association on Thursday had announced that shops in Old City will remain shut between 1pm and 5pm in support of the Tiranga rally against CAA, NRC and NPR

CHARMINAR: Normal life came to a halt in parts of Old City on Friday. The Old City Hyderabad Traders Association on Thursday had announced that shops in Old City will remain shut between 1pm and 5pm in support of the Tiranga rally against Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA), National Register of Citizens (NRC) and National Population Register (NPR).The market streets wore a deserted look as business establishments and educational institutions remained closed.Shopkeepers in areas such as Falaknuma, Bahadurpura, Shastripuram, Charminar , Gulzar Houz, Pathergatti, Laad Bazaar, Old Subzi Mandi, Tappachabutra, Jhirra, Asif Nagar, Mehdipatnam and Tolichowki downed their shutters.“We are happy to see the unity among public and political leaders. Protests should continue till these controversial bills are withdrawn,” said Syed Gulam Mahmood Hussain, a shopkeeper.In view of the rally, the timings for Friday prayers were changed in some mosques and Namaz was offered at 1pm, so that participants could reach the venue as early as possible. Soon after the prayers, many people, holding Tricolour, headed towards Eidgah Mir Alam to take part in the rally.A group of youths came out from Mecca Masjid, raising slogans against Prime Minister Narendra Modi, and vowed to ‘intensify their agitation in coming days if the controversial bills are not withdrawn’.Meanwhile, the police swung into action and managed to peacefully disperse the crowd gathered outside Mecca Masjid. Also, elaborate security arrangements were made in and around the Old City, and the police kept a close watch on the rally route.

Title: 196 hotels running without NOC from SPCB get notice
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Rudrapur: The regional office of State Pollution Control Board (SPCB) at Kashipur has slapped 196 hotels, dharamshalas, and restaurants with notices for operating without its NOC. The notice directs owners of these commercial establishments to seek clearance from SPCB by March 31 or face punitive measures

"Every hotel , restaurant, and dharamshala requires clearance, according to Water (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1974, and Air (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1981. In Udham Singh Nagar district, only 22 such establishments have NOC from SPCB. Hence, we have sent notices to establishments functioning without proper clearances," Anurag Negi, regional officer of the SPCB, told TOI.

The SPCB move comes after the body conducted an inspection of 218 commercial establishments in the district. The official added that the businesses, which have been sent notices, didn’t even bother to apply for NOC from SPCB. “Once we receive an application for pollution clearance, a technical team visits the spot and inspects provisions to control water and air pollution,” Negi explained.

On being asked about the provisions that such commercial establishments must have to get a NOC from SPCB, Negi said, “Hotels discharge kitchen waste and sewage in large quantities. These must be treated before being released into mainstream sewerage and drainage system. Every hotel must have an incinerator to safely dispose the leftover food, which can otherwise pollute the air," he said.

According to the notices, if owner of such an establishment applies for NOC within the mentioned time period, he/she will get relaxation in the fee, which is charged from the day when the business was opened.

"The notice states that bona fide owners of such establishments require permission to run their business. This is their last window to get pollution clearance. If they fail, legal action would be taken against them," Negi said.

Meanwhile, Sudhanshu Gava, director of Hotel Sonia in Rudrapur, said, “Dual consent is among the basic criteria mandatory for establishing a hotel/restaurant. We got the NOC from SPCB as have waste recycling and sewer water treatment plants. Regulations were always there in place and it is good that the authorities are strictly implementing them now.”

Title: Delhi: Sting ‘unmasks’ hostel attackers, all ABVP’s
Content:
File photo of masked miscreants entering JNU campus

NEW DELHI: A first-year student of JNU , who claimed to be affiliated to ABVP, admitted to “mobilising men from outside” and leading the attack by masked vigilantes and 20 ABVP members on teachers and students, and vandalising hostels on the evening of January 5, an undercover investigation by India Today has revealed.The student, Akshat Awasthi, said streetlights being switched off just before and during the attack was the work of “police, administration… whose police is it?” The lights were switched off, he said, as that was when “we were mobilising”.In the sting operation, Awasthi said that on Sunday he called the “organisational secretary of ABVP”, whom he named, but it was beeped out in the telecast. Following their chat, he mobilised Sunday evening’s hooliganism, he claimed.All three students interviewed in the investigation were from JNU. Awasthi is pursuing a French degree. The second, Rohit Shah, also asserting allegiance to ABVP, is in the French language course too.Awasthi also identified himself in the footage of the January 5 attack — jeans, jacket and a helmet covering his face and head. He said he could be seen rushing down the hostel corridor, smashing anything that came his way. He boasted that he mobilised the attack in retaliation to an assault allegedly by Left students on Periyar hostel earlier the same day.India Today reported Awasthi also identified both people in the most viral footage of the attack — of a girl with her face covered and the male with a sledgehammer — as fellow ABVP associates. Awasthi said that after the raid, he found a fellow ABVP member hiding. He assured her he was from ABVP, “took off the helmet, put my arm around her, and walked out as a couple”.The stick in his hand was pulled out from a flag near Periyar hostel. Asked if he hit anyone, Awasthi said, “There was a man with a flowing beard. He looked Kashmiri. I beat him and kicked down the gate.”Security guard GV Thapa told India Today that 10-15 men, in shawls with lathis, forced through Saraswatipuram Gate where he was on duty a little after 7pm on Sunday. “They threatened to beat me and went in,” he added.Shah told the undercover reporters that he lent Awasthi the helmet. “It is a must when you smash glass.” The mob came to his room too, but moved on after he told them (masked men) “it was an ABVP room.” Asked if he was proud of their actions, he said, “Of course, of course.”The third student was former JNUSU president of AISA, Geeta Kumari, who admitted to “closing the server room” to cripple the administration’s functioning. “There are no exams. None of our demands are met. He (VC Jagadesh Kumar) didn’t even meet us. Our VC does everything online, sends ‘love letter’ online, sends Happy Near Year online, sends warnings/ threats online…”Reacting to the probe, ABVP general secretary Nidhi Tripathi said, “Anyone participating in ABVP or JNUSU events cannot qualify to become members automatically. Akshat Awasthi is neither an office bearer, nor karyakarta of ABVP. Anyone involved in the violence at JNU should be prosecuted. We will fully support police in their investigation.”

Title: Delhi Metro's Blue Line trains crawl for entire day on Friday
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

A Delhi Metro train (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Train operations on the Yamuna Bank to Noida Electronic City section of Delhi Metro ’s busiest corridor – Blue Line – witnessed disruptions for almost the entire day after a fracture was detected on a rail.

This was the third time in three months that a ‘weld fracture’ affected train movement on the Blue Line.

The problem was first observed at 9.40am and from thereon, train services on the Noida leg of the Blue Line (Dwarka-Noida Electronic City/Vaishali) remained slow as maintenance could only be carried out after end of services at night.

“A precautionary temporary speed restriction (TSR) of 25 kmph was imposed for trains moving on Up Line (going towards Dwarka) section of Blue Line from Noida Sec-61 to Noida Sec-52 metro stations due to a weld fracture observed in this section in the morning,” a Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC) spokesperson said. “Due to this, services on the Noida Electronic City-Yamuna Bank section was affected since 9.40am. There was minor bunching of trains on the Down Line (towards Noida Electronic City) also as trains were being run a little slower to regulate all the trains on the line,” he said.

The corporation said that its team would take a maintenance block to carry out repairs (good weld) in the night after close of services, to avoid disturbing regular services in day time. “These welds at times get fractured due to change in temperature/weather conditions and generally happen in early morning hours. Today’s defect was also noticed in the morning and accordingly it was safely secured as per the established norms and procedures,” the spokesperson said.

He said that running trains at restricted speed is safe and as per standard practice. “All the tracks are properly maintained and inspected by maintenance teams through physical patrolling at night on a daily basis,” he said.

Title: Security withdrawal: M K Stalin slams Centre
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

MK Stalin

CHENNAI/MADURAI: DMK president M K Stalin on Friday took a sarcastic route to hit out at the Centre for its decision to withdraw the 'Z+' security given to him. “I wholeheartedly thank each and every one of the @crpfindia personnel for providing security cover for me over the last many years. I urge the government to utilise CRPF personnel to protect universities and students from those perpetrating violence in the name of religion,” Stalin, who is away on a two-day visit to Andaman & Nicobar Islands, said in a tweet.

The home ministry had on Thursday withdrew Z+ security cover to him as well as deputy chief minister O Panneerselvam, who however did not see any ulterior motive behind the move to withdraw security cover for Stalin. “The Union home ministry felt it was not needed and hence withdrew it. It is the same in my case too,” Panneerselvam told reporters at Chennai airport. “This also indicates that law and order is well maintained in Tamil Nadu ,” he added.

However, DMK allies MDMK and Congress slammed the Centre for the decision. While TNCC president K S Alagiri expressed doubts over the kind of security that Tamil Nadu police could provide for Stalin, Congress MP S Thirunavukkarasar urged the Centre to restore Z+ security for Stalin. Meanwhile, Tuticorin MP K Kanimozhi said that the Centre removed the security cover to prevent Stalin from functioning as a strong force against the Centre.

“Thalapathi (Stalin) has people’s protection and does not need any other protection. But those in power need protection as they are functioning against the people,” Kanimozhi said responding to questions at Tuticorin airport . She termed as eyewash the removal of Y+ cover for deputy chief minister O Panneerselvam saying it was done to avoid criticism. She said there was no surprise in the ruling party denying time for the DMK and opposition to talk against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) in the assembly. Kanimozhi also took part in a seminar on CAA organised by a people’s forum in Tirunelveli later in the day.

Title: Crime against children, women up by 57% & 44% in U’khand, shows NCRB report
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Dehradun: Uttarakhand has registered over 57% rise in the cases of crime against children, while the incidents of crime against women also increased by about 44%, according to the latest National Crime Record Bureau ( NCRB ) report.

According to the report, the number of registered cases of crime against children has increased to 1,307 in 2018 from 829 in 2017. While in case of crime against women, the numbers rose to 2,817 in 2018 from 1,944 in 2017.

Between 2016 and 2018, Uttarakhand witnessed a rise of around 93% in cases of crime against children. According to the report, 676 cases of crime against children were reported in 2016, which increased to 1,307 in 2018.

Out of the total number of crimes committed against children, 527 cases of kidnapping and abduction topped the charts followed by rape (268) and murder (14) cases.

Out of the total 294 child victims under POCSO Act, the highest, 144 victims, were in the age group of 16-18 years, followed by 110 in the age group of 12-16 years and 37 in the age group of 6-12 years. Significantly, in 173 cases out of total 294, the accused were known to the child victims.

In case of crime against women, Uttarakhand witnessed 561 rape cases in 2018, while 502 women were either kidnapped or abducted. About 63 women died or were killed in dowry-related cases, while 19 women were attempted to be raped and 548 women were assaulted with intent to outrage their modesty.

In 224, out of total 561 rape cases, a relative, guardian, teacher or person in position of trust was directly involved, according to the NCRB report. Moreover, 273 rape victims were minors, while rest 303 were adults.

According to Ashok Kumar, director general (law and order), “The latest NCRB report has reflected increase in the number of cases of crime against women and children in Uttarakhand. It is mainly due to the increased awareness among women and children about the crime in the society and consistent efforts of police to register each and every case.”

Title: Rajasthan: Eyeing desi tourists, government to revive domestic travel mart
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

A file picture of tourist at Jantar Mantar in the city

JAIPUR: Modelled after Kerala Tourism Mart, the secret behind the southern state’s transformation as a favourite tourist destination, Rajasthan Domestic Tourism Mart (RDTM) took off to a flying start in 2018. But as the new government took over and in melee of setting new priorities and reshuffling of officials, the department lost sight of the event in 2018.

With volatility in foreign tourist visitors increasing owing to CAA and NRC protests, now the department is relooking to revive the travel mart that in its first edition had attracted 200 domestic buyers who had 7,000 pre-structured meetings with 170 sellers of tourism products from Rajasthan.

“We will make it bigger and better this year. Domestic travellers have become the new life and blood of the tourism industry, given the increasing uncertainty in foreign tourist arrivals. The department has already had a discussion with the Federation of Hospitality and Tourism of Rajasthan (FHTR). We will try to time the event before the onset of the tourist season to get maximum purchase,” said Bhanwar Lal, director, department of tourism. While the popular attractions get a boost from the business-to-business event, the focus has been on popularizing unknown destinations in the state. “Promotion and marketing play an important role in promoting unknown destinations. Rajasthan has lot of popular destinations but we want to add new ones so that we get more repeat tourists every year,” added Bhanwar Lal.

The previous edition was held at Birla auditorium but this time the organizer FHTR is planning to move the event to JECC, a much bigger venue. Similarly, plans are afoot to increase the number of buyers and sellers. “The event will be shifted to JECC as we are working on increasing the number of buyers and sellers. The three-day event is scheduled to be held in the first week of July,” said Kuldeep Chandelia, chairman of RDTM.

The mart provides a platform to the hotels, resorts, other tourism products to showcase their experiences before tour operators, travel agents and other service providers from across the country. Rajasthan hosts Great Indian Travel Bazaar every year to attract foreign tourists and with RDTM now, the state can now promote its tourism experiences for the domestic tourists as well.

Title: National Road Safety Week commences from Saturday
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

The department will also create awareness at colleges, banks, IT companies and other institutions

PUNE: The traffic police will undertake several initiatives, including awareness drives, workshops and intensified drives, to nab rule violators while observing the National Road Safety Week from Saturday.

On the direction of the ministry of road transport and highways, the Maharashtra home department on Monday issued a notification directing its transportation counterpart and traffic police across the state to undertake initiatives as part of the 31st National Road Safety Week.

The Pune traffic police have associated with and trained NSS students from various colleges to raise awareness about road safety. The department will also create awareness at colleges, banks, IT companies and other institutions. It will undertake a helmet distribution and awareness drive in association with ICIC Lombard.

According to the notification, the departments will have to spread awareness about the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988, and safe driving practices, among others, through gatherings, banners, handbills and pamphlets. The departments have been told to put up boards mentioning emergency contact numbers at various locations, among other initiatives. Pune police commissioner K Venkatesham said, “Road Safety Week will be celebrated with several initiatives. As part of the week, we will also intensify action and conduct focused drives to nab violators of traffic rules.”

Title: 10 special teams hunt for accused who killed SSI
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

KANYAKUMARI: The state police have increased the number of special police teams to 10 to intensify the hunt for the duo who shot dead special sub inspector (SSI) of police Wilson at a check post on Tamil Nadu–Kerala border on Wednesday night.

The duo having suspected terror links murdured the 57-year-old police insepector by first shooting and then stabbing him when he was alone at the check post in the night. The inspector was attached to the Kaliyakkavilai police station in Kanyakumari district .

Initially, the police formed three teams and it was later increased to five teams on Thursday.

Deputy inspector general of police (DIG) for Tirunelveli range Praveen Kumar Abhinapu said that these teams are either headed by an officer in the rank of inspector or sub inspector and are under the supervision of superintendent of police (SP) of Kanyakumari district N Shreenath.

The DIG said that officers in the rank of deputy superintendent of Police (DSP) are coordinating the combined efforts with the Kerala Police.

Two more DSPs are working on different aspects. “We know who we have to arrest. We need to know where the accused are hiding,” Praveen Kumar said.

Stating that there is not enough headway in the case, officers across ranks are tight-lipped on the case, refusing to divulge more details on the status of the case. They expressed concern that letting out any additional information would affect their efforts to close in on their suspects.

Tamil Nadu Dalit Urimaigal Pathukapu Iyakkam (rights protection movement) petitioned the government through Kanyakumari district collector to transfer the SSI murder case to the CBI.

They pressed for laying speed breakers at all 36 check posts and post armed personnel at all the check posts.

Title: Rallies held for and against CAA in Madurai
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Members from TMMK staged a protest near Madurai Airport Condemning CAA on Friday

MADURAI: Nearly 20-25 outfits coming under a single banner held a protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) in Madurai on Friday. Similarly, a CAA support rally was also held by the Hindu Maha Sabha. Various outfits including the Campus Front of India (CFI) and Ekadhipatya Yedhirpu Iyakkam, under the ‘Federation Against State Repression’ banned held a protest near the K Pudur Bus Stand in the evening.

“Initially, police had refused permission for the protest. However, seeing the number of people who turned up, they allowed us to protest till 6pm,” said Karumugilan, one of the co-ordinators of the protest.

The protesters held posters and banners with slogans like ‘Stand with JNU’, ‘No CAA’, and ‘No NRC’. Some creative posters with illustrations condemned fascism and islamophobia. Periyar EV Ramasamy and B R Ambedkar’s portraits and quotes were also highlighted by the protesters.

They also demanded the removal of CAA.

Meanwhile, a pro-CAA rally organized by the Hindu Maha Sabha with around 30 participants was also held in the city. This rally too was initially denied permission by the police.

“We want to spread the message that nobody needs to worry about CAA being implemented. We are holding this rally to allay fears about the act,” said Annadurai, one of the organizers of the rally.

Title: Be inquisitive, vice-chairman of UGC tells students
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Pune: University Grants Commission vice-chairman Bhushan Patwardhan introduced to the students of the Vishwakarma University on Friday the concept of National Academic Credit Bank, where a student can earn credit much before taking admission.

Patwardhan was the chief guest at the first convocation ceremony of Vishwakarma University, while Pradeep Bhargava, MCCIA president, was the guest of honour. He urged students to be inquisitive and never stop asking questions in the quest of life-long learning. Vice-chancellor Professor Siddharth Jabade presented a brief account of various achievements of the university. tnn

Title: Trying to avoid signal, BMTC driver triggers serial accident
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Two people in the white car had a narrow escape when the BMTC bus ploughed into their vehicle on East End Main... Read More

Title: JNU's winter session to start on Monday
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

At a meeting with JNUSU members, led by Aishe Ghosh, the ministry remained non-committal on demands like notif... Read More

NEW DELHI: JNU vice-chancellor M Jagadesh Kumar on Friday announced that the university’s winter session would commence on Monday. He issued this statement immediately after his meeting with HRD secretary Amit Khare.

A series of meetings were held by HRD ministry with Kumar, JNU Students’ Union and University Grants Commission (UGC) chairperson DP Singh over the fee hike issue. The ministry officials said that the basic demand of students regarding fee hike had been agreed to by the university and an appeal was made to students to call off the agitation.

JNUSU members, led by president elect Aishe Ghosh, were told by officials that utility and service charges would be borne by UGC, as promised earlier. The ministry, however, remained non-committal on other demands of the students, including notification of the students’ union and dropping of proctorial inquiries.

Khare said, “JNU has agreed to the basic demand of students. They are requested to call off the agitation. Students won’t need to pay any utility fee or service charges, but only the increased room rent.”

A five-member team from JNU, including Kumar, registrar Pramod Kumar and three rectors, met Khare in the morning. “All decisions taken earlier about hostel fee will be implemented in totality. We have already written to UGC with estimated expenditure to release the funds. The deadline for registration will be extended, if need be. Classes will resume on January 13,” Kumar said.

Later, the ministry officials met four members of JNUSU. Ghosh said, “We are happy that the ministry has opened the dialogue. However, our demand for the VC’s resignation stands. We can’t have a dialogue with an incompetent person. We will call a meeting with counsellors and office bearers and take a call on calling off the agitation. We are waiting for the ministry’s decision to take the final call. We have also sought the ministry’s intervention in FIRs and proctorial inquiry initiated against us by the JNU administration.”

In November, the HRD ministry had formed a three-member committee to mediate between the agitating students and the JNU administration to restore normalcy in the campus. According to the formula proposed by the ministry in December, JNU would charge only the increased room rent and the service and utility charges would be borne by IGC. In return, the students would call off their agitation and engage in dialogue with the administration.

To compensate for the lost academic period, JNU was asked to extend the semester by two weeks. The university was also advised to notify the students’ union and withdraw police complaints against students.

Title: New toll gate at Simhachalam temple, FASTag likely
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Simhachalam temple illuminated for Vaikunta Ekadasi earlier this month

VISAKHAPATNAM: The Simhachalam temple will soon get a modern toll gate on the lines of the TTD’s Alipiri toll gate. It will replace the existing toll gate at the Simhachalam temple bus stop. The new system may have the FASTag as well.

With Visakhapatnam set to become executive capital, the temple management expects a traffic rush in the near future.

Preparations for the project have begun with widening of the ghat road from the foothill close to the Anjaneyana Swamy statue near Tholipavancha.

The temple management took the decision to ease traffic flow at the toll gate besides providing advanced security system similar to what the TTD has set up.

The Alipiri toll gate is all set to become the first non-NHAI toll plaza in the country and will promote cashless travel. The radio frequency identification-based FASTag system will involve electronic collection of toll fees instead devotees waiting in long queues.

At present, the Simhachalam temple doesn’t have any vehicle checking systems except collection of toll gate charges.

“But once the new toll gate is opened, there will be all kinds of security features. We are preparing a blueprint for the project,” said a senior temple officer.

According to sources, private contract agencies operate the existing toll gates for an annual fee of Rs 1 crore. The toll for a four-wheeler is Rs 30. Once the new system is enabled, the temple would earn more than Rs 1 crore, said the temple officer.

During special occasions such as Mukkoti Ekadasi and Chandanotsavam, there would be maximum visitors to the temple, apart from on weekends.

Executive officer of the temple, M Venkateswara Rao, said, “Yes, the toll gate project is under way. We will be able to complete it by the Chandotsavam this summer. The entire project has been handed over to donors. The temple is not spending from its funds.”

Meanwhile, this Sankranti, the temple will open a permanent museum of ancient jewellery of Lord Varaha Lakshmi Nrusimha Swamy. The museum will come up in the Ramanuja Kootam building recently built on the temple’s premises.

Title: Eleven teachers in Rudraprayag found to have fake BEd degrees
Content: Dehradun: Eleven teachers in Rudraprayag district have fake BEd degrees, the SIT informed the state government in a letter. All 11 teachers claimed to have received their BEd degrees from Meerut University, but the institute didn’t denied it. The SIT is not ruling out the possibility of an interstate gang that helps people get fake degrees.Manikant Mishra, in-charge of the SIT team that is probing the fake BEd degree scam in Uttarakhand, told TOI that educational records of as many as 11 teachers in Uttarakhand were not found in Meerut’s Chaudhary Charan Singh University.“We received information about degrees of around 23 teachers in the state being fake. An investigation found that 11 of them were literally fake. All of the fake degrees were ‘issued by’ Meerut University,” said Mishra, adding that of the 11 defaulters, two were women and nine men.“We sent around seven to eight reminders to the Chaudhary Charan Singh University to verify the B.ed degrees of these teachers who were in our radar but the varsity didn’t pay any heed. When we contacted the registrar of the university, we were told that they had never received any of our reminders,” said an SIT official, who refused to be named. The official added that the teachers claimed to have completed their BEd from Meerut University between 1994 to 2005, but the university didn’t have their records.Mishra added that the education department had been informed about the matter and the SIT had advised that FIRs be lodged against these teachers by the authorities concerned.SIT believes that an interstate gang is active both in Uttarakhand and Uttar Pradesh and is helping people get fake degrees. Notably, the SIT found around 97 teachers of Uttarakhand to have fake degrees in the last couple of years.

Title: Former MLA Sadanand Tanavade set to become next Goa BJP president
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Sadanand Tanavade

Title: Cop among 3 killed as bikes collide
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Three people, including a police constable, were killed in an accident as two bikes collided on Thirumangalam-Rajapalayam highway in Madurai on Friday.

The police constable Karthikpandi was heading towards T Kallupatti, near Peraiyur in Madurai, on his bike along with his brother Jeyapandi who was riding pillion.

At the Thirumangalam-Rajapalayam highway in Paraipatti, Karthikpandi’s bike collided with another bike with two college students, Kesavan and Ethanaraj from Bodi in Theni.

Karthikpandi, Kesavan and Ethanaraj died on the spot.

Jayapandi who was critically injured is undergoing treatment at Government Rajaji Hospital in Madurai.

Karthikpandi was attached to the Nathampatti police station near Virudhunagar district. Kesavan and Ethanaraj were pursuing Bcom (CA) at a college in Bodi, Theni.

The T Kallupatti police have registered an FIR under sections 279, 337, 304(A) IPC, which deals with rash driving and causing death due to negligence.

Police said that investigation is underway.

Title: YSRC cadres hold pro-capital rallies
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Visakhapatnam: YSRC organised rallies in support of the proposed executive capital in the city on Friday.

TDP president N Chandrababu Naidu had said that there were no demands from the city for the capital, prompting the YSRC leadership to swing into action, sources said.

MLAs and constituencies’ in charges led the rallies and minister for tourism M Srinivas Rao said seven districts, including the north Andhra districts, were backward in all aspects and the capital would boost the region’s growth.

Many organisations in north Andhra have started agitations as intellectuals joined hands for Vizag while others oppose the move, saying the city would lose its peace with it becoming the capital.

Many organisations have started signature campaigns and candle rallies in support of the capital. Congress too demanded the government to announce the capital status to the city immediately.

Assembly speaker Tammineni Seetaram said: “It is a shame that TDP is against the proposal. We would fight for the capital. Naidu provokes people and is organising protests to protect his assets. It is not the people’s movement in Amaravati,” he said.

Title: HC issues notice to director of Tehri dam rehab project
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Nainital: Uttarakhand high court (HC) on Friday issued notice to the director of Tehri Dam Rehabilitation Project after a Public Interest Litigation (PIL) alleged that in a colony built for the families of those affected by the project, the land meant for public utilities such as schools and parks have been sold for plotting.

The PIL, filed by three residents of the colony that has been set up in Haridwar, has also alleged connivance of the authorities in the case and has asked for the court’s intervention.

Speaking to TOI, Sidhharth Sah, the lawyer appearing for the petitioner said that the rehabilitation site named Suman Nagar houses around 500 families and during planning certain areas were earmarked for public utilities such as schools and parks. “However, even those areas in Suman Nagar were sold for plotting. This was in clear violation of the plan and therefore several residents have approached the court,” Sah said.

The bench of Chief Justice Ramesh Ranganathan and Justice Alok Kumar Verma has given the director three weeks’ time to respond to the petition. “The court has sent notices to the director of the rehabilitation project seeking his response to the petition and has now listed the case for February 11,’ Sah said.

Over 9,000 families were either fully or partially affected by the Tehri Dam project. These families have been rehabilitated at several locations across the state by the colonies developed by the government.

Title: In favour of three capitals: Congress
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Andhra Pradesh Congress women’s wing president, P Ramani Kumari

VISAKHAPATNAM: The Visakhapatnam Congress unit welcomed the state government’s proposal to set up the executive capital of the state in Vizag.

Addressing members of the media here on Friday, state Congress women’s wing president, P Ramani Kumari, said three out of seven backward districts in the state were in north-coastal AP.

Ramani Kumari said building a capital at Amaravati would prove to be too expensive and the government can set up an executive capital in Vizag, where infrastructure is available.

The proposal , she added was in keeping with the recommendation of decentralised development by the Sivaramakrishnan committee.

Title: Chennai: It’s time to dig deep, with fiction
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Extensive research often drew new perspectives and alternate stories, author Christopher C Doyle said at IIT M... Read More

CHENNAI: From the time he got his hands on a copy of Mahabharata, author Christopher C Doyle has only wondered why – why there was an epic of this scale with fantastical stories, when a far subtler spiritual text like the Bhagvad Gita was so much more in popular use; why there was a complex play of devas and asuras in the ‘Samudhra Mantan’ (churning of the ocean) when it could have well been an intense play of chemicals that led to the formation of the ‘amrit’ (nectar)?

Talking at IIT Saarang’s ‘Spotlight Lecture’ series on Friday, the fantasy writer explored answers to these questions and several more, backed by his unique style of research that intertwines science, history and archaeology with mythology .

“More than the stories, I have been fascinated with the scholarly articles and literature that connect mythologies of the world with historical studies. There’s a fair amount of evidence to show that almost in every mythology, there’s a tale that could be linked to something that actually happened,” he said.

Pointing out that he is compelled by the idea of renewing the interest of youngsters in their own culture – oral and written – Doyle said extensive research often drew new perspectives and alternate stories that could have been, “and this makes you curious,” he said. This generation has the least exposure to mythology but also a powerful hunger to know more, he said. “And they’re not going to read the Mahabharata to find answers.”

Which is why, in his books, Doyle questions events proliferated by popular mythology through the lens of science and history. “For the churning of the ocean for instance, I studied the Sanskrit meaning behind each sloka that points to a chemical process taking place inside a pot – with water, jewels, herbs and plants. In several instances in fact, you find that the word ‘samudhra’ or ocean, isn’t used at all,” he said.

Doyle pointed out that in countries like Egypt and the UK, existence and careful preservation of pre-historic evidence has made this process easier; the burial chambers in Wales for instance, whose rock structures were polished in a way that they served as parabolic mirrors and therefore astronomically aligned to tell the time of the year.

“In India unfortunately, such archeological evidence isn’t around to corroborate a lot of events. The best we can do is speculate with fiction and that is the way forward – to entertain and educate.”

Title: Jobs for freedom fighters’ kin: Spl committee set up
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Panaji: The state government has constituted a four-member screening committee headed by chief secretary Parimal Rai to vet and recommend children of those who fought for Goa’s liberation and in the independence struggle for various government jobs, home department officials said.

The home department issued the notification announcing the screening committee and has said that the descendants of the freedom fighters would be nominated for government jobs based on seniority and suitability for the posts.

“The officers on the screening committee will sponsor names of the children of freedom fighters from the list maintained by the home department, in precedence of seniority by age, suitable to the various posts under the scheme,” home under-secretary Nilesh Dhaigodkar said in the notification.

While the chief secretary will serve as chairman on the screening committee, the other members are special secretary/additional secretary, home department, additional secretary or joint secretary for personnel and the under secretary for home.

On December 19, while speaking at the state function to mark Goa Liberation Day, CM Pramod Sawant had assured the kin of freedom fighters that the government would provide them jobs, and said there was no need to launch an agitation for the same.

Title: JNU should have a police station: Subramanian Swamy
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Subramanian Swamy

AHMEDABAD: Calling for students’ safety on university campuses, Rajya Sabha MP from the BJP, Subramanian Swamy , said police stations must be set up on university campuses to keep students safe. Swamy spoke to the media after delivering a lecture on ‘Who are we? A quest for national identity’ at Indus University in Ahmedabad.

“Safety means assuring police presence by having police stations inside the campus. Today we have to summon the police; it takes time. Having a police station is important for university campuses in the country. This is not only for JNU, but we should start with JNU,” said Swamy.

Swamy also said that in the US, every university campus has a police station. “For JNU there shouldn’t be Delhi police alone but also a camp of BSF and CRPF.”

During his address, Swamy also took a jibe at JNU and said that the varsity should be de-constituted over time and after necessary ‘cleaning up’, it should be restarted. “JNU can never improve until it is shut down for two years. Uneducated and unqualified people were deliberately given admission there under the Congress rule. The hostel rent is Rs 10 per month and students there are as old as 35-40 years and fail every year. Students in JNU have only one aim – get a place to live in the campus in Delhi and travel across the country and participate in socialist programmes,” said Swamy.

“Majority professors there are socialists. Those who are not socialists have been stopped. After several such instances, the situation cannot be amended. A big step must be taken by closing it down for two years. Good students in JNU should be accommodated in Delhi University and Ambedkar University, among others which are nearby. The remaining must be dismissed and after necessary clean-up, it can be opened again,” he further said.

The Rajya Sabha MP also proposed changing the name of JNU. “If this seems to be tarnishing the image of JNU, the varsity’s name may also be changed and instead it can be renamed and restarted as Subhash Chandra Bose University,” he said.

Title: Odisha: Two government officials made to retire
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

BHUBANESWAR: The state government on Friday forced two sub-ordinate employees to retire from the service on charges inefficiency, lack of integrity and corruption and dismissed four others after they were convicted in vigilance cases.

Two assistant engineers — Narayan Tiadi and Gyanendra Patel — have been given compulsory retirement. Sources said Tiadi was involved in a vigilance case, while Patel was asked to retire as he remained absent from duty for the past several months without any valid reason.

Those dismissed from the service include Sanjay Kumar Chaudhury (ex-stipendiary engineer, Dasarathpur block), Pradeep Kumar Ray (ex-supervisor of Khadi board), Bigyan Kumar Beura (ex-stipendiary engineer, Banki) and Amiya Kumar Sethi (former JE, Nimapara).

Since August 2019, the state government has dismissed 59 officers on charges of corruption, while 12 people have been sent on compulsory retirement. This apart, pensions of 11 retired employees are not being released.

Title: Goa: Two held for snatching gold chains
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

SALIGAO/PANAJI: In separate cases, police arrested two men, natives of Bihar and Delhi, for snatching gold chains.

Mapusa police said Anandi Mayekar, 65, a resident of Revora , lodged a complaint on January 7, against a bike-borne suspect who snatched her gold chain weighing 32g, worth Rs 1.2 lakh. A team investigated the crime and apprehended Wazid Ali, 24, a resident of Mushirwado, Colvale , and native of Bihar.

Ali confessed to the crime, and police recovered the stolen jewellery from him.

Rakesh Sharma, 34, allegedly involved in 14 cases of theft and chain-snatching in Delhi and in Goa, was arrested by the crime branch from a guest house in Mandrem on Friday. During a search of his bag, four broken mangalsutras, three broken gold chains and one locket, together worth around Rs 5 lakh, were found.

On interrogation, Sharma confessed to having committed a series of property offences and thefts in Delhi, said crime branch SP Pankaj Kumar Singh . Further investigations are under way.

Title: Uttarakhand registers 14% rise in violent crimes: NCRB report
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Dehradun: Uttarakhand has registered an increase of over 14% in violent crimes occurred in 2018 compared to the previous year (2017), the latest National Crime Record Bureau (NCRB) report has revealed.

According to the NCRB 2018 report, released on Thursday, 3,137 violent crimes were registered in the Himalayan state, in comparison to 2,740 in 2017. In 2016, 2,330 violent crime incidents took place in Uttarakhand.

Among the Himalayan states, Uttarakhand performed quite poorly in terms of violent crimes, except Assam and Jammu & Kashmir which reported 29,417 and 3,959 violent crime incidents respectively. The neighbouring state of Himachal Pradesh recorded only 1,861 violent crimes against 1,566 in 2017, registering a rise of about 18%.

Out of the total violent crimes committed, kidnapping and abduction accounted for maximum share with 1,177 incidents, followed by rape (561), rioting (549), murder (211) and robbery (180).

In the detailed analysis of murders committed in Uttarakhand, the NCRB report, compiled on the basis of inputs provided by all states and Union Territories, showed ‘disputes’ to be the most common motive for murders with 45 such incidents. ‘Gain’ was cited as motive for 31 murder incidents, followed by family dispute (21) and property dispute (17).

In Uttarakhand, 83 victims of murders were adults (in the age group of 18 years to 30 years), followed by 80 victims in the age group between 30-45 years.

Title: Leopard kills woman in Rudraprayag, fourth case in two months
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Dehradun: A 45-year-old woman was mauled to death by a leopard in Rudraprayag district of Garhwal on Thursday. The woman’s family staged protests and demanded that the animal be captured immediately, after they discovered her body in the forest late in the evening. This the fourth case of death by leopard attack in Pauri in the last two months.

The victim, identified as 45-year-old Kalpeshwari Devi from Dhari Gaon, had gone to the forest to collect fodder. “The woman’s family launched a manhunt when she didn’t return after three hours. They found her slippers at the edge of the forest. When they ventured inside, they found the woman’s body,” said divisional forest officer (DFO) (Narendranagar) Dharam Singh Meena.

The DFO added that compensation had been initiated for the family and the formalities will be completed as soon as the department gets the woman’s post mortem report.

A forest department official, who did not wish to be named, said that the village where the incident took place is close to Papdasu village in Rudraprayag district, where a 55-year-old woman was killed by a leopard on December 6 last year. Since then, the forest department has deployed shooters in the area to tranquilize or kill the leopard. The team of shooters even claimed to have shot at a leopard but a body was never recovered.

The forest department has set up cages in the area to trap the animals and have also advised heads of villages to stay alert. The villagers have been asked to avoid moving about in the forest area alone. Village heads have been asked to take extra precautions when women or children go out alone.

Before the December incident, a 35-year-old woman, Sudha Devi, was killed on November 8. On November 6, a leopard killed one Madan Singh Bisht (50) of Satni village.

Title: ‘Abolish income tax to save economy’
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Ahmedabad: Rajya Sabha MP from Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), Subramanian Swamy, called for abolishing income tax to save the economy. After delivering a public lecture on ‘Who Are We? A Quest for National Identity’, Swamy spoke to the media and said that abolishing income tax is the first step for improving the economy. When asked what measures need to be taken for economic condition, he said, “There are several steps, but the first step is to abolish income tax. It spreads poison in our country. It terrorises...People are always scared as to when the I-T inspector will come and harass them. People genuinely pay taxes but they (tax inspectors) will keep on harassing them. People are depressed with this. People are scared of taking a step forward and to abate these fears, I-T should be abolished.” Talking about the economic scenario, Swamy said that there is a demand shortage. “The problem in our economy is shortage of demand. To abate this, disposable incomes must be there in people’s hand.” “The interest rates should also be rationalized and should not be more than 9%. At the same time, fixed deposits should give 9% returns, instead of the current 6%,” he added. tnn

Title: Delhi: Between Left and Right, police wall keeps peace
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Police said security was tightened to prevent the two groups from interacting with each other

NEW DELHI: Braving the chill in the evening, different factions of JNU students yet again came face-to-face on Friday. However, unlike the violence that erupted on January 5, there was silence amid a heavy police presence.

While women students formed a human chain from Sabarmati T-point to the north gate of the campus holding posters and placards against the “ABVP violence”, members of ABVP and JNU Teachers’ Federation (JNUTF) and alumni conducted a silent march against “Leftist terror”.

Policemen in plainclothes made sure that there was a gap between both the groups. No slogans were raised, and there was only the sound of moving feet.

Wearing black bands over their mouths and holding black clothes — from shawls, dupattas to petticoats — the women students protested against “ABVP’s toxic masculinity.” Former JNU president Geeta Kumari, holding a poster with the poem of Hindi poet Bidrohi, said, “This protest is against ABVP and the violence it unleashed on students and teachers. We will only hold posters and remain silent.”

Calling it a march to restore academic culture in JNU, the Right-wing students, teachers and alumni marched from Sabarmati T-point to the main gate. “Locking down schools is not our idea of JNU. Research work should not be halted for petty political gains,” said an ABVP activist. They gave a call to students to register for the winter semester without any fear.

However, Karamchari Union of JNU, which was advertised to be a part of the march, clarified that they didn’t participate as an organisation. “But we are always in favour of bringing peace in the campus,” the union said.

Police said security was tightened to prevent the two groups from interacting with each other. “We formed two lines, comprising male and female policemen in civvies, who marched in between the two protesting groups. We achieved our objective of maintaining a distance between them,” said DCP (Southwest) Devender Arya.

ABVP has called for a march “against Red terror, in support of CAA” at DU Arts Faculty on Saturday.

Title: Vishwajit against tiger reserve, OK with corridor
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Panaji: Health minister and Valpoi MLA Vishwajit Rane on Friday shot down demands of environmental activists to declare Mhadei Wildlife Sanctuary a tiger reserve. He said such a move would stall development.

The minister, in whose constituency the carcasses of the four tigers were found, said the government could instead declare a tiger corridor to facilitate the movement of the big cats from Karnataka.

“We support a tiger corridor. The government must ensure that a buffer zone is left and a tiger corridor is created. A tiger reserve will impact our development. The laws governing tiger reserves are very strict. Development will get stalled. People will suffer. Those within the sanctuary are already suffering,” he said. “We are keen on protecting tigers but we must also think of the people living in the area.”

Rane was reacting to demands from environmentalists and other citizens for declaration of the Mhadei Wildlife Sanctuary as a tiger reserve in the wake of the death of four tigers in Sattari over four days. He criticised former Lt Governor J F R Jacob for declaring such an expansive area as part of the Mhadei Wildlife Sanctuary. “One must apply their mind. It must be thoroughly investigated,” he said.

“No one has the right to declare a tiger reserve. It is the people’s land. A tiger corridor is necessary,” he said, adding that chief minister Pramod Sawant was competent enough to handle the matter and get to the bottom of the problem that resulted in the death of four tigers, including two cubs, in Golauli.

“The case has to be thoroughly investigated and those responsible should be taken to task,” he said.

Title: Left’s role in violence exposed, says BJP
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: BJP on Friday said Delhi Police probe has ‘unmasked’ the ‘masked Left-wing students’ who were involved in January 5 violence on JNU campus with Union minister Smriti Irani saying that the indictment highlights the inherent desire of the Left to spread a culture of mobocracy.

“Ever since people reposed faith in the Modi government in 2019 and the outright rejection of malicious and divisive campaign by the opposition, many attempt have been made to create an atmosphere of anarchy across the country, threatening India’s vibrant democratic traditions,” Irani said.

“Delhi Police’s ongoing probe into the January 5 violence has made it clear that students affiliated to Left-wing bodies were involved in the incident,” Union minister Prakash Javadekar said. He added that CPI, CPI(M) and AAP have been rejected in the Lok Sabha polls and “they are now using students for their vested interests”.

“Today’s police press conference established that for the past five days, the chorus that was created deliberately to blame ABVP, BJP, and others, wasn’t true. It is the Left organisations that pre-planned violence, disabled CCTV and destroyed server,” he claimed.

Irani said it was evident that a large number of students who wanted to register to pursue their scholastic goals were “prevented from doing so in order to fuel the political fires of the opposition”.

“Parties and ideas rejected by the people have tried to use students of JNU as proxies to create a perception of agitation among India’s youth. This belies the fact that there are over 900 university campuses in India, where students are peacefully pursuing academics,” she said.

HRD minister Ramesh Pokhriyal said he was “distressed” over the involvement of JNU students in the violence as pointed out by the Delhi Police probe. He said the ministry would not tolerate any violence and anarchy on the campus as it was committed to ensuring academic atmosphere in educational institutions.

Referring to the January 5 violence, Irani said, “ What is disturbing is the glossing of the violence perpetrated by these (Left) students, and the glorification of such behaviour as ‘dissent’.”

Without naming any party, the minister said the opposition parties don’t leave any opportunity at creating a false narrative “just before some election in some state or at the national level”. “This time around, it is assembly elections season again and it is no surprise that another bunch of seasonal saviours are being discovered alongside attempts to create a false narrative.”

Title: ‘Personal or financial gain tops murder motives in 2018’
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

BHUBANESWAR: The motive of most murders in the state in 2018 was gain (personal or financial), according to the latest findings of the National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB). Altogether 1,378 persons were murdered in 2018, while at least 832 of them were killed for some benefits or gains, the NCRB report said.

While the report has no mention of the details of such cases, police sources said most of the crimes were executed by the acquaintances of the deceased. In most cases, the motive of the murder was to acquire someone’s wealth, a senior police officer said.

The report said at least 54 persons were murdered for previous enmity (personal vendetta). Dowry was the motive of murders in 119 cases and love affairs in 38 cases.

The NCRB data showed marginal increase in the total number of suicides in the state. While 4,493 persons committed suicide in the state in 2017, the figure went up to 4,592 in 2018. Family problems drove at least 1,460 persons to end their lives in 2018. The report said at least 40 persons committed suicide owing to financial bankruptcy, about 230 for marriage-related issues and 114 owing to failure in examinations.

Title: Natural gas supply project in Haridwar to be completed by Dec 2020, say officials
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Haridwar: A five-year project to supply natural gas for cooking purposes in Haridwar will be completed by December this year, according to officials.

Work on the Rs 200 crore-project to reach around 1,000 households has already started. It was initiated in 2016. Notably, Haridwar is among the four districts of Uttarakhand – others namely, Dehradun , Nainital and Udham Singh Nagar - where work is currently in progress under the Central government project. The Haridwar project covers Laksar and Roorkee towns as well.

The project aims at supplying natural gas through a gas pipeline. It is a joint venture of Bharat Petroleum Corporation Limited (BPCL) and Gail Gas, the latter’s project manager Paranjai Joshi told TOI on Thursday.

Initially, the project faced hurdles in laying down a pipeline due to the city’s river-bed strata with boulders, thereby making digging of pits rather difficult. Another problem arose as BHEL refused to provide gas and it had to be taken from Jwalapur. This involved the pipeline crossing the Ganga canal.

“Overcoming initial hiccups like these, we succeeded in laying 700 inch km line out of total 850 inch km by December 2019. We are confident that the project will be over well before the start of the Kumbh 2021 in Haridwar,” Joshi added.

Though the total households initially included in the project are 17,000, the number is likely to go up. Similarly, the cost of the project will also increase as it is reviewed, he also said.
