As compared to LPG, natural gas has many advantages. It is cheaper and more convenient to use. Being lighter than air, natural gas in case of leakage goes up and dissolves in the atmosphere unlike LPG which sinks.

However, while using it, the same precaution has to be taken as is done in using LPG, because this is potentially dangerous, Joshi explained. The major work in the project has been to lay steel pipes of greater diameter in streets. For lanes, ancillary pipes of lesser diameter are used. Connections to domestic households and small commercial establishments are different from those given to industrial units, Joshi added.

Once the project is completed, registration will begin for consumer connection across Haridwar. For this, registration fee of Rs 300 and refundable security of Rs 5,500 will be charged.

Title: Register police plaints against Milind Naik: Cong
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Vasco: Congress has threatened to protest outside the Mormugao police station if the police fail to register complaints lodged against urban development minister and local MLA Milind Naik by Monday.

GPCC general secretary Sankalp Amonkar said, “Naik is indulging in dictatorship, and the Mormugao police are supporting him. He has been wielding his power and taking revenge against people with the help of police.”

Several days ago, an argument had taken place between Naik and a local, Suraj Chodankar, over obtaining permission to cut down an old tree. A scuffle had ensued during which Naik was allegedly pushed down by Chodankar, and a complaint was filed against the latter.

However, the counter-complaint filed by Chodankar against Naik has not been registered by Mormugao police. Two other complaints were also filed against Naik, which have not been registered.

Amonkar warned of an agitation if the complaints were not registered.

Title: Visakhapatnam schools, colleges mark Sankranti
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: Several schools, colleges and other institutions, such as the Integral Institute of Advanced Management in MVP Colony and the Sri Chaitanya School in Asilmetta, conducted pre-Sankranti celebrations on Friday.

Celebrations at these institutions included traditional bonfires, known as ‘bhogi’, ‘bommala koluvu’, ‘gobbipaatalu’ and ‘bhogi pallu sambaralu’. ‘Haridasu keerthanalu’, Basavanna Narthana and traditional folk dances of Sankranti were presented.

Traditional Telugu snacks were prepared by the students. As a part of celebrations, rangoli competitions were also conducted at various schools.

Title: Ahmedabad: Passports dispatched in 7.5 days on average
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Sonia Yadav

AHMEDABAD: The Regional Passport Office, Ahmedabad, in 2019, was able to dispatch tatkal passports on the day of application itself, while the average time to dispatch a normal passport was 7.5 days.

Passport office staff said the RPO Ahmedabad had in 2019 issued 6.93 lakh passports, which was more than the passports issued in 2018. The officials said that on an average 2,400 passports were printed every day. The Centre has simplified the police verification process, where police now only report criminal antecedents and citizenship of the applicant.

This resulted in 28% drop in the number of adverse police verification reports and the average time taken for police verification improved by a day from the earlier 11 days it took. According to Sonia Yadav, regional passport officer, Ahmedabad, the RPO Ahmedabad had four new Passport Seva Kendras — two at Ahmedabad and one each at Vadodara and Rajkot, where daily 2,500 appointments were given to passport applicants.

The Ahmedabad RPO covers 22 Lok Sabha constituencies, while the remaining four LS constituencies in the state come under the Surat RPO. The officials said that with two Passport Seva Kendras opened at post offices in Chota Udepur and Godhra all the 26 Lok Sabha constituencies were covered.

RPO officials said that in 12 Passport Seva Kendras, including some at post offices, appointments were given within the next day, while in 17 Passport Seva Kendras at post offices, appointments were given within 5 working days. In 2019, in six Passport Adalats, 4,000 files were cleared. Another Passport Adalat is being held this month where 2,000 applicants have been called.

Title: Why is Arvind Kejriwal not taking clear stand: Shashi Tharoor
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Shashi Tharoor

NEW DELHI: Senior Congress functionary Shashi Tharoor on Friday accused Arvind Kejriwal of not taking a “clear stand” on the Citizenship Amendment Act as he felt the CM wanted both supporters and opponents of the new law by his side in the upcoming polls.

At a press conference, Tharoor said: “On what basis should people vote for him (Kejriwal) if he cannot speak on the issue...I don’t know whose orders he is receiving. Who has asked you not to speak about violence against your students, not meet the injured students, and not take a clear stand on CAA? You are the CM and there is nobody to order you (sic).”

Tharoor cited an old tweet of Kejriwal against then chief minister Sheila Dikshit claiming that people would not vote for a “helpless” CM. “He (Kejriwal) tweeted this years ago — we do not want such a helpless CM. Let him read his own tweet now. Do parents want such a helpless CM who, when their children are facing lathis, does not meet them?” Tharoor asked.

AAP did not react to Tharoor’s comments. Sanjay Singh had earlier said that had Kejriwal gone to JNU, BJP would have vitiated the atmosphere there and blamed it on him.

Tharoor also attacked BJP. “Definitely, the intention of BJP before almost every election is to create polarisation. We hope the educated voters of Delhi resist any such move,” he said.

Leader of Opposition in assembly Vijender Gupta said it was Congress and AAP that tried to polarise voters by “misleading” the minorities. “They (Congress) started connecting CAA and NRC and misled people... There is violence in selective areas and universities and a deliberate attempt to target BJP,” he said.

Title: NCRB: Goa fourth on crimes against and by foreigners
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: For a state that promotes tourism , Goa’s crime statistics relating to foreigners is nothing to be proud about. The state ranks fourth in crimes against and by foreigners, according to National Crime Record Bureau ( NCRB ) data.

Goa recorded 34 cases of crime against foreigners in 2018 with Maharashtra topping the list with 63 cases, followed by Uttar Pradesh (62) and Tamil Nadu (51).

Data shows 138 cases of crime committed by foreigners have been registered across the state in 2018. West Bengal recorded 744 cases, followed by Karnataka (175) and Himachal Pradesh (147).

‘Crime in India’, an annual release of the Union home ministry’s NCRB, has collected, collated and published statistics of crimes committed against foreigners and by foreigners in India.

Not a single crime has been committed by foreigners in Jharkhand, Nagaland and Odisha.

A senior police officer said that Goa receives a large number of foreign tourists and that is the reason the number of crimes is reported against them and crime committed by them is high compare to the many other states.

Among those arrested over a period are nationals of Iran, UK, Israel, Kenya, Russia, Ghana, Tanzania, Germany, Nigeria, Sweden, Uganda, Nepal, Georgia, Italy, Czech Republic, Romania, Afghanistan, French, Jordan, Austrian, Turkey, South Africa, South Korea, Uzbekistan, Yemen and Ivory Coast.

While Nigerians are mostly involved in narcotic cases, Romanians are involved in ATM frauds and Tanzanians are primarily booked for overstaying and not having valid travel documents, police said. Russians too were found to be involved in drug cases.

Cases in which foreigners have been booked or arrested include attempt to murder, rape, rioting, assault on public servant, cheating, under Foreigners Act, immoral trafficking, possession and peddling of narcotics and theft among other violations.

NCRB said that 55 cases of human trafficking have been reported in the state. The purpose of human trafficking in Goa is for sexual exploitation or prostitution. In 2018, Goa police filed 69 chargesheets in human trafficking cases.

Title: Ninder stir called off after government vows to address demand
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Congress leader Mahesh Joshi with farmers at Ninder village

JAIPUR: Farmers protesting in Nindar village since the last four days called off their stir on Friday after getting an assurance from the government to resolve their problems.

They had buried themselves neck deep in the ground in protest against acquisition of their land for a housing scheme by the Jaipur Development Authority (JDA).

The Congress' chief whip in Rajasthan Assembly, Mahesh Joshi, met the farmers on Friday afternoon and assured them that the government would soon find a solution. He told reporters that a committee would be formed to hold talks with the protesters.

By evening, JDA commissioner T. Ravikanth formed a committee consisting of nine members including members of the district administration. The committee will organise a meeting with the farmers on January 13 at JDA meeting hall.

The protest was named as Ninder ‘Zameen Samadhi Satyagrah’ under the leadership of Narendra Singh Shekhawat. They have been demanding that their land should be acquired as per the revised Land Acquisition Act and compensation must be given.

The farmers said they called off the protest after the government assured them that the matters would be resolved through talks.

Title: Foresters draw flak for not demarcating sanctuary area
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Forest officials have called the deaths a case of ‘revenge killing’, after a cow and a buffalo of the forest d... Read More

KERI: The two-member central government committee that has been appointed to probe the successive deaths of four tigers in Goa, has reprimanded the state’s forest officials for not having demarcated the Mhadei Wildlife Sanctuary area where the deaths are suspected to have taken place due to man-animal conflict.

The committee, comprising Rajendra Garawad and Ayya Mallya, arrived in the state on Friday and visited the Golauli forest in Sattari — which is part of the wildlife sanctuary and where the carcasses were found — to carry out investigations. Both members told state forest officials that as the Mhadei Wildlife Sanctuary was declared in 1999, steps to demarcate its boundaries should be taken immediately.

Garawad and Mallya, who were accompanied by state deputy conservator of forests (wildlife division) Vikas Desai, will be in Goa for four days and will submit their findings in the death of the four tigers to the Union environment ministry.

Meanwhile, Goa forest officials took a fourth accused, Jyotiba Pavane, in their custody for the tiger killings. Interrogation of all four suspects is on, they said.

Forest department officials have called the deaths a case of ‘revenge killing’, after a cow and a buffalo of the forest dwellers were preyed on by the tigers. They said that the villagers, enraged due to loss of livelihood, poisoned a buffalo kill. When the tigers returned to feed on the buffalo, it led to their deaths.

Two of the earlier accused, Vithu Pavane and Malo Pavane, told forest officials that the tigers were killed due to poisoning of the buffalo and have confessed to burying two of the big cats. The accused have, however, not yet disclosed who was responsible for the poisoning, forest officials said.

On Friday, all four accused were produced before the Valpoi JMFC and remanded in seven days custody. Nandkumar Parab and other officials of forest department are investigating the case.

Title: Gujarat assembly: Pro-CAA resolution passed
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Gujarat CM Vijay Rupani

GANDHINAGAR: The Gujarat assembly on Friday passed a resolution supporting the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) with a majority, even as there was an uproar in the assembly after a Congress MLA opposed the act with a banner written with his own blood.

Pradipsinh Jadeja, minister of state, home, law and legislative affairs, moved the resolution to support the CAA. Jadeja’s resolution was supported by CM Vijay Rupani and all BJP MLAs, while the leader of opposition Paresh Dhanani and all Congress MLAs opposed the resolution.

Repeating what CM Vijay Rupani has said earlier, Jadeja said, “There are 150 countries for Muslims, but India is the only country for Hindus. The CAA is for protecting the rights of Hindus, Sikhs, Christians, Jains and Buddhists in the three neighbouring Islamic countries of Pakistan , Bangladesh and Afghanistan .” He also alleged that the Congress is spreading misconceptions about the legislation.

Paresh Dhanani, leader of opposition in the state assembly, said, “The CAA along with the NRC, have created panic among poor Indian Muslims and even among those from scheduled castes and tribes, as many from these communities still do not have any identity papers. The BJP is trying to divert the public’s attention from unemployment, rising prices and other serious issues.”

Meanwhile, Rupani, reacting to independent MLA Jignesh Mevani ’s allegations about the CM’s Burmese origins, said that his father and mother had Indian passports and he was born in India and has an Indian passport.

Title: Dalit body slams fund diversion for Amma Vodi
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: Dalita Hakkula Porata Smithi (DHPS) slammed the state government for using funds of corporations for financing Amma Vodi during a table conference held here on Friday.

J V Prabhakar, president, DHPS, said the government had diverted Rs 6,108 crore out of Rs 6,456 crore grant for various corporations.

He said it was unfortunate the government which should protect the weaker sections was diverting funds for their upliftment. “Lack of funds is not an excuse to divert funds from corporations which are supposed to finance scholarship, self-employment and related activities for the benefit of the financially and socially weaker sections of society,” Prabhakar said.

Prabahakar said the government was delaying payment of scholarships, mess bills and other welfare schemes along with salaries for those employed on contract, while on the other hand it was diverting funds.

He said the government must try to raise funds from other sources. Members of Aikya Vedika urged all communities to condemn the diversion of corporation funds.

Members of caste organisations attended the conference .

Title: Lead actor of Marathi movie held, aides booked for fraud
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Nagpur: The lead actor of Marathi film ‘Prem Rang’ Bunty Mendke, co-actor Rupesh Bhaisware along with producers of the film Ashish Majan and Prashant Kale have been booked by Ganeshpeth police in a case of alleged cheating of two job-aspiring brothers from Gondia to the tune of Rs 18.55 lakh. Another person, identified as Saurabh, too has been made a co-accused in the case.

Ganeshpeth police squad, under PI SS Kumare, arrested Mendke and Bhaisware on January 7. The two have been remanded to custody till January 13.

Police said Majan, who also has offences registered against him at Dhantoli and Ajni police stations, is the mastermind of the racket that has duped not only the job aspirants on the pretext of giving them employment as clerks at Auditor General (AG) office but many others including loan seekers and also a couple who had financed their film.

Ganeshpeth police, which busted the gang, also received complaints from two more persons including one from whom the gang had taken Rs 6 lakh to finance their films promising to return Rs 10 lakh after the release but did not fulfill their promise.

In the latest case, Majan and others had taken substantial amount promising Anil Nagpure and his brother Sunil jobs at AG office in 2017. The money was taken from father of the brothers who is complainant in the case. He stated Majan had conducted fake selection examination and interview of Anil Nagpure and his brother Sunil at Income tax office in Mumbai. They had also pasted a fake list of the successful candidates outside the office of the Income Tax in which the names of the Nagpure brothers were mentioned.

The racketeers later issued appointment letters to Anil and Sunil on different dates mentioning their posting as clerks at AG office. Police said Majan and his gang were deferring the date of joining for more than one year which created doubt regarding their motive as Anil and Sunil had started pressuring them. The Nagpures were also abused and threatened by the gang that had pretended to return their money through cheques that bounced.

The Nagpures had tried to approach crime branch which ignored their complaint. So they wrote to the city police chief BK Upadhyay following which an offence was registered at Ganeshpeth police station where a squad comprising constable Nitin Mishra, Virendra Karade, Nishikant Meshram, Sachin Aswar and others was formed to probe the case.

It is learnt Majan and accomplices had opened an office at Dhantoli around a year ago. They had met Nagpure brothers, whose family members had arranged the cash after selling properties, near Ganeshpeth bus stop.

Title: Fringe group puts up anti-protest posters outside JNU campus
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Every poster has been signed by one Surjeet Yadav, who claims to be a Hindu Sena member

NEW DELHI: Delhi Police will probe into some posters put up on lampposts outside the JNU campus on Thursday night allegedly by a fringe Hindu group seeking “azadi” from the Left. Every poster has been signed by one Surjeet Yadav, who claims to be a Hindu Sena member.

The probe will find out how the posters appeared on Baba Gangnath Marg ahead of the barricades despite the round-the-clock presence of a police team on the road, a source said.

Claiming responsibility for the act, Vishnu Gupta, president of Hindu Sena, said the posters were put up for public information. “Many students sympathise with Naxalites and anti-national activities. So in the name of protests over fee hikes, they are obstructing education of other fellow students,” he alleged. The slogans include “Hume Chahiye Azadi”, often used by JNU protesters, and “Desh ke Dushmano se Azadi, Maoists, Terrorists se Azadi”. Police may call Yadav for questioning.

JNU students said the banners had further “vitiated the atmosphere”. Another fringe group, Hindu Raksha Dal, had already claimed responsibility for the January 5 attack on students on the JNU campus.

Title: BITS Goa professor's work shows anti-malarial drug’s potential in treating lung cancer
Content:
Angshuman Sarkar

PANAJI: Four years after receiving a grant from the Centre’s department of biotechnology to work on repurposing an anti-malarial drug for the possible treatment of lung cancer, Angshuman Sarkar, an assistant professor at BITS Pilani KK Birla Goa campus, has successfully demonstrated how it kills lung cancer cells in humans.Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), which accounts for 80% of all lung cancer cases diagnosed, is notoriously tough to treat because of its resistance to drugs. Once the drug based on Sarkar's research is made available in the market, it is set to achieve two remarkable objectives—make treatment significantly more affordable and increase the lifespan of patients.The repurposed drug is based on Quinacrine (QC), a well-known anti-malarial medication.“Two of the major challenges for the treatment of lung cancer are chemo resistance and metastasis (spreading of cancer in other parts of body). NSCLC amongst all other types are much more prone to acquire resistance despite the variety and combination of drugs being used,” said Sarkar, who works at the institute’s department of biological sciences, and received his post-doctoral training at the Cleveland Clinic’s cancer biology department.“Almost all patients who receive treatment acquire resistance after cycles of treatment given to them,” said Sarkar, whose research has also been accepted for publication in ‘Oncotarget’, one of the world’s top oncology journals.NSCLC is sub-categorised into carcinoma, adenocarcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma. Adenocarcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma account for most lung cancer cases diagnosed in India.Sarkar said scientists have begun to repurpose old and clinical drugs used for other treatment towards cancer cure due to the extremely high cost of even a single cycle of innovative therapies.“Worldwide, a lot of emphasis has been placed on discovering bioactive compounds which have potential effects on cancer progression, metastatic spread as well as overcoming the chemo resistant adaptation by cancer cells,” Sarkar told TOI.“Quinacrine is one such synthetic bioactive compound, popularly known as anti-malarial drug. There have been few reports of uncovering the anti-cancerous potential of this molecule (QC) on different types of cancer.”A detailed scientific work was carried out by Sarkar and his co-workers at his department at BITS Pilani, Goa Campus, in collaboration with IBAB, Bengaluru. Through their work, QC’s effects on human lung cancer cells have been established for the first time.“At present, soon after a patient is detected with NSCLC, within a year or two, the person dies, and chemotherapy does not work. We believe that our finding will help the scientific community formulate better drug conjugates and combinations with this molecule, which may curb the progression and lethality of this demonic disease affecting millions of lives every year,” said Sarkar.“As biomedical researchers and a part of scientific community, it is our first and foremost responsibility to find medications that can effectively cure diseases and can be affordable for every human being to utilize its benefits,” he said.

Title: Visakhapatnam: First-time voters share wish list ahead of polls
Content:
Representative image

The millennial voters, who would be voting in a civic election for the first time, are taking their democratic rights seriously and focusing on issues that would be the determining factors in the polls

VISAKHAPATNAM: As officials gear up to conduct civic polls in the city after a gap of seven years, the millennial voters, who would be voting in a civic election for the first time, are taking their democratic rights seriously and focusing on issues that would be the determining factors in the polls.“I want a neat, clean and pollution-free environment. Often I have seen garbage pile up in my neighbourhood. I want the civic body to focus on state-of-the art waste disposal management and keep my locality neat and clean,” 22-year-old M Pushpa, who stays in Madhurawada area of the city, says.Pushpa, who got her name registered in the electoral rolls just before the 2019 general elections, cast her vote for the first time on April 11 last year, when simultaneous polls were held for the Lok Sabha and AP assembly. Of the around 10 lakh new voters added to the electoral rolls in AP in 2019, close to 5,000 are from the city and would cast their vote in a civic election for the first time.Pushpa’s neighbour, 21-year-old K Ravi Prasad, wants the GVMC to create more sporting infrastructure in the city and save the remaining few sports grounds. He claimed that over the last few years around three grounds were turned into residential localities.“There is hardly any ground left in my locality where we can enjoy a game of cricket or football. Around 5-6 years back we used to have at least four grounds in our locality where we used to play tennis ball cricket. Today, only two grounds are left and you would see multiple matches taking place at the same time. I don’t want these two remaining grounds to vanish too. The civic body should ensure there’s at least one ground in every locality,” added Prasad.Most youths in the city also want GVMC to build dedicated hangout zones with parking lots where they can spend their evenings with friends. “If Visakhapatnam becomes the executive capital there are apprehensions that the city would become congested. The civic body must ensure that there are enough open spaces and parks in the city. And importantly, it must ensure there are proper parking lots at those places,” suggests K Ramesh, a 22-year-old student who is pursuing his MBA.The youngsters are also concerned about the environment. They want the city to remain free from pollution, as it is now, after it becomes the capital. “If Vizag becomes the executive capital, the civic body has a huge responsibility to keep pollution levels under check. The civic bosses must ensure that development does not come at the cost of polluting the environment. My city should remain as beautiful as it is today,” demanded 24-year-old C Suresh Raju, an engineering student.

Title: Delhi: Teachers labelled as ‘traitors of JNU’ in posters
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Mazhar Asif

NEW DELHI: A section of Jawaharlal Nehru University students has accused a few teachers of being a part of the recent violent attacks on the students on campus. The students have also put up posters near the hostels and in front of the central library with their names and pictures, alleging that they are “traitors of JNU” and “architects of violence.”

Students had earlier raised objections to the appointment of associate dean, School of Language, Mazhar Asif as a member of an investigation committee set up by the vice-chancellor, alleging that “he was one of the attackers.” The JNU administration had formed the committee on January 7 to inquire into the incidents of violence on January 5.

Students also alleged that Asif was a former member of the ABVP and led an attack on students on January 4. Several posters questioned his presence in the inquiry committee.

Asif, however, refuted the allegations and said that the charges were “baseless.” He added: “I vehemently condemn these. They are all my students and if anyone is attacked I am deeply hurt about that. We don’t discriminate among our students.”

The associate dean stated that the inquiry committee will soon come out with its report on the violence.

JNUSU vice-president Saket Moon alleged that the “committee was biased as Asif was one of the teachers who led the charge against the students on January 4.” Satish Chandra Yadav, JNUSU general secretary, claimed that “Asif was also present when there was violence near the School of Biotechnology.”

Four others, whose pictures were pasted together in different posters on campus, include Tapan Bihari of Centre for Political Studies (CPS); Prakash Chandra Sahoo, warden of Sabarmati Hostel; Abhinav Prakash, assistant professor in Delhi University; and Dhananjay Singh, JNU chief proctor.

Responding to the posters, chief proctor Dhananjay Mahapatra said that he will “file a complaint as it is a design to malign the chief proctor. We are going to take this very seriously. Since I have been a student of this university and teacher for more than 12 years, I have built up a reputation and I am yet to recover from this dismay, ever since I have seen it.”

Tapan Bihari refused to comment on the posters, stating that the registrar’s office will respond on this. Abhinav Prakash stated: “I don’t know why I have been named in the poster. It could be because I have been a critic of the left. There used to be a more mature left in the campus when I was there. Now, there is anarchy.”

Title: Bengaluru: 6 hours after bike crash, man wakes up to see friend dead near him
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: Six hours after a speeding motorcycle hit a stone on Nelamangala-Sondekoppa Road on Wednesday midnight, the pillion rider regained consciousness only to find his rider-friend lying dead next to him.

Nelamangala Rural police said Chandrashekar N, 24, of Seegehalli, regained consciousness after a passerby woke him up. Before things could dawn on Chandrashekar, he saw his friend, Punitha KC, 23, a resident of Seegehalli, off Magadi Road and from Kadarahalli near Hassan, lying dead in a pool of blood next to him.

Punitha and Chandrashekar worked in a private factory in Nelamangala and shared an accommodation in Seegehalli with another colleague, Siddanna.

Police said, “Punitha and Chandrashekar went from their workplace to Kunigal Cross to drop Siddanna so that he could to catch a bus to Hassan at 11pm. Later, the duo was riding back home when Punitha lost control of the bike and hit a stone near Mantanakurchi village gate. Both were thrown on to the road. As Nelamangala-Sondekoppa Road sees very poor traffic at night, the accident was not noticed by anyone.”

Chandrashekar told police that he felt numb with pain and fell unconsciousness soon after the accident. “But before that I could realise that Puneetha too had sustained severe injuries. I gained consciousness only around 6.30am when a passerby woke me up. I had sustained injuries on my right shoulder, right leg and near the right eye. I found Punitha dead next to the bike,” he stated in the complaint.

Chandrashekar has been admitted to a private hospital. Nelamangala Rural police handed over Punitha’s body to his kin on Thursday after autopsy at a government hospital.

Title: Was certain Rohit behind act, says Shweta Tiwari’s family
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Family members of Shweta

JAIPUR: We were certain that Rohit got my sister killed, said Shweta Tiwari ’s brother after cops arrested her husband for the murders.

Her family told TOI that she had suspected him of having an affair but they asked her not to doubt him to that extent. Although the cops found no evidence of an extramarital affair, the arrested husband did admit that he wanted to remarry.

Shweta’s brother Shubham Mishra, while speaking to TOI, said, “We never had any doubt that he killed my sister and nephew as he had been physically violent with her on many occasions. He had also threatened to kill her just two days before the murder .”

The family also claimed that despite fulfilling Rohit’s demands of dowry at the time when the couple got married, the demand kept increasing and Mishra added, “Even before Shweta and Rohit got married, his family created an issue over the wedding venue as they wanted us to organise it in Delhi in a lavish manner. After the marriage also Rohit kept asking my sister for the money from the fixed deposits made by my father.”

Regretting not taking his sister’s claims of Rohit having an affair, Mishra said that they had not realised that it could be actually true. Rohit had been a relationship in 2007 before he got married to Shweta and police officials said that although he did say that he wanted to start a new life with someone else, they are uncertain if it was with the same woman who he had been dating previously.

Her family also created a Facebook page called ‘Justice for Shreyam and Shweta’ in which they have asked for capital punishment for the accused.

Title: YSRC keen to wrest control of civic body from TDP
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Visakhapatnam: With the dates for the civic polls likely to be announced soon, the ruling YSRC has focused its attention on winning the GVMC elections. The port city is considered a TDP stronghold, and a win in the civic polls here would give a big boost to the ruling party which has been waiting for long to grab power in GVMC.

Though there are not many strong local leaders in the party, the YSRC is banking on the various welfare schemes of the government and the charisma of chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy to clinch things in its favour. The city, with a population of 19 lakh, is spread over 650 square kilometres. It became Greater Vizag in 2005 after the merger of Gajuwaka municipality and 32 peripheral areas.

Anakapalli and Bheemili municipalities were merged into Greater Visakha five years ago. Five panchayats on the outskirts of the city — Kapuluppada, Anandapuram, Nidigattu, Chepaluppada and JV Agraharam — too were merged with GVMC a few days back.

Vizag MP M V V Satyanarayana exuded confidence that the party will win the civic polls due to the good work of the government. “Not just Vizag, people across the state are in favour of YSRC. The chief minister thinks about the welfare of all sections of the society in his mind,” he told TOI.

According to YSRC sources, Jagan himself is keen to win the Vizag municipal elections area.

Title: Now, dealers have to offer discounts on cars: Godinho
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Porvorim: Transport minister Mauvin Godinho on Friday ruled out any extension of the 50% road tax cut on four-wheelers and two-wheelers and said that it was for automobile dealers to now announce discounts and incentives to clear their inventory ahead of the BSVI rollout.

The minister told reporters that if the state government had not announced the road tax cut, several automobile dealers would have had to shut down due to losses and huge inventory.

“If you see, the GST collections did not go down. The road tax would not have been even half of what we collected in that period,” Godinho said.

The minister said cut in road tax had also helped push sales of vehicles which had otherwise slumped due to the decline in the country’s economic situation.

“Dealers would have had to close down like it happened in Maharashtra and other places,” Godinho said.

Members of the Goa Automobile Dealers Association (GADA) met chief minister Pramod Sawant and Godinho with a request for the 50% cut in road tax to be extended up to March 31.

Title: Rohit Tiwari murder case: Neighbour’s CCTV clip nails killers of mother & son
Content:
A file photograph of people gathering outside Rohit Tiwari’s house in the city

JAIPUR: The CCTV camera footage of Rohit Tiwari ’s neighbour helped police crack the sensational twin murder case. After tracing the owner and seeking permission, cops broke into the neighbour’s house which was lying vacant for nearly a year. They found the footage which clearly showed the hired killer taking the dead baby out of the apartment.An official who was part of the investigation, on condition of anonymity told TOI, “We saw that the flat next to Rohit’s had a CCTV camera but the apartment was vacant for last one year. We got in touch with the owner and told him that we needed access to the footage. After he gave permission, we broke into the house. The footage gave us the strongest evidence.It showed that when Saurabh entered Rohit’s flat, his face was semi-covered but when he was leaving it with the baby’s body, the hired killer’s face was clearly visible.”According to the original murder plan, Chaudhary was supposed to bury the child’s body in some secluded location where it could never be found but in a moment of panic, he dumped it over the boundary wall of the residential complex. He was planned on coming back later to dispose of the body but by that time heavy police presence was already in the area, claimed cops.The case was a challenge to solve as there were no leads and the prime suspect, Rohit Tiwari was well prepared for interrogation as he had predicted his own arrest. ‘Cool and composed’, Tiwari was a tough nut to crack in the murder investigation, who neither shed a tear or even asked to go for his wife and son’s funeral, said cops.“In the three days since the murder of his wife and son, Rohit has not shed a single tear. We would have allowed him to go for their funeral also but he never sought permission. During the interrogation also he was absolutely composed”, said the official.Police officials said that Rohit, who is a chemical engineer, was highly intelligent and even expected that he will be arrested after his wife’s body was found.Jaipur commissioner of police Anand Shrivastav added that he had planned the crime to such an extent that he expected to be arrested and had prepared the answers accordingly.Police officials lamented that the accused chose this path instead of legal separation with his wife to avoid giving alimony and also he wanted to get rid of her at the earliest.

Title: Delhi: Shaheen Bagh juniors draw attention to CAA
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

The children have made new friends and found new hobbies over the last few weeks

NEW DELHI: Australia’s raging wildfires , actor Deepika Padukone’s portraits , Spiderman and Disney’s princesses: these were the subjects of painting for the many children of Shaheen Bagh on Thursday. The kids, aged between 5 and 15, have been accompanying their mothers as they sit under a canopy on Kalindi Kunj road in south-east Delhi to protest against the new citizenship law.

The nearly half-a-kilometre stretch they occupy is blockaded by police at both ends, but the yellow barricades also bear signs of their protests. “No to NRC, no to CAA” have been spray-painted across the barricades in bold letters. Bedsheets have been painted with images of resistance and words from the Preamble and the tricolor are hoisted at several places.

The women’s fight against CAA started on December 16, a day after Jamia Milia Islamia students were attacked by Delhi police. They came out of their homes, shaken by the images of violence, determined that they would sit on a “dharna” until CAA was repealed. But the women did not occupy the road alone. Along with them came their children — infants, toddlers, pre-adolescents and teens.

In the initial days, the children sat with the mothers, unsure of the “civil disobedience movement” that had brought the neighbourhood to national limelight. But as days passed, the toddlers began to venture further away from their mothers’ laps, and the teens began to ask questions about what the law meant.

When TOI visited the neighbourhood, many children sat in a group, independent of their mothers. Most of them had the tricolor painted on both their cheeks, and they listened intently to the speakers on stage. They carried posters against CAA and lent their voices to Inquilab slogans. Some even took charge of the mike and chanted “Hum kagaz nahin dikhayenge”.

The children have made new friends and found new hobbies over the last few weeks, especially after Usama, a young Jamia research scholar set up a makeshift library opposite the protest site. Today, he is both a companion and teacher to these kids.

“I came here a week ago with a hundred books. But within two days, we expanded our collection because more people donated their books. The volunteers here also crowdsourced stationery and A4 drawing sheets for children,” Usama told TOI.

Siblings Alina, 9, and Aliza, 6, have been visiting the library daily. So has Deepika. The three have become best friends now. The library volunteers encourage them to draw and give them a theme every day. The best paintings are then displayed in the “open exhibition” space, said another volunteer Younus, who also conducts art workshops for the children. Younus is a graduate student in Jamia’s fine arts department.

The paintings on display depict the students’ limitless imagination. There were paintings depicting the Australian wildfires with the message, Shaheen Bagh prays for Australia. It was drawn by Class IV student Ishtiyaq Nabi. There also are paintings thanking Deepika Padukone for her solidarity with JNU and slogans against CAA. But most common are self-portraits of students holding the national flag.

Surekha, one of the volunteers who donated the art material and books to the library, said: “The idea was to give the children and other protesters breathing space. This space gives them a chance to pause, read and think.”

The students get their ideas from storytelling sessions held at the library. On Wednesday, artiste Himanshu Bajpai, who made a cameo appearance in Sacred Games 2, held a session for them. But the children have other sources of inspiration too. As Hasan, a nine-year-old said, they draw their tales from the grandmothers who sit on the stage at the dharna. The two women — 82-year-old Bilkis Begum and 80-year-old Noor-un-Nisa — are an endless source of stories for the children. The women, who have lived through the Freedom Struggle, instill ideas of “secularism and unity” in them.

“This is another fight for freedom. We cannot be mere witnesses while the country’s Constitution is under attack. We are here to defend the idea of this nation. Why should we prove that we our grandfathers were born here?” asked Bilkis.

Another face of the resistance is 50-year-old Mehrun Nisa, who is on a hunger strike for nine days. A resident of Wazirabad, she quit her job at Jama Masjid canteen and came to Shaheen Bagh. The women say their fight is for all the children of this country. “The children are fighting for India, and we are fighting for them. There would be no future without them,” said Mehrun.

Title: Eight-year-old boy crushed under his school bus
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Yash Mishra (8), a STD III student, was killed after coming under the left rear wheels of his school bus at Daulat Patel Chowk in Bajeriya on Friday. He had alighted from the vehicle near his residence at Telipura.

The bus did not have a conductor, which is a violation of the directives issued by the Nagpur bench of Bombay High Court following a similar incident in 2012.

Yash, the only son of his parents Mewalal and Shraddha, was a student of Orange City High School at Gaddigodam. Sources said that Yash and another student got down from the bus which has a folding gate. Yash attempted to cross the road moving in front of the bus which mowed him down.

The driver of the bus, Praful Mathure, now in custody of Ganeshpeth police, failed to spot Yash.

Onlookers rushed a seriously injured Yash to Mayo Hospital where he died during treatment. Ganeshpeth police took Mathure into custody from the hospital and also have also seized the bus.

Sources said that Mathure’s wife used to be the conductor but had discontinued a few days ago to take care of their 3-year-old daughter. Yash used to go to school in an auto and return by the bus. The vehicle picked up students from other schools too.

Mewalal said he would pay Rs700 per month for the bus service. “My son returned safely every day. I did not expect this to happen,” said Mewalal who works at a railway station eatery. Shraddha was at home with her daughter Pihu when the incident took place.

Social worker Nutan Rewatkar said the management of the school must be booked in the case.

The school principal Sharda Naidu tried to distance her institution and it’s management from ownership of the bus. But the police have kept the option open to book them in the incident for negligence as per the Motor Vehicles Act, 1989 and Rules 2011.

Naidu said they have nothing to do with the operation and management of the bus. “The bus was being operated by the driver and he had given us in writing that the sole responsibility of the safety and security of the children was his,” she said. “We just gave him permission to use our school’s name on the vehicle,” said another school staffer.

A senior police official said the driver had the names of students from Orange City High School who would use the bus service.

Senior PI SS Kumare of Ganeshpeth police station said the school management’s neglect in ensuring safety of the students is being scrutinized. “The RTO would be also summoned to examine the vehicle,” he said.

Police have invoked section 304 of Indian Penal Code (IPC) for culpable homicide not amounting to murder.

The incident was reminiscent of the incident in 2012 when nine-year-old Virat Zade died after being crushed under the wheels of his school bus after alighting.

The Nagpur bench of Bombay HC had taken suo motu cognisance of the matter reported in the media. It passed strict directives to follow the Maharashtra Motor Vehicles (Regulations for School Buses), Rules 2011, irrespective of whether the schools own their buses or run contracted services.

Even the state education department had issued circulars to all the schools to ensure the buses were operated with conductors and had CCTV cameras.

Title: Tadoba’s Kolsa relocation to come at cost of 30k trees, 15k bamboo clusters
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

The villagers have identified this road-touch forest land

Nagpur: This is a classic case of ‘robbing Peter to pay back Paul’.

The Tadoba-Andhari Tiger Reserve (TATR) plans to relocate Kolsa village inside the reserve to Chichpalli range in the tiger corridor between Tadoba-Kanhalgaon-Kawal.

But it is an irony of conservation that to create inviolate space for tigers, the relocation will come at the cost of 30,000 teak and other tree species and over 15,000 bamboo clusters running into over 25 crore.

Compartment number 522 is spread over 380 hectares of which TATR plans to settle over 100 families in 280 hectares. The reserve forest is in possession of Forest Development Corporation of Maharashtra (FDCM), which is into commercial extraction of timber.

Kolsa villagers have identified this road-touch forest land which has presence of tigers and other wild animals. The dense forest, 3.5km from Mul city, also connects buffer zone of Kolsa range of TATR.

At a time when dense forest cover in the state has gone down by 95 sq km as per the latest FSI-2019 report, there is simmering anger among greens against such a move.

“Wildlife officials may argue that FDCM is into commercial extraction of timber and hence, tree felling should not be an issue. But the high-quality forest is home to many wild animals and is a functional corridor. We will oppose it tooth and nail,” said Green Planet Society chief Suresh Chopne.

TATR field director NR Praveen said the land has been identified by the villagers and accordingly, FDCM has been asked to enumerate trees and assets on the said land. “However, the proposal is in its initial stage and has not been sent to MoEFCC for approval,” he added.

In 2007, 128 families including all 79 from Botezari and 49 of 146 from Kolsa were relocated at Bhagwanpur in Mul as per the Rs1 lakh package then. Of the remaining 97 families from Kolsa, 16 voluntarily accepted Option-I (golden handshake policy by taking Rs10 lakh) and nine were relocated at Bhagwanpur in 2013.

The remaining families were reluctant to move out and now want dense forest land in Chichpalli range. During the last 5 years, the families have almost doubled but TATR officials said only those will benefit who were in the final list of the cut-off date in 2014.

As per the relocation package announced by NTCA, each member above 18 years and widows too are termed as one family and are entitled to get a package of Rs10 lakh.

FDCM divisional manager Vivek More, West Chanda, confirmed that TATR has demanded the said land and sought report on the number of trees, bamboo clusters and other assets on forest land.

“We are at work and in 8 days, a report will be submitted after doing valuation. Being close to TATR, the area has rich wildlife,” More added.

Bandu Dhotre, also a member of the committee on relocation of TATR villages, opposed the move. “I feel the relocation package needs to be enhanced. There should be a condition that unless PAPs procure alternative farm land, the money should not be released,” he said.

After large-scale felling of forest areas to relocate villages like Botezari, Palsagaon, Jamni and Navegaon from TATR, it was decided not to resettle people on forest land and encourage them to go for Option-1.

As reported by TOI on December 13, 2012, to relocate two Tadoba villages — Jamni and Navegaon (Ramdegi) at Khadsangi — the forest department felled 1.4 lakh trees.

“We can’t afford to lose forests anymore, especially in the backdrop of increasing tiger population in the state and flared up man-animal conflict in Chandrapur district. I fully agree that relocation is a must but it should be voluntarily with Option-I package or on scrub forests or zudpi lands,” said Chopne.

“The decision of Kolsa villagers is not binding. Earlier, relocation of Rantalodi in Tadoba was delayed as we were against giving them land in corridor patches of Belghata and Bholabuj in Sindewahi,” said Dhotre.

“On one hand, road widening is opposed as user agencies are not taking mitigation steps in corridor patches, while on the other, the forest department intends to destroy tiger habitats by razing huge canopy to relocate Kolsa villagers. This is unacceptable. Earlier, the decision to relocate Fulzari (Pench) was rejected by MoEFCC as the proposed site was dense forest,” said conservationist Prafulla Bhamburkar.

Title: Rajasthan HC notices to Aseemanand and 8 others for Ajmer blast
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

File picture of Aseemanand

JAIPUR: A division bench of Rajasthan High court on Friday issued notices to Swami Aseemanand and six others who were acquitted by the NIA court in March, 2017.

Notices were also sent to the two convicts — Bhavesh Patel and Devendra Gupta — who were sentenced to life in the case.

The bench comprising Justice Sangeet Raj Lodha and Justice Mahendra Goyal gave this interim direction while hearing the leave to appeal filed by Syed Sarwar Chishty, who is also a complainant in the Ajmer Dargah blast case.

The court dealing with NIA cases had sentenced Patel and Gupta to life and acquitted seven accused including Aseemanand on March 22, 2017.

Chisthy moved an application challenging the acquittal and the verdict given by the NIA court.

Advocate Rambabu Sharma said, “In the appeal, we have stated that the punishment given to the accused in the case is less and the other accused have been wrongly acquitted. We have also prayed that all the accused should be convicted and given capital punishment.”

It is noteworthy that the two accused including Patel and Gupta were sentenced to life imprisonment in this case. However, their sentence was suspended by the high court after an appeal filed by them.

At the same time, another accused Suresh Nair was also acquitted by the special court of NIA cases on December 19, 2019.

A blast took place at Ajmer’s sufi shrine of Khwaja Moiundhin Chisthy around 6.15 pm on October 11, 2007. Three people were killed while 15 people were injured. In this case, statements of a total of 184 people were recorded, in which 26 important witnesses turned hostile.

The people who were accused by the NIA court included Chandrashekhar Leve, Mukesh Vasani, Bharat Mohan Rateshwar, Lokesh Sharma, Mehul Kumar and Harshad Solanki.

Title: Korean in net for smuggling 4.5kg of gold worth Rs 1.8 crore
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Gold biscuits seized by DRI from the Korean citizen on Friday

JAIPUR: A 32-year-old Korean national was arrested by the Department of Revenue Intelligence (DRI), an anti-smuggling wing of the customs department at the Jaipur airport with an illegal possession of 4.5 kg of gold in biscuit form. The price of the gold seized from the possession of the tourist worth nearly 1.85 crore in the international market. This is first ever case when a Korean national is caught for smuggling in Rajasthan as claimed by the DRI officials.

Based on specific inputs the sleuths of the DRI checked the baggage of Korean national on Friday morning when he came from Ahmedabad in a domestic flight.

“Usually we can’t check the baggage of the domestic passengers. Since we had our intelligence input his bag and other things were checked. We found 45 gold biscuits each weight 100 grams which was 4.5 kg in total,” said a senior officer of DRI, Jaipur on the condition of anonymity.

Sleuths of DRI were facing lot of problems in the interrogation of the accused Korean national as communication has been a big barrier. The authorities were stunned to witness a very different and new modus operandi by the smugglers.

Title: Karnataka government’s refusal to admit 113 child porn cases shocks high court
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: The high court on Friday described as shocking the state government’s callous approach towards 113 cases of child sexual abuse, including pornography, revealed in data published by the ministry of women and child development in September 2018.

“It is difficult to educate government officers beyond a particular level,” a division bench headed by chief justice Abhay Shreeniwas Oka said, while indicating that it may direct for the personal appearance of the senior-most officer of the police department (DGP) over the failure to register basic FIRs, an elementary exercise under criminal law, in the cases.

The bench wondered how the state could be so callous and claim that no such incidents have been reported when the central ministry published data about 113 cases of sexual abuse targeting children housed in welfare centres, and the offences are serious in nature.

The court is hearing a PIL filed by Bachpan Bachao Andolan and Sampurna Behura, both New Delhi-based organisations. They have sought a direction for formulating a new or amended state child protection programme as the old policy restricts itself to children in school.

Citing the high number of cases found in the ministry’s data, both the organisations have sought for a status report on rehabilitation of the children and legal action against erring officials, apart from a probe by a special investigation team into the cases.

Title: Capital area continues to boil as women join protesting farmers
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Amaravati: Vijayawada and many villages in the capital region remained tense as protests against the proposal to shift the capital from Amaravati continued on Friday.

In most of the capital city villages, farmers, including women, braved police restrictions to participate in the protests. In Mandadam and Thullur, women offered prayers at local temple and set on a procession to go to Kanaka Durga temple.

Tension prevailed in Thullur when police prevented the women trying to breach the security cordon to go to Kanaka Durga temple. Women told the cops they did not need police permission to visit the temple. They asked the police to allow them to enter the temple as they were not going to battle against the government. With police refusing, the women confronted the forces.

The police resorted to mild lathicharge to disperse the crowd and restored control. The said the government should retain the capital city in Amaravati. They cursed the chief minister for deploying the police forces in peaceful villages and preventing them from visiting temples.

A similar situation prevailed in Mandadam where women gathered in huge numbers at a local temple. With cops preventing them from reaching the temple, the farmers took strong exception to the police attitude.

BJP state president Kanna Lakshminarayana condemned the police action against women. He flayed the chief minister for using police force to curb democratic protests. “Jagan had staged several agitations when he was opposition leader and has become an undemocratic force after becoming the CM,” said Lakshminarayana.

Rural district superintendent of police Ch Vijaya Rao said the police did not resort to lathicharge anywhere in the capital city. He said they requested the women to drop their plans to go in groups keeping in view of the restrictions imposed in the area. “We are duty bound to protect the law and order. We are not there to harm anyone,” said Vijaya Rao. He appealed to people to cooperate with the police and drop plans to take out rallies, dharnas and protests.

Meanwhile, Vijayawada city police locked up the Amaravati JAC office in Benz Circle and directed the convention centre owner not to lease it out to protests.

Title: Govt to encourage bee-keeping, incentives on cards
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Panaji: The department of industries, trade and commerce plans to launch a scheme to incentivise the bee-keeping (or apiculture ) in Goa. The scheme, with an allocation of Rs 75 lakh, will provide beehives to at least 100 trained bee-keepers at subsidised rate over the next five years, said officials.

“The scheme is meant for promotion of the bee-keeping industry, as bee-keeping leads to an increase in agricultural produce in the vicinity to the tune of 30% and the honey produced will supplement the income of the (scheme) applicant,” reads the proposal - likely to be announced in next few days.

The scheme, which is being given a push by industries minister, Vishwajit Rane , will provide funding to trained bee-keepers to help facilitate setting up of a beekeeping cluster and will also facilitate packaging of the produce. Rane is also the minister for skill development and entrepreneurship.

In October, the state government kick-started a large scale drive to train women and farmers in bee-keeping. Women farmer groups were identified as part of the initiative, with support from the Khadi and village industries commission (KVIC) and the agriculture technology management agency (Atma).

In Goa, KVIC will be the implementing agency of the scheme and applicants can avail a subsidy of 90% of the cost of up to 10 beehives and other equipment. Applicants from the SC/ST community will be eligible for 95% subsidy with an appraisal committee clearing the subsidy disbursal for all applicants.

The scheme will also provide support for skill development, technical know-how, quality control, certification and processing of by-products, which could be set up under cluster development schemes.

KVIC has identified beneficiaries from various villages like Morjim, Old Goa, Bicholim and Dabhal where bee-keeping could be taken up.

Title: Anti-squatter drive to start in Walled City from January 15
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

JMC conducted a anti-encroachment drive at Chandpole area in Walled City (File Photo)

JAIPUR: A 17-day anti-encroachment drive will be launched inside the Walled City from January 15 to remove squatters from the market.

Hawamahal zone deputy commissioner Surendra Yadav had requested the commissioner of Jaipur Municipal Corporation (JMC), Vijay Pal Singh, for permission to start the drive.

“Under this drive, we will remove the encroachments from the verandas and market areas. Hundreds of street vendors and shopkeepers have been encroaching the Walled City making it difficult for commuters and customers. This drive was under planning for a long time,” said Yadav. The JMC officials, however, denied that the move had anything to do with the Walled City being declared as a no-construction zone.

Surendra said, “The decision to remove illegal constructions will be taken after the heritage bylaws are notified and a committee under it is formed. That committee will take into consideration the drone survey conducted about the illegal buildings in the walled city. The drive starting from January 15 will be a planned drive for just encroachments.” Though the government has declared Walled City as a no-construction zone, the orders were not executed sincerely. Rampant construction has been going inside the city right under the nose of the authorities. Around Johri Bazaar and Kishanpole area, many under-construction buildings can be seen.

Title: Tamil Nadu BJP general secretary’s house burgled, gold and cash stolen
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

KRISHNAGIRI: Unidentified people broke into the house of state BJP general secretary K S Narendran at Chozan Nagar in Hosur town and made away with gold ornaments weighing nine sovereigns, Rs 1 lakh cash and a 7.5kg Sri Chakra statue on Thursday night.

Police said the incident took place when Narendran and his family members were away in Chennai to participate in the party events.

According to the BJP leader, he returned home around 2am on Friday. “I saw that the main door was broken open and valuables were missing from the house,” he said. Narendran immediately alerted the Hosur town police, who rushed to the crime scene.

“We have collected a few fingerprints from the house. We will nab the culprits at the earliest,” a police officer said.

The Hosur town police have registered a case and further inquiry is on.

Title: ACB nabs deputy headmaster for bribery
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: The Anti-Corruption Bureau ( ACB ) on Friday arrested deputy headmaster of ZP High School at Chanduluru village in Vizianagaram district for accepting a bribe of Rs 7,000.

ACB said E Sai Krishna Rao, deputy headmaster of ZP High School and Accredited Institute Co-ordinator for Open School Exams (APOSS), demanded a bribe of Rs 7,000 from a tuition teacher R Venkata Ramana, who came to collect the SSC markslists and transfer certificates of nine students who had appeared for open school exams in 2017-18.

Based on Ramana’s complaint, ACB laid a trap against the accused at his home in Chanduluru. The accused’s fingerprints turned positive result when subjected to chemical test. The tainted cash was recovered from the accused. ACB has seized related records from him.

Title: Karnataka: 29 years after car bought in auction was seized, man to get Rs 1.9 lakh relief
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: After multiple rounds of litigation spanning three decades and extending to the Supreme Court , the saga of a tourist cab which was seized over 31 years ago by the Regional Transport Office, Hassan, will finally come to an end.

The state government has agreed to a transport department proposal for releasing Rs 1,90,855 in favour of Kaleem Pasha, a resident of Magge village in Alur taluk in Hassan district, as per an order passed by the Karnataka high court on March 8, 2018, which has been upheld by the Supreme Court.

The amount to be paid to Pasha includes Rs 38,950 with 15% interest per annum from April 24, 1993 till May 31, 2019. Pasha had bought the tourist taxi in August 1989.

The vehicle originally belonged to a man called Ameer and was seized on December 24, 1988, by the Hassan RTO for non-payment of taxes. On August 8, the vehicle was auctioned at Hassan traffic police station. HR Shivashankar purchased the vehicle for Rs 20,200 and 10 days later, sold it to Pasha for Rs. 30,000. But Ameer moved the high court, challenging the auction. On February 20, 1991, the court ruled in Ameer’s favour.

The authorities were told to hand over the vehicle to Ameer, after collecting dues, but no order was passed on Pasha’s claim. Soon, Pasha moved a local court, seeking Rs 61,400 which he had invested. He said he had entered into a hire purchase agreement with a firm for purchase of the said vehicle and also spent Rs 8,950 on repairs and some more amount for obtaining a temporary permit. In all, he claimed Rs 41,400 was invested in addition to the purchase value. He added that he owed Rs 17,985 with 21% interest on the said amount to the firm with which he had an agreement.

However, authorities claimed Pasha could only proceed against Shivashankar. On September 26, 2000, the local court dismissed Pasha’s claim. He appealed before the district court in Hassan, but the plea was dismissed in 2004. He approached the high court which ruled in his favour in 2018. However, the state government moved the the Supreme Court.

Title: Ruias and Mittal lock horns over control of Hazira port
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Essar group promoter Prashant Ruia

AHMEDABAD: After a long-drawn battle to take control over debt-ridden Essar Steel, the Ruias of Essar group andruL N Mittal of ArcelorMittal group have locked horns for wresting control of the captive port at the steel plant facility at Hazira.

While Essar wants to handle third-party cargo – commercial cargo from other industries -- as per the state’s New Port Policy for the two captive jetties in Hazira that are owned by Essar Bulk Terminal Ltd, ArcelorMittal has opposed the move, said sources close to the matter.

ArcelorMittal, which acquired the steel facility in November after the Supreme Court approved its resolution plan, has renamed Essar Steel to AM/NS India, now a joint venture of ArcelorMittal with Nippon Steel group.

The Gujarat Maritime Board, the state’s maritime regulator, signed a supplementary agreement on December 13 with the promoters of Essar group, who own 74% in Essar Bulk Terminal Ltd, allowing them to handle third party cargo without any quantitative restriction. The GMB decision, however, has been put in abeyance by the state government after ArcelorMittal protested the decision – the same day when Laxmi Mittal called on chief minister Vijay Rupani on December 17.

The agreement was not approved by the state government hence it was put on hold, said government sources. “The representations from affected parties are under examination by the government. The government is reviewing the development,” said Mukesh Kumar, vice-chairman and CEO, GMB.

Essar group promoter Prashant Ruia also met senior state government officials on January 9 to discuss the matter, said sources.

In October 2019, the GMB introduced the New Port Policy with a view to “unlocking value in existing port infrastructure by allowing existing captive jetty holders to handle third party cargo and opportunity for new players.” The new policy grants exiting captive jetty holders the option to either opt-in or opt-out of the said policy framework. If an existing captive jetty holder opts in, then they are required to enter supplementary agreement with GMB.

AM/NS India, which owns 26% stake in EBTL, has made several representations to the state government in December that allowing EBTL to opt-in to the new policy would give backdoor entry to a third party for converting a captive jetty into a commercial jetty. EBTL holds the license for the two jetties with a direct berthing and AM/NS India has asked the government to transfer the license to them.

"Now that AM/ NS is the owner of Essar Steel, it expects the existing long-term agreements that are in place [with EBTL] to continue and no changes to the jetty intended for captive usage should be made without the explicit consent of AM/NS India. The jetty was provided on nomination basis to the steel plant as a captive user,” said a spokesperson for AM/NS.

In all there are four captive jetties, two of which are lighterage and owned by AM/NS India. The total cargo handling capacity of the four jetties is 50 million tonnes per annum and EBTL has drawn plans to take it to 100 MTPA.

An ArcelorMittal representative when contacted declined to comment on the matter. An e-mail sent to him remained unanswered.

Essar group promoters have in their representation to the state stated that EBTL has invested more than Rs 3,000 crore in the two jetties and the port is largely unutilized as only 22 million tonnes of captive cargo is being handled presently.

“EBTL’s agreement with GMB is in lines of the new port policy which is aimed at increasing cargo of Gujarat ports. How can AM/NS India, which is a minority stakeholder in EBTL, decide whether the company should opt-in or opt-out of a policy,” said a company official.

“New port policy is applicable to all 38 captive jetties in Gujarat enabling utilization of surplus/unutilized jetty capacity for 3rd party commercial cargo. EBTL has, with requisite approvals, opted in under the new policy as per law and new policy guidelines. EBTL is an independent company that specializes in ports and not a cost centre. EBTL has developed and operated the port as per licenses granted to EBTL pursuant to the MOU signed with GMB at Vibrant Gujarat 2007,” an Essar group official said in an e-mail response.

EBTL’s opting into the New Port Policy in no way affects any legitimate interests of steel mill and apprehensions if any are completely misplaced and unwarranted as EBTL continues to provide un interrupted services to steel mill as per earlier contracts signed since 2011 which clearly acknowledges EBTL’s rights, title and interest in respect of such facilities, it said.

"Now that AM/ NS is the owner of Essar Steel, it expects the existing long-term agreements that are in place [with EBTL] to continue and no changes to the jetty intended for captive usage should be made without the explicit consent of AM/NS India. The jetty was provided on nomination basis to the steel plant as a captive user,” said a spokesperson for AM/NS.

Title: 4 inmates get life for killing Pak convict in Jaipur jail
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: Less than a year after 44-year-old Pakistani citizen was killed at Jaipur central jail , a special court dealing with Sati Prevention case of Mahanagar(Jaipur) on Friday awarded life imprisonment by convicting four fellow prisoners.

Shakoorullah, who was a native of Sialkot and was serving a life term after his conviction in a terror-related case, was beaten to death by a group of inmates on February 20, 2019. Thereafter the case was taken up by the SOG who took two months in filing the charge-sheet against the four prisoners who were accused of the murder.

The four convicted are Ajit Singh, Manoj Pratap Singh, Kulvendra and Bhajan Meena

Among these accused Ajit Singh was serving a sentence of 20 years for raping a Japanese woman at the time of the incident.

Title: Delhi: Cops talking VC’s language, says JNU Students’ Union
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

While JNUSU asked why police had named all Left organisations but not ABVP, teachers called the probe disappoi... Read More

NEW DELHI: While Jawaharlal Nehru University Students’ Union (JNUSU) on Friday called the Delhi Police investigation “a litany of distortions, half-truths and outright lies”, JNU Teachers’ Association ( JNUTA ) said the press conference called by police showed that the mob violence on January 5 had been “glossed over as a non-event”. Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP), on the other hand, claimed the “truth of Left-perpetrated violence in JNU stands exposed”.

Barring two, all others named by Delhi Police are from Left groups or left-sympathisers. But JNUSU asked why police had named all Left organisations but not ABVP. It also questioned the decision to name JNUSU president Aishe Ghosh as a suspect when she had informed police about the violence.

“The silence of police on ABVP is deafening and its ploy to implicate the Left is an indication that this investigation is a political investigation with a clear agenda to placate Mr Amit Shah and ABVP, which can employ violence with impunity on the basis of its state backing,” JNUSU alleged. “The bent of the investigation and its insinuation point to a shameful collusion between ABVP and the state machinery, which must be exposed,” it added.

The exercise is meant to save ABVP and deflect attention from the violence, JNUSU claimed. “Police like the vice-chancellor is very fond of not taking the incident on January 5 in isolation. Never have the students of JNU either said the incidents of January 5 were in isolation. The police are conveniently talking the language of Mamidala Jagadesh Kumar,” it said.

The union appealed to people to see through this “malicious propaganda” being spread against JNU.

Terming the investigation disappointing, JNUTA demanded an independent probe. “Such underplaying of the incidents which shocked the nation and subjected several to extreme trauma is deeply disturbing,” JNUTA said while pointing out that police were yet to turn any of the teachers’ complaints into an FIR. This, along with the police attempt to paint JNUSU, which has been agitating against the fee hike for more than 75 days, as an unruly mob, reinforces “suspicions about the role of Delhi Police on the fateful day”, it added.

ABVP national general secretary Nidhi Tripathi, however, alleged the students disagreeing with the Left had always been subjected to violence by them at JNU and discriminated against by Left-wing teachers.

Title: Rajasthan to get first biotech park, incubation centre
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

JAIPUR: A biotechnology park and biotechnology incubation centre will soon come up in the state.

A Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) will be signed between the Centre’s biotechnology department and department of science and technology (DST), government of Rajasthan , said Dr Renu Swaroop, secretary (biotechnology), Central government.

She informed that this will provide an opportunity to Rajasthan to conduct research in the field of biotechnology and to provide employment to youths. On Friday, Swaroop was addressing State Biotech Cohort Meeting, which was attended by vice-chancellor, director and dean of all universities who are running biotechnology course, representatives from institutes conducting research in biotech and startups associated with it.

She said complete support and help from the Union government would be extended to promote biotechnology in Rajasthan. It will be done with the support of government company Biotechnology Industry Research Assistance Council (BIRAC).

She said utility of biotechnology is increasing in every field of today’s life, including health, agriculture and agriculture production, industry, edible food etc. In such a situation, there is the need to promote biotechnology.

She said encouraging biotechnology will give pace to the industrial development and research. Mugdha Sinha, secretary, DST said that assistance required in bioinformation, biomedical engineering and nano medicine etc will be encouraged in the state. “Recently, the state government had launched Nirogi Rajasthan (Healthy Rajasthan) and all possible assistance through bio informatics will be provided to strengthen it. Eco system and startup in biotechnology will be improved in the state with the help from Centre.”

She said that efforts will be made to get recognition to biotechnology science graduates in recruitment examination conducted by Rajasthan Public Service Commission (RPSC) to encourage scientists and youth associated with biotechnology, so that these youths get better employment opportunities. Science and biotechnology startup will be reverse pitched in the coming months and funding will be provided to these startups through BIRAC.

Title: Andhra Pradesh Government fixes GVMC wards at 98
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

VISAKHAPATNAM: The government has fixed the number of wards of the Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation ( GVMC ) at 98. The official notification, released on Friday by the municipal administration and urban development department, will be published in the extraordinary issue of the AP Gazette.

As per recently tweaked guidelines, there should be 90 wards for the first 15 lakh population. For every 50,000 people above 15 lakh, there shall be an additional elected member. There shall be one additional elected member for a fraction of more than 25,000 people and the fraction of less than 25,000 people shall be ignored while fixing the number of wards.

After the five new villages in Bheemili mandal were merged into the GVMC a few days ago, the population of the city has increased to 19.01 lakh. As per revised guidelines, the city got a total of 98 wards.

Title: Twenty sanitary workers with city corpn get insurance cover
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Coimbatore: The city corporation has introduced an accident insurance scheme for 20 sanitary workers, who clean manholes in the central zone.

The beneficiaries would receive up to Rs 10 lakh in case of fatal accidents and up to Rs 1 lakh for non-fatal accidents. This is in addition to the Pradhan Mantri Jeevan Jyoti Bima Yojna that provides a life cover of Rs 2 lakh.

Corporation commissioner J Sravan Kumar passed the order to include the workers under the scheme a week ago, said a corporation official. “Though the workers are using machines to clean manholes, there is a high chance of them inhaling toxic gases,” he said.

Forty-five sanitary workers are deployed to clean manholes in the city. “The civic body paid the annual premium of Rs 6,000 for the 20 workers covered under the scheme. We have initiated the process to include the others as well,” the official told TOI.

“The government had directed all local bodies to bring sanitary workers under insurance cover. All sanitary workers in Kerala and Karnataka have insurance cover, while their counterparts in Tamil Nadu were not included until recently,” said president of Social Justice Party N Pannerselvam. “By default, all uniformed officials have insurance and get risk allowance. After a long struggle, sanitary workers have been included in the scheme. But they are yet to get risk allowance,” he added.

Title: Areas around Amaravati to be developed
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Vijayawada: The high-power committee deliberating on decentralisation of development and administration, has decided to make recommendations for the development of Amaravati.

The meeting, held here on Friday, discussed the key recommendations of the GN Rao committee and the Boston Consulting Group on the capital relocation and development of the state.

As both the committees have favoured decentralization of administration, the high-power committee, consisting of 10 ministers and five senior officers, felt the need to address the issues of the people from the capital villages. They felt the need to hold talks with the people of Amaravati, besides exploring possibilities to develop Krishna, Guntur and Prakasam districts with focus on Amaravati.

The committee also decided to hold its next meeting on January 13 as it has been asked to complete its business at the earliest. The committee, headed by finance minister Buggana Rajendranath, had the initial study of the recommendations of the two committees at its first meeting held on January 8. On Friday, it focused on the recommendations suggested by both the committees to develop Krishna, Guntur and Prakasam districts, giving high priority to Amaravati.

The committee had a brief discussion on the promises made to the Amaravati farmers by the previous government and examined the proposals of the land pooling system (LPS) by the previous government. The capital region development authority (CRDA) officials briefed the committee on LPS and the commitments that the government has made with the farmers.

Some ministers felt the need to hold talks with the farmers’ representatives while some emphasized the need to develop the plots to be given to farmers in return for their land in the LPS.

The officials have told the committee to continue developmental works in the areas where the farmers were promised plots as that would silence the protest and pre-empt the opposition parties.

The committee also discussed the benefits to be offered to the secretariat employees if they were to move to Visakhapatnam. The committee studied the benefits offered by the previous government at the time of shifting them to Vijayawada from Hyderabad and decided to continue the benefits in Visakhapatnam.

Title: Obscene videos: BJP youth wing secy arrested
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Puducherry: The Karnataka police on Friday arrested Puducherry BJP youth wing secretary Rock Fredrick , 28, on charges of sending videos of him and his former girlfriend from Bengaluru in compromising positions to her and his friends .
