The Karnataka police registered a case against Fredrick after his girlfriend lodged a complaint at the Hubballi police station. A police team from Karnataka reached Puducherry on Thursday and arrested Fredrick on Friday with the help of the local police when he was spotted at Kurinji Nagar in the town limits.

Police said Fredrick and the woman were in a relationship a few months ago. He had made videos of their personal moments on his mobile. The couple broke up following differences and Fredrick began sending their personal videos to her, her relatives and friends besides sharing them with his friends.

The Karnataka police, who booked him under different sections of the Information Technology Act and Indian Penal Code arrested him and took him to Hubballi.

Title: Court grants bail in child assault case
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Panaji: The children’s court on Friday granted conditional bail to a man for assaulting his wife and their minor daughter in South Goa.

The prosecution stated that the 39-year-old on the afternoon of January 7 assaulted his wife and 13-year-old daughter with a belt, burnt her school bag and books by pouring petrol and threatened to kill the mother with fire after pouring petrol on her.

Based on the complaint filed by the mother, the police booked the man for voluntarily causing hurt, negligent conduct with respect to fire, criminal intimidation, mischief by fire and for abuse under the Goa Children’s Act. He was arrested by police on January 7.

The mother and minor girl were sent for medical examination, and the doctor on duty certified the injury as simple.

The prosecution further stated the mother and child are in a state of fear over the actions of the accused, and added that there is every possibility that the accused may commit such type of offences in the future. The prosecution also stated that due to timely intervention of the police, the accused was not able to complete his act of setting fire to his wife which could have resulted in her death.

In his bail application, the accused stated that he has no criminal antecedents and is innocent, and that the complaint was filed on account of a misunderstanding.

Title: Rajasthan: Online attendance of government school teachers soon
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: Government school teachers’ attendance will soon be registered online on the Shala Darpan portal, which will help the government to keep a watch on the presence of teachers in the schools. The scheme was supposed to start on January 1, 2020, but now the date of launch has been deferred due to some technical issue.

At present, biometric machines have been installed in the schools, but the teachers’ salaries are not dependent on it. After this system starts on Shala Darpan, the attendance sheet has to be filed on the portal every day. This record will be used to calculate the salaries of the employees every month.

An official of the education department who did not wish to be named said that some technical glitches prevented them from starting this on January 1, 2020. “We are planning to launch it by January 20 and notification will be issued soon,” said the official.

To make this a success, all the employees of the education department including teachers were supposed to be registered on the Shala Darpan portal. However, nearly 95,000 teachers haven’t registered. This may create a hurdle for the government to make the scheme into a success.

The move to register the teachers’ attendance online is appreciated but the teachers’ association is claiming it will not be successful in rural areas where internet connectivity is slow.

Vipin Sharma, general secretary, Rajasthan Primary and Secondary Teachers’ Association said that there are villages where internet connectivity is not good. “We respect this decision as it can curb the problem of teachers not fulfilling their duties properly. However, in villages where there is no internet, teachers may lose their salary for no reason. This should not be compulsory for those places,” said Vipin.

Title: School attempts world record by making largest notebook mosaic in Coimbatore
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Camford International School made an attempt to set a Guinness record by creating the largest notebook mosaic ... Read More

COIMBATORE: Students of Camford International School at Maniakaranpalayam in the city attempted to enter the Guinness World Records by creating the largest notebook mosaic with a life-size image of Tamil poet Thiruvalluvar. This was done to mark the 10th anniversary of the school.

More than 170 students, selected from class eight upwards, began making the mosaic from 8.30am. They first designed the 1200 ft large mosaic through a photograph with grids and started placing coloured notebooks in the assigned slots to create the image.

They finished the attempt a little after 10.30 am. The notebooks were of two sizes – long and king size, and of 14 colours. The final mosaic included 29,971 notebooks.

The students had spent time practicing the formations prior to the day of the attempt.

According to the Guinness World Records, the previous attempt of this kind was done in Abu Dhabi in March 2018, in an area of 702.8 sqft.

The school believes that the notebook mosaic measuring 1,114.82 square metres – made by the students on January 10 – would break the existing record.

The school had also made the largest disposable paper cup mosaic of former President Abdul Kalam, in 2017, and another postcard mosaic of the Royal Bengal Tiger in 2013.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: EC urges district administration to gear up for civic polls
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: The State Election Commissioner N Ramesh Kumar urged the district administration to gear up to conduct local body elections .

During a video conference held with various district collectors on Friday, the SEC said the district administration must be ready with the voters’ list and, after the declaration of the election date, strictly implement the code of conduct, which would come into play. He said the civic body elections would be held in two phases.

District collector V Vinay Chand said all the polling stations are ready and added that 39 returning officers, 39, MPDOs and 39 Tahsildars were appointed as AROs and received training. He said police bandobast would be strengthened in sensitive centres.

Title: 'Tirupur had seen 17% decrease in property crimes in 2019'
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

TIRUPUR: The city had witnessed a 17% drop in property crimes last year compared to 2018, said city police commissioner Sanjay Kumar while releasing annual crime report on Friday.

“While 324 property crimes - including theft, snatching, burglary and house break-ins - were reported in 2018, we saw only 277 such cases in 2019. And in 252 of the 277 cases we have detected the accused, recovered stolen properties worth Rs1.52 crore and handed them over to the victims,” he said.

The officer said Tirupur was also sensitive in terms of crimes against children and women. “The crimes against women decreased by 9% last year. In four such cases, mahila court had convicted the accused.”

Sanjay Kumar said they had intensified drive against ganja peddling and illegal sale of gutka. “We had registered 81 cases against 113 ganja peddlers, and seized 118kg marijuana last year. At least 2,322 banned tobacco products were seized from 496 people in 488 cases.”

He said 21 accused, who were arrested in various serious crimes, were detained under the Goondas Act in 2019. “It is a highest in a calendar year so far in the city."

The officer said fatal road accidents had also come down by 10% last year.

Title: PK asks Centre to hold all-party meet on capital shift proposal
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Vijayawada: Jana Sena president Pawan Kalyan on Friday urged the Union government to hold an all-party meeting on the capital city proposal .

“BJP played a significant role in Andhra Pradesh’s bifurcation. Prime Minister Narendra Modi had laid the foundation stone for the capital city in Amaravati. BJP should support Amaravati farmers,” Pawan said, while speaking to the media at Jana Sena head office in Mangalagiri.

He asked BJP leaders to make their views clear. “The BJP state leadership says it backs Amaravati. But one of their national spokespersons said that the party is not concerned about the proposal to shift the capital. The contradictory statements have created confusion,” the Jana Sena chief said.

He asked YSRC leaders and legislators to convince the farmers of Amaravati region about the proposals for three capitals. “YSRC is bringing regional disparities by giving different statements on Amaravati. They should take a stand on the capital and do justice to the farmers,” Pawan said.

Pawan added that he appreciated the fighting spirit of the farmers and said he would support them in every way possible.

Title: Jaipur hospital saves two heart patients with new technology
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: Doctors at private hospital here saved the life of a heart failure patient by connecting the pacemaker’s wire to the heart wire. At the same time, in another case, without performing open heart surgery, they succeeded in changing two valves simultaneously.

Dr Samin K Sharma, cardiologist and chairman of Eternal Hospital, claimed on Friday that both of these cases happened in the country for the first time. He told that it is unique in itself to connect the fourth wire directly to the heart wire when the other three wires of the pacemaker do not work properly. This helps in normalising the heartbeat by making equal current reach to all parts of the heart. Dr Jitendra Singh Makkar and Dr Kush Kumar Bhagat performed the surgery. While in the another case, Dr Ravindra Singh Rao replaced two valves of a patient’s heart simultaneously without open surgery. Aortic and mitral valves have been replaced by trans-catheter valve replacement technology . Dr Samin said that it is the hospital’s endeavour that modern techniques being adopted in the US should be made available to the common patients in Jaipur too.

Shakuntala Devi, 67, of Bharatpur had been suffering for a long time and her heart’s performance was reduced to 15 to 20%. The three wires of the pacemaker did not work, so to save her life, by adopting HOT-CRT technology, the fourth wire was connected to the heart’s main wire.

Sarita, 78, from Nagpur, had complaints of breathing and chest pain. Her two valves were not working. Open heart surgery was conducted on her to replace a valve in 2012, but now two valves were damaged. Performing open surgery again could prove dangerous due to the patient’s age and earlier operation. So, she was treated using the trans-catheter aortic valve replacement technique.

Title: Elections to all panchayat samitis stayed in Jaisalmer
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

JAISALMER: Jaisalmer is the only district in the state where the Supreme Court has stayed the election in all the panchayat samitis .

The state election commission on Thursday late night issued a list in which panchayati raj elections have been postponed in many gram panchayats across the state. The list comprised all the 167 gram panchayats of Jaisalmer, among others.

According to the list issued by the state election commission, the election of few panchayats have been stalled in few districts but Jaisalmer is the only district where elections in all the gram panchayats have been stayed.

After this decision, the political calculations in all the panchayats have changed. In many panchayats, sarpanchs have been elected unanimously but now they are unable to understand whether to celebrate or get disappointed. Many candidates had filed their nominations and were considering themselves winners, but now confusion prevails amid uncertainty. Candidates for post of sarpanch have spent lakhs of rupees in their areas. On Thursday, the state election commission had issued the order, along with the list to all district election officers.

District collector Namit Mehta said that as per the SEC programme, out of 167 gram panchayats, the election process was started in 97 gram panchayats, under which applications were received and scrutiny was done and even withdrawal had taken place, but now, after the Supreme Court stay, the process of delimitation in all gram panchayats in Jaisalmer has been affected and after the orders, the election has been postponed and new date for election will be announced soon. TNN

Title: Chennai cops move court to cancel bail of key murder suspects
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Police take away the three suspects picked up for harbouring the key accused involved in the Hindu Munnani lea... Read More

CHENNAI: The city police have moved to get cancelled the bail granted to suspected ISIS sympathisers C Khaja Moideen, A Abdul Shamim and S Syed Ali Nawas, key accused in the 2014 murder of Hindu Munnani leader K P S Suresh Kumar at Ambattur. The three had jumped bail in December, but on Thursday the Delhi police said they had picked up Khaja Moideen and Nawas.

Shamim, who is still absconding, is the main suspect in the murder of special sub-inspector Y Wilson on the TN-Kerala borderon Thursday.

Special public prosecutor C S S Pillai of NIA court , said the petition to cancel bail was moved by Ambattur assistant commissioner of police Kannan.

The Ambattur Industrial Estate police arrested 17 people, including a juvenile for the murder of Suresh Kumar.

All the arrested men came out on bail in April last year and appeared before the court for trial without fail. However, Nawas, Shamim, and Khaja Moideen, failed to appear before the court in December and went into hiding.

Khaja Moideen is also accused by the National Investigation Agency (NIA) of recruiting people for ISIS; details of his activities were submitted while moving court for cancelling the bail. Recording the submissions, the principal sessions court judge J Selvanadhan placed the petition on record.

The NIA court has also issued non-bailable warrant against Khaja Moideen at the instance of the prosecution.

Title: Women lathicharged during capital march
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Raising their voice: Women from the capital region villages take out a ‘Save Amaravati’ rally, on MG road in V... Read More

VIJAYAWADA: Amidst prevailing tension across the capital region, five women out of 3,000 from Mandadam village managed to march their way to visit Kanaka Durga temple to offer prayers on Friday.

Cops stopped thousands of women protesters in their tracks from marching towards the temple as they were already denied permission for the rally from Uddandarayunipalem village in the morning. Cops even initiated lathicharge against them after they tried to continue on their March at Thullur, Uddandarayunipalem and even at Bandar road in Vijayawada.

However, the cops did permit five women amongst them to go to the temple who offered prayers to the goddess that chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy should change his mind over the trifurcation of the capital and retain Amaravati.

Tension prevailed as the cops began detaining several women who vehemently tried to overpower them and continue their march.

Guntur urban police and Vijayawada commissionerate unit had issued an advisory on Thursday that no permission would be granted for the proposed rally citing that it would create ‘traffic problems’ as the Benz Circle flyover works are under way. Even AP Police Headquarters warned that action would be taken as per law if anyone violated the prohibitory orders under Section 144 of CrPC were already in place.

Title: Parents, teachers to stand guard against cyber crime among children
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Panaji: With online stalking and child pornography increasingly leaving youth as vulnerable targets, Mumbai-based NGO Reponsible Netism in partnership with Goa-based Human Touch Foundation is preparing a programme on cyber safety, which will be imparted through the directorate of education to teachers, students and parents.

“We already met with the education director and we are giving a proposal for the next academic year where we can train parents, teachers and students to be cyber caregivers and digital guardians,” founder of Reponsible Netism Sonali Patankar said.

Patankar, who was speaking at the national cyber psychology conference on child online protection on Friday, said they receive 25 cases a week of child pornography, child sexual abuse imagery and fake social media profiles created by fellow students among other complaints.

Cautioning against online stalkers, director projects at Responsible Netism, Unmesh Joshi, advised social media users to keep their accounts private and keep unknown followers at bay. He also spoke about child pornography and cautioned against uploading pictures of children on social media platforms if accounts are not secured.

Joshi underscored the need for teachers, principals and counsellors to report cases of child sexual abuse that they come across. “If you know of a crime, but don’t report it, once it’s proved in court the punishment is seven years imprisonment,” he said.

Title: Goa: Bainguinim plant gets green nod
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: The proposed solid waste management facility at Bainguinim has moved closer to reality with the state environment impact assessment authority (SEIAA) granting it environmental clearance (EC). “We have received the EC for Bainguinim plant . We are in the process of inviting expression of interest to select the bidder for setting up the plant. The entire process will be completed within five months after which the foundation stone will be laid and the work will be completed in 18 months,” waste management minister Michael Lobo told TOI.The EC has placed 12 general conditions for the construction of the plant and made it compliant for the project to prepare a report on energy conservation measures conforming to energy conservation norms as finalised by the Bureau of Energy Efficiency and submit it in three months time to the State Expert Appraisal Committee with a copy marked to Goa State Pollution Control Board.Referring to opposition to the facility, Lobo said the Goa Solid Waste Management Corporation (GSWMC) would be taking all MLA’s from Tiswadi, panchayat bodies and other stakeholders into confidence to allay any concerns about the facility. “There are a large number of hotels and building complexes coming up in the area and they will be generating a lot of garbage for which this facility is needed,” he said.Lobo said the state government had proposed two more garbage treatment plants after launching the waste management facility at Saligao . “The foundation stone for the Cacora plant has already been done. Now we're going to start on the Bainguinim plant. We’ve planned one more plant at Verna, which will handle waste from the Salcete coastal belt,” he said.The Bainguinim plant will be the state’s third garbage treatment plant.Lobo said that the Manohar Parrikar-led government had been the first to set up a modern waste management facility. “Every previous government would only talk, but we took action. We’ve also set up a waste management corporation, the first in the country, and also a waste management ministry,” he said.“We want to make entire Goa garbage-free by 2022. So far we’ve been able to handle about 30% of the waste,” Lobo said.The 250 tonne per day (TPD) capacity plant — 50 TPD segregated dry waste, 150 TPD segregated wet waste and 50 TPD mixed waste — will cater to Tiswadi and Ponda talukas.

Title: Expert: Know culture, customs to understand demography better
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Dr Niraj Rai delivers Bal Gangadhar Tilak memorial lecture on Thursday

Nagpur: People should look at a number of perspectives like culture, customs, languages and anthropology in view of various ethnic groups and different population backgrounds to understand the structure of demography in the current form. Archaeology plays an important role in understanding all these aspects, said scientist Niraj Rai of Birbal Sahni Institute of Palaeosciences (BSIP), Lucknow, on Thursday.

He was speaking on ‘Recent research in ancient Indian genetics: An archaeological perspective’ at the Lokmanya Bal Gangadhar Tilak memorial lecture organized by the PG department of ancient Indian history, culture and archaeology at Dr AK Dorle auditorium, Nagpur University campus off Amravati Road.

Present at the lecture were officiating pro-VC Vinayak Deshpande and professor and head of the department Preety Trivedi.

Shedding light on the anthropological facet, Rai said, “I am using archaeological and anthropological tools as an endeavour to connect knowledge with the advent of genetics. To study genetic structure of India, we have to keep several things in mind. Anthropologically, the Indian subcontinent was divided on the basis of languages. With different languages spoken across the regions, we have language barriers that have created groups having distinct identities.”

He said, “We have more than 4,500 well-defined population groups in the country, including 532 tribes and 72 primitive tribes. We have variety in languages, physical appearances and genetic architecture. This diversity forms due to variation in DNA.”

Speaking about evolution of modern humans, Rai drew parallels and pointed out the differences between human beings and our closest ancestor, the chimpanzee.

He said, “We don’t have much archaeological records of chimpanzees, but we do have an account of the hominin species. With the development in DNA technology, researchers have been able to read the sequencing of DNA codes of chimpanzees and modern humans all over the world. They discovered that our DNA matches up to 99% with the chimpanzees.”

Explaining the reasoning behind studying data from the past, Rai said it is like a time machine. “You can revisit the past and study how the changes in demography occurred over a period of time,” he said. He talked about his case study on ‘Reconstruction of the genetic make-up of Harappans’ and spoke about colonization of India at length.

Trivedi said, “Since childhood, our history books taught us about the Indus Valley civilization, influx and settling of the Vedic Aryans on the Indian soil, followed by multiple invasions from various people and countries. However, history being a discipline of continuous re-interpretation, research has been pursued in the past several decades to authenticate various theories regarding the origin and evolution of Indians and our culture.”

(Reporting by Manshika Vaikkath)

Title: Road accidents down in Andhra Pradesh, but increase in Vijayawada
Content:
Representative image

Data released by different agencies shows a mismatch when it comes to road accidents in Vijayawada city

VIJAYAWADA: While road accidents across the country remained more or less same in 2018 as compared to 2017, Andhra Pradesh is among the only states which recorded a declining trend in the total number of accidents. The state has reported 6.4 per cent less accidents in the year 2018 when compared to 2017, according to the data released by the National Crime Records Bureau ( NCRB ).However, data released by different agencies shows a mismatch when it comes to road accidents in Vijayawada city. According to the city police, there were 1,644 accidents in 2017, whereas NCRB data says there were 1,491 accidents. The data given by the ministry of road transport and highways shows that 1,648 accidents took place in Vijayawada city during 2017.For 2018, city police data suggests that 1,658 accidents took place, while NCRB data shows the number of accidents as 1,663 and according to the transport ministry data the number of accidents was 1,648.While NCRB data suggests that accidents are in an increasing trend in Vijayawada, city police claim that the number of accidents has actually come down. And this is, they say, despite a multi-fold increase in vehicular traffic after the city was made part of the capital. They also add that the decline in accidents is due to the effective enforcement measures they have undertaken.On the other hand, the number of railway accidents increased in Andhra Pradesh by about 12 per cent during the same period. At the same time, Vijayawada city has saw a 11 per cent increase in number of road accidents, recording an increasing trend, contrary to the declining trend in the state overall.When it comes to cause of accidents, over-speeding and negligent driving are the main culprits contributing to a majority of deaths in Andhra Pradesh. Weather conditions, defective vehicles, animal crossing, lack of road infrastructure, and parking vehicles on road shoulders were found to be the common causes of road accidents in the state.About 38 per cent of the accidents deaths took place on national highways, 24 per cent deaths happened on state highways and other roads contributed 38 per cent of deaths in Andhra Pradesh.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Teacher who made boy clean human excreta gets jail
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

NAMAKKAL: A 40-year-old government schoolteacher was on Friday sentenced to five years imprisonment for forcing a Class II student to clean human excreta from the classroom. The special court for SC/ST cases in the district combined court that heard the case also slapped on her a fine of Rs 1,000.

A court source identified the convict as R Vijayalakshmi, who was employed with the Namakkal municipality middle school in Ramapuram Pudur.

“When she entered the classroom on November 12, 2015, she found human excreta there. When she inquired, someone informed her that it was the doing of a Class III student the previous evening after school hours. Vijayalakshmi forced V Sasidharan, a Class II student, to clean the human excreta using his bare hands,” the source said.

Sasidharan informed his parents, who along with their relatives and neighbours, laid siege to the school the next day, demanding stern action against the teacher .

The then Namakkal superintendent of police, S R Senthilkumar, and education department officials pacified the crowd and assured stringent action against the teacher.

The Namakkal town police arrested Vijayalakshmi the same day (November 13, 2015) and lodged her in the Salem central women' s prison under judicial custody. The education department officials, meanwhile, placed her under suspension.

The case was heard by sessions judge K Dhanasekaran. After hearing both the sides, the judge sentenced Vijayalakshmi to five years imprisonment on Friday.

Title: ‘Maharashtra may extend loan waiver sum’
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

KOLHAPUR: Co-operation and marketing minister Balasaheb Patil said that the state government was considering extension in the limit of the loan waiver amount set for farmers.

Addressing the media in Karad , Patil said that government would soon form a committee to derive a solution to the problems faced by farmers who had taken loan of more than Rs two lakh.

He said that the government has already waived off farmers’ loans of up to Rs 2 lakh. He said that the committee is also expected to address the problems of the farmers who were paying regular instalments, but are facing financial crisis.

Patil said that the government would also decide on the loans that were taken by deceased farmers. In normal circumstances, the loan account is transferred to the legal heirs of the deceased; However, at times, some complications arise if the legal heirs are also defaulters”, he said, adding that the issue is crucial as only one member of a family can take benefit of loan waiver scheme. Patil said that the government was facing many such difficulties which it is planning to address soon with the help of the committee.

He indicated that the government may go soft on the cooperative institutions which are facing legal and financial problems at the moment. He also said that Maharashtra has a large network of cooperative institutions and the decision taken by the government would be in the interest of depositors, institutions and stakeholders.

Title: Graduation day celebrated at Gayatri Vidya Parishad College
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: Gayatri Vidya Parishad College held its graduation ceremony in Rushikonda on Friday. The programme was presided over by Prof PS Rao, president of the Parishad. Prof K Rama Mohan Rao, vice-chairman, AP State Council of Higher Education was the chief guest. In his speech, Prof Rao asked students to acquire soft skills to improve their career prospects.

Title: Andhra Pradesh government to conduct panchayat polls in capital region
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

AMARAVATI: In what could be considered as the final nail on the coffin of Amaravati, the government has decided not to constitute a metropolitan civic body for the ‘capital city’. Instead, it has decided to conduct the elections to all village panchayats within the capital city without altering their local body status. The residents will now elect sarpanches and ward members to their respective village panchayats.

The previous TDP government wanted to make the capital city area a municipal corporation by merging the villages in its ambit. It had also filed an affidavit in the high court in support of petitions challenging the land acquisition in the area. It stated that the government had decided to constitute a mega civic body under Capital Region Development Authority (CRDA). However, the TDP government had failed to go ahead with the plan although the term of the panchayats expired almost 18 months before the general elections. “The TDP government had not even moved a proposal to merge all the villages into a new civic body. They just made big promises,” rued a local farmer.

After the change of guard in the general elections, the Jaganmohan Reddy government had listed out its priorities for the development of the state and made it clear that spending a large amount of funds into Amaravati villages on the pretext of building a capital city was not on its agenda. After making plans to shift the seat of power to Visakhapatnam from Amaravati, the state government has directed Guntur district administration to finalise the reservations to the village local bodies as per the rules. District administration has already fixed the reservations for sarpanches, ward members, MPTCs in all the 29 villages in the capital region.

Meanwhile, the district administration is gearing up to issue the notification for elections to mandal parishad (MPTC) and zilla parishad territorial constituencies (ZPTC) on January 17 and village panchayats on February 8.

Title: Goa: Special session on dealing with students’ exam stress
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: In view of the examination season approaching and in order to help students deal with stress, the Goa State Commission for the Protection of Child Rights has organised a programme for heads of institutions.

“The aim of the programme is to sensitise them on issues of stress in students due to exams. This initiative will help in removing the stigma attached to counselling and promote positive perception,” chairperson Sushma Mandrekar-Chodankar stated.

“A call came from the national commission for protection of child rights to sensitise teachers considering the nature of incidents due to exam anxiety. Pariksha Parv 2.0 is intended to change the outlook of students towards exams,” she said.

Chairperson of the National Commission for Protection of Child Rights, Priyank Kanoongo will be present at the programme to be held on January 13, at Old Goa . Sessions will be conducted by Jyoti Chauthaiwale from the national chemical laboratory , Pune.

Allan Abreu, principal, GVM College of Education will educate participants on ‘De-stressing the exam stress ’, while Peter Castelino, psychiatrist and director, COOJ mental health foundation will present the ‘Psychological aspects of facing the examination and results’. This will be followed by panel discussions.

Chodankar said 600 heads of institutions are expected to attend the event.

Title: Chennai: Cops get 10 days custody of three IS sympathisers
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Two days after the Bengaluru police picked up three men for harbouring key accused in the July 18, 2014, murder of Hindu Munnani leader K P S Suresh Kumar at Ambattur and preparing fake travel documents for them, a city court sent them to 10-day police custody . The three were brought to Chennai on Thursday and remanded in custody.

‘Q’ branch officials arrested Mohamed Haneef Khan, 29, Imran Khan, 32, and Mohamed Zaid, 24, for harbouring Syed Ali Nawas, Abdul Shamim, and Khaja Moideen and helping them get fake documents to travel abroad.

Meanwhile, the Tamil Nadu ‘Q’ branch sleuths had arrested 28-year-old Liyakath Ali of Salem last week on suspicion of being an ISIS sympathiser.

All four were produced before the second metropolitan magistrate court in Egmore on Friday. The ‘Q’ branch sleuths filed two separate petitions before the court seeking 10 days custody to interrogate the four.

Magistrate Roshlin Durai granted police 10 days custody to question Mohamed Haneef Khan, Imran Khan, and Mohamed Zaid, while sanctioning just four days custody for Liyakath Ali. Ali is to be produced before the court on January 13.

Police suspect Khaja Moideen has been indoctrinating youth across the state since 2004. The day Delhi police announced his arrest, the Gujarat police picked up a man from Cuddalore at Vadodara on suspicion of ISIS links. Police also suspect SSI Wilson was gunned down by Shamim and Thowfique in a fit of rage once they heard Khaja Moideen had been picked up.

Title: Marathon to create awareness on child abuse
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Vellore: Aiming to curb crime against and sexual abuse of children, the Vellore district administration along with the education department and an NGO on Thursday organised a 3-km marathon from Katpadi Odai Pillaiyar temple to Panchayat union primary school in Gandhi Nagar.

More than 200 school and college students in and around Gandhi Nagar took part in the marathon holding placards.

Flagging off the awareness rally, collector A Shanmuga Sundaram said that within just nine days since the advent of the New Year, as many as three sexual abuse cases have been registered in Vellore district alone. Despite steps to ensure the accused face stringent punishment without any escape, lack of awareness on child abuse aids such crimes against children, he said. It’s the responsibility of every citizen to create a safer place for children by preventing their abuse, he said. Shanmuga Sundaram also applauded students and children for voluntarily participating in the marathon for a noble cause.

While addressing the students, Shanmuga Sundaram spotted a woman along with her baby seeking alms from passengers and commuters near the Odai Pillaiyar temple bus stop. Following this, he personally inquired with the woman and identified her to be Malleswari of Puthur from neighbouring Andhra Pradesh.

The woman said she was a destitute and after she lost the support of her relatives, has been leading a miserable existence begging. Based on the direction by the collector to lodge the woman and her child in a safe place until officials of social welfare department hold an inquiry, she was shifted to an orphanage in Katpadi by revenue officials.

Title: Differences likely to delay appointment of guardian min
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Pune: Sharp differences among three ruling parties – NCP , Congress and Shiv Sena – over the appointment of district guardian minister for Kolhapur have come to the fore. Congress minister Balasaheb Thorat was appointed the guardian minister but has refused to take charge.

Congress workers in Kolhapur are unhappy with chief minister Uddhav Thackeray, who they feel is acting at the behest of NCP leadership. Congress sources said minister of state for home, Satej Patil, has been deliberately sidelined and given responsibility of Bhandara district in Vidarbha region, which is far away from his home district.

Congress workers also claim that Patil’s appointment as district guardian minister has been scuttled because of strong opposition from a section of Shiv Sena leaders. Patil enjoys good relationship with Sena MP Sanjay Mandlik, which is not accepted by many Sena workers. Old Sena activists have always been raising doubt about Mandlik’s loyalty to the party and fear that he would eventually join Congress. Patil had publicly helped Mandlik in Lok Sabha election, defying party orders.

Patil’s supporters are disappointed that he was not accommodated as cabinet minister. Sources in Congress said Thorat, who is also revenue minister, is inclined to appoint Patil but NCP and Sena are reluctant over the move.

Thorat is expected to take up the issue with party high command. Thorat was scheduled to meet chief minister Uddhav Thackeray but the meeting could not take place as Thackeray was not in Mumbai.

Thorat is also said to be upset as he feels that he was not taken into confidence while appointing Hasan Mushrif as Ahmednagar district guardian minister. Ahmednagar is home district of Thorat. Similarly, Thorat was not given idea before announcement of his appointment as guardian minister for Kolhapur. Congress workers feel that Thackeray has taken the decision under the pressure from NCP.

Title: Two government schoolteachers arrested for sexually abusing girl students
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

Title: N Chandrababu Naidu raises ‘one state, one capital’ slogan, says won’t allow capital shift from Amaravati
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

CM N Chandrababu Naidu

RAJAHMUNDRY: TDP chief and former chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu raised the slogan ‘one state, one capital’ during a public rally in Rajahmundry on Friday.

“A large state like Uttar Pradesh has one capital. All other states in the country have one capital. What is the need of having three capitals? I will fight till the last to stop the government from shifting the capital from Amaravati ,” he said, while warning that the entire police force of the state will not be enough to arrest the people who are agitating for having the capital in Amaravati.

Lamenting that Amaravati has become a war zone due to the strong-arm tactics of the state government, Naidu alleged that woman protesters were beaten up by male police in the capital area.

“I have approached the National Women’s Commission to probe this. Efforts are being made to undo everything that my government did.

“ The high court building, DGP office, secretariat and assembly building have been built in Amaravati. It’s the best place to have the state’s capital, but this government has killed the goose that was capable of laying golden eggs,” he alleged.

Targeting state DGP Goutam Sawang, Naidu alleged that the police are violating the law by suppressing the peaceful movement of farmers in Amaravati.

“YSRC has no love for Visakhapatnam, the party is only interested in usurping prime land in the district,” he said. Naidu later took part in a rally with his party members under the aegis of Amaravati Parirakshna Samiti and collected donations from people to keep the Amaravati movement going.

Title: Arjun Hub comes up at Jaisalmer Military Station
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Jaisalmer: For providing speedy and focused repair to vital assemblies of the indigenous Arjun main battle tank (MBT), Arjun Hub was inaugurated on Thursday at Jaisalmer Military Station by lieutenant general V S Sreenivas, General Officer Commanding Konark Corps.

Army official sources said, “Arjun Hub at Jaisalmer Military Station was inaugurated on Thursday. There are regiments of Arjun Tank already in Jaisalmer. This initiative marks a significant step towards Indian Army’s effort to develop an all-encompassing and inclusive ecosystem to provide impetus to public-private partnerships towards enhancing operational availability of Arjun main battle tank.”

Battle Axe Division GOC Major General Rakesh Kapoor, DRDO scientists and many senior Army officers were present on the occasion.

Title: Kolhapur: Nursing student ends life in hostel room
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

KOLHAPUR: A second year nursing student committed suicide by hanging from the ceiling of a room at the premises of Chhatrapati Pramilaraje Hospital (CPR) on Friday morning, police said, adding that the motive behind the suicide is unknown.

The deceased — Shefali Raju Pawar alias Pooja — was found dead in the hostel room by her friends who immediately informed the college authorities and rushed her to the hospital. However, she was declared brought dead.

Shefali was a resident of Shiroli Pulachi in the Hatkanangale taluka. She is survived by her mother and two brothers.

Police said that Shefali had joined the nursing course two years back and was staying at the CPR hostel. On Thursday night, she went to her room after having dinner with her hostel friends. Her room-mate Shraddha Gade woke up at 6.30 am on Friday only to find Shefali’s bed empty. Gade thought that Shefali may be getting ready for classes. However, she failed to attend any of her classes.

Anxious, Gade returned to her room looking for Shefali, but in vain. Later, Shefali was found hanging by a black scarf from the ceiling of the neighbouring room. A wooden chair was also found near her.

Police said that they are investigating the incident and have not come across any suicide note. They also said that the deceased’s mobile phone was found lying on a table.

Police are checking Shefali’s call data records to find any clues that would lead them to her suicide.

Title: N Chandrababu Naidu raises ‘one state, one capital’ slogan, says won’t allow capital shift from Amaravati
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

CM N Chandrababu Naidu

RAJAHMUNDRY: TDP chief and former chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu raised the slogan ‘one state, one capital’ during a public rally in Rajahmundry on Friday.

“A large state like Uttar Pradesh has one capital. All other states in the country have one capital. What is the need of having three capitals? I will fight till the last to stop the government from shifting the capital from Amaravati ,” he said, while warning that the entire police force of the state will not be enough to arrest the people who are agitating for having the capital in Amaravati.

Lamenting that Amaravati has become a war zone due to the strong-arm tactics of the state government, Naidu alleged that woman protesters were beaten up by male police in the capital area.

“ The high court building, DGP office, secretariat and assembly building have been built in Amaravati. It’s the best place to have the state’s capital, but this government has killed the goose that was capable of laying golden eggs,” he alleged.

Targeting state DGP Goutam Sawang, Naidu alleged that the police are violating the law by suppressing the peaceful movement of farmers in Amaravati.

“YSRC has no love for Visakhapatnam, the party is only interested in usurping prime land in the district,” he said. Naidu later took part in a rally with his party members under the aegis of Amaravati Parirakshna Samiti and collected donations from people to keep the Amaravati movement going.

Title: With 664 farmers ending their lives in 2018, Andhra Pradesh stands fourth in farm sector suicides
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

VIJAYAWADA: While Andhra Pradesh is ranked ninth in the country when it comes to suicides, the state stands at the fourth place in the suicides of people from farm sector in the year 2018 according to the data released by National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB).

As many as 5,318 people, including 1,566 women, ended their lives in 2018, of which 664 were found to be either farmers or farm labourers. In other terms, more than 15 people committed suicide every day in Andhra Pradesh. Nearly two people from farm sector committed suicide every day during the year 2018.

Out of all the suicides that took place in the farm sector in 2018, 199 farmers—including 13 women—were cultivating crop on their own land. While 166 tenant farmers—including 12 women—committed suicide, as many as 299 farm labourers—of which 49 were women—ended their lives in Andhra Pradesh. Maharashtra, Karnataka and Telangana are the only states with a higher number of farm sector suicides in the country.

The state stands second in number of mass suicides ,with 11 incidents reported during 2018 in which 26 people ended their lives. Tamil Nadu topped the list, with 15 mass suicides claiming 35 lives.

When it comes to motive behind the suicides, illness was found to be the biggest reason, followed by family related issues. As many as 1,610 people committed suicides due to an illness and 1,515 people committed suicide due to family reasons.

Other reasons for suicides in Andhra Pradesh included bankruptcy and indebtedness (376 suicides), marriage related issues found (168 cases), failure in exams (85 cases) and love affairs (154 suicide cases) in the state during 2018.

As many as 29 people, including 18 women, committed suicide because of impotency and infertility issues and 32 people, including one man, committed suicide due to dowry related issues.

Title: KMC engineers go on mass leave, mayor assures resolving all issues
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

The KMC has a sanctioned strength of 41 engineers

KOLHAPUR: The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) engineers on Friday decided to go on a common leave for an indefinite period for assigning them non-technical works due to a shortage of staff. The mayor, however, claimed that the engineers will join regular work from Monday onwards.

The engineers are employed in various departments of KMC such as the public works department, project department, town planning department, water supply department, divisional ward offices, and electricity department. They claim that there is a shortage of engineers in the KMC.

Harshajit Ghatge, deputy city engineer of KMC said that there is a sanctioned strength of 41 engineers in the KMC, however, currently, there are only 36 functioning. “The engineers are assigned non-technical works frequently. We have to spend a lot of time on works like census, health, cleaning and removal of encroachments. Alongside we have to continue our technical works related to various departments. We want these assigning of non-technical works to be stopped. That is why we have decided to go on common leave for an indefinite period.”

Responding to the decision, mayor Surmanjiri Latkar met the delegation of engineers and assured them that a meeting will be convened to resolve the issues soon. Upon discussing with mayor, the engineers decided to resume the work from Monday onwards.

The engineers claimed that they hardly get time to look into the technical proposals which are submitted by the administration. At present several works are undertaken by the KMC which requires technical expertise. Ghatge said, “Several development works are going on in the city. We have to put our all technical knowledge in it for which we have to attend these works for full-time of our duty hours. Many man-days are lost in attending non-technical works.”

The engineers claimed that they are held responsible if public infrastructure turns out to be of the sub-standard quality.

Title: Forest rights: 100 claims to be settled per mnth
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Margao: The South Goa district administration has set a target of disposing 100 claims per month over land rights made by forest dwelling scheduled tribes and other traditional forest dwellers under the Forest Rights Act.

After conducting a review meeting of the progress of processing of the claims with revenue and forest officials, South Goa district collector Ajit Roy exuded confidence of meeting the target. “We have upgraded our target of clearing claims to 100 every month. Recently 59 sanads were issued to claimants,” he said.

Taking cognisance of the lack of coordination between revenue and forest officials in matters regarding processing of claims, Roy is learnt to have put in place a mechanism to ensure synergy between the two departments.

Sources privy to the meeting said that Roy took stock of the factors delaying the disposal of the cases. Sources said that lack of documentation by claimants and the requirement of 50% quorum at gram sabhas have turned out to be major impediments in speedy processing of claims.

Sources pointed out to a resolution of a long-pending issue in Deusa-Deau in Quepem where the tribal claimants had objected to the forest survey conducted using Google maps in 2005, complaining that their houses and properties were not correctly shown in them.

“The satellite image didn’t show their houses and other structures as they were covered by trees and foliage. The revenue officials then relied on birth certificates produced by the tribals in support of their claims of community existence,” a source said.

Title: Fishermen hail top court’s verdict
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Alappuzha: Fishermen have hailed the Supreme Court verdict upholding the Kerala HC for demolishing the Kapico resort on Nediyathuruthu Island in Panavally grama panchayat here. According to A K Sailan, 53, an inland fisherman of Panavally, they started the legal battle against Kapico after the resort authorities removed 13 of their licensed stake nets.

Panavally grama panchayat president Pradeep Koodaikkal welcomed the SC verdict. “But we don’t have funds or expertise to demolish the buildings,” he said. Grama panchayat secretary Usha P M said that they have started revenue recovery procedures as the Kapico Resort failed to pay the building tax of Rs 66,80,731 from 2013-2014 to 2018-2019 first half.

District collector M Anjana said that they will start the action once they received the apex court order.

tnn

Title: Fog-related mishaps on highways expose Rajasthan government’s safety measures
Content:
Police attributed the rise in accidents to the tendency of overtaking

Times View Bikaner, Churu and Sriganganagar districts are notorious for foggy mornings and evenings during winters. Though several highway accidents have taken place at Deshnok, Lakshasar and Jophasar in Bikaner district due to poor visibility over the last few days, the administration is yet to wake up from its slumber. In fact, none of the district administrations has taken steps to curb accidents. Most of the major mishaps are followed by debates, discussions and assurances of new traffic guidelines, identification of dark patches, installation of reflectors and speed-breakers on accident-prone highways, but most of these remain on paper. The district administration, transport department and police need to team up to address the problem. A well-designed campaign should also be launched by them against private bus operators to ensure that speed-limits are adhered to. Police and administration should sit with private bus and truck operators and warn them of punitive action if road rules are flouted.

JAIPUR: At least 50 people lost their lives in November last year due to poor visibility owing to fog on National Highway-11 in Bikaner . Thursday’s accident — in which eight persons were killed in the collision between a van and a bus in Churu district — has exposed the lofty claims of the administration on curbing accidents.TOI on Friday spoke to district collectors of Bikaner and Churu, which have seen maximum number of accidents from November 2019 onwards.Though the district administration had advocated for some measures to curb road accidents especially when visibility becomes an issue due to fog, nothing concrete has been done. “Majority of the bus operators promise to decrease the travel time as they promise four hours to reach Jaipur from Bikaner which has a total distance of nearly 377km. This is the main problem which leads to accidents,” said Ratan Singh, a native of Deshnok.While the local administration had announced to take measures and issue some guidelines, nothing much has been done except pasting the phone numbers of police control rooms in various buses. “In most of the accidents, it was found that drivers were overtaking while speeding. We have spoken to the bus operators, transporters and other stakeholders and urged them to follow the rules,” said a senior police officer of Bikaner district.However, after Thursday’s accident, the district collector of Bikaner Kumar Pal Gautam made a visit to the highway and instructed police officials to be extra vigilant during foggy weather. “We have four interceptors and have identified 27 dark spots. There are some curves and some technical issues which need to be rectified. We have issued stickers to private and RSRTC bus operators that have important telephone numbers,” said Gautam.Churu district is no different where the police have got merely one interceptor and the district too has some grey areas. “We had written to the highway authorities to put some speed breakers, put reflectors and have also asked the Public Works and Engineering Department to make efforts in identifying the spots where the accidents have taken place,” said an officer. When contacted, Sandesh Nayak, district collector, Churu, said, “We have asked the police, DTOs and transport authorities to intensify patrolling during the early and late evening hours, when there is heavy fog.”Police attributed the rise in accidents to the tendency of overtaking.“We have urged private bus operators, transporters to avoid overtaking especially when visibility is poor. We have also pasted our numbers in buses so that when a driver of a bus drives rashly, any passenger in the bus can call up the police,” said a senior officer of Rajgarh police station in Churu.

Title: Colony mourns death of youngsters in Churu crash
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: Seven of the eight youngsters — who died after the van in which they were travelling in, collided head on with a bus coming from opposite direction on Bikaner-Churu highway — were childhood friends. People living in Subashpura locality in Bikaner were shocked and shattered to know that the youths played together, studied together and even died together.

A day after the fatal mishap, everyone, from a 10-year-old boy Shehshak to 66-year-old Barkatullah, were in tears and could not believe the nightmare. None of the natives of Subashpura locality had dinner on Thursday after the funeral of the eight youngsters killed in the accident . On Friday, majority of the people either visited the nearby temples or the mosques to offer prayers for the departed souls. “They used to play cricket together, were in school together and now they all departed together in the mishap,” Rehana Khatoon, a native of Subashpura locality told TOI over phone while sobbing.

The deceased were identified Shafeeq Khan (26), Ramzan (22) his brother Akram (23), Ansar Khan (23), Sadik Khan (23), Asif Hassan (23), Ankit Jangir (25) and Mohit (23).

“We were preparing for the wedding of Shafeeq Khan and his elder brother and suddenly we had to prepare for their burial. Everyone is shattered. God knows what the family will do,” said Arif Khan, one of the relatives of Shafeeq on Friday.

Title: Rajasthan: Class XII practical exams from January 15
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

AJMER: Practical exams of Class XII board exams of Rajasthan Board of Secondary Education will be held from 15 January to February 14. For private students, practical exams will be from February 11 to 14. The board has constituted 35 flying squads to keep vigil on board practical exams. Board secretary Meghna Choudhary said a control room has been set up on the board premises here.

In all, 4,39,860 students will appear for the practical exam out of which 2,37,656 are in science and 2,02,204 in humanities. Altogether 8,000 examiners have been appointed to conduct the examination and 35 flying squads will monitor the condition of laboratories and availability of equipment. If the control room receives any complaint, these squads will take action immediately. If a student remains absent on the date of practical exams with valid reason, the examiner will again conduct practical exam for that student in another batch with special permission.

Board the has given power to district education officers to appoint examiners for some subjects. In most of the subjects, it has appointed examiners to conduct practical examination.

The board has directed examiners to inform the control room about the date of practical exam by email. This year examiners can also file their bills online for payment to conduct practical exams.

Title: ‘Agnipariksha must for Modi, Shah on CAA, NRC’
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Swaraj Foundation and Akanksha Foundation jointly organized a lecture by lawyer Asim Sarode (left) on ‘Are CAA... Read More

Nagpur: Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Union home minister Amit Shah must go through ‘agnipariksha’ (acid test) like Sita as they have lost the trust of Indian citizens, said Pune-based lawyer Asim Sarode during a talk on ‘CAA/NRC Rashtrahitache Ahet Ka?’ at Dhanwate Sabhagruh, Shankar Nagar, on Friday.

Seeking the test as decreed on Sita by Lord Ram, Sarode said Modi and Shah must not make CAA and NRC a prestige issue. “The government must tell people in writing that it will not implement the Act,” Sarode said, during the talk organized by Swaraj Foundation and Akanksha Prakashan.

“Since December 29 last year, both Modi and Shah have made a U-turn on NRC while trying to allay apprehensions among Muslims that they wouldn’t become stateless after CAA is implemented,” he said.

Addressing a gathering of around 100 teachers, professionals and intellectuals, Sarode said he had made it clear before coming here that if the event was organized by Muslims he wouldn’t come. “Then, it becomes a communal affair which is exactly what Modi and Shah want to polarize people for votebank,” he said.

In a backhand compliment, Sarode said, “We need to thank Modi and Shah. We the people started understanding the Indian Constitution. In a society where law is left unto lawyers and courts to interpret, it is good the citizens are becoming aware.”

Flashing a copy of the Citizenship Act 1955, Sarode said the law without amendment was stringent enough to deal with “illegal immigrants” and intruders. “It was amended five times before 2014, but no one came to know about it. Why, because there was no ill-intention or criminal conspiracy,” he said, adding that the amendment plays a mischief.

In his over 90-minute speech, Sarode questioned Modi and Shah’s understanding of the Act and Constitution. “When uneducated people try to make a law, it is a foolish Act, but when religious fanatics do it, it becomes poisonous. Grave injustices were meted out to Babasaheb Ambedkar, but while framing the Constitution, he didn’t do anything to take revenge,” he said.

Sarode ridiculed home minister Shah for his now viral comment ‘understand the chronology’ by reading out a sequence of Supreme Court judgements, historical facts and developments since 1947 which clearly guarantee equality to all.

“No protests as seen now took place when the Act was being framed between 1947 and 1955,” he said.

The lawyer called for a “detox’ from the poison spread in people’s mind while dubbing CAA/NRC unconstitutional and discriminatory on religious basis.

Title: ACB raids sub-registrar offices across state
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Vijayawada: In a first, the Anti-Corruption Bureau ( ACB ) held simultaneous raids at various sub-registrar offices across the 13 districts in the state and recovered over Rs 10 lakh of unaccounted money on Friday.

According to officials, ACB had taken cognisance of complaints about corruption coming in via the new toll free number 14400 at various sub-registrar offices. While it has been conducting surprise checks in a suo-moto manner against sub-registrar offices, this was the first time that massive ACB teams were deployed to raid revenue offices.

In Vijayawada, ACB raided Gunadala sub-registrar office and seized Rs 19,240 of unaccounted money. According to rules, any money standing beyond Rs 5,000 brought into a government office by an employee has to be declared. However, all the SROs that ACB raided had undeclared cash in the official’s possession. The highest amount was recovered from Anantapuram rural SRO—Rs 2.15 lakh in cash. SROs in Palasa in Srikakulam and Kakinada in East Godavari had over Rs 1 lakh of unaccounted money.

Officials said this was just a one-day collection of unaccounted money from these offices and said the magnitude of corruption would be more if one calculated all working days in a year. Overall, Rs 10.34 lakh cash was recovered across 13 districts in AP.

Title: Kerala: All set, ready to go, says collector
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Jet Demolition senior manager Kevin Smith (right) and Edifice Engineering MD Utkarsh Mehta (left) explain the ... Read More

KOCHI: The district collector on Friday issued an order imposing section 144 of the CrPC, from 8am to 5pm on January 11 and 12, in the exclusion zone of the buildings to be demolished in Maradu .

Accordingly, no one will be allowed entry within a 200m radius from the point of the blast during this period. Unauthorised parking, operation of drones and lanterns in the region will not be permitted. Also, people will not be allowed to use any type of fireworks, electronic equipment or gadgets. Further, all traffic — by air, water and land — is prohibited in the evacuation zone.

“An immediate prevention and speedy remedy is desirable for the safety of the public from the apprehended danger of the event of demolition of flats using explosives that have the potential to cause trouble or damage to human life within 200m of the event and that there is sufficient ground for proceeding under Section 144 of CrPC,” said collector S Suhas in his order.

“If anyone contravenes the order, they will be punished under section 188 of IPC that attracts simple imprisonment for a month or fine up to Rs 200 or both; and if such disobedience causes danger to human life or safety or affray, then imprisonment can be up to six months or a fine of up to Rs 1,000 or with both,” the order said.

The decision to impose section 144 was taken after a high-level meeting last week. The meeting emphasised that people residing within 200m of the buildings need to be evacuated and traffic regulation needs to be implemented as part of safety measures.

“Demolition of the four buildings is a challenging task. However, all steps have been taken to ensure that everything goes according to plan. Also ‘plan B’ has been put in place in case of medical emergencies. But, we are hopeful that there will be no unfortunate happening,” the collector said.

Meanwhile, on the request of the city commissioner, the collector has declared an abandoned multi-storied building on the western side of the NH as unsafe and entry to this building has been prohibited.

The district collector said that he has asked muncipal authorities to conduct a cleaning drive after the implosion. “If the situation normalises before the scheduled time, the prohibition order will be lifted before 5pm. Buses for transporting residents to temporary lodging facilities will be available at designated spots from 7.30am. Special attention will be ensured for senior citizens who need medical care,” he said.

Four boats of the Kerala police will be anchored in the backwaters at the boundary of the exclusion zone to prevent other boats from entering the area.

Title: All households will be linked with sewerage line in Ajmer
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

AJMER: Akbari Fort Museum and five different places will be renovated and beautified to attract more tourists. The Ajmer Smart City Ltd (ASCL) has okayed Rs 94 crore for this project. Ajmer Municipal Corporation commissioner and ACEO of ASCL Chinmayee Gopal issued the notice of time-bound bidding.

The walls and the interiors of Akbari Fort and museum will be renovated with a cost of Rs 4.04 crore. Similarly, there will be landscaping at five places including Anasagar Link Road, Jaipur Road, Regional College Road and two more places along with beautification of surrounding areas at a cost of Rs 2.16 crore. The major work which ASCL has taken up is to give connection of the sewerage line which was repaired and made functional recently by the civic body. The municipal corporation will also improve the sewerage line in Chachiyawas, Ratidang, Alakhnanda and Eidgah Road at a cost of Rs 87 crore.

ASCL has taken up this project to stop dumping of sewerage water and drainage into Anasagar and will take the water to Khapura Lake on Beawar Road to treat and reuse it. ASCL is going to link every household with sewerage line to stop dumping of filthy water into Anasagar Lake as well as to close open drainage system in the city. Recently, ASCL has begun constructing natural birds’ park at old Vishram Sthali, where a natural habitat will be developed for birds.

Title: Fraudsters posing as policemen extort money from truck drivers
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: No sooner does night befall than a group of people, projecting themselves to be ‘policemen’ and using barricades used by cops, station themselves on the AS Club signal situated on the Waluj-Paithan cross road falling under the limits of MIDC Waluj police station to extort money from truck drivers.

This menace, besides occuring right under the nose of the police, is continuing despite the suspects getting caught once. While accessing the records at MIDC Waluj police station, TOI has found that a few days ago, while an assistant commissioner of police (ACP) was on his nightly patrolling duty, he nabbed the suspects, made a diary entry in the night register of the police control room as well that of the area police station, before handing them over to MIDC Waluj police.

Surprisingly, the suspects were let off without registering an offence or initiating any kind of preventive action against them citing that there was no complaint registered against them. The police inaction on these suspects has raised many eyebrows.

As per the night register of city police control room, ACP (city) H N Bhapkar had mentioned, “While being on night patrolling, three suspects holding torch in their hands and wearing black jackets were spotted waylaying the vehicles coming from Pune and diverting them on left side of road towards Golwadi toll plaza.” The entry also mentions about the suspects forcefully taking money from the truck drivers.

TOI has obtained a copy of the names of suspects who were nabbed by the ACP and handed over to MIDC Waluj police station. Sources claimed that despite being caught, it did not deter the suspects from continuing their illegal activity at the said point between 1am and 5am daily without fail. A police inspector said on the condition of anonymity, “Any person found committing such an act should be booked for robbery, impersonation as government official, if not extortion.”

Aurangabad commissioner of police Chiranjeev Prasad told TOI, “We have launched a probe into the matter and records are being scanned.”

When contacted, Bhapkar refused to comment on the issue. Policemen at the MIDC Waluj police station as well as the police control room confirmed about the entry made by the officer.

Sources said that the suspects standing at the AS Club signal prevented the vehicles coming from Pune and Paithan road to directly head towards the city via Ahmednagar naka. The suspects either took money from the truck drivers for letting them go towards the city directly. If not, they would force the truck drivers to divert towards Golwadi road and come to Ahmednagar Naka via Cantonment toll plaza. This toll plaza has several cases registered against it for charging several times more toll than the stipulated charges from the truck owners.

A policeman said, “The issue of charging an exorbitant toll from trucks coming from others states is nothing new. Despite registration of offences, the said practice continues at the toll plaza.” According to sources, this menace also occurs at Sharmapaur Phata daily.

Title: Maharashtra: Panel told to draft measures for stopping river pollution
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

KOLHAPUR: Maharashtra Pollution Control Board ’s state member secretary E Ravindran directed the panel appointed by the Bombay high court (HC) and the MPCB ’s local unit to draft a proposal enlisting the measures to stop pollution of Panchganga river.

He also asked the MPCB regional unit to provide portable machines to treat the waste water released from various establishments located at the textile town of Ichalkaranji.

Most of the waste water released from the city is treated at the sewage treatment plants (STPs) set up by the KMC. However, the waste water released from the villages, towns and effluents discharged from the sugar mills and industries is still causing river pollution .

Uday Gaikwad, expert member of the panel said, “The focus needs to be on managing the river flow. If the river flows continuously, the intensity of the pollution is reduced. Also, there is a need to reuse the treated waste water, especially for irrigation. We suggested that small STPs be set up for every three to four villages.”

Title: ‘Strict action against panchayats for neglecting waste duties’
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Porvorim: Panchayats minister Mauvin Godinho on Friday said the department was in the process of amending the Goa Panchayat Raj Act in order to take punitive action against village panchayat office bearers who are found negligent.

The amendments are aimed at holding panchayats accountable for solid waste management and development in the village, said Godinho while speaking to the media.

“At present, the government is not satisfied with the way the panchayats are managing the garbage. In future, some amendments to the Panchayati Raj Act are going to made. In those amendments, we want to bring in a rule that if a panchayat does not manage garbage properly and if there is a threat of diseases due to the garbage problem, then action could be initiated for remission of duty, neglect of duty and non-adherence to garbage rules,” said the minister.

Godinho also announced that the process to recruit additional panchayat secretaries had commenced.

When asked about the government’s move to create a common cadre for panchayats, Godinho said that disparity in the pay structure had thwarted the implementation of the proposal.

“We are in the process of compiling the data on creation of common cadre. Common cadre will be implemented as soon as possible, but the disparity in salaries is one of the issues that we have to sort out. Some panchayats like Candolim and Calangute are rich, while some panchayats need grants,” said the minister.

Asked about the zilla panchayat elections, Godinho said that the notification could be expected on January 15.

He ruled out a fresh delimitation exercise.

Title: Rajasthan: Cold wave revives, Fatehpur logs -1.8°C
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Men warm themselves by a fire on a cold winter day in Jaipur (File Photo)

JAIPUR: Cold wave conditions aggravated in the state on Friday when majority of the places witnessed a decline in their minimum and maximum temperatures. Fatehpur remained the coldest in the state with a minimum temperature of minus 1.8°C, the Met reports said.

Attributing the continued dip in mercury to the active northerly winds, Jaipur Met office said that there would be mild rise in the minimum and maximum temperatures across the state.

Jaipurites woke up to another chilly morning as a minimum temperature of 5.2°C was recorded in the city. Even in the afternoon, a minimum temperature of 20.0°C was recorded. The traffic on the highways connecting Jaipur to Agra, Jaipur to Delhi and Jaipur to Ajmer was chaotic due to poor visibility in the morning. The ongoing spell of cold wave conditions has badly affected those who live on the streets. With the revival of the cold wave conditions in the state, huge rush was seen at the night shelters across the city. In the evening, roads wore an empty look as people confined themselves to their homes.

Fatehpur was followed by Churu where a minimum temperature of 1.8°C was recorded, Udaipur 2.4°C, Bikaner 3.8°C, Sriganganagar 4.4°C, Kota 5.0°C, Ajmer 6.0°C, Jodhpur 6.4°C and a minimum temperature of 7.0°C was recorded in Barmer.

In its forecast, Jaipur Met office said that mercury is likely to take an upward swing across the state. Also, from Sunday onwards, due to the western disturbances, majority of the places would witness cloudy and foggy conditions.

Title: Kolkata: Police take stock of Naihati blast damage
Content:
CID bomb defusing squad visits Chhai Ghat at Naihati

KOLKATA: Nobel laureate , Charles R Walgreen distinguished service professor of behavioural science and economics at University of Chicago’s Booth School of Business, has a Kolkata connect. The legendary teacher will deliver the Professor Amitava Bose Memorial Lecture at the Indian Institute of Management (IIM) Calcutta on Monday and meet his university friends.Bose was Thaler’s junior from the University of Rochester, while Alok Ray, a retired professor of economics from IIM-C, Dipankar Dasgupta, former professor of economics at the Indian Statistical Institute, and Anjan Mukherji, emeritus professor of economics at Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU), were his contemporaries from the same university.The Nobel laureate, who called on Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Thursday, will deliver a lecture on ‘Doing Economics in the 21st Century’ at the event. IIM-C will host a dinner that the Nobel laureate will attend with his friends from the city.“Kolkata has a strong connection with the University of Rochester from the late 1960s, when several students from the city took admissions in the economics department. Professor Dipankar Dasgupta, a stalwart teacher of the subject at the Indian Statistical Institute (ISI), were friends with Thaler at the university. There is a long list of meritorious students and alumni from Calcutta University, who also have a strong connection with the Nobel Laureate,” said Abhishek Bose, son of Amitava Bose, who has instituted the lecture in commemoration of the former IIMC director.

Title: Tamil Nadu: 47-year-old rowdy found hanging
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: A 47-year-old history-sheeter involved in two murders and six other cases in Villupuram committed suicide by hanging at his rented house in Old Washermenpet on Friday.

Police said P Boobalan of Kuilapalayam near Auroville stayed with his wife Sonia and children in the house and ran an eatery in the locality. Police said the reason for Boobalan’s suicide is not known.

Initial inquiries revealed that Boobalan had reformed and stayed away from a life of crime for three years. His body was taken to Stanley Government Hospital for autopsy.

Title: Pipelines laid five months ago, yet to see water in Dammaiguda
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Even after five months of getting new water connections, residents of Dammaiguda are yet to receive water supply.In September last year, the Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWSSB) laid a new drinking water network in Dammaiguda, connecting colonies in the vicinity. However, residents are left to the mercy of private water suppliers for drinking water as the HMWSSB is yet to provide regular water supply.“We have to spend close to Rs 600-2,000 per month only for drinking water. For household chores, we have to depend on borewell water, which is contaminated due to the Jawahar Nagar dumping yard,” said Lakshmi Yelam, a resident.Not just water, poor road connectivity and sewerage network, lack of streetlights, public parks, community halls in colonies, rising dog population are among other issues that plague the areas under the Dammaiguda Municipality.“The municipality attributes every developmental issue to shortage of funds. Whether it is relaying or repairing of roads or installation of streetlights, we are bluntly informed that there insufficient funds to carry our any work,” said a resident.

Title: Rajasthan: Cold wave revives, Fatehpur logs -1.8°C
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Men warm themselves by a fire on a cold winter day in Jaipur (File Photo)

JAIPUR: Cold wave conditions aggravated in the state on Friday when majority of the places witnessed a decline in their minimum and maximum temperatures. Fatehpur remained the coldest in the state with a minimum temperature of minus 1.8°C, the Met reports said.

Attributing the continued dip in mercury to the active northerly winds, Jaipur Met office said that there would be mild rise in the minimum and maximum temperatures across the state.

Jaipurites woke up to another chilly morning as a minimum temperature of 5.2°C was recorded in the city. Even in the afternoon, a minimum temperature of 20.0°C was recorded. The ongoing spell of cold wave conditions has badly affected those who live on the streets. With the revival of the cold wave conditions in the state, huge rush was seen at the night shelters across the city. In the evening, roads wore an empty look as people confined themselves to their homes.

Fatehpur was followed by Churu where a minimum temperature of 1.8°C was recorded, Udaipur 2.4°C, Bikaner 3.8°C, Sriganganagar 4.4°C, Kota 5.0°C, Ajmer 6.0°C, Jodhpur 6.4°C and a minimum temperature of 7.0°C was recorded in Barmer.
