Title: Husband, friend arrested for twin murders in Jaipur
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Saurabh (left) & Rohit Tiwari

JAIPUR: Police arrested two for the murders of Shweta Tiwari and her 21-month-old son Shreyam in Pratap Nagar on Friday.

The murdered woman’s husband Rohit Tiwari and his friend’s brother-in-law Saurabh Chaudhary are the two who have been arrested by the city police.

Tiwari, who hails from Delhi, had planned the gruesome killings along with Chaudhary, who was paid an advance of Rs 20,000 to execute the crime, police said.

The husband had conspired to kill his wife and son as he wanted to “delete his back history” to get married again. Shweta, who hails from Kanpur, and the infant were bludgeoned to death by the hired killer on December 7.

Rohit paid the killer Rs 20,000 as advance on January 3 at a hotel near the airport. Both the accused have confessed to the crime. A team has been sent to Udaipur as well to detain the husband’s friend who had recommended the killer.

The brutal tale started in December 2019 when 35-year-old Rohit spoke to his friend Hari Singh, who was also his colleague at Indian Oil Corporation (IOC) in Udaipur, where he was posted prior to Jaipur.

While talking about his marital issues, Rohit told his friend that he wanted to do away with his wife and son. Singh recommended his own brother-in-law Chaudhary for the task. Chaudhary was also well known to the accused husband.

On December 23, Rohit disconnected the CCTV cameras within his office premises at the Jaipur airport which remained switched off till January 7.

After making up his mind, he got in touch with Chaudhary and they set up a meeting at a hotel on January 3. “The two met and chalked out the plan to kill the mother-son duo. Rohit gave Chaudhary the advance amount as well. They decided that the murder had to be carried out at a time when Rohit is at work so that he has an alibi,” said police commissioner Anand Shrivastav.

On January 5, Rohit and Shweta got into a fight and he thrashed her badly, even threw a heat blower at her. He also called her brother and threatened to kill her. Shweta also threatened to lodge a police case against him if he continued this behaviour.

Two days later, on January 7, Rohit left for work as usual and the same afternoon Chaudhary came to his apartment. Since he was well acquainted with the family, Shweta was not suspicious about Chaudhary’s sudden arrival.

“Chaudhary had tea with Shweta and while she was not looking, he got the pestle stone from the kitchen and hit her on the head multiple times and broke her jaw. After killing her, he went to the other room and strangled the baby before hitting him on the head with the same pestle stone,” elaborated Shrivastav. He had come to the house without any weapon.

However, he did not immediately flee from the scene and waited for 20-25 minutes at Rohit’s house. To further ensure that there were no survivors, he slit Shweta’s throat before leaving the house with the baby’s body which he dumped in the forest area. He also took Shweta’s phone and took out the SIM which he put in another mobile. After this, the killer called and messaged Rohit from his wife’s number, with ransom demands. The ransom demands continued even after the child’s body was found on January 8.

After the murders, Chaudhary roamed around in the city before heading back to his house at night. Though he is a native of Agra, he resided in Sanganer.

Explaining how the case was cracked, Shrivastav said, “We were already questioning Rohit and at the same time our teams of over 200 cops were conducting door-to-door checks and trying to find out who all had visited the family’s flat on the day of the murders and before that. We checked call records as well as conducting continuous recce of the area. Linking the facts together, we zeroed down on Chaudhary and using traditional investigative methods, connected both the accused and arrested them.”

Title: Sambhajiraje Chhatrapati to observe hunger strike
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Sambhajiraje Chhatrapati

KOLHAPUR: Rajya Sabha MP Sambhajiraje Chhatrapati will observe one-day hunger strike at Pune-based Chhatrapati Chhatrapati Shahu Maharaj Research, Training and Human Development Institute (SARTHI) on Saturday.

SARTHI was set up early last year to provide the educational and employment consultancy to the students from Maratha and Maratha-kunabi community. Sambhajiraje received several complaints from the students over poor functioning of the institute located along Agharkar Road.

The MP claimed that few days ago he met chief minister Uddhav Thackeray and told him about the situation of the institute. “The CM had assured me that he will attend all the issues once the cabinet expansion takes place. I am going on one-day hunger strike and hundreds of students and activists from the community are going to participate. Since last many months, students are not getting scholarships, the financial aid assured for the students opting for competitive exams has not yet been fulfilled,” said Sambhajiraje.

The institute has been set up on the lines of BARTI (Babasaheb Ambedkar Research and Technical Institution), another Pune based institute which provides training to the backward class students for competitive exams.

Title: FASTag deadline approaches,yet traffic crawls at toll plazas
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Bengaluru: With only a few days left for all except one lane at toll plazas on national highways across the country to shift to FASTag-only mode, Karnataka seems to be lagging. While the share of FASTag in total transactions is hovering around 46% in the state, not much is being done to deter motorists without FASTag from straying into the cashless lanes.

The Ministry of Road Transport and Highways (MORTH) had last month stated that motorists entering FASTag lanes without the stickers will have to pay double the toll. The penalty was expected to force motorists to get FASTags instead of paying double toll or spending time in long queues on manual toll fee lanes.

However, only seven of the 37 toll plazas on national highways in Karnataka are levying the double toll. Only about 3,000 such cases have been booked between December 15 and January 7 and Rs 3.15 lakh has been collected as penalty by National Highways Authority of India ( NHAI ) from FASTag lane violators.

The double toll is being collected only at Nelamangala, Belur, Hejamady, Sasthan, Talapady, Brahamarkotlu and Suratkal toll plazas.

As predicted by the central ministry, the FASTag system has not been successful in reducing the waiting time at toll plazas in the state, motorists allege. Besides, system errors and glitches continue to affect the smooth rollout of the system in the state, they allege.

“I was travelling through the Sadahalli toll plaza near the airport recently when the system failed to detect my FASTag. The FASTag scanner there is unable to read stickers sometimes. Authorities should solve these issues before rolling out the system. This is leading to congestion in the FASTag lanes as well,” said Dipti A, a commuter.

Other motorists also pointed to double debits at a few toll plazas where toll operators collect cash from commuters citing glitches in the reader, after which the amount also gets debited automatically.

NHAI, Karnataka officials have expressed concern over whether the system will be rolled out without glitches, come January 15. While raising doubts about achieving the 100% FASTag toll collection goal by January 15, they have once again requested cabs to make the switch to FASTags.

“Although the race to buy FASTags has not picked up pace yet, right before the January 15 deadline, we expect to see another bout of people scrambling to buy FASTags,” said an NHAI official.

Earlier, all but one lane at toll plazas had to become FASTag-enabled by December 1, 2019. The Centre put off the implementation date to December 15, before postponing it again to January 15, 2020.

Title: Part of Goa’s SWR route to be ready by March next yr
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Margao: The South Western Railway (SWR) has set March 2021 as the tentative target to make the Margao-Sanvordem double-tracked route operational. Once accomplished, the partial Goa stretch will be the first to be made functional. It is part of the ongoing Hospet-Hubli-Tinaighat-Vasco double-tracking project.

Rail Vikas Nikas Ltd GM Sashibhushan Sahoo told TOI that the trial run of the route will be conducted by March this year. “We have completed over 75% of double-tracking on the Margao-Sanvordem stretch. We are awaiting a clearance from the National Wildlife Board to start work on the Castle Rock-Collem stretch. While we are aiming to operationalise the Margao-Sanvordem route by March 2021, the Sanvordem-Kalay stretch is likely to be completed by June-December 2021,” Sahoo said.

South Goa collector Ajit Roy on Thursday held a review meeting with senior officials of the district administration over SWR’s double-tracking project, particularly with regard to opposition to land acquisition by the locals between the Majorda and Vasco railway stations. “There are some bottlenecks in this stretch and we are working things out,” Roy told TOI.

“A notice inviting tenders has been issued for the 17-km Majorda-Vasco stretch,” Sahoo said. “We have fixed three-year time frame to complete this stretch.”

Signalling its intent to fast-track the project, the railways ministry has notified the Hospet-Hubli-Tinaigat-Vasco doubling project in Goa as the ‘special railway project’ which, Sahoo said, would facilitate the Indian Railways to acquire land under the Railways Act, 1989 in areas where the state government has failed to do so. The ministry has also notified road over-bridge (ROB) projects at Xelvon, Nessai and Cansaulim as special railway projects.

Under the Railways Act, a special project refers to one notified by the central government “for providing national infrastructure for a public purpose in a specified time frame”. The notification will come into effect from the date it is published in the Gazette.

Title: Rain paints Chennai suburbs green
Content:
Workers from Andhra Pradesh have been engaged in fields in Tiruvallur district

CHENNAI: This time last year, driving out of Chennai you would be greeted by barren brown fields as the city and its suburbs faced a drought-like situation after the monsoon failed in 2018. Now these same areas are a sea of green as farmers in Avadi, Poonamallee, Chitlapakkam and Tiruporur have planted paddy to cash in on the rains of 2019, which have left their wells and tanks brimming.Kancheepuram and Chengalpet districts have a total of 924 tanks, and most of them are filled to the brim. The result? The area under paddy and other crops has shot up.Data sourced by TOI from the agriculture department shows that 3,475 hectares are currently under crop across Chitlapakkam, Kattankulathur and Tiruporur blocks of Chengalpet district. This is 500 acres more than in 2017, when the suburb received a similar quantum of rain .In neighbouring Tiruvallur district, the area under crop has risen by a few thousand hectares in villages adjoining the city. Official data recorded till December 2019 showed farming was on in full swing in Avadi, Poonamallee, Minjur and Sholavaram blocks, spread across nearly 38,000 hectares. Of this, 88% constitutes paddy, while pulses, millets and oil seeds make up the rest. “In the next three months, the total area under cultivation would cross the 45,800 acres recorded in 2016-17,” said an agriculture department official at Tiruvallur.Agriculture department sources said a bumper harvest was in the offing as the suburbs recorded the right amount of rainfall, neither excess nor deficit. The areas have recorded a new high in area under crop since 2015, when floods swept clean some of these agrarian pockets.N Ramesh, a 67-year-old farmer from Mambakkam near Tambaram, said around 300 acres had been cultivated this year in his village. Neighbouring villages such as Ponmar also saw an increase in area under cultivation. “The main encouragement for farmers to take up cultivation despite shortage of farmhands and increase in fertilizer prices was the availability of adequate water. We expect a decent harvest without monetary losses this time,” he said.Pinning hope on good returns, farmers in Tiruvallur have brought in workers from Vijayawada and Machilipatnam in Andhra Pradesh. Dhananchezhiyan, a farmer from Thirunelai near Redhills, said, “The workers come in groups, stay for a month for sowing. Despite all the toil, farmers get barely reasonable returns while middlemen and traders pocket all the profit.”.Farmers in Sholavaram and Minjur blocks have raised concerns over pest attack. Dhananchezhiyan said several hundred hectares of paddy had been hit by brown plant hopper attack. “This will reduce yield to 19 bags per acre from 36 bags. The total harvest will, however, match last year’s yield as the cultivated area has increased,” he added.Agriculture department officials said farmers in Tiruvallur had chosen a paddy variety susceptible to pest attack. “We suggested TKM 13, a variety that can sustain in different climatic conditions and is less vulnerable to pest attack. But farmers preferred BPT 5024, which attracts better market rates,” the official said.

Title: Andhra Pradesh high court to get four new judges
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: A gazette notification was issued by the Union ministry of law and justice after the President gave his assent to appointment four new judges to the Andhra Pradesh high court .

The Supreme Court collegium had recommended Rao Raghunandan Rao, Battu Devanand, Donadi Ramesh and Ninala Jayasurya as judges of the Andhra Pradesh high court.

Accepting the recommendations, the Union government had sent the proposal to the President of India Ramnath Kovind.

As the President gave his assent to the proposal, a gazette notification has been issued on Friday appointing them as judges of Andhra Pradesh high court.

With the appointment of four new judges, the strength of the high court has reached 18 against the sanctioned strength of 37 judges. All the four newly appointed judges are practising advocates in the high court.

Title: Cop held under MCOCA for links with Rinda gang
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: The in-charge of Mangrulpeer police station of Washim district, Vinod Dighore, has been arrested by Nanded police under the stringent Maharashtra Control of Organised Crime Act (MCOCA) for his alleged connections with the notorious Rinda Gang.

The kingpin of the gang, Dilpreet Rinda, is wanted by police in different parts of the country, especially Maharashtra and Punjab. He has 17 offences registered against him in Nanded, while 25 offences are registered in different parts of Punjab.

Dighore was produced before the special MCOCA court on Friday and has been remanded in seven-day police custody.

According to sources, the suspect was part of the special squad of Nanded police’s local crime branch that was formed to arrest Rinda. At that time Dighore was an assistant inspector.

The hardened criminal, who has a bounty of several lakhs on his head, is accused of murder, extortion and kidnapping.

He is known for posting his photographs on Facebook with sophisticated firearms including AK-47. The criminal with suspected links to banned terror outfits from Punjab is also on the radar of the anti-terror squad (ATS).

Nanded superintendent of police Vijaykumar Magar told TOI, “While working on the Govind Kokulwar attempt to murder case, technical analysis revealed Dighore’s connection with Rinda gang following which he has been arrested.”

Expressing displeasure over an officer’s alleged connection with a wanted criminal, Magar said there is barely anything on record to show Dighore was in touch with the criminal as part of his assigned job to nail the criminal.

On August 17, 2019, Kokulwar — a Congress leader and former corporator known for his proximity to incumbent PWD minister Ashok Chavan — was shot at. Probing the case, the Nanded police managed to arrest six accused including Viru Bhandari, a key man of Rinda gang.

Investigation revealed that the firing was the result of a futile attempt by Rinda gang to extort money from Kokulwar.

The probe also pointed out that after learning about Kokulwar getting extortion calls, the officer instead of registering an offence and providing security, kept the information under wraps and allegedly remained in touch with members of Rinda gang.

Authorities informed that Dighore has a tainted service record and he has faced departmental actions in the form of suspension, stopping of increments and so on.

He joined as constable in the police department in Nagpur, before cracking inter-departmental exam and becoming a police sub-inspector and serving in Nagpur during the initial years.

Title: KMC’s pollution control measures satisfactory: NGT
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

National Green Tribunal

KOLHAPUR: After five years of regular hearings, the National Green Tribunal ( NGT ) has finally disposed the petition filed by a city based activist over pollution of Rankala lake and Panchganga river.

During a hearing held on Tuesday, the NGT found that the progress made by the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) to stop pollution of both the waterbodies is satisfactory.

The NGT also referred to the report submitted by Maharashtra Pollution Control Board ( MPCB ) which claimed that around 95% of the waste water generated in the city has been brought under treatment and only miniscule amount is currently released into the river.

Sunil Kemble, the petitioner, said, “The NGT in its last hearing maintained that the KMC has been able to get most of the waste water generated in the city treated. Works of diversion of nullahs is in the last stage of completion and soon most of the waste water will be released into the river only after treatment. I am satisfied that with my petition the issue of pollution was taken seriously.”

The filed petition initially objected to the works proposed to rejuvenate Rankala lake. The NGT earlier had observed that the proposed works should be scrapped as the works will not help much on addressing the pollution of the lake.

Instead, the court directed the KMC to speed up the pending work of Dudhali-based sewage treatment plant, obstruct the flow of sewage directly entering the lake. Accordingly a year ago, the KMC finally managed to commission the STP. In subsequent hearings, the issue of pollution of Panchganga river was raised and the directions were given to the KMC time-to-time.

A senior KMC official said, “The MPCB was asked to conduct third party audit of the works undertaken by us. According to MPCB, we have managed to bring 95% of waste water under the treatment system. The court is satisfied with our efforts and therefore disposed the petition. We are committed to treatment of 100% of waste water and in following days various other measures will be taken to ensure that every drop of waste water entering the river is treated.”

Title: Approach BDOs to obtain approval for large projects
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Porvorim: Following the January 1 circular restricting panchayats from issuing construction and occupancy approvals, the panchayat department has now issued a fresh circular with guidelines for large residential or commercial projects to approach Block Development Officers (BDOs) for the necessary approvals, said panchayat minister Mauvin Godinho.

The minister said that the intention of the fresh guidelines is to streamline the approval process and to ensure that real estate firms comply with solid waste management rules.

“Panchayats have no expertise to deal with garbage disposal; as a result, we have to send our technical people from the BDO to check if they have implemented scientific methods of garbage management or not,” said the minister.

He said that the purpose of the two circulars has been misunderstood by the village panchayats. Several panchayat office-bearers had held a meeting a few days earlier, slamming the government for trying to override the powers of the panchayats.

Speaking to the media on Friday, Godinho blamed the ‘lethargic’ steps taken by the panchayats for the government’s decision to intervene in the matter.

“I have seen that most of the panchayats are lethargic in picking up and maintaining cleanliness. Efforts being made are not as we expected, and the high court is breathing down our necks. It is our responsibility since we are the ones who have to file affidavits in court,” the minister said.

He then went on to explain that the change in the approval process was necessary in order to ensure that the courts did not issue a halt on construction in the state.

Presently, out of the 191 village panchayats, 87 villages have applied for funds to set up the material recovery facilities (MRF) while 67 village panchayats have identified sites to setup MRF facilities.

Title: Min Kalla rules out liquor ban in state
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Jaipur: The high-powered committee set up under senior cabinet minister BD Kalla to study the demand for liquor prohibition has ruled it out.

In its meeting on Friday, the committee, which included representatives of NGOs, said efforts would be made to reduce consumption of alcohol by creating awareness among people by highlighting its bad effects.

The minister said the government would take steps to reduce alcohol consumption, but no prohibition.

Kalla said full prohibition is in force in Gujarat and Bihar, but the experience of the ban in Gujarat was not good. Liquor is easily available there, he said. However, the department and NGO officials will visit Gujarat and Bihar to see the situation. “I can say with certainty that there will be no prohibition in Rajasthan.” He said the government had sent an official team to Bihar to study the effectiveness of the measure there. Now a team would be sent to Gujarat as well. The NGO representatives would also be made part of the delegation so that they could get first-hand information.

On the new liquor policy, Kalla said heritage hotels and historic buildings, which are frequented by foreign tourists, would be given liquor licenses. Apart from this, no new licenses will be issued, he said. The meeting was attended among others included medical and health minister Raghu Sharma, ACS (Home) Rajiv Swaroop, Excise Commissioner Vishnu Charan Malik, Finance Secretary Revenue Dr Prithvi, Pooja Chhabra associated with liquor ban drive. tnn

Title: SSKM Hospitals’ Woodburn Cabin 12.5 to be open for weekend
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

The cabin had earlier been used by many ministers but since 2011, it has been reserved for VVIPs under SPG pro... Read More

KOLKATA: Cabin No. 12.5 at SSKM Hospitals’ Woodburn ward remains under lock and key for most part of the year, except for cleaning early every morning. But hectic sprucing has been on over the past few weeks, as the hospital authorities will keep it ready for the weekend in case Prime Minister Narendra Modi requires any medical care during his visit to the city.

Since 2011, the cabin has been reserved for treatment for the PM, covered under Special Protection Group, which provides proximate security to the Prime Minister. According to the protocol, there has to be a health facility, with a special set-up, close to the place, where the PM stays overnight, in case the need arises. After arriving in the city on Saturday, Modi will stay the night at Raj Bhawan. Given its proximity, Institute of Post Graduate Medical Education and Research (IPGMER), better known as SSKM Hospital , has been chosen. The special security force will on Saturday take guard outside the cabin, which will again be shut once Modi leaves on Sunday.

“Following protocols, we are keeping the all facilities ready, including the special cabin at Woodburn ward, a medical team and an ambulance,” said IPGMER medical superintend and vice-principal Raghunath Misra. A team of doctor, comprising specialists in medicine, cardiology, anaesthesia and surgery, has been constituted. They will be backed by a team of technicians and nursing staff. A critical-care ambulance, complete with emergency care, and units of blood, matching that of Modi, will be kept on standby. Cabin 12.5 has four rooms, a retiring room, an examination room for patients, complete with portable gadgets, a dining room and an ante-chamber.

The hospital was founded way back in 1707. Initially built for the Europeans till 1770, the facility was known as Presidency Hospital. It was later named Presidency General Hospital or P G Hospital and in 1954, renamed Seth Sukhlal Karnani Memorial Hospital. The Woodburn ward was built between 1902 and 1908. Since 13 is considered unlucky, the cabin, flanked by 6 rooms on each side, became No. 12.5 when the British built it. The nomenclature continues.

The cabin had earlier been used by many ministers but since 2011, it has been reserved for VVIPs under SPG protection. Currently, only PM is covered by the special force. “No one protected by the SPG has had the need to be in the cabin in the recent past. We hope the occasion does not arise for Modi either. But no one knows. So, the hospital is keeping everything ready,” said a senior official at the hospital.

Title: Stir against CAA has to succeed: Oommen Chandy
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

High court judge Justice (Retd)B Kemal Pasha handing over the national flag to Ernakulam MP Hibi Eden, marking... Read More

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: AICC general secretary Oommen Chandy said that the agitation against Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ), which has spread across the country, has to succeed as the legislation has “thrown an open a challenge to the country’s secular credentials”.

“The ongoing agitations are to protect our democratic values and secular credentials. Hence, we cannot lose the battle against the challenge which has been thrown open by BJP and Sangh Parivar,” Chandy said. He was speaking at the function organized to conclude the 24-hour fast by former KPCC president M M Hassan before Raj Bhavan.

“If the agitation fails, then it would mean that the 130 crore people of the country have lost their battle. Our democracy and secularism cannot be surrendered before Narendra Modi and Amit Shah. They have come up with the Act with an aim to communally divide the country,” said Chandy.

“People have the right to dissent. But Modi-Shah combine is silencing dissenting voices using police, which is totally unjustifiable,” he said.

The former chief minister also slammed governor Arif Mohammed Khan for “advocating CAA with more vigour than BJP”. “His words and actions do not suit the position he holds. No governor in the country has come out supporting CAA like Khan. He has more enthusiasm than BJP leaders,” Chandy added.

Title: Debris may change pH of lake water
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Police arrive for duty a day before the demolition of apartment complexes

MARADU: The district administration and other departments concerned should consider cleaning up of the Vembanad lakebed in the region as the mixing of debris generated from the demolition of four illegal apartment complexes may lead to variation in the pH value of the water, said Kerala University of Fisheries and Ocean Sciences (Kufos) vice-chancellor A Ramachandran.

He said that even a slight variation in the pH value of water may seriously affect the fish population in the lakebed. “In case of any heavy debris falling in the lake, it should be removed as early as possible,” he said.

“Fish tend to migrate for survival. If a portion of the debris fall in the nearby lake, the aquatic species will migrate to a safer place. But if the blocks of heavy concrete debris remained in the lakebed forever, it may lead to severe ecological problems. So, the district administration as well as the state government should act promptly to clear the huge from the lake as early as possible,” he said.

Meanwhile, experts said that geological impact of the controlled implosions must be studied. “There is no cause for panic as the expected tremor due to the blasts will be of the magnitude of 2 and 3 in the Richter scale,” said K T Damodaran, geologist, and former director of school of marine sciences, Cochin University of Science and Technology. “It may cause just a jerk in the surrounding buildings which may lead to minor vibrations and rattling of the window panes,” he said.

“As the demolition will be carried out by controlled implosions and it is up to the ground level, there is a remote chance for tremor,” said K N Krishnakumar, deputy director, Collegiate Education, Kottayam.

Title: Goa: Panaji cops create messaging group to curb rented car, bike thefts
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: To combat the increasing cases of rent-a-bike and rent-a-car thefts in the city, Panaji police have turned to a messaging app.

Police have created a group on the messaging app and added all Panaji-based rent-a-bike and rent-a-car operators and directed them to upload photographs and identity proofs of their customer to help them check for any criminal records using the Crime and Criminal Tracking Network and Systems (CCTNS).

During the last couple of days several rent-a-bike and rent-a-car theft cases have been reported at the Panaji police station, Panaji PI Sudesh Naik told TOI. Among those who have reported thefts are also those who rented their private two- and four-wheelers, he said.

In many cases, police said they had found that those hiring the vehicle had submitted fake id proofs. In some other cases, police found that the vehicle had been abandoned.

Panaji police on Friday held a meeting with rent-a-bike and rent-a-car owners during which they cautioned them from renting out vehicles without collecting photographs and identity proofs from customers as the data is of vital importance in case need to track someone arises. Police asked rent-a-car and rent-a-bike operators to strictly maintain a register with identity details of all their clients.

Title: Kill zone: Chennai third among metros in 2018
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: There weren’t any gang wars, communal conflicts or dacoities, but Chennai recorded the third highest number of murders in 2018 among the country’s metros .Personal enmity and petty quarrels accounted for more than half the murders, pushing the number up by 11% in one year, according to the latest report of the National Crime Records Bureau.The 172 murders in Chennai in 2018 come behind Delhi’s 416 and Bengaluru’s 218. Mumbai stood fourth with 164.Until 2016, most metros recorded a decline in murders, but some like Chennai have seen a steady increase. While, 27% of the murders were due to enmity, 23% of them were because of petty quarrels. About 18% of the murders were crimes of passion over extramarital relationships or love affairs.Police commissioner A K Viswanathan said, “We can curtail murders by improving the police patrolling in the neighbourhood. They can also be reduced by focussing more to get conviction in all cases, which will play a deterrent role.”Data gathered from the state’s ambulance service and from city hospitals reveals the details about the incidence of murderous attacks. Two of five patients brought into the emergency department across the state with traumatic injuries is a victim of assault, according to data available with the Tamil Nadu Accident and Trauma Initiative. For instance, of 764 admissions on January 8, there were 321 cases of assault, 482 road accident victims and 623 falls.The ratio isn’t very different for city hospitals, say health department officials. Assault cases include a wide range of cases from drunken brawls to petty quarrels and fisticuffs. The mortality in assault cases is not as high as road accidents, where injured are at risk of death. “In most fights, the injury is not big. But when the motive is to kill, the patients suffer grevious wounds and risk of death in these cases is also higher,” said Rajiv Gandhi Government General Hospital dean Dr R Jayanthi. On January 8, while an assault victim died in the hospital, there were nine road accident deaths.

Title: Fresh attack by pink locusts most destructive: Government body
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

The new swarm of locusts has created panic among the farmers

JAIPUR: The Locust Warning Organization (LWO) has raised a red flag on the fresh wave of locust attack to be the most destructive lot to the ministry of agriculture and the state government. The fresh swarm of locusts entered from Pakistan are neither black nor yellow. They are Pink in color and are called adult locust with very high capacity to eat and stamina for long distance migration.

The LWO has feared that they can fly into far off places due to their stronger capacity has send chill down the line among the farmers of the affected area.

Sharing the details of the fresh wave of attack, ML Gujjar, head of Locust Warning Organization (LWO) based in Jodhpur says, “The pink coloured locust is destructive among all breeds of locust. It is 30-45 days of age with very strong wings than the usual black and yellow ones. They fly in gregarious format with speed faster among all breeds and are fatal for rabi crops in progress.”

Union Jal Shakti minister Gajendra Singh Shekhawat will visit the locust affected villages in Jodhpur on Saturday. He will visit villages in Luni and Pokharan areas of Jodhpur. The movement of Pink Locust has been noticed in Khajuwala in Bikaner and some parts of Barmer on Friday. The LWO team has rushed to affected areas to restrict their movements. Another striking feature which has shocked the LWO officials is that India-Pakistan border has always been the breeding ground for locust during summers and Iran during winters. “For the first time, we have witnessed this phenomenon that Pink locust are also breeding in the affected area in India,” said Gujjar.

Union ministry of agriculture is also facing a challenge to deal with the attack happening since May 23. Known as crop savouring insect, the United Nation’s Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) is play a vital role in minimizing the danger of Locust in countries like Pakistan, Afghanistan, Iran and middle eastern countries to west African ones. “So far, the movement of locust has been restricted to desert districts. We are revising our strategy to deal with the fresh swarms before it reaches any major urban area,” said Gujjar. Figure says that 3.5 lakh hectare of land has been covered by the locust attack since May. The financial assessment of the damage caused to Kharif and now Rabi crop has yet to be made by the agriculture department.

Title: Rajasthan home department forbids use of manjha
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: The state's home department on Friday prohibited use of manjha for kite flying. Additional chief secretary (ACS), Home, Rajeeva Swarup wrote to all district magistrates and police commissioners of Jaipur and Jodhpur in this regard. It has been directed to ensure that kite flying is avoided from 6am to 8am and 5pm to 7pm.

Swarup asked the officials concerned to ensure that due publicity is given, particularly, before Makar Sankranti and sale of such banned material should be stopped for the purpose of kite flying.

Title: KMC staff beats AIMIM office-bearer, six booked
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

KOLHAPUR: A major scuffle broke between the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) staff and All India Majlis-e-Ittehadul Muslimeen (AIMIM) on Friday morning at KMC the building, which saw one party official being badly beaten.

The locals from the Sadar Bazaar area had arrived at KMC building demanding the housing unit for a local person named Sujit Mane. However, the officials claimed that the person owing to certain conditions cannot be granted the housing unit. Mane had earlier moved a petition in the local court, which too stated that he is not eligible for the housing unit. The locals were enraged as they carried out the march to the KMC building.

Harshajit Ghatge, divisional engineer of KMC said, “We were in the meeting as I got the call from one of the locals, who started abusing me. We stated the current status of the case of the housing units provided under ‘Gharkul Scheme’. However, some of them started manhandling us.”

In response, the KMC staff beat Shahid Sheikh, AIMIM’s the spokesperson who led the march. Sheikh got himself admitted in the Chhatrapati Pramila Raje Civil Hospital (CPR) due to the heavy beating. Subsequently, some of the locals moved to Lakshmipuri Police Station to register the case. Officials led by Ghatge too arrived at the police station to register the case. As an evening, the process of registering the case from both sides was going on.

Ghatge said that the protesters had met him on Thursday with their grievances. The protesters claimed that the KMC officials misbehaved with them and therefore they took the march to KMC. Sheikh said that the complaint against the officials has also been submitted to the civic chief Mallinath Kalshetti.

Meanwhile, Lakshmipuri police station lodged FIR against six identified persons and three unknown after the police complaint filed by Ghatge. The FIR has been registered under IPC sections-353, 332, 143, 147, 323, 506 mostly related to abusing, manhandling, obstructing public duty and hurting. The six people who are booked are Shahid Sheikh, Sujit Mane, Suhail Bagwan, Imran Sheikh, Pravin Waghmare and Toufik Mulla.

Title: CM Pinarayi Vijayan calls for a united front against Citizenship (Amendment) Act
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

CM Pinarayi Vijayan

KOCHI: The chief minister called on the opposition to stand together as a single force to get the Centre to withdraw the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ).

Speaking after inaugurating the Bharanagatana Samrakshana Sangamam to protest against CAA, the chief minister called on all political parties including the main opposition to set aside their party internal squabbles and join hands in the protests against the communal agenda of the Sangh Parivar .

Equating the stand taken by the RSS to divide India based on religious grounds, he said that this has been their agenda as they wanted the country to become like Germany. “We all know the Germany of those days which was led by Hitler and his annhilation of the Jews. Similarly, the RSS and the Sangh Parivar are against the Muslims, Christians and Communists,” he said.

He said that the CAA protests are similar to the freedom struggle which saw the youth come out in large numbers as all campuses are erupting with protests. “What is happening in JNU has shocked the nation but the students have already said that they would continue to protests despite being attacked by goons and police,” said the CM.

“India was a highly respected country in the world because of its democratic values but today there is no nation in the world that has not expressed its displeasure over the happenings in the last couple of months,” Vijayan said

Title: YSRC jittery over TDP man breaching CM YS Jaganmohan Reddy’s security ring
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

CM YS Jaganmohan Reddy

AMARAVATI: The YSRC cadres are worried that a staunch TDP supporter was able to get near chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy several times in the last few weeks.

According to sources said VKS Reddy from Kurnool district found Bandaru Saidarao from Chandarlapadu village in Nandigama constituency moving in the CM’s inner circle in the last few days. Rao was seen behind the CM during Amma Vodi public meeting held in Chittoor on Thursday.

According to Reddy, Rao is a staunch TDP follower in Nandigama constituency in Krishna district. Saida Rao, who worked as an outsourcing employee in the secretariat during the TDP regime, gained entry into the CM’s close circle. Reddy retrieved many of Saida Rao’s video posts on social media backing TDP and Chandrababu Naidu.

Rao was also seen lashing out at YS Jagan in his video-posts on social media. He was also seen making critical comments against Jagan after an attempt on his life was made in Visakhapatnam airport before the elections.

Several of his posts were directly linked to CBN army, TDP’s youth wing.

“I don’t know whether he is still working in the secretariat or somewhere else. I am not even demanding to oust him from his job. I am concerned about our chief minister’s safety,” said VKS Reddy in his message to the top YSRC leadership.

Sources said the YSRC leadership has launched a probe into the alleged security breach. It is not clear whether they have brought the issue to the notice of police and security personnel. YSRC cadre are worried about the safety of the chief minister especially after the attempt made on Jagan before the elections.

They are afraid that someone might try to harm the chief minister in the wake of his plans to shift the capital city from Amaravati.

Title: Bombay high court issues notice to co-op department officials
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: The Aurangabad bench of Bombay High Court has issued notices to the officials of cooperative department, police and office-bearers of a defunct cooperative housing society that continued to function despite cancellation of its registration.

Col Pawan Kumar Sharma (retd.) approached the high court through lawyer NL Jadhav, seeking directions to the police to register an FIR against office-bearers of the dissolved KDR Farms Cooperative Housing Society for allegedly misrepresenting facts involving a high court order.

As per Sharma’s petition, the housing society was wrongfully claiming that were carrying out works in the KDR Farms premises, spread across 17 acre on the outskirts of the city, with orders from the high court. In fact, the court had ordered a status quo and disallowed them to carry out works.

The petitioner contended that he had bought the plot by registered sale deed on October 1, 2003, but the builder had failed to provide amenities he had promised. “However, in collusion with some second-hand purchasers of the plots at the KDR Farms, the builder illegally registered a cooperative housing society,” Sharma said.

The petitioner had challenged this and accordingly the divisional registrar of cooperative society cancelled the registration of the society in January 2011. It was challenged by one of the respondents Rajendra Kulkarni, before the then cooperative minister, who rejected his plea.

Chairman of the defunct society and Kulkarni challenged the divisional registrar’s decision and minister’s verdict before the court in December 2015 on which the court ordered status quo.

Still an advertisement was published in newspapers by the society in January 2019 inviting tenders to repair the road which cannot be done as the society was not in existence.

Following the petition, the bench comprising justices TV Nalawade and SM Gavhane ordered issuance of notices to the seven respondents, including the government, police and the officials of the cooperative department and the two office-bearers of the defunct society returnable on January 14.

Title: SIT to probe Avni’s shooting, says minister
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Nagpur: The Shiv Sena-led Maharashtra Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government will reopen the shooting of Pandharkawda tigress T1 or Avni by setting up a special investigating team (SIT) to look into the lapses that led to the killing.

Talking to TOI on Friday, housing minister Jitendra Awhad said, “Though the structure of SIT has not been decided, we have asked forest minister Sanjay Rathod to do the needful as there is demand by the aggrieved parties.”

“Three days ago, wildlife lover and Nagpur-based Dr Jerryl Banait had submitted a memorandum to me. He also met chief minister Uddhav Thackeray and environment minister Aditya Thackeray and apprised them of the lapses. Chief minister too has agreed to the demand,” said Awhad.

Forest minister Sanjay Rathod from Shiv Sena, who was on tour of his constituency in Digras, was not available for comments. Forest ministry too was clueless about the demand.

“We have no intimation in this regard. The report submitted by chief wildlife warden on the issue is pending with state’s law and judiciary ministry for its opinion in the matter,” said Mantralaya officials.

Top sources said Rathod, who hails from Yavatmal, is reluctant to set up an SIT, may be fearing people’s wrath as there was huge resentment among villagers against Avni, charged with killing 13 people in 18 months.

Dr Banait confirmed he met Thackerays and housing minister Awhad to demand action against Hyderabad-based sharpshooter Asghar Ali Khan, who was not authorized to shoot Avni.

“It was only in the presence of his father Shafat Ali Khan in whose name permit was issued by chief wildlife warden. Shafat was absent when Avni was shot on the night of November 2, 2018,” said Banait.

Detailed investigations by the NTCA and state-level committees have submitted that Asghar violated Arms Act, 1958, Indian Veterinary Council Act (IVCA) 1984, Wildlife (Protection) Act, 1972 and Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, 1985, while shooting T1.

Former forest minister Sudhir Mungantiwar had promised that if these committees indicted Asghar, action will be taken. However, even 26 months later no action has been taken either by the state government or NTCA. The Forest Development Corporation of Maharashtra (FDCM) has gone a step ahead by giving a clean chit to Asghar.

NTCA member-secretary Anup Kumar Nayak said, “We have sent several reminders seeking reply from the state government and PCCF (wildlife) but there is no response.”

Title: ‘Teachers should do research for new skills’
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Dignitaries at the international meet on ‘Advances in Mechanical Engineering’ organized at VNIT, on Friday

Nagpur: It is important for teachers to do research so that they could provide quality education to students and give them an insight into various subjects to acquire new skills, said BS Murty, director of Indian Institute of Technology, Hyderabad, on Friday.

He was speaking as the chief guest at the inauguration of two-day ‘International conference on advances in mechanical engineering (ICAME 2020)’ organized as part of the 60th anniversary celebrations of Visvesvaraya National Institute of Technology (VNIT). Chairman of board of governors of VNIT Vishram Jamdar presided while director Pramod Padole was the guest of honour.

Murty said, “I observed that teaching is not given the important it deserves as compared to research. Therefore teaching, coupled with research, will go a long way in guiding students in an efficient manner. Research helps in understanding the subject better and therefore teachers should pursue it.”

Jamdar said as the topic of the conference suggested, it is more relevant in current times to contribute to rapid progress mechanical engineering is doing. “I remember the days when mechanical engineering was just about producing machines and mechanical products. But with the changing times, mechanical engineering has assumed greater important in development,” he said.

In his keynote address, Slovakia Peter Monka, professor at Technical University of Kosice, spoke on manufacturing trends as drivers.

Mark King, reader in sports biomechanics and associate dean for enterprise at School of Sport Exercise and Health Sciences at Loughborough University, laid emphasis on optimizing sports performance.

Padole said the institute is entering the 60th year and various events and activities pertaining to teaching, which includes synergy and research, industry-institute interaction, are part of the celebrations.

On Saturday, Jaydeep Balakrishnan, associate dean of faculty support, College of Business Administration, California State University, Sacramento (USA), will speak on ‘21st century ethical business entrepreneurship: A Gandhian perspective’.

Nitin Pangarkar, associate professor, strategy and policy, National University of Singapore (NUS) Business School, will speak on ‘Strategies for building a productive research career’.

At the outset, organizing secretary Shital Chiddarwar proposed a vote of thanks.

A souvenir was released at the programme by the dignitaries. The valedictory function and prize distribution will be held on Saturday.

(Reporting by Janhavi Dave)

Title: Kolkata: Expect flight delays as PM Narendra Modi flies in today
Content:
Narendra Modi

KOLKATA: Flights arriving in Kolkata during a 20-30 minute period on Saturday late afternoon will be kept on hold to allow a buffer for Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s safe passage. Departing flights will also be on hold during the period. On Sunday late morning and afternoon, when Modi departs from the city, other flights may be held back for a while as well.Sources said the security enhancement would begin much before Air India One touches down at Kolkata airport. As the Embrair jet approaches Kolkata, the distance between it and other passenger flights arriving at the airport will be increased to twice the usual distance maintained between flights. Even during the journey, the PM aircraft will be assigned an altitude with a minimum gap of 2,000ft with other planes.On touchdown, the plane will be taken to a bay next to the old domestic terminal, at least 500m away from the other bays where planes are parked. Here, the PM will either take his BMW 7 Series limousine and exit through gate no. 4 or hop into an Mi-17V-5 helicopter to travel to Race Course.“When the PM accepts greetings from dignitaries at the airport, the area will be cordoned off and vehicular movement in the apron area, including passenger coaches and ground support equipment, will be restricted. The security protocol will lead to some delays in flight operations,” the source said.Flight operations are expected to resume shortly after PM leaves the airport. Though a chopper can take off from the parking bay, given the PM’s elaborate security detail, the Indian Air Force chopper will taxi to the runway before flying off. Flights will be allowed to depart from Kolkata shortly after the helicopter takes off as they will head in different directions: passenger flights will take towards Madhyamgram and PM’s chopper will head southward for Race Course via Salt Lake.However, if he takes the road, traffic along the route will be halted and allowed to resume only when the convoy is 3km away. Roads could be blocked for 15-20 minutes, leading to logjams that could last upto 40-45 minutes. Airlines have urged passengers taking flights between 3pm and 5pm to start at least two additional hours at hand to prevent missing flights owing to road blockades. Passengers arriving in flights between 3.30pm and 4.30pm are also likely to encounter commute delays.On Sunday late morning-afternoon, flights will be halted as soon as PM boards the chopper at Race Course as it will take the same flight path as other incoming aircraft. Flight operations are likely to remain suspended till after PM’s flight departs the city. “There may be longer delays of upto an hour due to the VIP movement,” the official said.

Title: PM Narendra Modi to unveil second largest oil painting in Kolkata
Content:
Narendra Modi

KOLKATA: As Prime Minister Narendra Modi remotely inaugurates the newly revamped Royal Gallery at Victoria Memorial Hall from Currency Building on Saturday, visitors will get to see the second largest oil painting in the world after 25 years .The 23ftX17ft painting, ‘ Jaipur Procession ’, by Russian orientalist painter Vasily Vereshchagin portrays a procession led by the Prince of Wales, who later became King Edward VII, and the Maharaja of Jaipur on the first elephant, followed by British political agent Sir Alfred Lyall on a second elephant and officials and nobles of Jaipur after him.“It was a challenge to restore the extensive hall without shifting the massive painting. We did not want to run any risk. The painting was properly wrapped for the work. A much smaller painting, which we shifted, weighed 200kg,” said an official of National Building Construction Corporation, which restored the galleries at Victoria. Besides ‘Jaipur Procession’, the warrior attire and a lock of hair of Tantia Tope, general of the 1857 rebellion, will be up for viewing.Modi will also unveil another restored gallery, Portrait Gallery, where Abanindranath Tagore’s, ‘Bharata Mata’, and the desk on which Bankim Chandra Chattopadhyay reportedly wrote ‘Vande Mataram’ will be displayed.“But Currency Building was restored the best. The PM will thrown it open to the public as on ode to the art of Bengal, showcasing art across three centuries. An exhibition, ‘Ghare Baire (Home, World and Beyond)’, will provide a glimpse of the diversity and depth of Bengal’s art,” said Raghvendra Singh, CEO, Development of Museums and Cultural Spaces, ministry of culture. “I am proud of the restored Currency Building. It is a cultural space created for exhibitions of paintings, poets’ conferences, literary meets and theatre festivals.”The PM will also inaugurate the revamped Belvedere House, part of Belvedere Estate, where the National Library of India is located. Besides, Metcalfe Hall, which will hold an exhibition, ‘Ami Kolkata—Its History and Culture’, and another on 100 years of Bengali cinema, in collaboration with Film Heritage Foundation, will also be dedicated to the nation by the PM.

Title: PM, guv greet veteran singer
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Prime Minister Narendra Modi greeted singer K J Yesudas on his 80th birthday. In his tweet, the Prime Minister said: “On the special occasion of his 80th birthday, greetings to the versatile singer K J Yesudasji. Melodious music and soulful renditions have made him popular across all age groups. He has made valuable contributions to Indian culture. Wishing him a long and healthy life.”

Governor Arif Mohammed Khan also conveyed birthday greetings to the singer. In his message, the governor said: “No day passes in the life of a Keralite, without the soothing caress of his melodious voice. May it remain so, forever.”

Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan also greeted Yesudas.

Title: Rajasthan government mulls ‘smart card’ for all on lines of Aadhaar
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

JAIPUR: After replacing Bhamashah card with ‘Jan Aadhaar card’, now the state IT department had proposed yet another ‘ smart card ’, for every citizen on the lines of centre’s Aadhaar card. The Jan Aadhaar card in place of Bhamashah card considers each family as a unit, while individual card issued to the citizen would help to keep track on individual beneficiary schemes as all beneficiary schemes are going online with direct cash benefits.

This card would be used for all government individual beneficiary schemes, including scholarships, pension, health insurance etc. This exercise would also help the state government to create a separate database of its citizens as the Central government’s Aadhaar database is not shared with the states, sources privy to the development said. Such database will come handy to the government to formulate new policy and programmes.

According to sources, the proposal has been sent to the finance department and the IT department is awaiting the green signal. Another reason for mooting a separate smart card for citizen is ration cards under the public distribution system in the state is set for a revision. The government plans to switch to smart ration cards replacing the existing paper cards in the form of books.

The department could integrate the smart ration cards with the new cards so that it could serve both the purposes.

This card with a permanent number of would help the government to keep a track on the individuals having the benefits of the various schemes and help to avoid chances of pilferage and duplication. Officials familiar with the development said, all depends on the clearance to the project at the top level.

Title: Prospect of investing in NASA costs Aurangabad man Rs 2.5 crore
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: A city-based man was duped of Rs 2.5 crore on the pretext of getting hefty returns on the investments made for supplying spare parts to National Aeronautics and Space Administration ( NASA ).

One of the five accused, identified as Abhijit Vijay Pansare, was arrested from the city. Articles, including an identity card claiming to be of an IPS officer currently posted with the Prime Minister’s Office and serving with the Research and Analysis Wing (RAW), has been recovered from his possession.

The Economic Offences Wing (EOW) of the city police, carrying out a discreet probe for days, have registered an offence against five people, including two women and a lawyer. In the offence registered with the Cidco police station, the suspects have been booked on the charges of criminal breach of trust, cheating, forgery and criminal conspiracy.

In addition, the suspects have also been slapped with various sections of the Maharashtra Protection of Interest of Depositors (In Financial Establishments) Act, 1999.

Citing contents of the complaint, EOW inspector Shrikant Navle said that the suspects were introduced to the complainant Sharad Gawli, an architect by profession, through a common friend.

It was Pansare who reportedly claimed that his firm M/s Science Kudos has bagged a contract for manufacturing RRC reactor of five megawatts, but lacked finance to complete the contract.

To win the architect’s trust, the suspect even produced forged contract papers, work orders and signed cheques. Falling prey to the trap, Gawli gave money to the suspect.

EOW authorities said that the entire transaction took place between October 20, 2016, and October 12, 2017. It was days after the promised deadline for getting hefty returns on the investment made that Gawli began following up with the suspect. However, he only got evasive replies.

After years of persuasion to get back his money, Gawli recently reached out to the commissioner of police Chiranjeev Prasad and lodged a written complaint in this regard. Considering the gravity of the case, the matter was handed over to the EOW which carried out a detailed probe before registering an offence against the suspects.

Following the recovery of the forged identity cards from the suspects, EOW is probing if the suspects have duped any more people using similar modus operandi.

Title: All they hope is for a proper cremation of the departed in Dammaiguda
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Residents have no option but to hold cremations in this open plot next to the Dammaiguda lake

HYDERABAD: Residents of over 50 colonies under the Dammaiguda Municipality limits are finding it difficult to get a decent resting place for their dear departed. With the municipality failing to provide a crematorium and a burial ground, families are forced to conduct the final rites in an open and undemarcated plot next to the Dammaiguda lake.

As if their fight for better roads and water supply over the past many years wasn’t enough, residents also have to struggle for a proper cremation/burial of the departed. The grieving families have to shed social inhibitions and other factors, and conduct cremations in the open piece of land.

“People burn dead bodies in the open in the middle of a residential area,” said Venkata Subba Rao, a resident of Sunshine Colony. “Family members are seen sitting on the road until the final rituals are completed. It’s a sad view for every commuter using the lake road.”

The road leading to the make-shift crematorium is also in a pathetic condition. It turns worse in the monsoon. The road turns muddy and inaccessible, and it becomes difficult for people to conduct the final rites of the deceased in the open.

Over the past few years, multiple representations seeking crematorium or a burial ground have been submitted by the residents of Sunshine Colony, Aditya Nagar, MLR Colony, Vedadri Nagar, and VMS Homes among others. Few residents had also approached the Central Pollution Control Board to prevent the burning of dead bodies in an open plot.

Adding to the misery is the Jawahar Nagar dump yard, which has polluted air, water and soil in the area. Balaji, resident of Aditya Nagar, said: “Foul smell engulfs the area due to burning of dead bodies. With the Jawahar Nagar dump yard stench, it only adds to our miseries. While people are fighting for clean water and clean soil, we are fighting for clean air.”

According to residents, the municipality had allocated 0.5 gunthas of land near the Jawahar Nagar dump yard. In November 2019, officials of Dammaiguda Municipality had also assured to resolve the cremation ground issue within 15 days. However, till date, there has been no progress on construction of a crematorium or burial ground in the vicinity.

Title: 2 months on, corpn’s water ATM awaits inauguration
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Trichy: The drinking water dispensing ATM facility installed on West Boulevard (WB) road is yet to be opened to the public even as the work on it was completed by the local body a few months ago.

Trichy Corporation, in its 2019-20 budget, has planned to set up 70 such water dispensers across the city to make drinking water accessible at a reasonable price. The project was supposed to be executed under public-private partnership (PPP) model initially at 43 spots. The contractor will be responsible for maintaining the water purifier for a period of 10 years apart from collecting money, while the corporation would bear the cost of installing borewells.

The local body identified the Marakkadai overhead water tank (OHT) complex on WB road to commission the city’s first water ATM in July 2019 at a cost of 5 lakh. Although the work on it was completed a couple of months back, the ATM is yet to be unveiled.

People can collect one litre of water in bottles by dropping one rupee coin in the ATM while for collecting 20 litres of treated water in the cans they should purchase a rechargeable smart card. The delay is also causing losses for the contractor. “Civil work on two water ATMs including at Marakkadai OHT complex and near Main guard gate is complete. Soon we will open them for public use,” an official said, while refusing to share the reason for the delay.

Private agencies charge 30 for a 20 litre water can while the civic body will offer the same amount of water for just 7. Residents will have to bring their own containers. The smart cards, which can be recharged, were planned to be issued at free of cost at the ATMs.

Title: Rajasthan seeks Rs 2,800 crore from Centre for NREGA dues
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Dr Renu Swaroop, secretary, department of biotechnology (centre) addresses State Biotech Cohort meeting on Fri... Read More

JAIPUR: The state's Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA) department has sent a proposal to the union ministry for rural development urging them to release funds amounting to Rs 2,800 crore for the payment of wages to the workers, material component and for running the scheme till March, 2020.

Even as the state government had been demanding the centre to release funds for the payment of wages to the MNGREGA workers, due since October 2, the centre had said that they were not being able to pay the wages due to lack of funds. The due amount has already gone up to Rs 864 crore in the state. Apart from wages, material component amounting to Rs 1,026 crore is also due. The remaining Rs 910 crore will be used for running the scheme till March 2020.

According to sources, out of Rs 60,000 crore budget allotted for the MGNREGA scheme, the centre has already spent Rs 57,500 crore. "They (the centre) had released Rs 95 crore. But this amount is very less. This will cover the farmers' wages for five days only," a MGNREGA official had said. The state’s Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA) department, having already crossed the target of generating 23 crore persondays, having achieved 24 crore mandays by December 2019, the centre had revised the labour budget to 30 crore persondays for the financial year 2019-20, sanctioning an additional fund of nearly Rs 1,500 crore.

Earlier, chief minister Ashok Gehlot had also written to union minister for rural development Narendra Singh Tomar requesting him to release the funds for the payment of wages to the MGNREGA workers.

Title: West Bengal: Charged for negligence after pet dog’s death, vet loses licence for 6 months
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: We have heard of doctors being booked for medical negligence. This time it is a veterinary doctor who has been booked for medical negligence during the treatment of a pet dog by the West Bengal Veterinary Council ( WBVC ). The council has decided to cancel Subhas Sarkar’s licence for six months and asked him to surrender his registration certificate. He will not be able to to practise in this period.In the beginning of last year, the council got a complaint from Rebanta and Manisha Bhattacharya that their pet Liza had died while being treated by Sarkar. The pet’s parents from Kolkata’s TN Chaterjee Street alleged that the beagle died due to sheer negligence by the vet. The council started an inquiry upon getting the complaint. A team of veterinary doctors, who probed the treatment of Liza, found lapses on the part of Sarkar. He was called to the council’s office in Belgachhia several times during the hearing and was given the opportunity to defend himself. But Sarkar failed to turn up. On July 31, 2019, Sarkar was also asked to reply to the charges of guilt and professional negligence. But the council didn’t get any reply.Consequently, WBVC, in its meeting held on November 29, 2019, found Sarkar guilty of violating standard professional code of ethics. On January 6, the council decided to struck off the vet’s registration for six months starting from January 10. “It was an unanimous decision taken by the board after a through probe,” said WBVC registrar, Ananda Mohan Chandra.When contacted, Sarkar claimed to be not aware of any such verdict against him. He added that he did not want to speak about the case. “I am not aware of such a decision against me. I am yet to get any communication from WBVC,” he said.The verdict by the council has been lauded by pet lovers. They feel that actions like this would instil a sense of fear and responsibility in veterinary doctors. “Animals also feel pain but they cannot express it in words like humans. So, such wrong treatment is always a punishable offence,” said Sumatika Chowdhury, a pet parent.

Title: Maradu flat demolition: They feel punished for someone else’s sins
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

N J Antony, a resident near Alfa Serene, covered his house with tarpaulin sheets to protect the structure, ahe... Read More

KOCHI: “Every time I pass by Alfa Serene, I feel as if I am at a house where someone has died. It is painful to think that the towers would come down within seconds,” says Aravindan, a former construction labourer. Aravindan, who is now 65-years-old, had worked for close to three years on both towers of Alfa Serene at Maradu as an ironworker bending steel rods and tying rebars with a metal hooking tool.

“I worked there till the structural works were complete,” says Aravindan, who lives near Arakkal temple at Nettoor. For most of the local residents, the demolition is a painful event though they are aware of the illegalities that led to it. “Think of all the homeless people. They could have given the apartments to them,” said Dineshan, an electrician who stays near Alfa Serene. According to him many older buildings near the apartment complex had suffered cracks. “We all have been residing here peacefully for decades and now we are being punished for someone else’s sins,” says Prasad, who retired as a driver from government service.

The residents who stay near the apartment complexes, to be demolished by Vijay Steels on Saturday, have been asked to vacate at least three hours before the demolition.

“First they said 9am, now they want us to move out by 8am. But there are many families who are yet to get the promised three-month rent,” said Lalan, who retired from KSRTC. Didhi, who stays behind Alfa Serene, said she has kept their bags ready but did not move out since the promised three-month rent was not paid by the municipality . “Six families here have not been paid the promised rent,” said Didhi, who plans to move to Tripunithura.

Some are bitter about the insurance and the casual manner in which their concerns regarding security of their homes were treated. “The mosque facade was wrapped with polythene sheets by authorities only today after much pleading,” said Lalan, pointing to the glass facade of the Khadeejathul Kubra Islamic Complex, which also houses a madrassa.

Some hope that a public facility like a children’s park would come up in the spot once the building is demolished. “I think a park would be ideal because the kids here do not have such a facility,” said Lalan. But others are dismissive. “We hear the builder can construct another apartment complex in the same spot if he wants to. I don’t harbour such hope,” said Prasad.

Title: Kolkata: Series of rallies lined up to send message to PM Narendra Modi
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Narendra Modi

KOLKATA: Armed with black flags and anti-CAA sky lanterns, political parties and mass organisations will bring out rallies and organize flash mobs when Prime Minister Narendra Modi visits Kolkata on Saturday evening.

While the mass organizations are not continuing with the airport blockade programme, large rallies will be organized at Kaikhali, around 4km from the airport. Members from districts like North 24 Parganas, Nadia and Murshidabad will gather at different points on VIP Road. A rally from Bhangar, led by members of the Jami Jibika Bastutantra-O-Paribesh Rakkha Committee, will join the protest.

Another group will gather at Y Channel and move towards Raj Bhavan for the gherao programme at 4pm. Some of the mass organisations like Jatiya Bangla Sammelan will hold protests at College Street at 3pm.

Left Front and other organizations will take out rallies protesting the CAA and NRC from Victoria House to Gandhi Statue at 2pm.

Trinamool Chhatra Parishad will hold a protest at the Rani Rashmani Road from 11am to 7pm.Youth Congress will show black flag to PM Modi near Millennium Park at 7pm. The SUCI (C) will take out a rally from Subodh Mullick Square to Rani Rashmani Road.

Kolkata Police — along with Bidhannagar and Howrah police — on Thursday night completed barricading the entire stretch along which Modi’s convoy will pass. All crossings have been covered by drop gates to stop protesters from having access to roads.

Title: Consignment of Qurans from Saudi Arabia to be auctioned in Kochi
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

KOCHI: A large consignment of the Holy Quran which was sent to Kerala for free distribution from Saudi Arabia is set to be auctioned out at Kochi after the importer, an Arabic college principal, expressed unwillingness to receive it as he was unable to pay the customs duty which amounted to Rs 8 lakh.

An advertisement of the auction notice issued by MIV Logistics in a Malayalam newspaper has been doing the rounds on social media. Abdul Salam I P, the importer, said that there is no controversy in the issue as a friend from Saudi had sent it to him for free distribution but he was not expecting such a high customs duty.

“It was imported after following correct documentation and through proper declarations. There is nothing unusual in it and hence there is no need for a controversy. There were some newspaper reports aimed at creating divisions. But there is nothing malicious in this,” said Abdul Salam.

He added that the Holy Quran is available for free in Saudi Arabia. “The holy book was aimed at the economically weaker believers. It was sent to Kochi in the backdrop of several faithful losing their Quran in the floods,” said Salam.

The ad for auctioning the books appeared in dailies in which January 20, 2020, 10am to 5pm was notified as the time for inspection and January 21 as date for e-auction. The auction notice was placed under the title ‘e-auction for disposal of unclaimed/uncleared imported goods by e-auction’. As per the notice, the consignment of the holy book weighed over 25,000kg. The base amount reportedly is Rs 1 lakh. Anyone quoting a higher amount will able to acquire the consignment.

The consignment landed at the Vallarpadom International Container Transhipment Terminal about six months ago. As the importer expressed his inability to pay the customs duty, they decided to auction it.

The auctioning will be held after getting the concerned customs clearance, sources said.

“I don’t know why it is becoming a controversy. We simply didn’t have the money to pay as customs duty. They informed me that the books would be auctioned out. And I understand that it has already been put up for auctioning on January 21,” said Abdul Salam.

Title: Youth succumbs to accident injuries, gives life to five
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: 21-year-old Aditya, who succumbed to injuries sustained in a road accident that occurred on December 29, gave life to five people. The first in 2020, organs of Aditya were donated to the five people registered with Mrithasanjeevani, the state’s organ transplant programme.

Aditya, who met with an accident at Sasthamangalam on December 29, suffered brain death on Thursday. The parents of Aditya, K V Manoj and Bindhu Manoj told the doctors that all organs that can be donated should be harvested from Aditya’s body. His liver and one kidney were given to two patients in a private hospital. One kidney was given to a patient at MCH Thiruvananthapuram . The corneas were given to the government ophthalmic hospital.

Aditya’s body will be handed over to the parents on Saturday and will be taken to their house at Pippinmoodu near Sasthamangalam. The burial will take place at St Mary Queen of Peace Basilica, Nalanchira at 3pm.

The accident involving a car driven by an unidentified driver, Adithya and Abdul Rahim, 44, of Vallikode near Nedumangadu took place at around 8pm. Rahim, a delivery executive of Uber Eats, succumbed to his injuries on the spot. Adithya was rushed to Medical College Hospital and later transferred to KIMS hospital.

Musuem sub-inspector Syamraj J Nair said that a probe is on to track the car and the driver.

Title: In Bhutan, greens mostly win over devpt: Former PM
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Mumbai: In a battle between development and environment in Bhutan , greens mostly win. Bhutan’s former prime minister Dasho Tshering Tobgay told TOI his country’s environmental strategy was called the middle path. If a new project is expected to cause “excessive damage to the environment” it would not be allowed even at the expense of development, he said.

Tobgay said taking such decisions was never easy, therefore a country needs an enlightened leadership that does not just think of now and today. Leaders must be willing to step back and accept the challenges of climate change, he said during his lecture at IIT-Bombay ’s Techfest 2020, on how Bhutan had been able to maintain its carbon negative status. He said leadership must transcend kings, PMs and presidents but it means everyone at the individual level must be part of a large overall plan. He lauded India's efforts in renewable solar and wind energy as also getting LPG gas to the poor. “All these are big-ticket efforts and happening at the national level. At the state level, a clarion call must be made to local administration. All that aggregate effort will be good for the environment.”

While aware of the Aarey metro shed, he said it was inappropriate to comment on the issue as he was an “outsider”. — Hemali Chhapia

Title: Corpn school takes a ‘smart’ step to attract more students
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Trichy: The 80-year-old Trichy Corporation ’s elementary school in Puthur has got an airconditioned smart classroom equipped with audio-visual accessories. The aim of setting up the smart classroom is to increase the number of students enrolled in the school.

At present, there are only 35 students, including 24 girls studying between Classes I to V in the school situated on Bharathidasan Road. It has been catering to the basic education needs of underprivileged students in Vannarapettai locality. As the school’s strength has not seen any significant improvement in recent years, school headmistress P Amsavalli mooted a proposal to improve the infrastructure on a par with private schools. Subsequently, she used her own money to set up the smart classroom equipped with a projector, digital screen and audio systemsand an airconditioner at a cost of Rs 1 lakh . “We already had a computer. Through the QR scanner, the contents of textbooks were digitised. With the help of projector and audio systems, classes for the children from now on will be conducted completely in a digital way,” Amsavalli said.

The management said the smart classroom facility was established to prevent the parents from shifting their wards to private schools. Inaugurated last Saturday, the digital classroom evoked positive good response from the parents.

Besides the smart classroom, the school has also launched spoken English classes for the students. “Spoken English classes will be conducted by a college professor who volunteered to do it free of cost. We have also launched the distribution of healthy snacks like fruit salad and chickpeas during the morning hours,” Amsavalli added.

With two teachers including the HM, the management has planned to add one more smart classroom for augmenting the student strength.

Title: Greens fume at plan to fell 110 trees in Aurangabad
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

AURANGABAD: Environment activists have expressed their displeasure after the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) issued a public notice in local newspapers on Friday morning asking for any objections to the felling of 110 trees for the Gopinath Munde memorial.

The activists objected to cutting of trees and said that the two-day time allotted for lodging objections to the trees felling is too short.

The municipal corporation, in a public notice on Friday, has given a list of 31 applications made by different individuals and organisations for cutting of trees. These applicants had sought permission from the civic body to cut trees in their property. Rotten trees, safety hazards and infrastructure development were the reasons provided for cutting of trees. The list also includes an application seeking public permission to cut 110 trees of different species for the establishment of Gopinath Munde’s memorial on the Government Milk Dairy land on Jalna Road.

The notice has sparked outrage among activists.
