According to activist Pankaj Shakkarwar, the public notice issued by the AMC under the Maharashtra (Urban Areas) Protection and Preservation of Trees Act, 1975 beats the core spirit of the law as the window to register objection is too short. “We expect that the memorial of such great personalities to be established by planting more trees and not by felling them,” Shakkarwar said.

Kishor Pathak, a nature lover and a homeopathic doctor, said that the Government Milk Dairy land which has been selected for Munde memorial has a thick green cover and a rich biodiversity . “For the nearby Jalna Road which sees heavy traffic all-round the day, the green cover acts as an oxygen hub,” Pathak said.

Also, the tree authority constituted by the municipal corporation, which gives the final nod for such applications, haven’t met for the last eight months, Pathak said.

AMC garden superintendent Vijay Patil said over the last eight months, the model code of conduct was implemented three times due to elections. “We have scheduled a meeting on Monday with the members of tree authority. No tree will be cut without the permission of the tree authority,” Patil said.

Title: First timers take the plunge into electoral politics with basic amenities on agenda
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Ramana Reddy Ward 19-Boduppal(Left) Shrikant Swami Ward 9, Manikonda(Middle) Buddiga Satya Veni Ward 6, Tellap... Read More

HYDERABAD: With discontent running high among people across municipalities, several candidates with no political track record have decided to contest the upcoming polls. Techies and businessmen are among those jumping into the poll fray hoping to make a difference on ground.

Software engineer Naveen Kumar Alashyam, who is contesting from Ward 8 in Manikonda , is among those who have filed nominations disgruntled with the lack of basic amenities in the area.

“I am planning to resign and take the voice of the people to the government,” said the 38-year-old, who says the struggle for water and good roads has been an uphill task till now.

“Growing up in the 80s, I saw my father stand tall even against Naxals. Like him, I too want to work for the people,” he said. Alashyam is among two candidates who are being put up by the Alkapur Township Residents’ Forum. Members of the Forum have been fighting for basic amenities for the township for long, but in vain.

The other candidate, Shrikant Swami, is a businessman contesting from Ward 9, Manikonda. “We are living in this high-profile IT corridor area in 2020, but it feels like we are back in the 1970s,” said Swami.

He says that safe drinking water is his primary poll plank. Speaking about why the resident welfare association has put up candidates this year, he said, “We had faith that local leaders and the government will do some good, but all in vain. So, we have decided to represent ourselves in the government bodies.”

In Tellapur, 45-year-old, Buddiga Satya Veni will contest from Ward 6. A software employee, her foray into electoral politics came after the protests over cutting of hundreds of trees on Tellapur-Nallagandla stretch last year.

“I was the first person to notice the chopping of trees, and among the first to sit there in protest.” Joining BJP, she said she wanted to ensure there is accountability over several issues, including roads, water and environment.

Twenty-five-year-old Saini Naveen Kumar will be a fresh face from Ward 16, Boduppal. Contesting as an Independent, this mechanical engineer has been working with a private firm. For him, education will be the focus. “Boduppal does not have a junior or degree college,” he said. If he wins, among the first priorities will be establishing a library in the area, he said.

On a similar plank, Ramana Reddy, from Ward 19 in Boduppal said he will push for better educational institutions. Asked why he decided to contest as an Independent, he said, “It’s about the connect I feel with people, and the need to take the municipality forward.”

Title: Dindigul Road receives VIP treatment for Vice-President visit
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Roads in trichy Cleaned ahead of vice president visit

TRICHY: Residents and commuters frequently passing through Karumandapam were in for a surprise three days ago to notice that either end of Dindigul Road had suddenly turned so clean without any litter. In fact corporation workers for the past few days have been leaving no stone unturned to make the locality look free of waste and temporary encroachments.

The reason? Vice-President Venkaiah Naidu ’s Trichy visit on Friday for the inauguration of the centenary year celebrations of National College Trichy (NCT) at Karumandapam. The appreciation from many soon turned into scorn on realising that such an effort, taken up on a war-footing, could only happen for VIP visits and never sustain. All through the route of the Vice President , at least 100 sanitary workers were involved in clearing the silt along the roads apart from the litter found on the vacant spaces adjacent to the roads in Mannarpuram, Trichy junction RoB and Karumandapam locality. The stretch usually witnesses heaps of accumulated waste. “Trichy corporation can do such impeccable cleaning every day without waiting for the VIPs to visit the city. Though the main roads of Karumandapam looked free of litter, the interior streets were not cleaned,” C Balasubramanian, a resident of Karumandapam said.

Apart from removing the waste accumulated on vacant space, corporation workers also removed the temporary encroachments on Dindigul Road. State highways department also refurbished the road that was sporting several potholes in a hurry. “The roads heading to Karumandapam look so wide now and the potholes near Trichy junction RoB were also corrected. It is sad that such work happens only when VIPs visit,” H Ghouse Baig, a resident of Khajamalai added.

Title: Looking at tree plantation options, says Maharashtra CM on Balasaheb Thackeray memorial
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Astik Kumar Pandey briefs Uddhav Thackeray (left) about the plan for Balasaheb Thackeray memorial

AURANGABAD: Chief minister Uddhav Thackeray on Friday said that he is exploring options on how more trees can be planted instead of cutting them at Priyadarshini Garden — the site selected for constructing Balasaheb Thackeray memorial .

He also told the designers to ensure that the memorial is environmentally rich and compliments the bio-diversity. Later, the two designers presented their plans for the project to district guardian minister Subhash Desai.

The Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has selected a 17-acre green space in Priyadarshini Garden in Cidco N-6 area for building the memorial of Shiv Sena founder Balasaheb Thackeray.

The project is titled Thackeray Smruti Van and the state government has allocated Rs 5 crore for the purpose. The establishment of the memorial, however, has been a cause of concern for environmentalists who fear that large number of trees will be axed to make way for the memorial. A PIL in this matter was also filed in the high court.

According to AMC, the garden has a total of 8,670 trees of which 850 have dried. Though mayor Nandkumar Ghodele, a Sena office-bearer, had earlier clarified that that the AMC will not cut any trees for the project, the environmentalists are still skeptical.

On Friday, Thackeray accompanied by Desai and Maharashtra chief secretary Ajoy Mehta visited the garden to take a review. At the site, the CM was briefed about two draft designs of the project produced by designers Manoj Dave from Noida and Dhiraj Deshmukh from Aurangabad in presence of municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey.

“The site should have trees that can become habitat for more birds,” Thackeray told the designers.

When Kishor Pathak, a nature lover, appealed to the CM to prevent cutting of trees for the memorial, Thackeray said he is exploring options how the number of trees can be increased at the site.

Speaking to TOI, Dave said that the designers have reworked their plan to ensure that project is environment-friendly.

Rajendra Joshi, a member of the activist group that is pushing for Garden’s conservation, said, “It seems to be a good plan and doesn’t require cutting of any trees rather includes additional plantation.”

Title: Trichy headquarters opening first step towards 2021 polls: Kamal Hasan
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Kamal Hasan

TRICHY: Inaugurating the third party headquarters near Trichy on Friday evening, Makkal Needhi Maiam (MNM) founder Kamal Haasan said that bringing the headquarters to the people and cadres was their first step towards the 2021 state assembly election. Earlier in the day, the actor-turned-politician discussed strategies with the newly elected party functionaries including state and district-level functionaries and urged them to strengthen the party at the grassroots by participating in grama sabhas.

Coming on the heels of launching headquarters in Chennai and Coimbatore, MNM representatives said the third headquarters was aimed at reaching the cadres and public in the central districts. Addressing the media after inaugurating the office at Ganesapuram near the Bhel township, Kamal Haasan said, “This (opening of headquarters) is the first step from us in preparing ourselves for 2021 ( Tamil Nadu assembly election). Instead of making the people visit us, the headquarters has now come to the people.” Party functionaries said that similar headquarters will be opened either in Madurai or Tirunelveli in the coming days. In a veiled criticism of the “cash for vote” system in the state, Kamal urged party cadres to be honest and promote honesty among the voters to change the state for good.

“To be honest is always possible. I request everyone to invest in Tamil Nadu, not only the monetary investment but also honesty as one of the forms of investments,” Kamal added. Claiming that there is no vacuum in the state, the MNM party founder said, “There is always a place in the heart of people but not vacuum. Deserving and qualified people are needed,” Kamal said. MNM sources said that the party cadres were told to participate effectively in grama sabha meetings and ensure better outcome from them to attract rural people to the party.

Title: Give life to folk art forms: Nanjil Sampath
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Nanjil Sampath

TRICHY: Public speaker and politician Nanjil Sampath , on Friday, said that what he achieved by acting in just two films, he could not achieve it in 32 years of public speaking and added that there is immense respect for art forms in the state.

Speaking at intercollegiate cultural festival in St Joseph’s college in Trichy on Friday, he urged students to take up any of the folk art forms to preserve them. He said films are very strong medium to connect to people and he is being recognized for his work in cinema. He asked students to focus on studies but give time to the art forms too as they may end up practicing the art form for the rest of their lives.

Giving examples of directors he worked with, Sampath said that most of them were engineers, who ended up making films. He said 63 ancient folk art forms that originated in this region are on the verge of extinction and asked students to give life to these art forms.

Title: Two years on, govt sells only 4.7k of 1 lakh tonnes of Malaysian sand
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Bengaluru: Malaysian sand, imported with much fanfare two years ago at a cost of over Rs 20 crore, has found very few takers. As a result, the government is stuck with 96% stock, which is lying at Krishnapattinam (Andhra Pradesh) port and is clueless on how to dispose of it.

The Congress government led by Siddaramaiah had decided to import sand beat alleged scarcity of the local variety. Till date, the government has sold only 4,750 tonnes of the one lakh tonnes it imported. Officials say the main reason for the lack of takers is concerns over quality and the price.

Mysore Sales International Limited (MSIL), the nodal government agency entrusted with procuring the sand, had initially planned to sell it in 50kg bags at a price of Rs 200 per bag. But buyers found it uneconomical as local sand from river beds was available at almost the same price in 2018, when the first consignment of sand from Malaysia arrived in the country.

“More than the pricing, people preferred the quality of sand mined from river beds. So they naturally preferred local sand over the imported product. MSIL also failed to convince customers on the quality of imported sand,” said an official of the mines and geology department.

Dealers also found the idea of selling sand in sacks unviable. Realising the problem, the government slashed the price of imported sand by 25% and allowed dealers to sell in bulk. But by then, the damage had been done. “The commodity had lost its appeal,” said a Malaysian sand dealer.

However, Mahaveer, a MSIL consultant in-charge of procurement and sale of Malaysian sand, insisted demand for the imported variety was robust. “We have got an order for 10,000 tonnes and the sale will go through in a week,” Mahaveer said.

He attributed the low sale to legal hurdles in transporting sand to Karnataka from Krishnapattinam port.

“When the sand arrived at the port, inter-state movement of mines was not allowed as per the Mines and Minerals Act. We could not transport the sand, although there was demand. The state government amended this rule only in November 2019. We can now focus on marketing the remaining sand aggressively,” he said.

He also said concerns about quality are unfounded. “The imported sand is IS383 certified. It has passed seven quality parameters,” he said.

Title: Kerala: Five held for threatening, robbing two doctors
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

MALAPPURAM: Kolathur police in the district arrested five persons on Friday for allegedly threatening and robbing two doctors.

Those arrested have been identified as Nabeel, 24, Jubais, 23, Muhammed Muhsin, 21, Abdul Gafoor, 34 and Satheesh Kumar, 25, all hailing from Kolathur near Perinthalmanna.

According to police, the incident occurred on Wednesday night. A young male doctor and a female doctor were talking in a car, which was parked on the road side at Erumathadam near Kolathur. They were taking a break after a long journey. The gang of five, who were travelling on two motorcycles, upon seeing the doctors, threatened them. The gang also snatched a debit card from one of the doctors and withdrew Rs 17,000 using the card. They also snatched Rs 3,000 cash from the doctors.

The doctors later approached Kolathur police and lodged a formal complaint.

On Friday morning, a police team led by sub-inspector Sharon arrested those involved in the robbery. The arrested have been remanded to 14-day judicial custody.

In a similar incident recently, a circulation staff of a newspaper was threatened by a gang at Perinthalmanna. The victim, who is native of Thrissur, was attacked by a three-member gang, which took away cash and other documents. But, the culprits behind the incident are yet to be arrested.

Title: Goa: Five booked for holding Rs 1.4 crore in old notes
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

POINGUINIM: Canacona police on Thursday night caught five persons from Kerala in illegal possession of old currency notes of Rs 1,000. The currency notes amounted to Rs 1.4 crore.

Assistant sub-inspector (ASI) Ramkrishna Velip said that his team stopped a car with five occupants. Police, after finding the currency notes, registered a case under Section 489C read with Section 34 of the Indian Penal Code , and other relevant laws.

The five accused — Abdul Kedar, 44, Saleem Abdul Rehman 33, Rasak Mohammed 45, Aboobaker Saddeques, 24, and Yusuf Abdul Rehman 32 — all residents of Kasargod, Kerala, were remanded to custody by Judicial Magistrate First Class (JMFC), Canacona. Three more arrests were made late Friday evening.

Title: Two die, one serious after consuming liquor
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: Two daily wage labourers died under unexplained circumstances while one person was hospitalised after consuming liquor near Thuraiyur town on Friday. Police suspect that the victims could have added something to the liquor for increasing the intoxication, thus causing the fatality.

Police sources said the three labourers identified as Damodaran, 55, P Saravanan, 30 and R Sathish, 30, all working in Kannanur village, consumed liquor in their possession on Friday morning around 6.30 am. After their binge session near a hairdressing outlet, the trio headed to their respective houses in the hamlet. However, Saravanan swooned and died on reaching home while Damodaran fell sick and was first rushed to Kannanur PHC from where he was referred to Thuraiyur GH. He died before getting any medical attention. Meanwhile, Sathish was rushed to Perambalur GH after he complained of uneasiness and is undergoing intensive care. Jambunathapuram police personnel rushed to the spot and carried out inquiries.

“The liquor bottle seems to be that of Tasmac but the batch number found in the bottle is not in sales and circulation now. The deceased Damodaran had brought the liquor bottle, so the origin of the liquor is known only to him. The victims may have added ingredients to enhance the intoxicating effect,” a senior police official investigating the crime said.

Police sources added that the smell of floor cleaner emanated from the liquor bottle consumed by the trio. Jambunathapuram police collected the remains in the bottle and viscera of the victims and sent the samples to the police forensic laboratory in Trichy city for detailed investigation. The condition of Sathish was said to be serious and further inquiry is under way.

Title: Chandigarh: No hiccups for BJP as Rajbala Malik is new mayor
Content:
Local MP Kirron Kher and BJP chief Sanjay Tandon congratulate Rajbala Malik after she won the post of mayor in... Read More

CHANDIGARH: BJP on Friday won all the three seats in the mayoral elections in a show of unity that ensured there was no cross-voting to help rival Congress.Rajbala Malik defeated Gurbax Rawat of Congress to become the new mayor for a term of one year. She secured all the 22 votes of the BJP-SAD alliance in the house of 27 having five Congress councillors. Similarly, Ravi Kant Sharma and Jagtar Singh Jagga of BJP bagged the posts of senior deputy mayor and deputy mayor. Their opponents, Sheela Phool Singh and Ravinder Kaur Gujral, got 5 votes each. Unlike the past, no single vote was found invalid.The elections were held under the supervision of deputy commissioner Mandip Singh Brar at the MC office in Sector 17. Presiding officer Charanjeev conducted the proceedings. As secretary Ani Garg started informing about the procedure and norms of polling, a spat broke out between BJP and Congress councillors. Local MP Kirron Kher also had an argument with the opposition councillors.Raising the issue of secrecy of ballot, leader of opposition and Congress councillor Devinder Singh Babla said it needs to be ensured that if someone breaches the secrecy of ballot, he or she should be punished. “Many councillors have two mobile phones but they kept only one outside the compartment. It should be their responsibility if the secrecy is breached. In fact, pens should also be kept outside,” said Babla before the start of voting.BJP councillor Arun Sood replied, “Former union minster Pawan Kumar Bansal in 2011 mayoral elections had objected to keeping mobile phones outside. There is full secrecy in today’s election.”Senior leaders of both BJP and Congress reached well in time to the visitors’ gallery to watch the proceedings. From BJP, party chief Sanjay Tandon, organisation head Dinesh Kumar and others were present, while city chief Pardeep Chhabra and other senior leaders from the Congress. The family members of the candidates also reached the gallery.Police had made security arrangements inside and outside the assembly hall. Besides local cops, sleuths of the security and intelligence wing kept an eye on the venue.

Title: Chennai: Exchange household items at corporation’s ‘swap shop’ on January 12, 13
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

CHENNAI: The corporation will organise an exchange mela of sorts in Adyar zone on Sunday and Monday through which residents can exchange recyclable and reusable items from their households.

Those who do not wish to exchange can even donate used items.

This ‘ swap shop ’ will be set up at the Tamil Nadu Housing Board community hall near Besant Nagar bus terminus. The project has been initiated by Alby John, deputy commissioner, South Region, Greater Chennai Corporation .

The items will be sold at a nominal price at the ‘reuse and reduce’ sale and residents can swap similar items. From toys to electrical appliances such as toasters to small furniture, bags, trolleys and used bicycles, citizens can exchange items they want to.

The civic body has urged the public to not use the opportunity to dispose old items and share things in working condition which would be of use to others. “The idea is to reduce shopping and start swapping. What we may not need anymore can be of real use to someone else,” said a senior corporation official.

According to an official statement, the civic body may also purchase items from those who bring recyclable objects in bulk.

However, corporation officials have urged residents to look at it not as an opportunity to get rid of household waste and bring only those objects that are reusable.

Residents, who may not be able to visit the ‘swap shop’, can drop off the items at collection points set up in wards across Adyar (Zone 13), the corporation said. According to a corporation official, it’s also an opportunity to cut the amount of waste being sent to Kodungaiyur and Perungudi dumpyards.

The city generates about 5,200 tonnes of solid waste a day and the civic body has adopted various measures — from segregation to resource recycling and composting units — to reduce the waste sent to landfills, an official said.

“Instead of waiting for the items to get to the point where they are unusable and eventually dumped, this is a better option,” the official added.

Title: Assistant professor, college ‘clueless’ as UGC asks them to return wasted research fund
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: The university grants commission (UGC) has asked an assistant professor of a government aided arts and science college to refund the money sanctioned to him for a minor research project in 2017. While the fund was sanctioned to the college account, the faculty member never received it and the college too failed to inform him about it. The college claimed it was unaware of having received the fund as it was transferred to its common account.

The UGC had sanctioned Rs 1 lakh to P Soundararajan, assistant professor of economics department, Urumu Dhanalakshmi College, for his minor project to study the impact of information and communication technology on rural development in Trichy district. He was informed about the fund being sanctioned but didn’t receive any communication from the UGC it was transferred. Last month-end, after almost two years, he received a mail from UGC directing him to refund Rs 65,000 with 10% interest per annum. The UGC claimed that the fund was released by it in 2017 for the project but he had not submitted any report on his research.

E R Ravichandran, principal of Urumu Dhanalakshmi College, told TOI that they never received any communication from UGC on release of the fund to the bank account of the college. “While Soundararajan too didn’t receive any communication, we were unaware that we had received funds from UGC. Since we receive funds to a common bank account of the college where other faculty members too receive funds, we didn’t realise that we had received funds meant for Soundararajan,” he said.

He further said that the developments happened in 2017 and it has been only six months since he took charge as principal of the college. However, Association of University Teachers (AUT) put the onus of the incident on the college management and sought a special audit from the UGC of the funds allotted by it to the college.

Title: Practise ideology after leaving institution: VP to students
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Vice President of India Venkaiah Naidu meet the students on attending the inauguration of centenary year celeb... Read More

Vice-President M Venkaiah Naidu has asked students to practise any ideology only after they are out of their institution as a tense mind cannot pay attention to academic activity. He said protest is part of democracy . “But we should not allow destruction of public property. We should not allow violence to take place in any public activity as peace is prerequisite for progress.” .

Naidu was in Trichy on Friday to inaugurate the centenary celebrations of National College Trichy (NCT). “Nothing wrong in supporting an ideology but practising an ideology should be only when you are out of the institutions,” he said adding that such activities will spoil the future of students and reputation of the institution. Starting his speech in Tamil by greeting members of the NCT college management, he stressed on preserving the mother tongue. He said there was nothing wrong in learning Hindi, but it should not be imposed. In this respect, Naidu said it was only by knowing the language spoken by the majority in the country that he could rise to the second constitutional authority of the country. He stressed that all state government communication should be in the local language.

Title: Provide police cover for Muthoot staff willing to work: Kerala HC
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

KOCHI: Kerala high court on Friday ordered for providing police protection to employees at all branches and regional office of Muthoot Finance Ltd who are willing to work amid the protest against closure of some branches. The court also said conciliation talks should take place.

Justice A Muhamed Mustaque issued the order after considering a petition filed by the company’s managing director George Alexander through senior advocate George Poonthottam .

In the petition, the company had sought police protection for the employees at its 568 branches as well as the regional office. Stone-pelting on the managing director and registration of a criminal case following it as well as instances of employees being obstructed by protesters were highlighted before the court.

Title: Residents threaten ‘jail bharo’ protest
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Aurangabad: Locals from different communities have threatened to carry out a mass ‘jail bharo’ agitation against the Parbhani police for booking over 10,000 people in at least two of the six cases registered on December 20 for protesting against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and the proposed National Register of Citizens (NRC).

While five of the offences have been registered for violence, the sixth case has been lodged for forcing shops in the market to remain shut. The registered FIRs include names of even those who had been out of the country for performing of Umrah—a mini pilgrimage. There are some names which have allegedly been repeated in the FIRs. The protest in Parbhani took a violent turn after some miscreants resorted to stone pelting.

People from different walks of life have formed Samvidhan Bachao Samiti (SBS), an umbrella organisation to put up a united front against the implementation of the CAA, NRC and NPR.

SBS president Vijay Wakode told TOI, “It is shocking that around 12, 000 people have been booked in at least two of the five FIRs. We want these FIRs to be withdrawn as innumerable innocents have been booked.”

The members of the outfit made a presentation to Parbhani district collector on Friday. Later, the members took out a mega rally in the town against the police’s alleged excesses as well as against CAA, NRC and NPR.

SBS vice president Rajan Kshirsagar said, “Parbhani police are trying to replicate the Gorakhpur pattern here. We will not let that happen. The incident of stone pelting has been used as an opportunity by the police for committing vendetta against the citizens.”

Nitin Sawant, another core committe member, said that the Parbhani police were prejudiced against Muslims and that was the sole reason why even the innocents, who tried stopping the miscreants from stone pelting, were named in the FIRs.

Regional head of Jamiat Ulema E Hind, Mufti Mirza Kaleem, said that Maulana Rafiuddin Ashrafi, who went for Umrah on December 11 from Mumbai to Saudi Arabia returned only on December 26. Ashrafi, who is Parbhani district’s leading cleric who leads the Eid prayers, found his name in the FIR despite being on a pilgrimage.

Veterinary Anwar Ali Shah had gone to Pune on December 19 and returned just a couple of days ago. Hafeez Nazir, who too had been for Umrah and returned days after the incident, also found his name in the FIRs.

Despite repeated attempts, Parbhani superintendent of police Krishnakant Upadhyay could not be reached for his comments. Special inspector general of police, Nanded range, Manoj Lohiya told TOI, “The investigation officer (IO) is going through the video clips. Only those identified are facing action. There is no question of any innocent being implicated.”

Title: Mock drill conducted
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Kundannoor bridge, usually packed with vehicles, wore a deserted look on Friday noon as police blocked the tra... Read More

KOCHI: At 12.45pm, a siren was heard and vehicles on byroads leading to the flats at Maradu were blocked. Later, the siren was sounded four more times from Maradu municipality around 2pm and vehicle movement resumed once again. This was done as part of the mock drill to ascertain the preparedness of various agencies involved in the demolition of the four illegal buildings on Saturday and Sunday.

The drill, headed by commissioner Vijay Sakhare, was conducted so that the police, fire force and medical personnel understood their duties and identified spots they need to guard at the exclusion zone of each building. Fire tenders and ambulances were parked at the boundary of the exclusion zone.

The drill at 10am was delayed as the technical committee and demolition expert from Indore SB Sarwate inspected each site to review preparedness. Also, during the drill, traffic on NH-66 was blocked for 10 minutes and it led to congestion. Seeing the police contingent, pedestrians and students came near Holy Faith H2O to click photos.

After completing the drill at the municipality building, the technical committee moved to Jains Coral Cove for the same procedure. Though the siren was sounded five times, it did not invoke much curiosity as everyone knew what was going on. Police, fire, revenue officials and technical committee members will monitor the implosion of Holy Faith H2O and Alfa Serene sitting at the control room on different screens.

The drill at Golden Kayaloram will be done on Saturday after the demolition of Holy Faith H2O and Alfa Serene.

Title: Projects worth Rs 1 lakh crore registered: CM Pinarayi Vijayan
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

CM Pinarayi Vijayan

KOCHI: New projects worth nearly Rs 1 lakh crore were registered at Ascend Kerala 2020, the global investors meet organized by the departments of industries and commerce, said chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan . On Friday, the state government signed MoUs with some the investors or received letters of intent from others.

“We had 136 projects are ready for investment today and further two were added just now – between all these projects, there will be total investments of Rs 32,008 crore. On top this, the Kerala Infrastructure Fund Management Ltd signed an MoU on Friday, but is only one among their six projects with a total worth of Rs 8,110 crore,” Vijayan said.

“Apart from these, the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority has shown interest in investing Rs 66,900 crore in developing logistics parks across the state. So, of this, there are altogether fresh promises to invest Rs 98,708 crore,” Vijayan said. With a number of investors unable to make it to the event, the chief minister has deputed principal secretary (industries) K Ellangovan to meet such potential investors in the coming days.

Regarding the ease of doing business, our state had lagged behind, compared to others and our current endeavour is to make Kerala one of the top five states in terms of ease of conducting business, Vijayan said. “We have already made significant improvements in this regard and that was the result of co-ordinated efforts of various governmental agencies. Through discussions with investors we identified the bottlenecks and brought out legislations like Kerala Micro Small Medium Enterprises Facilitation Act,” he added.

In Kerala, you will not need any middlemen to start business, Vijayan said. “You can approach any official, right from village officer to the CM’s office, where a friendly attitude will be ensured. We know that there are some officials who take a negative stand and to sort that out, we will organize a meeting of heads of departments and representatives of investors,” he said.

The government will also focus on skill development. “If you need to be employed in these new projects, you might need new skillsets and training. For this, we will revise the curriculum after discussions with the universities and respective industry,” Vijayan said.

Title: Nobel laureate Richard Thaler explores Kolkata connect
Content:
Richard Thaler (ANI photo)

KOLKATA: Nobel laureate , Charles R Walgreen distinguished service professor of behavioural science and economics at University of Chicago’s Booth School of Business, has a Kolkata connect. The legendary teacher will deliver the Professor Amitava Bose Memorial Lecture at the Indian Institute of Management (IIM) Calcutta on Monday and meet his university friends.Bose was Thaler’s junior from the University of Rochester, while Alok Ray, a retired professor of economics from IIM-C, Dipankar Dasgupta, former professor of economics at the Indian Statistical Institute, and Anjan Mukherji, emeritus professor of economics at Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU), were his contemporaries from the same university.The Nobel laureate, who called on Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Thursday, will deliver a lecture on ‘Doing Economics in the 21st Century’ at the event. IIM-C will host a dinner that the Nobel laureate will attend with his friends from the city.“Kolkata has a strong connection with the University of Rochester from the late 1960s, when several students from the city took admissions in the economics department. Professor Dipankar Dasgupta, a stalwart teacher of the subject at the Indian Statistical Institute (ISI), were friends with Thaler at the university. There is a long list of meritorious students and alumni from Calcutta University, who also have a strong connection with the Nobel Laureate,” said Abhishek Bose, son of Amitava Bose, who has instituted the lecture in commemoration of the former IIMC director.

Title: 'Chhapaak' declared tax-free in Rajasthan
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Bollywood actress Deepika Padukone visiting a Hindu temple in Mumbai (AFP File Photo)

JAIPUR: Bollywood Actor Deepika Padukone 's film ' Chhapaak ' has been declared tax-free in Rajasthan .

The film has been facing the wrath of a certain section of people after Padukone visited the Jawaharlal Nehru University in Delhi to express solidarity with the students who were attacked by a masked mob on January 5.

The decision to declare the film tax-free in Rajasthan was taken on Friday night.

"The move of exempting the film from tax has been welcomed by people. The film will educate people," chief minister Ashok Gehlot told reporters on Saturday.

'Chhapaak', directed by Meghna Gulzar, presents the story of acid attack survivor and activist Laxmi Agarwal.

Title: Widening of Sangolda road planned to ease traffic
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Saligao: Two developmental works — the improvement of a dilapidated underground culvert and the widening of a road at Mae De Deus ward in Sangolda will soon commence.

Saligao MLA Jayesh Salgaonkar on Friday inaugurated the projects, estimated to cost Rs 13 lakh.

The road to be widened currently connects the ward from the main Chogm road and takes commuters towards Guirim.

With a temple being located on the same stretch along with a church, the road often witnesses traffic congestion. The works are being taken up by the authorities as a solution to this issue.

“While inspecting the road, we noticed that the culvert was on the verge of being damaged. So we prepared an estimate and decided to take up the works,” the Saligao MLA said.

The culvert will be made three metres wide and 10 metres long. The road will be widened by three metres.

Senior citizens in the area had been demanding the road widening work to be taken up on priority to ease the traffic congestion.

Title: Submit report on waste plant, NGT tells Chandigarh administration
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

The National Green Tribunal was not satisfied with the functioning of the garbage processing plant at Dadumajr... Read More

CHANDIGARH: The National Green Tribunal ( NGT ) has directed the UT administration to submit a detailed report on the functioning of the Jaypee garbage processing plant at Dadumajra.

UT adviser Manoj Parida, municipal corporation commissioner K K Yadav and UT chief conservator of forests Debendra Dalai appeared before the NGT on Friday in connection with cases related to water pollution, solid waste management and air pollution.

The officials submitted a detailed presentation of construction and demolition waste plant, legacy waste bio mining plant, bio medical waste plant and functioning of sewage treatment plants in the city. The NGT members were ‘impressed’ with the steps taken by the administration in other areas but not satisfied with the functioning of the garbage processing plant.

Recently, the NGT had directed Justice Pritam Pal (retd) committee to review the solid waste management situation in Chandigarh. The NGT has even sought a report from the panel on or before January 31, 2020.

Earlier, the committee had been looking into the pollution at river Ghaggar.

The civic body and the Jaypee plant are at loggerheads over the processing of garbage at the Dadumajra site.

The latest tribunal order stated, “We are informed that the committee constituted by the tribunal in original application to oversee the compliance of Solid Waste Management Rules-2016, headed by Justice Pritam Pal is still in operation. The committee must furnish a report.”

Recently, another committee formed by the NGT had submitted in its report that 25,000 metric tonne unprocessed mixed waste has been lying at the garbage processing plant. The report was placed before the NGT during its resumed hearing in connection with the solid waste management system in the city. On this, the NGT had asked the civic body to complete the task by March 31, 2020.

The committee formed by the NGT comprised Chandigarh Pollution Control Committee (CPCC) member secretary, representative of Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) and Union ministry of environment, forest and climate change , and a professor from Punjab Engineering College, Chandigarh.

The CPCC had even sought a clarification from the MC as the NGT was keeping a close eye on the matter. In a letter, the CPCC had written that during their panel’s visit to the plant on October 23, 2019, between 2pm and 3pm, the Jaypee management had submitted that the plant was accepting 150 metric tonne of waste a day, whereas the MC staff said the average waste that went there was 242.27 metric tonne a day. But till date, the MC failed to submit a reply. The CPCC had asked the MC commissioner to give clarification on the data mismatch.

Recently, the pollution panel had slapped a penalty of Rs 1.46 crore on Jaypee for violating environment rules while processing garbage at the dumping ground. The penalty was calculated at Rs 75,000 daily from February 20 to September 2. The notice was issued under Section 33-A of the Water (Prevention of the Pollution) Act, 1974, Section 31-A of the Air (Prevention of the Pollution) Act of 1981 and Section 5 of the Environment Protection Act of 1986.

The processing plant authorities had challenged the penalty before the tribunal.

The CPCC had earlier, too, issued a show-cause notice to Jaypee after finding various violations.

Title: KT Rama Rao bats for industrial corridors, wants Centre support for dry port
Content:
Industries minister KT Rama Rao

Industries minister KT Rama Rao urged Union industries and commerce minister Piyush Goyal to sanction two new industrial corridors

HYDERABAD: Days after training guns at the Centre for giving a short shrift to Telangana, industries minister KT Rama Rao urged Union industries and commerce minister Piyush Goyal to sanction two new industrial corridors — one between Hyderabad and Nagpur and another between Hyderabad and Warangal.He also sought a southern industrial corridor Hyderabad-Bengaluru-Chennai covering four states and support for setting up a dry port in Telangana and multi-modal logistics parks. KTR , who met Goyal in Delhi on Thursday night, also invited him for Bio Asia meet, which will be held in Hyderabad in February.He said the Telangana government is giving top priority for the growth of industries. “Many industries have set up units and assistance from the Centre will further help the growth of industrial sector,” he said.Earlier speaking at the Wings India-2020 curtain-raiser programme, KTR said aerospace and defence sector are a priority for Telangana. The minister said the Telangana Academy of Skill and Knowledge had partnered with several aerospace and defence organisations to prepare necessary manpower.He said several companies had invested in aerospace and defence industries in the past five years. KTR said Telangana is the only state in the country that has a separate drone policy.The minister said the Telangana government is planning to develop five heliports at various places for better air connectivity. He said the government is also keen to make ‘flying for all’ a possibility in the next few years. He later gave an overview of the defence and aerospace eco-system in Telangana.KTR met aerospace and defence head honchos in Delhi on the sidelines of Wings India. GE Aviation country head Vikram Rai met KTR. Tata and GE Aviation together set up a world class centre of excellence on aero-engine components in Hyderabad in 2018. The minister and Rai discussed about the operations of GE in Telangana and plans for future expansion.Anand Stanley, president and MD, Airbus India, Nik Khanna, MD, BAE Systems-India, also met the minister.Later in the day, Pierre Dickeli, CEO, Safran India, met KTR and gave him an update on their expansion plans in Telangana. Safran set up a facility to manufacture aircraft engine parts in Telangana and has recently opened its second plant.

Title: HDK releases videos to prove top cop’s hand in M’luru violence
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Bengaluru: Former chief minister HD Kumaraswamy on Friday released several videos of the clashes that broke out during protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act in Mangaluru on December 19, to show police had prompted the violence. Two men died in police firing . Kumaraswamy demanded the setting up of a joint House committee to investigate the incident.

“The main culprit is Mangaluru city police commissioner PS Harsha. He was the one who instigated the mob. A joint legislative committee comprising members from all parties alone can bring out the truth behind police excess. I will take up this issue on the floor of the House in the upcoming session," Kumaraswamy told reporters on Friday.

He said police instigated the violence by pelting stones at protesters. When protesters retaliated, police opened fire. He said that magisterial inquiry ordered by the government cannot be trusted.

In all, Kumaraswamy released 35 video clips . He alleged the police attack was unprovoked and was unleashed on students, bystanders and street vendors. “Even before the police commissioner ordered his men to fire, cops were ready to fire. This is not just a case of failure of law and order, but willful involvement of police forces in violence,” he said. “I wanted to present the videos to Justice Gopala Gowda, who is conducting a public hearing, but police did not allow me to do so.”

Title: Group drinking in public assaults cops
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Chandigarh: Four persons allegedly assaulted a police party and freed a man arrested for drinking in public from its custody at Dadumajra colony in Sector 38 on Thursday night, leading the cops to arrest a husband-wife duo. The other two accused are absconding.

The two accused are Madan and his wife Jhummi Devi, both residents of Dadumajra colony

Kuldeep Singh, a head constable, alleged he was on night patrolling duty with another cop in Dadumajra Colony. Kuldeep Singh said when he reached the rear side of Royal Bakery, he spotted four people consuming alcohol in an auto-rickshaw around 8 pm. As they saw the cops, they tried to flee but Kuldeep Singh caught one of them.

Kuldeep Singh said he was taking the accused towards the police beat box, when one person, Golu alias Kala, and another came in front of them. Both started misbehaving and abusing the two cops, the complaint alleged. Golu allegedly pushed Kuldeep Singh and ran away. Kuldeep Singh said he chased and caught Golu near a temple. In the meantime, Madan and his wife Jhummi Devi with four to five persons reached the spot. They allegedly assaulted the police party and freed Golu. Passersby intervened and rescued the head constable from them. However, all the accused managed to flee the spot.

Later, Kuldeep Singh informed police helpline 112 and more cops reached the spot. On the statement of Kuldeep Singh, Maloya police registered a case under sections 332 (whoever voluntarily causes hurt to any person being a public servant in the discharge of his duty as such public servant), 353 (assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of his duty), 224 (resistance or obstruction by a person to his lawful apprehension) and 225 (resistance or obstruction to lawful apprehension of another person) of the IPC against Jhummi, Madan, Golu and others. Later, Madan and Jhummi were arrested and produced before a court, which remanded him in judicial custody for 14 days.

2 Arrested

Police have arrested a husband-wife duo for the violence. They had allegedly come with four to five people, attacked the cops and freed one of the persons drinking in public from police custody at Dadumajra colony in Sector 38 on Thursday night. On January 6, Maloya police arrested three people for allegedly assaulting cops, rioting and damaging public property at Dadumajra Colony. Police produced all the three accused before a local court, which sent them in judicial custody for 14 days.

Title: Goa: Two arrested for sex racket at Mandrem
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

Title: Goa cops leave for UP to gain information on imposter
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Sunil Kumar Singh

PANAJI: A team of the crime branch of the Goa police left for Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh on Friday to find out the antecedents of the accused who was arrested for impersonating as a cooperative minister of the UP government. The court has also extended his police custody by four more days.

Speaking to TOI, crime branch SP Pankaj Kumar Singh said that as per investigation, it has come to light that the accused had impersonated only to avail of free stay in Goa.

Sunil Kumar Singh, 48, a resident of Lucknow, was arrested early this week. Until his arrest, Singh was a state guest, who was accorded all facilities. He stayed at plush government guest houses, toured the state in a government provided vehicle, had a police security officer (PSO) to accompany him wherever he went, and also attended an event in South Goa as the ‘chief guest’. It was only when he inquired about a masseuse and massage services over a drink that his cover was finally blown.

It all started with an email that the protocol department received, requesting to book the state-run Circuit House for Singh’s stay. Without verifying the email, the department considered him as a state guest and reserved a room for three days in the city.

Title: Wigneswaran: Grant dual citizenship to Sri Lankan Tamils
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Vellore: Justice C V Wigneswaran , former chief minister of Sri Lanka ’s Northern Province and the chief guest at a Pongal event organised by Vellore Tamil Sangam at Voorhees College , on Friday urged the Indian government to grant dual citizenship to Sri Lankan Tamils earning their livelihood on Indian soil for more than three decades.

Addressing the media, Wigneswaran said, “Our key demand is that Sri Lankan Tamils return to our motherland. However, considering the benefits they receive in India (Tamil Nadu), including education for their children, which they could not disassociate from all of a sudden, we request the Indian government to grant dual citizenship to the Lankan Tamils living as refugees after addressing all legal issues so that their children’s education is not affected.”

Elected president with overwhelming support from Sinhalas and Buddhists, the Gotabaya Rajapaksa government’s every move focuses only on the welfare and prosperity of these two majority communities which gave him an easy win, he said. Tamil people who are in minority have been sidelined and are leading a fear-filled life since the crowning of Gotabaya, he said.

“Since the civil war broke out in Sri Lanka in 1983, so far more than 10 lakh Lankan Tamils have migrated to various countries fearing for their lives and are living as refugees. Only in a few countries have they been granted citizenship. If dual citizenship is awarded to the entire 10 lakh Sri Lankan Tamil migrants and their descendants, it will create a prosperous platform in our motherland,” he added.

Asked whether Tamils are subjected to any cruelty by the Sri Lankan government, Wigneswaran said, “Learning from experience, the Gotabaya government won’t initiate any steps that disturb the peace of Tamils and hope it won’t incite any hatred against them. We hope that the Gotabaya government’s present stand of not cooperating with the UN probe on war crimes will also be reconsidered at the earliest.”

Title: Narmada-Gambhir Link Project to quench thirst of 43 Sanwer villages
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Indore: To ensure adequate supply of water for drinking and irrigation, Narmada-Gambhir Link project was inaugurated in Kankaria village of Sanwer tehsil by NVDA minister Surendra Singh Baghel and health minister Tulsiram Silawat on Friday.

Amidst slogans of ‘Jai Narmada Maiyya’, the ministers inaugurated the project that will meet water demand for drinking and agriculture in 43 villages of Sanwer area.

“I had a dream to bring Narmada water in Sanwer to solve water shortage. I had given a slogan ‘Narmada Maiyya Sanwer Chalo’ in 1985. It finally got fulfilled,” said Silawat adding that farmers will now get uninterrupted water supply for irrigation.

He added that three clusters of total 43 villages will be prepared to supply tap water for drinking in every household.

While addressing the gathering, Baghel congratulated locals on inauguration of the project. “On Silawat’s initiative, state government prepared an intensive irrigation scheme for Sanwer, which will be implemented with a cost of Rs 2400 crore and will benefit 182 villages of the area and help in irrigation in 80,000 hectare,” the NVDA minister said.

He added that 2.5 MLD water will also be supplied for drinking in Sanwer.

On the occasion, Depalpur MLA Vishal Patel also raised demand of developing Yashwant Sagar as a tourist destination while former minister Rameshwar Patel demanded developing a ‘Kund’ at Narmada-Gambhir Link Project in Kankariya village.

Baghel assured both leaders to do the needful.

Title: Kid pours hot water on herself, dies
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Indore: A four-year-old girl died on Friday from grievous burn injuries sustained, when she poured hot water on her body from a tub kept by her mother to give her a bath.

Banganga police station in charge Indramani Patel said that the incident took place in Karol Bagh on Wednesday.

Minor daughter of watchman Rampal Golkar identified as Ritika was playing in the front room, when her mother Pinki called her to take a bath. She poured the hot water into the tub and summoned her. While Pinki went to the other room to keep the water container, the minor rushed to the bathroom and poured the water on her shoulder using a tumbler. Hearing her screams, Pinki rushed inside and tried to pour cold water on her burns. She alerted her neighbours and asked for their help. They rushed the minor to the hospital where she was admitted for treatment. The left portion of her body was burnt because of the hot boiling water, said doctors. They treated her for two days but her condition started deteriorating and she succumbed to the injuries on Friday morning. Banganga police said that the case has been registered and body of the minor was handed over to family members after post mortem examination and further investigations have been initiated. TNN

Title: TRS neta bids party goodbye, back in two hours
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

D Dayakar Reddy

HYDERABAD: It had all the trappings of realpolitik. On Friday morning, a peeved TRS leader bade goodbye to the party and jumped into Congress. D Dayakar Reddy , however, quit the grand old party and came back rushing to the ruling party. This high drama began and got over in two hours.

While Congress leaders claimed that Dayakar was bulldozed by minister Ch Malla Reddy, TRS leaders asserted Dayakar had rejoined the party on his own volition after realising his folly.

What forced Dayakar to go out and again come back into TRS? Associates close to him said he was hurt that the TRS leadership did not announce his candidature for the mayor post from Peerzadiguda Municipal Corporation. Dayakar had worked as a upa sarpanch of Peerzadiguda as a TDP leader and joined TRS five years ago. He also served as TRS secretary of Rangareddy district.

He is considered as a close associate of former Medchal MLA M Sudheer Reddy. Sudheer and Malla Reddy, who presently represents Medchal in the state assembly, are believed to not get along well and it is alleged that Dayakar was denied the mayoral candidature because of his closeness with Sudheer.

Sources said Dayakar has been nursing the mayoral ambitions from the newly formed Peerzadiguda corporation. Malla Reddy is in-charge of the party Medchal unit and Dayakar’s chances suffered a setback after it became clear the party was considering another candidate.

In the meanwhile, Congress saw a chance and roped in Malkajgiri MP A Revanth Reddy, who went to Dayakar’s house and invited him to join Congress. Dayakar was not only assured of the mayor candidature but was also handed over form ‘B’ as a Congress nominee for the ward member (since it is an indirect election).

Dayakar then joined Congress in presence of Revanth and Medchal Congress unit chief Srisailam Goud at around 12 noon. About half a dozen of his supporters also joined Congress. Revanth even addressed a media conference with Dayakar in tow. Once Malla Reddy got wind of this, he made a dash to the house of Dayakar at Peerzadiguda along with Malkajgiri TRS incharge Marri Rajasekhar Reddy. He held closed-door discussions with Dayakar and mollified him.

When Revanth, who was on his way back home, came to know about Malla Reddy camping at Dayakar’s house, he rushed to the latter’s house. Alerted by this development, Malla Reddy took Dayakar in his car to an undisclosed location. Since last reports came in, Dayakar continued to be incommunicado to TRS and Congress leaders.

Title: Embrace Industry 4.0 fast: Experts
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

KOCHI: Experts at the global investors meet, Ascend 2020 Kerala , on Friday stressed the need for the country to embrace Industry 4.0 and digital technologies at the earliest so as to lap up investment opportunities and compete with other emerging nations.

While speaking at a plenary session on ‘Industry 4.0 – Trends and Impact for Future’, on the final day of the two-day meet, Sushant Rabra, partner-digital, KPMG India, said that globally, Industry 4.0 and digital technologies are being adopted across sectors like manufacturing, transportation, energy and telecom.

Rabra added that for the adoption of Industry 4.0 in India, the government can act as a facilitator while the industry bodies can function as enablers by bringing together all stake holders.

In his address, Dr Suresh Nair, CTO, NeST Group, said there was no option but to adopt Industry 4.0 since it’s beneficial in all aspects like quality, cost, delivery and safety.

Commenting on Kerala’s perspective on the subject, Nair said: “It will give more opportunities for startups, and hardware and software borders will merge. Kerala’s strengths are engineering talent and resources.”

Title: Satara Road's BRTS lane swings between now on and now off
Content:
The BRTS is a good concept and will work if planned and executed in a flawless manner: Secretary of PMP Pravas... Read More

TimesView The BRTS route on Satara Road is in a mess. Its revival has failed due to the utter lack of coordination between civic departments and transport authorities. While flyovers between Swargate and Padmavati have damaged the original corridor’s alignment, the authorities have now began installing ten new bus stops promising that these will not obstruct the Metro work which is being contemplated in the same corridor. It is high time that all the agencies submit a joint plan to ensure that their projects do not overlap and the taxpayer’s money is not wasted.

PUNE: Months after the Pune traffic police announced opening up of all four Bus Rapid Transit System routes in Pune for movement of all traffic, fresh barricades have come up on some sections of the Pune-Satara Road and construction of new bus stops along the Katraj-Swargate BRTS corridor has started.Owner of a welding workshop outside Parvati Industrial Estate said, “The work between Market Yard junction and Panchami Hotel junction started 15 to 20 days ago. The earlier barricades were removed and new ones have been installed. The movement of traffic towards Katraj has increased manifold as the road has once again narrowed down after one side of the opened BRTS corridor was blocked.”Two construction workers on the stretch said, “We have installed new railings on the Swargate to Katraj side right now. Work is going on along the entire 5 km stretch. New bus stops are also being made. Some are ready, like the one outside Hotel Panchami. The ones under construction will have the same design. After this, the barricade on the other side of the corridor will be finalized.”Local resident Purva Sankhla said over the last decade, they have seen the BRTS fail as a project. Some new bus stops were created a few months ago but the work was stalled. The corridor was opened for movement of all vehicles and barricades were removed. Now, parts of the corridor have been blocked and work has commenced, she added.“There is no clarity on what is going on. What if the plan for the extension of the Metro is cleared and the newly constructed corridor has to be blocked again or brought down to accommodate construction of the Metro? Is there a greater inclusive plan for an integrated transport system? This looks like nothing but a waste of money,” she said.Secretary of PMP Pravasi Manch, Sanjay Shitole, said, “The BRTS is a good concept and will work if planned and executed in a flawless manner. As of now, there are no safety measures along the corridors. The authorities are repeating the same mistakes while redoing the corridor. The new bus stops, for example, have no visibility to see the oncoming bus, just the like old ones. The new work is adding cosmetic appeal and is a waste of money.”Shitole also questioned the need for a metro along the same route as the BRTS. “Instead of wasting crores on an underground metro, alternatives like smaller standing buses along the Katraj-Swargate stretch would be cheaper and more efficient,” he explained.Programme director of Parisar, Ranjit Gadgil said that the civic body needs an integrated BRTS and Metro plan. “There has been ad-hoc completion and stoppage of BRTS work. There is no clarity on when and how the BRTS corridor mentioned in the Development Plan (DP) will be made. We have raised this issue with the old and present municipal commissioner but have not heard from them. A meeting between the Metro officials and PMC road department needs to be held to work out a plan for an integrated transit system rather than each body functioning individually. Overlaps of metro and BRTS will not be beneficial for anybody,” Gadgil explained.BRTS manager, Anant Waghmare said the work on the Satara Road corridor has been going on for a while now.“We are making 10 bus stops along the stretch and the corridor will resemble the Alandi Road one. We have also considered the probable metro work along this stretch. Ahmednagar Road and parts of Pimpri-Chinchwad have the metro running through the BRTS corridor but there have been no hindrances. The Satara Road corridor will also work in a similar fashion,” he said.

Title: MY sets up 2nd board to check the accused
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Indore: MY Hospital administration constituted a second medical board to prepare a report on health condition of a high-profile-attempt to murder accused admitted in a private ward of the hospital despite a previous board recommending against his admission and suggesting treatment in out-patient department (OPD).

Kapil Jaiswal, accused of opening fire at a businessman, Shailendra Verma, at an office in Indore Trade Centre on January 3, was admitted to MY Hospital the next day with complaints of blunt trauma and bleeding hemorrhoids. The accused was put under care of Dr Sonia Moses in private ward number 310 of surgical unit.

The court of JFMC Mayank Shukla on February 5 sought opinion on Jaiswal’s health conditions from Choti Gwaltoli police. Police asked MY superintendent about the medical opinion in accordance to court order.

Hospital sources said a medical board comprising professor (surgery) Dr Manish Kaushal, assistant professor (medicine) Dr Manoj Gupta and assistant professor (surgery) Dr Abhay Brahmate was constituted on January 7 on order of medical officer Aparna Sharma with permission of MY superintendent Dr AD Bhatnagar.

Assistant professor (orthopaedic) Dr Namit Pawar was included in the board a day later.

Medical board headed by Dr Kaushal on January 8 found that admission was not required and recommended that Jaiswal may be treated in OPD of neurology and orthopaedic. This recommendation was signed by all doctors on the panel.

But, a footnote was written individually by Dr Namit Pawar in the report referring the case to senior neuro physician, neurosurgeon and senior orthopaedic doctor.

Subsequently, Dr Moses discharged the patient from her care and sent a note to on-duty doctor asking that police may be informed about the move. But before the information was conveyed, Jaiswal was taken under care of hospital deputy director Dr DK Sharma.

“I received a call for transfer of the patient with injury on the back,” Dr Sharma told TOI, confirming formation of the first medical board.

He said the board could not arrive at a clear conclusion and advocated for opinion from senior neurosurgeon, neuro physician and orthopaedician.

Subsequently, a fresh medical board comprising neuro surgeon Dr Rakesh Gupta, surgeon Dr Arvind Shukla, orthopaedic Dr Laxman Banoda and neurologist Dr Archana Sharma was formed. It examined Jaiswal and is learnt to have come to a conclusion that he may be given conservative treatment for his spinal issue.

Title: Fluctuating temperatures trigger ailments, children worst-affected
Content:
Young children and people above 60 years are more vulnerable to these ailments.

PUNE: Seasonal changes triggered by the night temperatures dropping faster than the day’s mercury levels, coupled with the moisture in the atmosphere, are triggering ailments such as cold, cough, flu and diarrhoea among children and adults.Expressing concerns over the rise in viral infection and allergic bronchitis cases, doctors have urged people to protect themselves guarded against cold, stay away from those suffering from cold and fever, wash hands at regular intervals and keep the body warm, as viruses attack most when the body temperature is down.“Of the total children I see every day, about 60% are down viral fever. About 3-4% of them have bacterial pneumonia — an infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs,” paediatrician Sanjay Mankar said. “The most affected are the children less than five years of age. Children typically get affected with bacterial pneumonia after an episode of viral fever,” said Mankar, who is also president of the Indian Academy of Paediatrics (IAP), Pune.Paediatrician Jitendra Oswal, deputy medical director of Bharati Hospital, said, “Winter ailments such as common cold, sore throat, sinusitis, lower respiratory infections including bronchitis, bronchopneumonia, bronchiolitis and asthma are on the rise. Since January 1, we have been seeing around 50-60 children daily at our paediatric outpatient department.”“As the body has to adjust to the low and fluctuating temperatures, a weakened immune system becomes an easy target for bacteria and viruses. Winter is the blooming season for various flowers. Allergic disorders like asthma caused by the pollen aggravate during the season. Besides, smog and cold air precipitate asthma attack,” Oswal said.Young children and people above 60 years are more vulnerable to these ailments. “Children are getting affected with fever, cough, runny or blocked stuffy nose, sneezing, headache, pain in throat, body ache, breathing difficulty and noisy respiration. Often, other family members are affected simultaneously,” he said.“People with bronchial asthma, diabetes, heart disease and kidney disease are more vulnerable to contracting influenza. Also, children and adults who are on immuno-suppressive therapy for diseases such as cancer, arthritis and other autoimmune diseases are also at high risk of contacting these infections,” Oswal said.Paediatrician Amruta Walimbe said, “If treatment is delayed or not taken, the cure for diseases such as common cold, sore throat and sinusitis can take longer time, usually over a week. In case of lower respiratory tract infections and asthma, delayed treatment can lead to respiratory failure.”

Title: Hyderabad: Rebels defy, quit their parties, file nominations
Content:
K Chandrashekhar Rao

Notwithstanding TRS chief K Chandrasekhar Rao’s diktat to party ticket aspirants in municipal elections that they will face the axe if they go against the party’s decision in selection of candidates

HYDERABAD: Notwithstanding TRS chief K Chandrasekhar Rao’s diktat to party ticket aspirants in municipal elections that they will face the axe if they go against the party’s decision in selection of candidates, many TRS leaders have either filed their nomination papers as party candidates or quit the party on the last day of nominations on Friday.For instance, R Srinivas Reddy, a sitting TRS councillor of Badangpet municipal corporation, was denied ticket by the TRS from Ward 29. He quit TRS and joined Congress on Thursday, and filed nomination on Friday. Interestingly, the mother-son duo of E Ranamma and E Ramu Goud did not get any assurance for TRS tickets, after which they quit the party, and are now contesting on BJP tickets.Similarly, brothers Peddabavi Samara Simha Reddy and Peddabavi Darshan Reddy of Badangpet filed their nominations from TRS, and are waiting for the party’s decision.In Peerzadiguda corporation, several TRS leaders including Maniram Naik, Bodige Ramdas Goud, K Kumar, Bodige Krishna and Jagadishwar Reddy have resigned, and filed their nominations from Congress.With pressure from party leaders to give Form B to those contesting on the party symbol, MLAs, who are in-charge for municipalities elections, have kept issuance of Form B (to recognise as party candidate officially by the election commission) on hold.In a relief to all political parties, the Telangana State Election Commission on Friday permitted them to give Form A, and the candidates to submit Form B till the last day of withdrawal of nominations on January 14. Generally, parties and candidates have to submit their Form A and B along with the nominations.Parties used this opportunity to hold back giving Form B, mainly to thwart rebel candidates from switching over to other parties.The parties are hopeful of convincing rebel candidates before withdrawal of nominations on January 14. In a counter to the party’s strategy, party aspirants have filed their nominations, and are waiting for the party’s decisions. Some others quit the party to join those offering tickets.TRS president K Chandrasekhar Rao announced that those who could not be given tickets will be given nominated post or co-option members in urban local bodies. He directed that if they do not fall in line, they will face expulsion.

Title: Woman hangs self in front of year-old child
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Indore: A 25-year-old woman committed suicide by hanging self in front of her one-year-old child. The incident took place in Maruti Palace area of Chandan Nagar on Friday morning.

The woman was reportedly depressed after her brother had hanged himself two months ago. The matter came to fore after a few hours after neighbours peeped into the house through the window after hearing screams of the child. They found that the woman identified as Reena, wife of Dinesh Vanshkar was hanging from the ceiling following which they broke the door and rescued the baby. The family members and police officials were informed following which the body was sent for post mortem examination and was later handed over to family members. Family members said that around two months ago, Reena’s brother Jagdeesh had hanged himself at their village in Dhamnod following which she went into depression. She was also seeing a doctor for the same. The woman leaves behind a son, who lives with his grandparents. Her husband was away for work when the incident took place. TNN

Title: TRS sitting pretty ahead of civic polls
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

CM K Chandrashekhar Rao

HYDERABAD: It’s advantage for TRS even before elections are held to 120 municipalities and 10 municipal corporations on January 22. TRS has over 120 crucial votes on its side for election of mayors and municipal chairpersons. As per the Municipal Act, MPs, MLAs and MLCs are ex-officio members having voting rights for election of mayors and chairpersons in municipal corporations and municipalities they opt for.

TRS has 104 MLAs and 13 MPs from Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha and 30 MLCs as ex-officio members on its side. Congress has six MLAs, three MPs and an MLC and BJP has three MPs, an MLA and MLC.

“Even if 15 to 30 from core city of Greater Hyderabad who opt for GHMC are exempted from the list, the ruling TRS still will have about 130 ex-officio votes. In the case of a tight contest for election of mayors or chairpersons, the ex-officio votes will be crucial,” a senior TRS leader said.

As per the Municipal Act, it is going to be an indirect election for mayors and municipal chairpersons. Corporators will elect one among them as a mayor, while councillors will elect one among them as a chairperson in municipalities. Unless Congress and BJP have a clear majority, it will be difficult for the two main opposition parties to win the seat of mayors.

Title: 15-year-old girl dies of dengue in Puducherry
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Representative image

PUDUCHERRY: A 15-year-old girl died of dengue on Friday in Puducherry . The girl identified as S Ramya, a Class IX student of a government girls’ higher secondary school was undergoing treatment at the Indira Gandhi government general hospital and postgraduate institute since she was admitted on January 5.

Health officials said the girl was suffering from high fever and was admitted with symptoms of dengue. She did not respond to the treatment and died on Friday.

A team of experts deputed by the Union government in 2017 to investigate the outbreak of dengue in Puducherry cited several inadequacies in the preparedness in the prevention of dengue by the Puducherry government. The team warned that the issue will go out of control if proper precautionary measures were not taken up immediately. The team identified red alert areas in the town limits that have become breeding ground for dengue disease-spreading mosquitoes.

The government launched a series of initiatives and brought down the incidence of dengue by 5% in 2018 when compared to 2017. The government hospitals, community health centres and primary health centres started administering nilavemu decoction to the people reducing the incidence of dengue in the territory. TNN

Title: Gurugram: Mercury drops, air quality better but may deteriorate coming week
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

As per the SAFAR forecast, the air quality in the city is likely to be within the ‘moderate’ levels (File phot... Read More

GURUGRAM: The city on Friday witnessed a decline in maximum and minimum temperatures. The average maximum temperature that was recorded at 18°C on Thursday came down to 15°C on Friday, while the average minimum temperature recorded at 8°C on Thursday dropped to 5°C on Friday.

The air quality remained in the ‘moderate’ level, but deteriorated slightly during the last 24 hours. The air quality index (AQI), which was recorded at 124 (moderate) on Thursday, deteriorated to 138 (moderate) on Friday.

Track the pollution level in your city

The AQI that was recorded in the ‘poor’ category on Sunday and Monday, improved to ‘moderate’ level on Tuesday and Wednesday, and further improved on Thursday.

According to the Met department, the air quality might deteriorate further as the wind speed that reached up to 20-25kmph is going down gradually. “There is a forecast of generally cloudy sky in the next 48 hours. However, a decline in the maximum and minimum temperature is expected,” said a Met official.

According to the IMD forecast, the maximum and minimum temperatures are expected to be between 15°C and 5°C on Thursday. As per the SAFAR forecast, the air quality in the city is likely to be within the ‘moderate’ levels and AQI is expected to be between 173 and 189, but might reach the ‘poor’ level on Monday.

Delhi’s minimum temperature continued to fall. It dipped by another three notches to be recorded at 5.3 degrees Celsius on Friday morning. However, both the minimum and maximum temperatures are likely to start rising from Sunday onward.

“There will be clear skies and sunny conditions during the day,” a Met official said. On Friday, Delhi recorded an air quality index of 203 which means, it remained in the ‘poor’ level.

Title: Burning bus or train won’t help, burn the idea: Venkaiah Naidu
Content:
This story is from January 11, 2020

Venkiah Naidu

NAGPUR: In an oblique reference to the ongoing protests against CAA, NRC and NPR and attack on JNU students, vice-president Venkaiah Naidu on Friday said here that obstruction and destruction must be stopped while people must “burn the problematic idea” reminding that “after all this is your country”.

Amid the prevailing opposition to CAA, NRC and NPR, peaceful protests have been carried out across the country with alleged violence being reported from BJP-ruled Uttar Pradesh and Karnataka.

Delhi, where law and order comes under Union home ministry, too saw violence at Jamia University and JNU in the wake of opposition to right wing ideas.

“Burning bus or train will not help anyone. You will have to burn the idea and not physical things. Violence can never succeed. Entire world has come to know this. If you have tension you can’t pay attention. Peace must prevail in the country,” said Naidu.

At the same time, he said institutions of learning must teach students about freedom fighters Chandrashekhar Azad and Bhagat Singh.

Naidu emphasized on peaceful coexistence. “India is one nation having so many languages and traditions. Peace is very much required for progress. We must all come together to see that we create a peaceful existence, peaceful country and peaceful world,” he said.

The vice-president also said that prosperity alone is not enough while our traditional knowledge must be passed on to all generation for maintaining peace in the country. “Indian civilization is one of the oldest. India has a great future as our ‘parampara’ has quality of adaptability,” said Naidu.

He was speaking at the inauguration of the three-day 50th session of the All India Oriental Conference organized by Kavikulaguru Kalida Sanskrit University (KKSU) at the Suresh Bhat Auditorium.

Being a proponent of native languages, Naidu started his speech in Marathi and then went on to acknowledge Sanskrit connection with several North Indian as well as international languages.

On educating GenNext about Indian heroes, saints and personalities, Naidu said he was compulsorily taught History subject.

“Now not much importance is given to history, PT and craft. Teach kids who was Azad, Bhagat Singh, Sant Tukaram, Jhansi Rani, Alur Sitaraman,” he said.

Appealing for an overhaul in education system, Naidu said the Kasturirangan committee has given good recommendations which must be adopted. “During our school days, we were taught to respect nature. Nature plus culture means better future. Culture is way of life. Whatever you call it, Hindu Sanskriti or any other term, be proud of it,” he said.

Naidu called for revisiting the Indian ancient system of learning and teaching to overcome colonization. “It is high time we revisited our system. I appeal to all principals and academicians to teach our kids only in mother tongue. There is a notion that if one doesn’t know English one can’t go higher in life. God has decided the time so don’t worry. Our PM didn’t go to a convent school, I am the son of a farmer, former President Abdul Kalam didn’t start his education in English,” he said.

Union minister and city MP Nitin Gadkari, guardian minister Nitin Raut, KKSU VC Shrinivasa Varakhedi, RSS think-tank MG Vaidya, several functionaries of the Sangh and academicians were present.

‘Do chandra namaskar’
